Transitory deceptions are\r\n      thus presented to the organs which, when they occur to men of strength of\r\n      mind and of education, give way to scrutiny, and their character being\r\n      once investigated, the true takes the place of the unreal representation.\r\n      But in ignorant times those instances in which any object is\r\n      misrepresented, whether through the action of the senses, or of the\r\n      imagination, or the combined influence of both, for however short a space\r\n      of time, may be admitted as direct evidence of a supernatural apparition;\r\n      a proof the more difficult to be disputed if the phantom has been\r\n      personally witnessed by a man of sense and estimation, who, perhaps\r\n      satisfied in the general as to the actual existence of apparitions, has\r\n      not taken time or trouble to correct his first impressions. This species\r\n      of deception is so frequent that one of the greatest poets of the present\r\n      time answered a lady who asked him if he believed in ghosts:&mdash;&ldquo;No,\r\n      madam; I have seen too many myself.&rdquo; I may mention one or two instances of\r\n      the kind, to which no doubt can be attached.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The first shall be the apparition of Maupertuis to a brother professor in\r\n      the Royal Society of Berlin.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      This extraordinary circumstance appeared in the Transactions of the\r\n      Society, but is thus stated by M. Thiebault in his &ldquo;Recollections of\r\n      Frederick the Great and the Court of Berlin.&rdquo; It is necessary to premise\r\n      that M. Gleditsch, to whom the circumstance happened, was a botanist of\r\n      eminence, holding the professorship of natural philosophy at Berlin, and\r\n      respected as a man of an habitually serious, simple, and tranquil\r\n      character.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      A short time after the death of Maupertuis,<a href="#linknote-2"\r\n       name="linknoteref-2" id="linknoteref-2"><small>2</small></a> M. Gleditsch\r\n      being obliged to traverse the hall in which the Academy held its sittings,\r\n      having some arrangements to make in the cabinet of natural history, which\r\n      was under his charge, and being willing to complete them on the Thursday\r\n      before the meeting, he perceived, on entering the hall, the apparition of\r\n      M. de Maupertuis, upright and stationary, in the first angle on his left\r\n      hand, having his eyes fixed on him. This was about three o&rsquo;clock,\r\n      afternoon. The professor of natural philosophy was too well acquainted\r\n      with physical science to suppose that his late president, who had died at\r\n      Ble, in the family of Messrs. Bernoullie, could have found his way back\r\n      to Berlin in person. He regarded the apparition in no other light than as\r\n      a phantom produced by some derangement of his own proper organs. M.\r\n      Gleditsch went to his own business, without stopping longer than to\r\n      ascertain exactly the appearance of that object. But he related the vision\r\n      to his brethren, and assured them that it was as defined and perfect as\r\n      the actual person of Maupertuis could have presented. When it is\r\n      recollected that Maupertuis died at a distance from Berlin, once the scene\r\n      of his triumphs&mdash;overwhelmed by the petulant ridicule of Voltaire,\r\n      and out of favour with Frederick, with whom to be ridiculous was to be\r\n      worthless&mdash;we can hardly wonder at the imagination even of a man of\r\n      physical science calling up his Eidolon in the hall of his former\r\n      greatness.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-2" id="linknote-2"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      2 (<a href="#linknoteref-2">return</a>)<br /> [ Long the president of the\r\n      Berlin Academy, and much favoured by Frederick II., till he was\r\n      overwhelmed by the ridicule of Voltaire. He retired, in a species of\r\n      disgrace, to his native country of Switzerland, and died there shortly\r\n      afterwards.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The sober-minded professor did not, however, push his investigation to the\r\n      point to which it was carried by a gallant soldier, from whose mouth a\r\n      particular friend of the author received the following circumstances of a\r\n      similar story.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Captain C&mdash;&mdash; was a native of Britain, but bred in the Irish\r\n      Brigade. He was a man of the most dauntless courage, which he displayed in\r\n      some uncommonly desperate adventures during the first years of the French\r\n      Revolution, being repeatedly employed by the royal family in very\r\n      dangerous commissions. After the King&rsquo;s death he came over to England, and\r\n      it was then the following circumstance took place.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Captain C&mdash;&mdash; was a Catholic, and, in his hour of adversity at\r\n      least, sincerely attached to the duties of his religion. His confessor was\r\n      a clergyman who was residing as chaplain to a man of rank in the west of\r\n      England, about four miles from the place where Captain C&mdash;&mdash;\r\n      lived. On riding over one morning to see this gentleman, his penitent had\r\n      the misfortune to find him very ill from a dangerous complaint. He retired\r\n      in great distress and apprehension of his friend&rsquo;s life, and the feeling\r\n      brought back upon him many other painful and disagreeable recollections.\r\n      These occupied him till the hour of retiring to bed, when, to his great\r\n      astonishment, he saw in the room the figure of the absent confessor. He\r\n      addressed it, but received no answer&mdash;the eyes alone were impressed\r\n      by the appearance. Determined to push the matter to the end, Captain C&mdash;&mdash;\r\n      advanced on the phantom, which appeared to retreat gradually before him.\r\n      In this manner he followed it round the bed, when it seemed to sink down\r\n      on an elbow-chair, and remain there in a sitting posture. To ascertain\r\n      positively the nature of the apparition, the soldier himself sate down on\r\n      the same chair, ascertaining thus, beyond question, that the whole was\r\n      illusion; yet he owned that, had his friend died about the same time, he\r\n      would not well have known what name to give to his vision. But as the\r\n      confessor recovered, and, in Dr. Johnson&rsquo;s phrase, &ldquo;nothing came of it,&rdquo;\r\n       the incident was only remarkable as showing that men of the strongest\r\n      nerves are not exempted from such delusions.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Another illusion of the same nature we have the best reason for vouching\r\n      as a fact, though, for certain reasons, we do not give the names of the\r\n      parties. Not long after the death of a late illustrious poet, who had\r\n      filled, while living, a great station in the eye of the public, a literary\r\n      friend, to whom the deceased had been well known, was engaged, during the\r\n      darkening twilight of an autumn evening, in perusing one of the\r\n      publications which professed to detail the habits and opinions of the\r\n      distinguished individual who was now no more. As the reader had enjoyed\r\n      the intimacy of the deceased to a considerable degree, he was deeply\r\n      interested in the publication, which contained some particulars relating\r\n      to himself and other friends. A visitor was sitting in the apartment, who\r\n      was also engaged in reading. Their sitting-room opened into an\r\n      entrance-hall, rather fantastically fitted up with articles of armour,\r\n      skins of wild animals, and the like. It was when laying down his book, and\r\n      passing into this hall, through which the moon was beginning to shine,\r\n      that the individual of whom I speak saw, right before him, and in a\r\n      standing posture, the exact representation of his departed friend, whose\r\n      recollection had been so strongly brought to his imagination. He stopped\r\n      for a single moment, so as to notice the wonderful accuracy with which\r\n      fancy had impressed upon the bodily eye the peculiarities of dress and\r\n      posture of the illustrious poet. Sensible, however, of the delusion, he\r\n      felt no sentiment save that of wonder at the extraordinary accuracy of the\r\n      resemblance, and stepped onwards towards the figure, which resolved\r\n      itself, as he approached, into the various materials of which it was\r\n      composed. These were merely a screen, occupied by great-coats, shawls,\r\n      plaids, and such other articles as usually are found in a country\r\n      entrance-hall. The spectator returned to the spot from which he had seen\r\n      the illusion, and endeavoured, with all his power, to recall the image\r\n      which had been so singularly vivid. But this was beyond his capacity; and\r\n      the person who had witnessed the apparition, or, more properly, whose\r\n      excited state had been the means of raising it, had only to return into\r\n      the apartment, and tell his young friend under what a striking\r\n      hallucination he had for a moment laboured.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      There is every reason to believe that instances of this kind are frequent\r\n      among persons of a certain temperament, and when such occur in an early\r\n      period of society, they are almost certain to be considered as real\r\n      supernatural appearances. They differ from those of Nicolai, and others\r\n      formerly noticed, as being of short duration, and constituting no habitual\r\n      or constitutional derangement of the system. The apparition of Maupertuis\r\n      to Monsieur Gleditsch, that of the Catholic clergyman to Captain C&mdash;&mdash;,\r\n      that of a late poet to his friend, are of the latter character. They bear\r\n      to the former the analogy, as we may say, which a sudden and temporary\r\n      fever-fit has to a serious feverish illness. But, even for this very\r\n      reason, it is more difficult to bring such momentary impressions back to\r\n      their real sphere of optical illusions, since they accord much better with\r\n      our idea of glimpses of the future world than those in which the vision is\r\n      continued or repeated for hours, days, and months, affording opportunities\r\n      of discovering, from other circumstances, that the symptom originates in\r\n      deranged health.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Before concluding these observations upon the deceptions of the senses, we\r\n      must remark that the eye is the organ most essential to the purpose of\r\n      realizing to our mind the appearance of external objects, and that when\r\n      the visual organ becomes depraved for a greater or less time, and to a\r\n      farther or more limited extent, its misrepresentation of the objects of\r\n      sight is peculiarly apt to terminate in such hallucinations as those we\r\n      have been detailing. Yet the other senses or organs, in their turn, and to\r\n      the extent of their power, are as ready, in their various departments, as\r\n      the sight itself, to retain false or doubtful impressions, which mislead,\r\n      instead of informing, the party to whom they are addressed.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Thus, in regard to the ear, the next organ in importance to the eye, we\r\n      are repeatedly deceived by such sounds as are imperfectly gathered up and\r\n      erroneously apprehended. From the false impressions received from this\r\n      organ also arise consequences similar to those derived from erroneous\r\n      reports made by the organs of sight. A whole class of superstitious\r\n      observances arise, and are grounded upon inaccurate and imperfect hearing.\r\n      To the excited and imperfect state of the ear we owe the existence of what\r\n      Milton sublimely calls&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The airy tongues that syllable men&rsquo;s names, On shores, in desert sands,\r\n      and wildernesses.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      These also appear such natural causes of alarm, that we do not sympathize\r\n      more readily with Robinson Crusoe&rsquo;s apprehensions when he witnesses the\r\n      print of the savage&rsquo;s foot in the sand, than in those which arise from his\r\n      being waked from sleep by some one calling his name in the solitary\r\n      island, where there existed no man but the shipwrecked mariner himself.\r\n      Amidst the train of superstitions deduced from the imperfections of the\r\n      ear, we may quote that visionary summons which the natives of the Hebrides\r\n      acknowledged as one sure sign of approaching fate. The voice of some\r\n      absent, or probably some deceased, relative was, in such cases, heard as\r\n      repeating the party&rsquo;s name. Sometimes the aerial summoner intimated his\r\n      own death, and at others it was no uncommon circumstance that the person\r\n      who fancied himself so called, died in consequence;&mdash;for the same\r\n      reason that the negro pines to death who is laid under the ban of an Obi\r\n      woman, or the Cambro-Briton, whose name is put into the famous cursing\r\n      well, with the usual ceremonies, devoting him to the infernal gods, wastes\r\n      away and dies, as one doomed to do so. It may be remarked also, that Dr.\r\n      Johnson retained a deep impression that, while he was opening the door of\r\n      his college chambers, he heard the voice of his mother, then at many\r\n      miles&rsquo; distance, call him by his name; and it appears he was rather\r\n      disappointed that no event of consequence followed a summons sounding so\r\n      decidedly supernatural. It is unnecessary to dwell on this sort of\r\n      auricular deception, of which most men&rsquo;s recollection will supply\r\n      instances. The following may be stated as one serving to show by what\r\n      slender accidents the human ear may be imposed upon. The author was\r\n      walking, about two years since, in a wild and solitary scene with a young\r\n      friend, who laboured under the infirmity of a severe deafness, when he\r\n      heard what he conceived to be the cry of a distant pack of hounds,\r\n      sounding intermittedly. As the season was summer, this, on a moment&rsquo;s\r\n      reflection, satisfied the hearer that it could not be the clamour of an\r\n      actual chase, and yet his ears repeatedly brought back the supposed cry.\r\n      He called upon his own dogs, of which two or three were with the walking\r\n      party. They came in quietly, and obviously had no accession to the sounds\r\n      which had caught the author&rsquo;s attention, so that he could not help saying\r\n      to his companion, &ldquo;I am doubly sorry for your infirmity at this moment,\r\n      for I could otherwise have let you hear the cry of the Wild Huntsman.&rdquo; As\r\n      the young gentleman used a hearing tube, he turned when spoken to, and, in\r\n      doing so, the cause of the phenomenon became apparent. The supposed\r\n      distant sound was in fact a nigh one, being the singing of the wind in the\r\n      instrument which the young gentleman was obliged to use, but which, from\r\n      various circumstances, had never occurred to his elder friend as likely to\r\n      produce the sounds he had heard.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It is scarce necessary to add, that the highly imaginative superstition of\r\n      the Wild Huntsman in Germany seems to have had its origin in strong fancy,\r\n      operating upon the auricular deceptions, respecting the numerous sounds\r\n      likely to occur in the dark recesses of pathless forests. The same clew\r\n      may be found to the kindred Scottish belief, so finely embodied by the\r\n      nameless author of &ldquo;Albania:&rdquo;&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;There, since of old the haughty Thanes of Ross Were wont, with clans and\r\n      ready vassals thronged, To wake the bounding stag, or guilty wolf; There\r\n      oft is heard at midnight or at noon, Beginning faint, but rising still\r\n      more loud, And louder, voice of hunters, and of hounds, And horns\r\n      hoarse-winded, blowing far and keen. Forthwith the hubbub multiplies, the\r\n      air Labours with louder shouts and rifer din Of close pursuit, the broken\r\n      cry of deer Mangled by throttling dogs, the shouts of men, And hoofs,\r\n      thick-beating on the hollow hill: Sudden the grazing heifer in the vale\r\n      Starts at the tumult, and the herdsman&rsquo;s ears Tingle with inward dread.\r\n      Aghast he eyes The upland ridge, and every mountain round, But not one\r\n      trace of living wight discerns, Nor knows, o&rsquo;erawed and trembling as he\r\n      stands, To what or whom he owes his idle fear&mdash; To ghost, to witch,\r\n      to fairy, or to fiend, But wonders, and no end of wondering finds."<a\r\n      href="#linknote-3" name="linknoteref-3" id="linknoteref-3"><small>3</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It must also be remembered, that to the auricular deceptions practised by\r\n      the means of ventriloquism or otherwise, may be traced many of the most\r\n      successful impostures which credulity has received as supernatural\r\n      communications.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-3" id="linknote-3"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      3 (<a href="#linknoteref-3">return</a>)<br /> [ The poem of &ldquo;Albania&rdquo; is,\r\n      in its original folio edition, so extremely scarce that I have only seen a\r\n      copy belonging to the amiable and ingenious Dr. Beattie, besides the one\r\n      which I myself possess, printed in the earlier part of last century. It\r\n      was reprinted by my late friend Dr. Leyden in a small volume entitled\r\n      &ldquo;Scottish Descriptive Poems.&rdquo; &ldquo;Albania&rdquo; contains the above, and many other\r\n      poetical passages of the highest merit.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The sense of touch seems less liable to perversion than either that of\r\n      sight or smell, nor are there many cases in which it can become accessary\r\n      to such false intelligence as the eye and ear, collecting their objects\r\n      from a greater distance and by less accurate enquiry, are but too ready to\r\n      convey. Yet there is one circumstance in which the sense of touch as well\r\n      as others is very apt to betray its possessor into inaccuracy, in respect\r\n      to the circumstances which it impresses on its owner. The case occurs\r\n      during sleep, when the dreamer touches with his hand some other part of\r\n      his own person. He is clearly, in this case, both the actor and patient,\r\n      both the proprietor of the member touching, and of that which is touched;\r\n      while, to increase the complication, the hand is both toucher of the limb\r\n      on which it rests, and receives an impression of touch from it; and the\r\n      same is the case with the limb, which at one and the same time receives an\r\n      impression from the hand, and conveys to the mind a report respecting the\r\n      size, substance, and the like, of the member touching. Now, as during\r\n      sleep the patient is unconscious that both limbs are his own identical\r\n      property, his mind is apt to be much disturbed by the complication of\r\n      sensations arising from two parts of his person being at once acted upon,\r\n      and from their reciprocal action; and false impressions are thus received,\r\n      which, accurately enquired into, would afford a clew to many puzzling\r\n      phenomena in the theory of dreams. This peculiarity of the organ of touch,\r\n      as also that it is confined to no particular organ, but is diffused over\r\n      the whole person of the man, is noticed by Lucretius:&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n<pre xml:space="preserve">\r\n&ldquo;Ut si forte manu, quam vis jam corporis, ipse\r\n Tute tibi partem ferias, reque experiare.&rdquo;\r\n </pre>\r\n    <p>\r\n      A remarkable instance of such an illusion was told me by a late nobleman.\r\n      He had fallen asleep, with some uneasy feelings arising from indigestion.\r\n      They operated in their usual course of visionary terrors. At length they\r\n      were all summed up in the apprehension that the phantom of a dead man held\r\n      the sleeper by the wrist, and endeavoured to drag him out of bed. He\r\n      awaked in horror, and still felt the cold dead grasp of a corpse&rsquo;s hand on\r\n      his right wrist. It was a minute before he discovered that his own left\r\n      hand was in a state of numbness, and with it he had accidentally encircled\r\n      his right arm.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The taste and the smell, like the touch, convey more direct intelligence\r\n      than the eye and the ear, and are less likely than those senses to aid in\r\n      misleading the imagination. We have seen the palate, in the case of the\r\n      porridge-fed lunatic, enter its protest against the acquiescence of eyes,\r\n      ears, and touch, in the gay visions which gilded the patient&rsquo;s\r\n      confinement. The palate, however, is subject to imposition as well as the\r\n      other senses. The best and most acute <i>bon vivant</i> loses his power of\r\n      discriminating betwixt different kinds of wine, if he is prevented from\r\n      assisting his palate by the aid of his eyes,&mdash;that is, if the glasses\r\n      of each are administered indiscriminately while he is blindfolded. Nay, we\r\n      are authorized to believe that individuals have died in consequence of\r\n      having supposed themselves to have taken poison, when, in reality, the\r\n      draught they had swallowed as such was of an innoxious or restorative\r\n      quality. The delusions of the stomach can seldom bear upon our present\r\n      subject, and are not otherwise connected with supernatural appearances,\r\n      than as a good dinner and its accompaniments are essential in fitting out\r\n      a daring Tam of Shanter, who is fittest to encounter them when the poet&rsquo;s\r\n      observation is not unlikely to apply&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;Inspiring bauld John Barleycorn, What dangers thou canst make us scorn!\r\n      Wi&rsquo; tippenny we fear nae evil, Wi&rsquo; usquebae we&rsquo;ll face the devil. The\r\n      swats sae ream&rsquo;d in Tammie&rsquo;s noddle, Fair play, he caredna deils a bodle!&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Neither has the sense of smell, in its ordinary state, much connexion with\r\n      our present subject. Mr. Aubrey tells us, indeed, of an apparition which\r\n      disappeared with a curious perfume as well as a most melodious twang; and\r\n      popular belief ascribes to the presence of infernal spirits a strong\r\n      relish of the sulphureous element of which they are inhabitants. Such\r\n      accompaniments, therefore, are usually united with other materials for\r\n      imposture. If, as a general opinion assures us, which is not positively\r\n      discountenanced by Dr. Hibbert, by the inhalation of certain gases or\r\n      poisonous herbs, necromancers can dispose a person to believe he sees\r\n      phantoms, it is likely that the nostrils are made to inhale such\r\n      suffumigation as well as the mouth.<a href="#linknote-4"\r\n       name="linknoteref-4" id="linknoteref-4"><small>4</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-4" id="linknote-4"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      4 (<a href="#linknoteref-4">return</a>)<br /> [ Most ancient authors, who\r\n      pretend to treat of the wonders of natural magic, give receipts for\r\n      calling up phantoms. The lighting lamps fed by peculiar kinds of medicated\r\n      oil, and the use of suffumigations of strong and deleterious herbs, are\r\n      the means recommended. From these authorities, perhaps, a professor of\r\n      legerdemain assured Dr. Alderson of Hull, that he could compose a\r\n      preparation of antimony, sulphur, and other drugs, which, when burnt in a\r\n      confined room, would have the effect of causing the patient to suppose he\r\n      saw phantoms.&mdash;See &ldquo;Hibbert on Apparitions,&rdquo; p. 120.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      I have now arrived, by a devious path, at the conclusion of this letter,\r\n      the object of which is to show from what attributes of our nature, whether\r\n      mental or corporeal, arises that predisposition to believe in supernatural\r\n      occurrences. It is, I think, conclusive that mankind, from a very early\r\n      period, have their minds prepared for such events by the consciousness of\r\n      the existence of a spiritual world, inferring in the general proposition\r\n      the undeniable truth that each man, from the monarch to the beggar, who\r\n      has once acted his part on the stage, continues to exist, and may again,\r\n      even in a disembodied state, if such is the pleasure of Heaven, for aught\r\n      that we know to the contrary, be permitted or ordained to mingle amongst\r\n      those who yet remain in the body. The abstract possibility of apparitions\r\n      must be admitted by every one who believes in a Deity, and His\r\n      superintending omnipotence. But imagination is apt to intrude its\r\n      explanations and inferences founded on inadequate evidence. Sometimes our\r\n      violent and inordinate passions, originating in sorrow for our friends,\r\n      remorse for our crimes, our eagerness of patriotism, or our deep sense of\r\n      devotion&mdash;these or other violent excitements of a moral character, in\r\n      the visions of night, or the rapt ecstasy of the day, persuade us that we\r\n      witness, with our eyes and ears, an actual instance of that supernatural\r\n      communication, the possibility of which cannot be denied. At other times\r\n      the corporeal organs impose upon the mind, while the eye and the ear,\r\n      diseased, deranged, or misled, convey false impressions to the patient.\r\n      Very often both the mental delusion and the physical deception exist at\r\n      the same time, and men&rsquo;s belief of the phenomena presented to them,\r\n      however erroneously, by the senses, is the firmer and more readily\r\n      granted, that the physical impression corresponded with the mental\r\n      excitement.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      So many causes acting thus upon each other in various degrees, or\r\n      sometimes separately, it must happen early in the infancy of every society\r\n      that there should occur many apparently well-authenticated instances of\r\n      supernatural intercourse, satisfactory enough to authenticate peculiar\r\n      examples of the general proposition which is impressed upon us by belief\r\n      of the immortality of the soul. These examples of undeniable apparitions\r\n      (for they are apprehended to be incontrovertible), fall like the seed of\r\n      the husbandman into fertile and prepared soil, and are usually followed by\r\n      a plentiful crop of superstitious figments, which derive their sources\r\n      from circumstances and enactments in sacred and profane history, hastily\r\n      adopted, and perverted from their genuine reading. This shall be the\r\n      subject of my next letter.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="link2H_4_0003" id="link2H_4_0003"> </a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <div style="height: 4em;">\r\n      <br /><br /><br /><br />\r\n    </div>\r\n    <h2>\r\n      LETTER II.\r\n    </h2>\r\n<pre xml:space="preserve">\r\n    Consequences of the Fall on the Communication between Man and the\r\n    Spiritual World&mdash;Effects of the Flood&mdash;Wizards of Pharaoh&mdash;Text in\r\n    Exodus against Witches&mdash;The word <i>Witch</i> is by some said to mean\r\n    merely Poisoner&mdash;Or if in the Holy Text it also means a Divineress,\r\n    she must, at any rate, have been a Character very different to be\r\n    identified with it&mdash;The original, <i>Chasaph</i>, said to mean a person\r\n    who dealt in Poisons, often a Traffic of those who dealt with\r\n    familiar Spirits&mdash;But different from the European Witch of the\r\n    Middle Ages&mdash;Thus a Witch is not accessary to the Temptation of\r\n    Job&mdash;The Witch of the Hebrews probably did not rank higher than a\r\n    Divining Woman&mdash;Yet it was a Crime deserving the Doom of Death,\r\n    since it inferred the disowning of Jehovah&rsquo;s Supremacy&mdash;Other Texts\r\n    of Scripture, in like manner, refer to something corresponding more\r\n    with a Fortune-teller or Divining Woman than what is now called a\r\n    Witch&mdash;Example of the Witch of Endor&mdash;Account of her Meeting with\r\n    Saul&mdash;Supposed by some a mere Impostor&mdash;By others, a Sorceress\r\n    powerful enough to raise the Spirit of the Prophet by her own\r\n    Art&mdash;Difficulties attending both Positions&mdash;A middle Course adopted,\r\n    supposing that, as in the Case of Balak, the Almighty had, by\r\n    Exertion of His Will, substituted Samuel, or a good Spirit in his\r\n    Character, for the Deception which the Witch intended to\r\n    produce&mdash;Resumption of the Argument, showing that the Witch of Endor\r\n    signified something very different from the modern Ideas of\r\n    Witchcraft&mdash;The Witches mentioned in the New Testament are not less\r\n    different from modern Ideas than those of the Books of Moses, nor do\r\n    they appear to have possessed the Power ascribed to\r\n    Magicians&mdash;Articles of Faith which we may gather from Scripture on\r\n    this point&mdash;That there might be certain Powers permitted by the\r\n    Almighty to Inferior, and even Evil Spirits, is possible; and in\r\n    some sense the Gods of the Heathens might be accounted Demons&mdash;More\r\n    frequently, and in a general sense, they were but logs of wood,\r\n    without sense or power of any kind, and their worship founded on\r\n    imposture&mdash;Opinion that the Oracles were silenced at the Nativity\r\n    adopted by Milton&mdash;Cases of Demoniacs&mdash;The Incarnate Possessions\r\n    probably ceased at the same time as the intervention of\r\n    Miracles&mdash;Opinion of the Catholics&mdash;Result, that witchcraft, as the\r\n    Word is interpreted in  the Middle Ages, neither occurs under the\r\n    Mosaic or Gospel Dispensation&mdash;It arose in the Ignorant Period, when\r\n    the Christians considered the Gods of the Mahommedan or Heathen\r\n    Nations as Fiends, and their Priests as Conjurers or\r\n    Wizards&mdash;Instance as to the Saracens, and among the Northern\r\n    Europeans yet unconverted&mdash;The Gods of Mexico and Peru explained on\r\n    the same system&mdash;Also the Powahs of North America&mdash;Opinion of\r\n    Mather&mdash;Gibb, a supposed Warlock, persecuted by the other\r\n    Dissenters&mdash;Conclusion.\r\n</pre>\r\n    <p class="pfirst">\r\n      <span class="dropcap" style="font-size: 4.00em">W</span>hat degree of\r\n      communication might have existed between the human race and the\r\n      inhabitants of the other world had our first parents kept the commands of\r\n      the Creator, can only be subject of unavailing speculation. We do not,\r\n      perhaps, presume too much when we suppose, with Milton, that one necessary\r\n      consequence of eating the &ldquo;fruit of that forbidden tree&rdquo; was removing to a\r\n      wider distance from celestial essences the beings who, although originally\r\n      but a little lower than the angels, had, by their own crime, forfeited the\r\n      gift of immortality, and degraded themselves into an inferior rank of\r\n      creation.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Some communication between the spiritual world, by the union of those\r\n      termed in Scripture &ldquo;sons of God&rdquo; and the daughters of Adam, still\r\n      continued after the Fall, though their inter-alliance was not approved of\r\n      by the Ruler of mankind. We are given to understand&mdash;darkly, indeed,\r\n      but with as much certainty as we can be entitled to require&mdash;that the\r\n      mixture between the two species of created beings was sinful on the part\r\n      of both, and displeasing to the Almighty. It is probable, also, that the\r\n      extreme longevity of the antediluvian mortals prevented their feeling\r\n      sufficiently that they had brought themselves under the banner of Azrael,\r\n      the angel of death, and removed to too great a distance the period between\r\n      their crime and its punishment. The date of the avenging Flood gave birth\r\n      to a race whose life was gradually shortened, and who, being admitted to\r\n      slighter and rarer intimacy with beings who possessed a higher rank in\r\n      creation, assumed, as of course, a lower position in the scale.\r\n      Accordingly, after this period we hear no more of those unnatural\r\n      alliances which preceded the Flood, and are given to understand that\r\n      mankind, dispersing into different parts of the world, separated from each\r\n      other, and began, in various places, and under separate auspices, to\r\n      pursue the work of replenishing the world, which had been imposed upon\r\n      them as an end of their creation. In the meantime, while the Deity was\r\n      pleased to continue his manifestations to those who were destined to be\r\n      the fathers of his elect people, we are made to understand that wicked men&mdash;it\r\n      may be by the assistance of fallen angels&mdash;were enabled to assert\r\n      rank with, and attempt to match, the prophets of the God of Israel. The\r\n      matter must remain uncertain whether it was by sorcery or legerdemain that\r\n      the wizards of Pharaoh, King of Egypt, contended with Moses, in the face\r\n      of the prince and people, changed their rods into serpents, and imitated\r\n      several of the plagues denounced against the devoted kingdom. Those powers\r\n      of the Magi, however, whether obtained by supernatural communications, or\r\n      arising from knowledge of legerdemain and its kindred accomplishments,\r\n      were openly exhibited; and who can doubt that&mdash;though we may be left\r\n      in some darkness both respecting the extent of their skill and the source\r\n      from which it was drawn&mdash;we are told all which it can be important\r\n      for us to know? We arrive here at the period when the Almighty chose to\r\n      take upon himself directly to legislate for his chosen people, without\r\n      having obtained any accurate knowledge whether the crime of witchcraft, or\r\n      the intercourse between the spiritual world and embodied beings, for evil\r\n      purposes, either existed after the Flood, or was visited with any open\r\n      marks of Divine displeasure.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      But in the law of Moses, dictated by the Divinity himself, was announced a\r\n      text, which, as interpreted literally, having been inserted into the\r\n      criminal code of all Christian nations, has occasioned much cruelty and\r\n      bloodshed, either from its tenor being misunderstood, or that, being\r\n      exclusively calculated for the Israelites, it made part of the judicial\r\n      Mosaic dispensation, and was abrogated, like the greater part of that law,\r\n      by the more benign and clement dispensation of the Gospel.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The text alluded to is that verse of the twenty-second chapter of Exodus\r\n      bearing, &ldquo;men shall not suffer a witch to live.&rdquo; Many learned men have\r\n      affirmed that in this remarkable passage the Hebrew word CHASAPH means\r\n      nothing more than poisoner, although, like the word <i>veneficus</i>, by\r\n      which it is rendered in the Latin version of the Septuagint, other learned\r\n      men contend that it hath the meaning of a witch also, and may be\r\n      understood as denoting a person who pretended to hurt his or her\r\n      neighbours in life, limb, or goods, either by noxious potions, by charms,\r\n      or similar mystical means. In this particular the witches of Scripture had\r\n      probably some resemblance to those of ancient Europe, who, although their\r\n      skill and power might be safely despised, as long as they confined\r\n      themselves to their charms and spells, were very apt to eke out their\r\n      capacity of mischief by the use of actual poison, so that the epithet of\r\n      sorceress and poisoner were almost synonymous. This is known to have been\r\n      the case in many of those darker iniquities which bear as their\r\n      characteristic something connected with hidden and prohibited arts. Such\r\n      was the statement in the indictment of those concerned in the famous\r\n      murder of Sir Thomas Overbury, when the arts of Forman and other sorcerers\r\n      having been found insufficient to touch the victim&rsquo;s life, practice by\r\n      poison was at length successfully resorted to; and numerous similar\r\n      instances might be quoted. But supposing that the Hebrew witch proceeded\r\n      only by charms, invocations, or such means as might be innoxious, save for\r\n      the assistance of demons or familiars, the connexion between the conjurer\r\n      and the demon must have been of a very different character under the law\r\n      of Moses, from that which was conceived in latter days to constitute\r\n      witchcraft. There was no contract of subjection to a diabolic power, no\r\n      infernal stamp or sign of such a fatal league, no revellings of Satan and\r\n      his hags, and no infliction of disease or misfortune upon good men. At\r\n      least there is not a word in Scripture authorizing us to believe that such\r\n      a system existed. On the contrary, we are told (how far literally, how far\r\n      metaphorically, it is not for us to determine) that, when the Enemy of\r\n      mankind desired to probe the virtue of Job to the bottom, he applied for\r\n      permission to the Supreme Governor of the world, who granted him liberty\r\n      to try his faithful servant with a storm of disasters, for the more\r\n      brilliant exhibition of the faith which he reposed in his Maker. In all\r\n      this, had the scene occurred after the manner of the like events in latter\r\n      days, witchcraft, sorceries, and charms would have been introduced, and\r\n      the Devil, instead of his own permitted agency, would have employed his\r\n      servant the witch as the necessary instrument of the Man of Uzz&rsquo;s\r\n      afflictions. In like manner, Satan desired to have Peter, that he might\r\n      sift him like wheat. But neither is there here the agency of any sorcerer\r\n      or witch. Luke xxii. 31.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Supposing the powers of the witch to be limited, in the time of Moses, to\r\n      enquiries at some pretended deity or real evil spirit concerning future\r\n      events, in what respect, may it be said, did such a crime deserve the\r\n      severe punishment of death? To answer this question, we must reflect that\r\n      the object of the Mosaic dispensation being to preserve the knowledge of\r\n      the True Deity within the breasts of a selected and separated people, the\r\n      God of Jacob necessarily showed himself a jealous God to all who, straying\r\n      from the path of direct worship of Jehovah, had recourse to other deities,\r\n      whether idols or evil spirits, the gods of the neighbouring heathen. The\r\n      swerving from their allegiance to the true Divinity, to the extent of\r\n      praying to senseless stocks and stones which could return them no answer,\r\n      was, by the Jewish law, an act of rebellion to their own Lord God, and as\r\n      such most fit to be punished capitally. Thus the prophets of Baal were\r\n      deservedly put to death, not on account of any success which they might\r\n      obtain by their intercessions and invocations (which, though enhanced with\r\n      all their vehemence, to the extent of cutting and wounding themselves,\r\n      proved so utterly unavailing as to incur the ridicule of the prophet), but\r\n      because they were guilty of apostasy from the real Deity, while they\r\n      worshipped, and encouraged others to worship, the false divinity Baal. The\r\n      Hebrew witch, therefore, or she who communicated, or attempted to\r\n      communicate, with an evil spirit, was justly punished with death, though\r\n      her communication with the spiritual world might either not exist at all,\r\n      or be of a nature much less intimate than has been ascribed to the witches\r\n      of later days; nor does the existence of this law, against the witches of\r\n      the Old Testament sanction, in any respect, the severity of similar\r\n      enactments subsequent to the Christian revelation, against a different\r\n      class of persons, accused of a very different species of crime.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In another passage, the practices of those persons termed witches in the\r\n      Holy Scriptures are again alluded to; and again it is made manifest that\r\n      the sorcery or witchcraft of the Old Testament resolves itself into a\r\n      trafficking with idols, and asking counsel of false deities; in other\r\n      words, into idolatry, which, notwithstanding repeated prohibitions,\r\n      examples, and judgments, was still the prevailing crime of the Israelites.\r\n      The passage alluded to is in Deuteronomy xviii. 10, ii&mdash;&ldquo;There shall\r\n      not be found among you anyone that maketh his son or his daughter to pass\r\n      through the fire, or that useth divination, or an observer of times, or an\r\n      enchanter, or a witch, or a charmer, or a consulter with familiar spirits,\r\n      or a wizard, or a necromancer.&rdquo; Similar denunciations occur in the\r\n      nineteenth and twentieth chapters of Leviticus. In like manner, it is a\r\n      charge against Manasses (2 Chronicles xxxviii.) that he caused his\r\n      children to pass through the fire, observed times, used enchantments and\r\n      witchcraft, and dealt with familiar spirits and with wizards. These\r\n      passages seem to concur with the former, in classing witchcraft among\r\n      other desertions of the prophets of the Deity, in order to obtain\r\n      responses by the superstitious practices of the pagan nations around them.\r\n      To understand the texts otherwise seems to confound the modern system of\r\n      witchcraft, with all its unnatural and improbable outrages on common\r\n      sense, with the crime of the person who, in classical days, consulted the\r\n      oracle of Apollo&mdash;a capital offence in a Jew, but surely a venial sin\r\n      in an ignorant and deluded pagan.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      To illustrate the nature of the Hebrew witch and her prohibited criminal\r\n      traffic, those who have written on this subject have naturally dwelt upon\r\n      the interview between Saul and the Witch of Endor, the only detailed and\r\n      particular account of such a transaction which is to be found in the\r\n      Bible; a fact, by the way, which proves that the crime of witchcraft\r\n      (capitally punished as it was when discovered) was not frequent among the\r\n      chosen people, who enjoyed such peculiar manifestations of the Almighty&rsquo;s\r\n      presence. The Scriptures seem only to have conveyed to us the general fact\r\n      (being what is chiefly edifying) of the interview between the witch and\r\n      the King of Israel. They inform us that Saul, disheartened and discouraged\r\n      by the general defection of his subjects, and the consciousness of his own\r\n      unworthy and ungrateful disobedience, despairing of obtaining an answer\r\n      from the offended Deity, who had previously communicated with him through\r\n      his prophets, at length resolved, in his desperation, to go to a divining\r\n      woman, by which course he involved himself in the crime of the person whom\r\n      he thus consulted, against whom the law denounced death&mdash;a sentence\r\n      which had been often executed by Saul himself on similar offenders.\r\n      Scripture proceeds to give us the general information that the king\r\n      directed the witch to call up the Spirit of Samuel, and that the female\r\n      exclaimed that gods had arisen out of the earth&mdash;that Saul, more\r\n      particularly requiring a description of the apparition (whom,\r\n      consequently, he did not himself see), she described it as the figure of\r\n      an old man with a mantle. In this figure the king acknowledges the\r\n      resemblance of Samuel, and sinking on his face, hears from the apparition,\r\n      speaking in the character of the prophet, the melancholy prediction of his\r\n      own defeat and death.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In this description, though all is told which is necessary to convey to us\r\n      an awful moral lesson, yet we are left ignorant of the minuti attending\r\n      the apparition, which perhaps we ought to accept as a sure sign that there\r\n      was no utility in our being made acquainted with them. It is impossible,\r\n      for instance, to know with certainty whether Saul was present when the\r\n      woman used her conjuration, or whether he himself personally ever saw the\r\n      appearance which the Pythoness described to him. It is left still more\r\n      doubtful whether anything supernatural was actually evoked, or whether the\r\n      Pythoness and her assistant meant to practise a mere deception, taking\r\n      their chance to prophesy the defeat and death of the broken-spirited king\r\n      as an event which the circumstances in which he was placed rendered highly\r\n      probable, since he was surrounded by a superior army of Philistines, and\r\n      his character as a soldier rendered it likely that he would not survive a\r\n      defeat which must involve the loss of his kingdom. On the other hand,\r\n      admitting that the apparition had really a supernatural character, it\r\n      remains equally uncertain what was its nature or by what power it was\r\n      compelled to an appearance, unpleasing, as it intimated, since the\r\n      supposed spirit of Samuel asks wherefore he was disquieted in the grave.\r\n      Was the power of the witch over the invisible world so great that, like\r\n      the Erictho of the heathen poet, she could disturb the sleep of the just,\r\n      and especially that of a prophet so important as Samuel; and are we to\r\n      suppose that he, upon whom the Spirit of the Lord was wont to descend,\r\n      even while he was clothed with frail mortality, should be subject to be\r\n      disquieted in his grave at the voice of a vile witch, and the command of\r\n      an apostate prince? Did the true Deity refuse Saul the response of his\r\n      prophets, and could a witch compel the actual spirit of Samuel to make\r\n      answer notwithstanding?\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Embarrassed by such difficulties, another course of explanation has been\r\n      resorted to, which, freed from some of the objections which attend the two\r\n      extreme suppositions, is yet liable to others. It has been supposed that\r\n      something took place upon this remarkable occasion similar to that which\r\n      disturbed the preconcerted purpose of the prophet Balaam, and compelled\r\n      him to exchange his premeditated curses for blessings. According to this\r\n      hypothesis, the divining woman of Endor was preparing to practise upon\r\n      Saul those tricks of legerdemain or jugglery by which she imposed upon\r\n      meaner clients who resorted to her oracle. Or we may conceive that in\r\n      those days, when the laws of Nature were frequently suspended by\r\n      manifestations of the Divine Power, some degree of juggling might be\r\n      permitted between mortals and the spirits of lesser note; in which case we\r\n      must suppose that the woman really expected or hoped to call up some\r\n      supernatural appearance. But in either case, this second solution of the\r\n      story supposes that the will of the Almighty substituted, on that\r\n      memorable occasion, for the phantasmagoria intended by the witch, the\r\n      spirit of Samuel in his earthly resemblance&mdash;or, if the reader may\r\n      think this more likely, some good being, the messenger of the Divine\r\n      pleasure, in the likeness of the departed prophet&mdash;and, to the\r\n      surprise of the Pythoness herself, exchanged the juggling farce: of sheer\r\n      deceit or petty sorcery which she had intended to produce, for a deep\r\n      tragedy, capable of appalling the heart of the hardened tyrant, and\r\n      furnishing an awful lesson to future times.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      This exposition has the advantage of explaining the surprise expressed by\r\n      the witch at the unexpected consequences of her own invocation, while it\r\n      removes the objection of supposing the spirit of Samuel subject to her\r\n      influence. It does not apply so well to the complaint of Samuel that he\r\n      was <i>disquieted</i>, since neither the prophet, nor any good angel\r\n      wearing his likeness, could be supposed to complain of an apparition which\r\n      took place in obedience to the direct command of the Deity. If, however,\r\n      the phrase is understood, not as a murmuring against the pleasure of\r\n      Providence, but as a reproach to the prophet&rsquo;s former friend Saul, that\r\n      his sins and discontents, which were the ultimate cause of Samuel&rsquo;s\r\n      appearance, had withdrawn the prophet for a space from the enjoyment and\r\n      repose of Heaven, to review this miserable spot of mortality, guilt,\r\n      grief, and misfortune, the words may, according to that interpretation,\r\n      wear no stronger sense of complaint than might become the spirit of a just\r\n      man made perfect, or any benevolent angel by whom he might be represented.\r\n      It may be observed that in Ecclesiasticus (xlvi. 19, 20), the opinion of\r\n      Samuel&rsquo;s actual appearance is adopted, since it is said of this man of\r\n      God, that <i>after death he prophesied, and showed the king his latter end</i>.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Leaving the further discussion of this dark and difficult question to\r\n      those whose studies have qualified them to give judgment on so obscure a\r\n      subject, it so far appears clear that the Witch of Endor, was not a being\r\n      such as those believed in by our ancestors, who could transform themselves\r\n      and others into the appearance of the lower animals, raise and allay\r\n      tempests, frequent the company and join the revels of evil spirits, and,\r\n      by their counsel and assistance, destroy human lives, and waste the fruits\r\n      of the earth, or perform feats of such magnitude as to alter the face of\r\n      Nature. The Witch of Endor was a mere fortune-teller, to whom, in despair\r\n      of all aid or answer from the Almighty, the unfortunate King of Israel had\r\n      recourse in his despair, and by whom, in some way or other, he obtained\r\n      the awful certainty of his own defeat and death. She was liable, indeed,\r\n      deservedly to the punishment of death for intruding herself upon the task\r\n      of the real prophets, by whom the will of God was at that time regularly\r\n      made known. But her existence and her crimes can go no length to prove the\r\n      possibility that another class of witches, no otherwise resembling her\r\n      than as called by the same name, either existed at a more recent period,\r\n      or were liable to the same capital punishment, for a very different and\r\n      much more doubtful class of offences, which, however odious, are\r\n      nevertheless to be proved possible before they can be received as a\r\n      criminal charge.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Whatever may be thought of other occasional expressions in the Old\r\n      Testament, it cannot be said that, in any part of that sacred volume, a\r\n      text occurs indicating the existence of a system of witchcraft, under the\r\n      Jewish dispensation, in any respect similar to that against which the\r\n      law-books of so many European nations have, till very lately, denounced\r\n      punishment; far less under the Christian dispensation&mdash;a system under\r\n      which the emancipation of the human race from the Levitical law was\r\n      happily and miraculously perfected. This latter crime is supposed to infer\r\n      a compact implying reverence and adoration on the part of the witch who\r\n      comes under the fatal bond, and patronage, support, and assistance on the\r\n      part of the diabolical patron. Indeed, in the four Gospels, the word,\r\n      under any sense, does not occur; although, had the possibility of so\r\n      enormous a sin been admitted, it was not likely to escape the warning\r\n      censure of the Divine Person who came to take away the sins of the world.\r\n      Saint Paul, indeed, mentions the sin of witchcraft, in a cursory manner,\r\n      as superior in guilt to that of ingratitude; and in the offences of the\r\n      flesh it is ranked immediately after idolatry, which juxtaposition\r\n      inclines us to believe that the witchcraft mentioned by the Apostle must\r\n      have been analogous to that of the Old Testament, and equivalent to\r\n      resorting to the assistance of soothsayers, or similar forbidden arts, to\r\n      acquire knowledge of toturity. Sorcerers are also joined with other\r\n      criminals, in the Book of Revelations, as excluded from the city of God\r\n      And with these occasional notices, which indicate that there was a\r\n      transgression so called, but leave us ignorant of us exact nature, the\r\n      writers upon witchcraft attempt to wring out of the New Testament proofs\r\n      of a crime in itself so disgustingly improbable. Neither do the exploits\r\n      of Elymas, called the Sorcerer, or Simon, called Magus or the Magician,\r\n      entitle them to rank above the class of impostors who assumed a character\r\n      to which they had no real title, and put their own mystical and ridiculous\r\n      pretensions to supernatural power in competition with those who had been\r\n      conferred on purpose to diffuse the gospel, and facilitate its reception\r\n      by the exhibition of genuine miracles. It is clear that, from his\r\n      presumptuous and profane proposal to acquire, by purchase, a portion of\r\n      those powers which were directly derived from inspiration, Simon Magus\r\n      displayed a degree of profane and brutal ignorance inconsistent with his\r\n      possessing even the intelligence of a skilful impostor; and it is plain\r\n      that a leagued vassal of hell&mdash;should we pronounce him such&mdash;would\r\n      have better known his own rank and condition, compared to that of the\r\n      apostles, than to have made such a fruitless and unavailing proposal, by\r\n      which he could only expose his own impudence and ignorance.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      With this observation we may conclude our brief remarks upon <i>witchcraft</i>,\r\n      as the word occurs in the Scripture; and it now only remains to mention\r\n      the nature of the <i>demonology</i>, which, as gathered from the sacred\r\n      volumes, every Christian believer is bound to receive as a thing declared\r\n      and proved to be true.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      And in the first place, no man can read the Bible, or call himself a\r\n      Christian, without believing that, during the course of time comprehended\r\n      by the Divine writers, the Deity, to confirm the faith of the Jews, and to\r\n      overcome and confound the pride of the heathens, wrought in the land many\r\n      great miracles, using either good spirits, the instruments of his\r\n      pleasure, or fallen angels, the permitted agents of such evil as it was\r\n      his will should be inflicted upon, or suffered by, the children of men.\r\n      This proposition comprehends, of course, the acknowledgment of the truth\r\n      of miracles during this early period, by which the ordinary laws of nature\r\n      were occasionally suspended, and recognises the existence in the spiritual\r\n      world of the two grand divisions of angels and devils, severally\r\n      exercising their powers according to the commission or permission of the\r\n      Ruler of the universe.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Secondly, wise men have thought and argued that the idols of the heathen\r\n      were actually fiends, or, rather, that these enemies of mankind had power\r\n      to assume the shape and appearance of those feeble deities, and to give a\r\n      certain degree of countenance to the faith of the worshippers, by working\r\n      seeming miracles, and returning, by their priests or their oracles,\r\n      responses which &ldquo;palter&rsquo;d in a double sense&rdquo; with the deluded persons who\r\n      consulted them. Most of the fathers of the Christian Church have intimated\r\n      such an opinion. This doctrine has the advantage of affording, to a\r\n      certain extent, a confirmation of many miracles related in pagan or\r\n      classical history, which are thus ascribed to the agency of evil spirits.\r\n      It corresponds also with the texts of Scripture which declare that the\r\n      gods of the heathen are all devils and evil spirits; and the idols of\r\n      Egypt are classed, as in Isaiah, chap. xix. ver. 2, with charmers, those\r\n      who have familiar spirits, and with wizards. But whatever license it may\r\n      be supposed was permitted to the evil spirits of that period&mdash;and\r\n      although, undoubtedly, men owned the sway of deities who were, in fact,\r\n      but personifications of certain evil passions of humanity, as, for\r\n      example, in their sacrifices to Venus, to Bacchus, to Mars, &amp;c., and\r\n      therefore might be said, in one sense, to worship evil spirits&mdash;we\r\n      cannot, in reason, suppose that every one, or the thousandth part of the\r\n      innumerable idols worshipped among the heathen, was endowed with\r\n      supernatural power; it is clear that the greater number fell under the\r\n      description applied to them in another passage of Scripture, in which the\r\n      part of the tree burned in the fire for domestic purposes is treated as of\r\n      the same power and estimation as that carved into an image, and preferred\r\n      for Gentile homage. This striking passage, in which the impotence of the\r\n      senseless block, and the brutish ignorance of the worshipper, whose object\r\n      of adoration is the work of his own hands, occurs in the 44th chapter of\r\n      the prophecies of Isaiah, verse 10 <i>et seq</i>. The precise words of the\r\n      text, as well as common sense, forbid us to believe that the images so\r\n      constructed by common artisans became the habitation or resting-place of\r\n      demons, or possessed any manifestation of strength or power, whether\r\n      through demoniacal influence or otherwise. The whole system of doubt,\r\n      delusion, and trick exhibited by the oracles, savours of the mean juggling\r\n      of impostors, rather than the audacious intervention of demons. Whatever\r\n      degree of power the false gods of heathendom, or devils in their name,\r\n      might be permitted occasionally to exert, was unquestionably under the\r\n      general restraint and limitation of providence; and though, on the one\r\n      hand, we cannot deny the possibility of such permission being granted in\r\n      cases unknown to us, it is certain, on the other, that the Scriptures\r\n      mention no one specific instance of such influence expressly recommended\r\n      to our belief.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Thirdly, as the backsliders among the Jews repeatedly fell off to the\r\n      worship of the idols of the neighbouring heathens, so they also resorted\r\n      to the use of charms and enchantments, founded on a superstitious\r\n      perversion of their own Levitical ritual, in which they endeavoured by\r\n      sortilege, by Teraphim, by observation of augury, or the flight of birds,\r\n      which they called <i>Nahas</i>, by the means of Urim and Thummim, to find\r\n      as it were a byroad to the secrets of futurity. But for the same reason\r\n      that withholds us from delivering any opinion upon the degree to which the\r\n      devil and his angels might be allowed to countenance the impositions of\r\n      the heathen priesthood, it is impossible for us conclusively to pronounce\r\n      what effect might be permitted by supreme Providence to the ministry of\r\n      such evil spirits as presided over, and, so far as they had liberty,\r\n      directed, these sinful enquiries among the Jews themselves. We are indeed\r\n      assured from the sacred writings, that the promise of the Deity to his\r\n      chosen people, if they conducted themselves agreeably to the law which he\r\n      had given, was, that the communication with the invisible world would be\r\n      enlarged, so that in the fulness of his time he would pour out his spirit\r\n      upon all flesh, when their sons and daughters should prophesy, their old\r\n      men see visions, and their young men dream dreams. Such were the promises\r\n      delivered to the Israelites by Joel, Ezekiel, and other holy seers, of\r\n      which St. Peter, in the second chapter of the Acts of the Apostles, hails\r\n      the fulfilment in the mission of our Saviour. And on the other hand, it is\r\n      no less evident that the Almighty, to punish the disobedience of the Jews,\r\n      abandoned them to their own fallacious desires, and suffered them to be\r\n      deceived by the lying oracles, to which, in flagrant violation of his\r\n      commands, they had recourse. Of this the punishment arising from the Deity\r\n      abandoning Ahab to his own devices, and suffering him to be deceived by a\r\n      lying spirit, forms a striking instance.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Fourthly, and on the other hand, abstaining with reverence from accounting\r\n      ourselves judges of the actions of Omnipotence, we may safely conclude\r\n      that it was not his pleasure to employ in the execution of his judgments\r\n      the consequences of any such species of league or compact betwixt devils\r\n      and deluded mortals, as that denounced in the laws of our own ancestors\r\n      under the name of <i>witchcraft</i>. What has been translated by that word\r\n      seems little more than the art of a medicator of poisons, combined with\r\n      that of a Pythoness or false prophetess; a crime, however, of a capital\r\n      nature, by the Levitical law, since, in the first capacity, it implied\r\n      great enmity to mankind, and in the second, direct treason to the divine\r\n      Legislator. The book of Tobit contains, indeed, a passage resembling more\r\n      an incident in an Arabian tale or Gothic romance, than a part of inspired\r\n      writing. In this, the fumes produced by broiling the liver of a certain\r\n      fish are described as having power to drive away an evil genius who guards\r\n      the nuptial chamber of an Assyrian princess, and who has strangled seven\r\n      bridegrooms in succession, as they approached the nuptial couch. But the\r\n      romantic and fabulous strain of this legend has induced the fathers of all\r\n      Protestant churches to deny it a place amongst the writings sanctioned by\r\n      divine origin, and we may therefore be excused from entering into\r\n      discussion on such imperfect evidence.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Lastly, in considering the incalculable change which took place upon the\r\n      Advent of our Saviour and the announcement of his law, we may observe\r\n      that, according to many wise and learned men, his mere appearance upon\r\n      earth, without awaiting the fulfilment of his mission, operated as an act\r\n      of banishment of such heathen deities as had hitherto been suffered to\r\n      deliver oracles, and ape in some degree the attributes of the Deity.\r\n      Milton has, in the &ldquo;Paradise Lost,&rdquo; it may be upon conviction of its\r\n      truth, embraced the theory which identifies the followers of Satan with\r\n      the gods of the heathen; and, in a tone of poetry almost unequalled, even\r\n      in his own splendid writings, he thus describes, in one of his earlier\r\n      pieces, the departure of these pretended deities on the eve of the blessed\r\n      Nativity:&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n<pre xml:space="preserve">\r\n  &ldquo;The oracles are dumb,\r\n   No voice or hideous hum\r\nRuns through the arched roof in words deceiving;\r\n   Apollo from his shrine\r\n   Can no more divine,\r\nWith hollow shriek the steep of Delphos leaving;\r\nNo nightly trance or breathed spell\r\nInspires the pale-eyed priests from the prophetic cell.\r\n\r\n  &ldquo;The lonely mountains o&rsquo;er,\r\n   And the resounding shore,\r\nA voice of weeping heard and loud lament;\r\n   From haunted spring and dale,\r\n   Edged with poplar pale,\r\nThe parting Genius is with sighing sent;\r\nWith flower-inwoven tresses torn,\r\nThe Nymphs in twilight shade of tangled thickets mourn.\r\n\r\n  &ldquo;In consecrated earth,\r\n  And on the holy hearth,\r\nThe Lars and Lemures moan with midnight plaint;\r\n  In urns and altars round,\r\n  A drear and dying sound\r\nAffrights the Flamens at their service quaint;\r\nAnd the chill marble seems to sweat,\r\nWhile each peculiar Power foregoes his wonted seat.\r\n\r\n  &ldquo;Peor and Baalim\r\n  Forsake their temples dim,\r\nWith that twice-battered god of Palestine;\r\n  And mooned Ashtaroth,\r\n  Heaven&rsquo;s queen and mother both,\r\nNow sits not girt with tapers&rsquo; holy shine;\r\nThe Lybic Hammon shrinks his horn;\r\nIn vain the Tyrian maids their wounded Thammuz mourn.\r\n\r\n  &ldquo;And sullen Moloch, fled,\r\n  Hath left in shadows dread\r\nHis burning idol all of darkest hue;\r\n  In vain with cymbals ring,\r\n  They call the grisly king,\r\nIn dismal dance about the furnace blue;\r\nThe brutish gods of Nile as fast,\r\nIsis and Orus, and the Dog Anubis, haste.&rdquo;\r\n </pre>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The quotation is a long one, but it is scarcely possible to shorten what\r\n      is so beautiful and interesting a description of the heathen deities,\r\n      whether in the classic personifications of Greece, the horrible shapes\r\n      worshipped by mere barbarians, or the hieroglyphical enormities of the\r\n      Egyptian Mythology. The idea of identifying the pagan deities, especially\r\n      the most distinguished of them, with the manifestation of demoniac power,\r\n      and concluding that the descent of our Saviour struck them with silence,\r\n      so nobly expressed in the poetry of Milton, is not certainly to be lightly\r\n      rejected. It has been asserted, in simple prose, by authorities of no mean\r\n      weight; nor does there appear anything inconsistent in the faith of those\r\n      who, believing that, in the elder time, fiends and demons were permitted\r\n      an enlarged degree of power in uttering predictions, may also give credit\r\n      to the proposition, that at the Divine Advent that power was restrained,\r\n      the oracles silenced, and those demons who had aped the Divinity of the\r\n      place were driven from their abode on earth, honoured as it was by a guest\r\n      so awful.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It must be noticed, however, that this great event had not the same effect\r\n      on that peculiar class of fiends who were permitted to vex mortals by the\r\n      alienation of their minds, and the abuse of their persons, in the case of\r\n      what is called Demoniacal possession. In what exact sense we should\r\n      understand this word <i>possession</i> it is impossible to discover; but\r\n      we feel it impossible to doubt (notwithstanding learned authorities to the\r\n      contrary) that it was a dreadful disorder, of a kind not merely natural;\r\n      and may be pretty well assured that it was suffered to continue after the\r\n      Incarnation, because the miracles effected by our Saviour and his\r\n      apostles, in curing those tormented in this way, afforded the most direct\r\n      proofs of his divine mission, even out of the very mouths of those ejected\r\n      fiends, the most malignant enemies of a power to which they dared not\r\n      refuse homage and obedience. And here is an additional proof that\r\n      witchcraft, in its ordinary and popular sense, was unknown at that period;\r\n      although cases of possession are repeatedly mentioned in the Gospels and\r\n      Acts of the Apostles, yet in no one instance do the devils ejected mention\r\n      a witch or sorcerer, or plead the commands of such a person, as the cause\r\n      of occupying or tormenting the victim;&mdash;whereas, in a great\r\n      proportion of those melancholy cases of witchcraft with which the records\r\n      of later times abound, the stress of the evidence is rested on the\r\n      declaration of the possessed, or the demon within him, that some old man\r\n      or woman in the neighbourhood had compelled the fiend to be the instrument\r\n      of evil.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It must also be admitted that in another most remarkable respect, the\r\n      power of the Enemy of mankind was rather enlarged than bridled or\r\n      restrained, in consequence of the Saviour coming upon earth. It is\r\n      indisputable that, in order that Jesus might have his share in every\r\n      species of delusion and persecution which the fallen race of Adam is heir\r\n      to, he personally suffered the temptation in the wilderness at the hand of\r\n      Satan, whom, without resorting to his divine power, he drove, confuted,\r\n      silenced, and shamed, from his presence. But it appears, that although\r\n      Satan was allowed, upon this memorable occasion, to come on earth with\r\n      great power, the permission was given expressly because his time was\r\n      short.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The indulgence which was then granted to him in a case so unique and\r\n      peculiar soon passed over and was utterly restrained. It is evident that,\r\n      after the lapse of the period during which it pleased the Almighty to\r\n      establish His own Church by miraculous displays of power, it could not\r\n      consist with his kindness and wisdom to leave the enemy in the possession\r\n      of the privilege of deluding men by imaginary miracles calculated for the\r\n      perversion of that faith which real miracles were no longer present to\r\n      support. There would, we presume to say, be a shocking inconsistency in\r\n      supposing that false and deceitful prophecies and portents should be\r\n      freely circulated by any demoniacal influence, deceiving men&rsquo;s bodily\r\n      organs, abusing their minds, and perverting their faith, while the true\r\n      religion was left by its great Author devoid of every supernatural sign\r\n      and token which, in the time of its Founder and His immediate disciples,\r\n      attested and celebrated their inappreciable mission. Such a permission on\r\n      the part of the Supreme Being would be (to speak under the deepest\r\n      reverence) an abandonment of His chosen people, ransomed at such a price,\r\n      to the snares of an enemy from whom the worst evils were to be\r\n      apprehended. Nor would it consist with the remarkable promise in holy\r\n      writ, that &ldquo;God will not suffer His people to be tempted above what they\r\n      are able to bear.&rdquo; I Cor. X. 13. The Fathers of the Faith are not strictly\r\n      agreed at what period the miraculous power was withdrawn from the Church;\r\n      but few Protestants are disposed to bring it down beneath the accession of\r\n      Constantine, when the Christian religion was fully established in\r\n      supremacy. The Roman Catholics, indeed, boldly affirm that the power of\r\n      miraculous interference with the course of Nature is still in being; but\r\n      the enlightened even of this faith, though they dare not deny a\r\n      fundamental tenet of their church, will hardly assent to any particular\r\n      case, without nearly the same evidence which might conquer the incredulity\r\n      of their neighbours the Protestants. It is alike inconsistent with the\r\n      common sense of either that fiends should be permitted to work marvels\r\n      which are no longer exhibited on the part of Heaven, or in behalf of\r\n      religion.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It will be observed that we have not been anxious to decide upon the\r\n      limits of probability on this question. It is not necessary for us to\r\n      ascertain in what degree the power of Satan was at liberty to display\r\n      itself during the Jewish dispensation, or down to what precise period in\r\n      the history of the Christian Church cures of demoniacal possession or\r\n      similar displays of miraculous power may have occurred. We have avoided\r\n      controversy on that head, because it comprehends questions not more\r\n      doubtful than unedifying. Little benefit could arise from attaining the\r\n      exact knowledge of the manner in which the apostate Jews practised\r\n      unlawful charms or auguries. After their conquest and dispersion they were\r\n      remarked among the Romans for such superstitious practices; and the like,\r\n      for What we know, may continue to linger among the benighted wanderers of\r\n      their race at the present day. But all these things are extraneous to our\r\n      enquiry, the purpose of which was to discover whether any real evidence\r\n      could be derived from sacred history to prove the early existence of that\r\n      branch of demonology which has been the object, in comparatively modern\r\n      times, of criminal prosecution and capital punishment. We have already\r\n      alluded to this as the contract of witchcraft, in which, as the term was\r\n      understood in the Middle Ages, the demon and the witch or wizard combined\r\n      their various powers of doing harm to inflict calamities upon the person\r\n      and property, the fortune and the fame, of innocent human beings, imposing\r\n      the most horrible diseases, and death itself, as marks of their slightest\r\n      ill-will; transforming their own persons and those of others at their\r\n      pleasure; raising tempests to ravage the crops of their enemies, or\r\n      carrying them home to their own garners; annihilating or transferring to\r\n      their own dairies the produce of herds; spreading pestilence among cattle,\r\n      infecting and blighting children; and, in a word, doing more evil than the\r\n      heart of man might be supposed capable of conceiving, by means far beyond\r\n      mere human power to accomplish. If it could be supposed that such\r\n      unnatural leagues existed, and that there were wretches wicked enough,\r\n      merely for the gratification of malignant spite or the enjoyment of some\r\n      beastly revelry, to become the wretched slaves of infernal spirits, most\r\n      just and equitable would be those laws which cut them off from the midst\r\n      of every Christian commonwealth. But it is still more just and equitable,\r\n      before punishment be inflicted for any crime, to prove that there is a\r\n      possibility of that crime being committed. We have therefore advanced an\r\n      important step in our enquiry when we have ascertained that the <i>witch</i>\r\n      of the Old Testament was not capable of anything beyond the administration\r\n      of baleful drugs or the practising of paltry imposture; in other words,\r\n      that she did not hold the character ascribed to a modern sorceress. We\r\n      have thus removed out of the argument the startling objection that, in\r\n      denying the existence of witchcraft, we deny the possibility of a crime\r\n      which was declared capital in the Mosaic law, and are left at full liberty\r\n      to adopt the opinion, that the more modern system of witchcraft was a\r\n      part, and by no means the least gross, of that mass of errors which\r\n      appeared among the members of the Christian Church when their religion,\r\n      becoming gradually corrupted by the devices of men and the barbarism of\r\n      those nations among whom it was spread showed, a light indeed, but one\r\n      deeply tinged with the remains of that very pagan ignorance which its\r\n      Divine Founder came to dispel.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      We will, in a future part of this enquiry, endeavour to show that many of\r\n      the particular articles of the popular belief respecting magic and\r\n      witchcraft were derived from the opinions which the ancient heathens\r\n      entertained as part of their religion. To recommend them, however, they\r\n      had principles lying deep in the human mind and heart of all times; the\r\n      tendency to belief in supernatural agencies is natural, and indeed seems\r\n      connected with and deduced from the invaluable conviction of the certainty\r\n      of a future state. Moreover, it is very possible that particular stories\r\n      of this class may have seemed undeniable in the dark ages, though our\r\n      better instructed period can explain them in a satisfactory manner by the\r\n      excited temperament of spectators, or the influence of delusions produced\r\n      by derangement of the intellect or imperfect reports of the external\r\n      senses. They obtained, however, universal faith and credit; and the\r\n      churchmen, either from craft or from ignorance, favoured the progress of a\r\n      belief which certainly contributed in a most powerful manner to extend\r\n      their own authority over the human mind.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      To pass from the pagans of antiquity&mdash;the Mahommedans, though their\r\n      profession of faith is exclusively unitarian, were accounted worshippers\r\n      of evil spirits, who were supposed to aid them in their continual warfare\r\n      against the Christians, or to protect and defend them in the Holy Land,\r\n      where their abode gave so much scandal and offence to the devout. Romance,\r\n      and even history, combined in representing all who were out of the pale of\r\n      the Church as the personal vassals of Satan, who played his deceptions\r\n      openly amongst them; and Mahound, Termagaunt, and <i>Apollo</i> were, in\r\n      the opinion of the Western Crusaders, only so many names of the arch-fiend\r\n      and his principal angels.
