The genius of Milton alone could\r\n      discard all these vulgar puerilities, and assign to the author of evil the\r\n      terrible dignity of one who should seem not &ldquo;less than archangel ruined.&rdquo;\r\n       This species of degradation is yet grosser when we take into consideration\r\n      the changes which popular opinions have wrought respecting the taste,\r\n      habits, powers, modes of tempting, and habits of tormenting, which are\r\n      such as might rather be ascribed to some stupid superannuated and doting\r\n      ogre of a fairy tale, than to the powerful-minded demon who fell through\r\n      pride and rebellion, not through folly or incapacity.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Having, however, adopted our present ideas of the devil as they are\r\n      expressed by his nearest acquaintances, the witches, from the accounts of\r\n      satyrs, which seem to have been articles of faith both among the Celtic\r\n      and Gothic tribes, we must next notice another fruitful fountain of\r\n      demonological fancies. But as this source of the mythology of the Middle\r\n      Ages must necessarily comprehend some account of the fairy folk, to whom\r\n      much of it must be referred, it is necessary to make a pause before we\r\n      enter upon the mystic and marvellous connexion supposed to exist between\r\n      the impenitent kingdom of Satan and those merry dancers by moonlight.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="link2H_4_0005" id="link2H_4_0005"> </a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <div style="height: 4em;">\r\n      <br /><br /><br /><br />\r\n    </div>\r\n    <h2>\r\n      LETTER IV.\r\n    </h2>\r\n<pre xml:space="preserve">\r\n    The Fairy Superstition is derived from different sources&mdash;The\r\n    Classical Worship of the Silvans, or Rural Deities, proved by Roman\r\n    Altars discovered&mdash;The Gothic Duergar, or Dwarfs&mdash;Supposed to be\r\n    derived from the Northern Laps, or Fins&mdash;&ldquo;The\r\n    Niebelungen-Lied&rdquo;&mdash;King Laurin&rsquo;s Adventure&mdash;Celtic Fairies of a\r\n    gayer character, yet their pleasures empty and illusory&mdash;Addicted to\r\n    carry off Human Beings, both Infants and Adults&mdash;Adventures of a\r\n    Butler in Ireland&mdash;The Elves supposed to pay a Tax to Hell&mdash;The\r\n    Irish, Welsh, Highlanders, and Manxmen held the same belief&mdash;It was\r\n    rather rendered more gloomy by the Northern Traditions&mdash;Merlin and\r\n    Arthur carried off by the Fairies&mdash;Also Thomas of Erceldoune&mdash;His\r\n    Amour with the Queen of Elfland&mdash;His re-appearance in latter\r\n    times&mdash;Another account from Reginald Scot&mdash;Conjectures on the\r\n    derivation of the word Fairy.\r\n</pre>\r\n    <p class="pfirst">\r\n      <span class="dropcap" style="font-size: 4.00em">W</span>e may premise by\r\n      observing, that the classics had not forgotten to enrol in their mythology\r\n      a certain species of subordinate deities, resembling the modern elves in\r\n      their habits. Good old Mr. Gibb, of the Advocates&rsquo; Library (whom all\r\n      lawyers whose youth he assisted in their studies, by his knowledge of that\r\n      noble collection, are bound to name with gratitude), used to point out,\r\n      amongst the ancient altars under his charge, one which is consecrated, <i>Diis\r\n      campestribus,</i> and usually added, with a wink, &ldquo;The fairies, ye ken."<a\r\n      href="#linknote-22" name="linknoteref-22" id="linknoteref-22"><small>22</small></a>\r\n      This relic of antiquity was discovered near Roxburgh Castle, and a\r\n      vicinity more delightfully appropriate to the abode of the silvan deities\r\n      can hardly be found.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-22" id="linknote-22"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      22 (<a href="#linknoteref-22">return</a>)<br /> [ Another altar of elegant\r\n      form and perfectly preserved, was, within these few weeks, dug up near the\r\n      junction of the Leader and the Tweed, in the neighbourhood of the village\r\n      of Newstead, to the east of Melrose. It was inscribed by Carrius\r\n      Domitianus, the prefect of the twentieth legion, to the god Sylvanus,\r\n      forming another instance how much the wild and silvan character of the\r\n      country disposed the feelings of the Romans to acknowledge the presence of\r\n      the rural deities. The altar is preserved at Drygrange, the seat of Mr.\r\n      Tod.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Two rivers of considerable size, made yet more remarkable by the fame\r\n      which has rendered them in some sort classical, unite their streams\r\n      beneath the vestiges of an extensive castle, renowned in the wars with\r\n      England, and for the valiant, noble, and even royal blood, which has been\r\n      shed around and before it&mdash;a landscape ornamented with the distant\r\n      village and huge abbey tower of Kelso, arising out of groves of aged trees&mdash;the\r\n      modern mansion of Fleurs, with its terrace, its woods, and its extensive\r\n      lawn&mdash;form altogether a kingdom for Oberon and Titania to reign in,\r\n      or any spirit who, before their time, might love scenery, of which the\r\n      majesty, and even the beauty, impress the mind with a sense of awe mingled\r\n      with pleasure. These silvans, satyrs, and fauns with whom superstition\r\n      peopled the lofty banks and tangled copses of this romantic country, were\r\n      obliged to give place to deities very nearly resembling themselves in\r\n      character, who probably derive some of their attributes from their classic\r\n      predecessors, although more immediately allied to the barbarian\r\n      conquerors. We allude to the fairies, which, as received into the popular\r\n      creed, and as described by the poets who have made use of them as\r\n      machinery, are certainly among the most pleasing legacies of fancy.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Dr. Leyden, who exhausted on this subject, as upon most others, a\r\n      profusion of learning, found the first idea of the elfin people in the\r\n      Northern opinions concerning the duergar, or dwarfs.<a href="#linknote-23"\r\n       name="linknoteref-23" id="linknoteref-23"><small>23</small></a> These\r\n      were, however, it must be owned, spirits of a coarser sort, more laborious\r\n      vocation, and more malignant temper, and in all respects less propitious\r\n      to humanity, than the fairies (properly so called), which were the\r\n      invention of the Celtic people, and displayed that superiority of taste\r\n      and fancy which, with the love of music and poetry, has been generally\r\n      ascribed to their race, through its various classes and modifications.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-23" id="linknote-23"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      23 (<a href="#linknoteref-23">return</a>)<br /> [ See the essay on the\r\n      Fairy Superstition, in the &ldquo;Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border,&rdquo; of which\r\n      many of the materials were contributed by Dr. Leyden, and the whole\r\n      brought into its present form by the author.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In fact, there seems reason to conclude that these duergar were originally\r\n      nothing else than the diminutive natives of the Lappish, Lettish, and\r\n      Finnish nations, who, flying before the conquering weapons of the As,\r\n      sought the most retired regions of the North, and there endeavoured to\r\n      hide themselves from their Eastern invaders. They were a little,\r\n      diminutive race, but possessed of some skill probably in mining or\r\n      smelting minerals, with which the country abounds. Perhaps also they\r\n      might, from their acquaintance with the changes of the clouds, or\r\n      meteorological phenomena, be judges of weather, and so enjoy another title\r\n      to supernatural skill. At any rate, it has been plausibly supposed that\r\n      these poor people, who sought caverns and hiding-places from the\r\n      persecution of the As, were in some respects compensated for inferiority\r\n      in strength and stature by the art and power with which the superstition\r\n      of the enemy invested them. These oppressed yet dreaded fugitives\r\n      obtained, naturally enough, the character of the German spirits called\r\n      Kobold, from which the English goblin and the Scottish bogle, by some\r\n      inversion and alteration of pronunciation, are evidently derived.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The Kobolds were a species of gnomes, who haunted the dark and solitary\r\n      places, and were often seen in the mines, where they seemed to imitate the\r\n      labours of the miners, and sometimes took pleasure in frustrating their\r\n      objects and rendering their toil unfruitful. Sometimes they were\r\n      malignant, especially if neglected or insulted; but sometimes also they\r\n      were indulgent to individuals whom they took under their protection. When\r\n      a miner, therefore, hit upon a rich vein of ore, the inference commonly\r\n      was, not that he possessed more skill, industry, or even luck, than his\r\n      fellow-workmen, but that the spirits of the mine had directed him to the\r\n      treasure. The employment and apparent occupation of these subterranean\r\n      gnomes or fiends, led very naturally to identify the Fin, or Laplander,\r\n      with the Kobold; but it was a bolder stretch of the imagination which\r\n      confounded this reserved and sullen race with the livelier and gayer\r\n      spirit which bears correspondence with the British fairy. Neither can we\r\n      be surprised that the duergar, ascribed by many persons to this source,\r\n      should exhibit a darker and more malignant character than the elves that\r\n      revel by moonlight in more southern climates.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      According to the old Norse belief, these dwarfs form the current machinery\r\n      of the Northern Sagas, and their inferiority in size is represented as\r\n      compensated by skill and wisdom superior to those of ordinary mortals. In\r\n      the &ldquo;Niebelungen-Lied,&rdquo; one of the oldest romances of Germany, and\r\n      compiled, it would seem, not long after the time of Attila, Theodorick of\r\n      Bern, or of Verona, figures among a cycle of champions over whom he\r\n      presides, like the Charlemagne of France or Arthur of England. Among\r\n      others vanquished by him is the Elf King, or Dwarf Laurin, whose dwelling\r\n      was in an enchanted garden of roses, and who had a body-guard of giants, a\r\n      sort of persons seldom supposed to be themselves conjurers. He becomes a\r\n      formidable opponent to Theodorick and his chivalry; but as he attempted by\r\n      treachery to attain the victory, he is, when overcome, condemned to fill\r\n      the dishonourable yet appropriate office of buffoon and juggler at the\r\n      Court of Verona.<a href="#linknote-24" name="linknoteref-24"\r\n       id="linknoteref-24"><small>24</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-24" id="linknote-24"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      24 (<a href="#linknoteref-24">return</a>)<br /> [ See an abstract, by the\r\n      late learned Henry Weber, of &ldquo;A Lay on this subject of King Laurin,&rdquo;\r\n       complied by Henry of Osterdingen. &ldquo;Northern Antiquities,&rdquo; Edinburgh,\r\n      1814.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Such possession of supernatural wisdom is still imputed by the natives of\r\n      the Orkney and Zetland Islands to the people called <i>Drows</i>, being a\r\n      corruption of duergar or <i>dwarfs</i>, and who may, in most other\r\n      respects, be identified with the Caledonian fairies. Lucas Jacobson Debes,\r\n      who dates his description of Feroe from his Pathmos, in Thorshaven, March\r\n      12, 1670, dedicates a long chapter to the spectres who disturbed his\r\n      congregation, and sometimes carried off his hearers. The actors in these\r\n      disturbances he states to be the <i>Skow</i>, or <i>Biergen-Trold</i>&mdash;<i>i.e.</i>,\r\n      the spirits of the woods and mountains, sometimes called subterranean\r\n      people, and adds, they appeared in deep caverns and among horrid rocks; as\r\n      also, that they haunted the places where murders or other deeds of mortal\r\n      sin had been acted. They appear to have been the genuine northern dwarfs,\r\n      or Trows, another pronunciation of Trollds, and are considered by the\r\n      reverend author as something very little better than actual fiends.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      But it is not only, or even chiefly, to the Gothic race that we must trace\r\n      the opinions concerning the elves of the middle ages; these, as already\r\n      hinted, were deeply blended with the attributes which the Celtic tribes\r\n      had, from the remotest ages, ascribed to their deities of rocks, valleys,\r\n      and forests. We have already observed, what indeed makes a great feature\r\n      of their national character, that the power of the imagination is\r\n      peculiarly active among the Celts, and leads to an enthusiasm concerning\r\n      national music and dancing, national poetry and song, the departments in\r\n      which fancy most readily indulges herself. The Irish, the Welsh, the Gael,\r\n      or Scottish Highlander, all tribes of Celtic descent, assigned to the Men\r\n      of Peace, Good Neighbours, or by whatever other names they called these\r\n      sylvan pigmies, more social habits, and a course of existence far more\r\n      gay, than the sullen and heavy toils of the more saturnine Duergar. Their\r\n      elves did not avoid the society of men, though they behaved to those who\r\n      associated with them with caprice, which rendered it dangerous to\r\n      displease them; and although their gifts were sometimes valuable, they\r\n      were usually wantonly given and unexpectedly resumed.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The employment, the benefits, the amusements of the Fairy court, resembled\r\n      the aerial people themselves. Their government was always represented as\r\n      monarchical. A King, more frequently a Queen of Fairies, was acknowledged;\r\n      and sometimes both held their court together. Their pageants and court\r\n      entertainments comprehended all that the imagination could conceive of\r\n      what was, by that age, accounted gallant and splendid. At their\r\n      processions they paraded more beautiful steeds than those of mere earthly\r\n      parentage&mdash;the hawks and hounds which they employed in their chase\r\n      were of the first race. At their daily banquets, the board was set forth\r\n      with a splendour which the proudest kings of the earth dared not aspire\r\n      to; and the hall of their dancers echoed to the most exquisite music. But\r\n      when viewed by the eye of a seer the illusion vanished. The young knights\r\n      and beautiful ladies showed themselves as wrinkled carles and odious hags&mdash;their\r\n      wealth turned into slate-stones&mdash;their splendid plate into pieces of\r\n      clay fantastically twisted&mdash;and their victuals, unsavoured by salt\r\n      (prohibited to them, we are told, because an emblem of eternity), became\r\n      tasteless and insipid&mdash;the stately halls were turned into miserable\r\n      damp caverns&mdash;all the delights of the Elfin Elysium vanished at once.\r\n      In a word, their pleasures were showy, but totally unsubstantial&mdash;their\r\n      activity unceasing, but fruitless and unavailing&mdash;and their\r\n      condemnation appears to have consisted in the necessity of maintaining the\r\n      appearance of constant industry or enjoyment, though their toil was\r\n      fruitless and their pleasures shadowy and unsubstantial. Hence poets have\r\n      designed them as &ldquo;<i>the crew that never rest</i>.&rdquo; Besides the unceasing\r\n      and useless bustle in which these spirits seemed to live, they had\r\n      propensities unfavourable and distressing to mortals.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      One injury of a very serious nature was supposed to be constantly\r\n      practised by the fairies against &ldquo;the human mortals,&rdquo; that of carrying off\r\n      their children, and breeding them as beings of their race. Unchristened\r\n      infants were chiefly exposed to this calamity; but adults were also liable\r\n      to be abstracted from earthly commerce, notwithstanding it was their\r\n      natural sphere. With respect to the first, it may be easily conceived that\r\n      the want of the sacred ceremony of introduction into the Christian church\r\n      rendered them the more obnoxious to the power of those creatures, who, if\r\n      not to be in all respects considered as fiends, had nevertheless,\r\n      considering their constant round of idle occupation, little right to rank\r\n      themselves among good spirits, and were accounted by most divines as\r\n      belonging to a very different class. An adult, on the other hand, must\r\n      have been engaged in some action which exposed him to the power of the\r\n      spirits, and so, as the legal phrase went, &ldquo;taken in the manner.&rdquo; Sleeping\r\n      on a fairy mount, within which the Fairy court happened to be held for the\r\n      time, was a very ready mode of obtaining a pass for Elfland. It was well\r\n      for the individual if the irate elves were contented, on such occasions,\r\n      with transporting him through the air to a city at some forty miles&rsquo;\r\n      distance, and leaving, perhaps, his hat or bonnet on some steeple between,\r\n      to mark the direct line of his course. Others, when engaged in some\r\n      unlawful action, or in the act of giving way to some headlong and sinful\r\n      passion, exposed themselves also to become inmates of Fairyland.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The same belief on these points obtained in Ireland. Glanville, in his\r\n      &ldquo;Eighteenth Relation,&rdquo; tells us of the butler of a gentleman, a neighbour\r\n      of the Earl of Orrery, who was sent to purchase cards. In crossing the\r\n      fields, he saw a table surrounded by people apparently feasting and making\r\n      merry. They rose to salute him, and invited him to join in their revel;\r\n      but a friendly voice from the party whispered in his ear, &ldquo;Do nothing\r\n      which this company invite you to.&rdquo; Accordingly, when he refused to join in\r\n      feasting, the table vanished, and the company began to dance and play on\r\n      musical instruments; but the butler would not take part in these\r\n      recreations. They then left off dancing, and betook themselves to work;\r\n      but neither in this would the mortal join them. He was then left alone for\r\n      the present; but in spite of the exertions of my Lord Orrery, in spite of\r\n      two bishops who were his guests at the time, in spite of the celebrated\r\n      Mr. Greatrix, it was all they could do to prevent the butler from being\r\n      carried off bodily from amongst them by the fairies, who considered him as\r\n      their lawful prey. They raised him in the air above the heads of the\r\n      mortals, who could only run beneath, to break his fall when they pleased\r\n      to let him go. The spectre which formerly advised the poor man continued\r\n      to haunt him, and at length discovered himself to be the ghost of an\r\n      acquaintance who had been dead for seven years. &ldquo;You know,&rdquo; added he, &ldquo;I\r\n      lived a loose life, and ever since have I been hurried up and down in a\r\n      restless condition, with the company you saw, and shall be till the day of\r\n      judgment.&rdquo; He added, &ldquo;that if the butler had acknowledged God in all his\r\n      ways, he had not suffered so much by their means; he reminded him that he\r\n      had not prayed to God in the morning before he met with this company in\r\n      the field, and, moreover, that he was then going on an unlawful business.&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It is pretended that Lord Orrery confirmed the whole of this story, even\r\n      to having seen the butler raised into the air by the invisible beings who\r\n      strove to carry him off. Only he did not bear witness to the passage which\r\n      seems to call the purchase of cards an unlawful errand.<a\r\n      href="#linknote-25" name="linknoteref-25" id="linknoteref-25"><small>25</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-25" id="linknote-25"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      25 (<a href="#linknoteref-25">return</a>)<br /> [ &ldquo;Sadducismus\r\n      Triumphatus,&rdquo; by Joseph Glanville, p. 131. Edinburgh, 1790.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Individuals, whose lives had been engaged in intrigues of politics or\r\n      stratagems of war, were sometimes surreptitiously carried off to\r\n      Fairyland; as Alison Pearson, the sorceress who cured Archbishop Adamson,\r\n      averred that she had recognised in the Fairy court the celebrated\r\n      Secretary Lethington and the old Knight of Buccleuch, the one of whom had\r\n      been the most busy politician, the other one of the most unwearied\r\n      partisans of Queen Mary, during the reign of that unfortunate queen. Upon\r\n      the whole, persons carried off by sudden death were usually suspected of\r\n      having fallen into the hands of the fairies, and unless redeemed from\r\n      their power, which it was not always safe to attempt, were doomed to\r\n      conclude their lives with them. We must not omit to state that those who\r\n      had an intimate communication with these spirits, while they were yet\r\n      inhabitants of middle earth, were most apt to be seized upon and carried\r\n      off to Elfland before their death.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The reason assigned for this kidnapping of the human race, so peculiar to\r\n      the elfin people, is said to be that they were under a necessity of paying\r\n      to the infernal regions a yearly tribute out of their population, which\r\n      they were willing to defray by delivering up to the prince of these\r\n      regions the children of the human race, rather than their own. From this\r\n      it must be inferred, that they have offspring among themselves, as it is\r\n      said by some authorities, and particularly by Mr. Kirke, the minister of\r\n      Aberfoyle. He indeed adds that, after a certain length of life, these\r\n      spirits are subject to the universal lot of mortality&mdash;a position,\r\n      however, which has been controverted, and is scarcely reconcilable to that\r\n      which holds them amenable to pay a tax to hell, which infers existence as\r\n      eternal as the fire which is not quenched. The opinions on the subject of\r\n      the fairy people here expressed, are such as are entertained in the\r\n      Highlands and some remote quarters of the Lowlands of Scotland. We know,\r\n      from the lively and entertaining legends published by Mr. Crofton Croker&mdash;which,\r\n      though in most cases told with the wit of the editor and the humour of his\r\n      country, contain points of curious antiquarian information&mdash;that the\r\n      opinions of the Irish are conformable to the account we have given of the\r\n      general creed of the Celtic nations respecting elves. If the Irish elves\r\n      are anywise distinguished from those of Britain, it seems to be by their\r\n      disposition to divide into factions and fight among themselves&mdash;a\r\n      pugnacity characteristic of the Green Isle. The Welsh fairies, according\r\n      to John Lewis, barrister-at-law, agree in the same general attributes with\r\n      those of Ireland and Britain. We must not omit the creed of the Manxmen,\r\n      since we find, from the ingenious researches of Mr. Waldron, that the Isle\r\n      of Man, beyond other places in Britain, was a peculiar depository of the\r\n      fairy traditions, which, on the island being conquered by the Norse,\r\n      became, in all probability, chequered with those of Scandinavia from a\r\n      source peculiar and more direct than that by which they reached Scotland\r\n      or Ireland.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Such as it was, the popular system of the Celts easily received the\r\n      northern admixture of Drows and Duergar, which gave the belief, perhaps, a\r\n      darker colouring than originally belonged to the British fairyland. It was\r\n      from the same source also, in all probability, that additional legends\r\n      were obtained of a gigantic and malignant female, the Hecate of this\r\n      mythology, who rode on the storm and marshalled the rambling host of\r\n      wanderers under her grim banner. This hag (in all respects the reverse of\r\n      the Mab or Titania of the Celtic creed) was called Nicneven in that later\r\n      system which blended the faith of the Celts and of the Goths on this\r\n      subject. The great Scottish poet Dunbar has made a spirited description of\r\n      this Hecate riding at the head of witches and good neighbours (fairies,\r\n      namely), sorceresses and elves, indifferently, upon the ghostly eve of\r\n      All-Hallow Mass.<a href="#linknote-26" name="linknoteref-26"\r\n       id="linknoteref-26"><small>26</small></a> In Italy we hear of the hags\r\n      arraying themselves under the orders of Diana (in her triple character of\r\n      Hecate, doubtless) and Herodias, who were the joint leaders of their\r\n      choir. But we return to the more simple fairy belief, as entertained by\r\n      the Celts before they were conquered by the Saxons.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-26" id="linknote-26"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      26 (<a href="#linknoteref-26">return</a>)<br /> [ See &ldquo;Flyting of Dunbar\r\n      and Kennedy.&rdquo;]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Of these early times we can know little; but it is singular to remark what\r\n      light the traditions of Scotland throw upon the poetry of the Britons of\r\n      Cumberland, then called Reged. Merlin Wyllt, or the wild, is mentioned by\r\n      both; and that renowned wizard, the son of an elf or fairy, with King\r\n      Arthur, the dubious champion of Britain at that early period, were both\r\n      said by tradition to have been abstracted by the fairies, and to have\r\n      vanished without having suffered death, just at the time when it was\r\n      supposed that the magic of the wizard and the celebrated sword of the\r\n      monarch, which had done so much to preserve British independence, could no\r\n      longer avert the impending ruin. It may be conjectured that there was a\r\n      desire on the part of Arthur or his surviving champions to conceal his\r\n      having received a mortal wound in the fatal battle of Camlan; and to that\r\n      we owe the wild and beautiful incident so finely versified by Bishop\r\n      Percy, in which, in token of his renouncing in future the use of arms, the\r\n      monarch sends his attendant, sole survivor of the field, to throw his\r\n      sword Excalibar into the lake hard by. Twice eluding the request, the\r\n      esquire at last complied, and threw the far-famed weapon into the lonely\r\n      mere. A hand and arm arose from the water and caught Excalibar by the\r\n      hilt, flourished it thrice, and then sank into the lake.<a\r\n      href="#linknote-27" name="linknoteref-27" id="linknoteref-27"><small>27</small></a>\r\n      The astonished messenger returned to his master to tell him the marvels he\r\n      had seen, but he only saw a boat at a distance push from the land, and\r\n      heard shrieks of females in agony:&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n<pre xml:space="preserve">\r\n&ldquo;And whether the king was there or not\r\n  He never knew, he never colde\r\n For never since that doleful day\r\n  Was British Arthur seen on molde.&rdquo;\r\n </pre>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-27" id="linknote-27"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      27 (<a href="#linknoteref-27">return</a>)<br /> [ See &ldquo;Percy&rsquo;s Reliques of\r\n      Ancient English Poetry.&rdquo;]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The circumstances attending the disappearance of Merlin would probably be\r\n      found as imaginative as those of Arthur&rsquo;s removal, but they cannot be\r\n      recovered; and what is singular enough, circumstances which originally\r\n      belonged to the history of this famous bard, said to be the son of the\r\n      Demon himself, have been transferred to a later poet, and surely one of\r\n      scarce inferior name, Thomas of Erceldoune. The legend was supposed to be\r\n      only preserved among the inhabitants of his native valleys, but a copy as\r\n      old as the reign of Henry VII. has been recovered. The story is\r\n      interesting and beautifully told, and, as one of the oldest fairy legends,\r\n      may well be quoted in this place.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Thomas of Erceldoune, in Lauderdale, called the Rhymer, on account of his\r\n      producing a poetical romance on the subject of Tristrem and Yseult, which\r\n      is curious as the earliest specimen of English verse known to exist,\r\n      flourished in the reign of Alexander III. of Scotland. Like other men of\r\n      talent of the period, Thomas was suspected of magic. He was said also to\r\n      have the gift of prophecy, which was accounted for in the following\r\n      peculiar manner, referring entirely to the elfin superstition:&mdash;As\r\n      True Thomas (we give him the epithet by anticipation) lay on Huntly Bank,\r\n      a place on the descent of the Eildon Hills, which raise their triple crest\r\n      above the celebrated Monastery of Melrose, he saw a lady so extremely\r\n      beautiful that he imagined it must be the Virgin Mary herself. Her\r\n      appointments, however, were rather those of an Amazon or goddess of the\r\n      woods. Her steed was of the highest beauty and spirit, and at his mane\r\n      hung thirty silver bells and nine, which made music to the wind as she\r\n      paced along. Her saddle was of <i>royal bone</i> (ivory), laid over with\r\n      <i>orfeverie</i>&mdash;<i>i.e.</i>, goldsmith&rsquo;s work. Her stirrups, her\r\n      dress, all corresponded with her extreme beauty and the magnificence of\r\n      her array. The fair huntress had her bow in her hand, and her arrows at\r\n      her belt. She led three greyhounds in a leash, and three raches, or hounds\r\n      of scent, followed her closely. She rejected and disclaimed the homage\r\n      which Thomas desired to pay to her; so that, passing from one extremity to\r\n      the other, Thomas became as bold as he had at first been humble. The lady\r\n      warns him that he must become her slave if he should prosecute his suit\r\n      towards her in the manner he proposes. Before their interview terminates,\r\n      the appearance of the beautiful lady is changed into that of the most\r\n      hideous hag in existence. One side is blighted and wasted, as if by palsy;\r\n      one eye drops from her head; her colour, as clear as the virgin silver, is\r\n      now of a dun leaden hue. A witch from the spital or almshouse would have\r\n      been a goddess in comparison to the late beautiful huntress. Hideous as\r\n      she was, Thomas&rsquo;s irregular desires had placed him under the control of\r\n      this hag, and when she bade him take leave of sun, and of the leaf that\r\n      grew on tree, he felt himself under the necessity of obeying her. A cavern\r\n      received them, in which, following his frightful guide, he for three days\r\n      travelled in darkness, sometimes hearing the booming of a distant ocean,\r\n      sometimes walking through rivers of blood, which crossed their\r\n      subterranean path. At length they emerged into daylight, in a most\r\n      beautiful orchard. Thomas, almost fainting for want of food, stretches out\r\n      his hand towards the goodly fruit which hangs around him, but is forbidden\r\n      by his conductress, who informs him these are the fatal apples which were\r\n      the cause of the fall of man. He perceives also that his guide had no\r\n      sooner entered this mysterious ground, and breathed its magic air, than\r\n      she was revived in beauty, equipage, and splendour, as fair, or fairer,\r\n      than he had first seen her on the mountain. She then commands him to lay\r\n      his head upon her knee, and proceeds to explain to him the character of\r\n      the country. &ldquo;Yonder right-hand path,&rdquo; she says, &ldquo;conveys the spirits of\r\n      the blessed to Paradise; yon downward and well-worn way leads sinful souls\r\n      to the place of everlasting punishment; the third road, by yonder dark\r\n      brake, conducts to the milder place of pain from which prayer and mass may\r\n      release offenders. But see you yet a fourth road, sweeping along the plain\r\n      to yonder splendid castle? Yonder is the road to Elfland, to which we are\r\n      now bound. The lord of the castle is king of the country, and I am his\r\n      queen. But, Thomas, I would rather be drawn with wild horses, than he\r\n      should know what hath passed between you and me. Therefore, when we enter\r\n      yonder castle, observe strict silence, and answer no question that is\r\n      asked at you, and I will account for your silence by saying I took your\r\n      speech when I brought you from middle earth.&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Having thus instructed her lover, they journeyed on to the castle, and\r\n      entering by the kitchen, found themselves in the midst of such a festive\r\n      scene as might become the mansion of a great feudal lord or prince. Thirty\r\n      carcases of deer were lying on the massive kitchen board, under the hands\r\n      of numerous cooks, who toiled to cut them up and dress them, while the\r\n      gigantic greyhounds which had taken the spoil lay lapping the blood, and\r\n      enjoying the sight of the slain game. They came next to the royal hall,\r\n      where the king received his loving consort without censure or suspicion.\r\n      Knights and ladies, dancing by threes (reels perhaps), occupied the floor\r\n      of the hall, and Thomas, the fatigues of his journey from the Eildon hills\r\n      forgotten, went forward and joined in the revelry. After a period,\r\n      however, which seemed to him a very short one, the queen spoke with him\r\n      apart, and bade him prepare to return to his own country. &ldquo;Now,&rdquo; said the\r\n      queen, &ldquo;how long think you that you have been here?&rdquo; &ldquo;Certes, fair lady,&rdquo;\r\n       answered Thomas, &ldquo;not above these seven days.&rdquo; &ldquo;You are deceived,&rdquo;\r\n       answered the queen, &ldquo;you have been seven <i>years</i> in this castle; and\r\n      it is full time you were gone. Know, Thomas, that the fiend of hell will\r\n      come to this castle to-morrow to demand his tribute, and so handsome a man\r\n      as you will attract his eye. For all the world would I not suffer you to\r\n      be betrayed to such a fate; therefore up, and let us be going.&rdquo; These\r\n      terrible news reconciled Thomas to his departure from Elfin land, and the\r\n      queen was not long in placing him upon Huntly bank, where the birds were\r\n      singing. She took a tender leave of him, and to ensure his reputation,\r\n      bestowed on him the tongue which <i>could not lie</i>. Thomas in vain\r\n      objected to this inconvenient and involuntary adhesion to veracity, which\r\n      would make him, as he thought, unfit for church or for market, for king&rsquo;s\r\n      court or for lady&rsquo;s bower. But all his remonstrances were disregarded by\r\n      the lady, and Thomas the Rhymer, whenever the discourse turned on the\r\n      future, gained the credit of a prophet whether he would or not; for he\r\n      could say nothing but what was sure to come to pass. It is plain that had\r\n      Thomas been a legislator instead of a poet, we have here the story of Numa\r\n      and Egeria. Thomas remained several years in his own tower near\r\n      Erceldoune, and enjoyed the fame of his predictions, several of which are\r\n      current among the country people to this day. At length, as the prophet\r\n      was entertaining the Earl of March in his dwelling, a cry of astonishment\r\n      arose in the village, on the appearance of a hart and hind,<a\r\n      href="#linknote-28" name="linknoteref-28" id="linknoteref-28"><small>28</small></a>\r\n      which left the forest and, contrary to their shy nature, came quietly\r\n      onward, traversing the village towards the dwelling of Thomas. The prophet\r\n      instantly rose from the board; and, acknowledging the prodigy as the\r\n      summons of his fate, he accompanied the hart and hind into the forest, and\r\n      though occasionally seen by individuals to whom he has chosen to show\r\n      himself, has never again mixed familiarly with mankind.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-28" id="linknote-28"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      28 (<a href="#linknoteref-28">return</a>)<br /> [ This last circumstance\r\n      seems imitated from a passage in the &ldquo;Life of Merlin,&rdquo; by Jeffrey of\r\n      Monmouth. See Ellis&rsquo;s &ldquo;Ancient Romances,&rdquo; vol. i. p. 73.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Thomas of Erceldoune, during his retirement, has been supposed, from time\r\n      to time, to be levying forces to take the field in some crisis of his\r\n      country&rsquo;s fate. The story has often been told of a daring horse-jockey\r\n      having sold a black horse to a man of venerable and antique appearance,\r\n      who appointed the remarkable hillock upon Eildon hills, called the\r\n      Lucken-hare, as the place where, at twelve o&rsquo;clock at night, he should\r\n      receive the price. He came, his money was paid in ancient coin, and he was\r\n      invited by his customer to view his residence. The trader in horses\r\n      followed his guide in the deepest astonishment through several long ranges\r\n      of stalls, in each of which a horse stood motionless, while an armed\r\n      warrior lay equally still at the charger&rsquo;s feet. &ldquo;All these men,&rdquo; said the\r\n      wizard in a whisper, &ldquo;will awaken at the battle of Sheriffmoor.&rdquo; At the\r\n      extremity of this extraordinary depot hung a sword and a horn, which the\r\n      prophet pointed out to the horse-dealer as containing the means of\r\n      dissolving the spell. The man in confusion took the horn, and attempted to\r\n      wind it. The horses instantly started in their stalls, stamped, and shook\r\n      their bridles, the men arose and clashed their armour, and the mortal,\r\n      terrified at the tumult he had excited, dropped the horn from his hand. A\r\n      voice like that of a giant, louder even than the tumult around, pronounced\r\n      these words:&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n<pre xml:space="preserve">\r\n&ldquo;Woe to the coward that ever he was born,\r\n That did not draw the sword before he blew the horn!&rdquo;\r\n </pre>\r\n    <p>\r\n      A whirlwind expelled the horse-dealer from the cavern, the entrance to\r\n      which he could never again find. A moral might be perhaps extracted from\r\n      the legend&mdash;namely, that it is best to be armed against danger before\r\n      bidding it defiance. But it is a circumstance worth notice, that although\r\n      this edition of the tale is limited to the year 1715, by the very mention\r\n      of the Sheriffmoor, yet a similar story appears to have been current\r\n      during the reign of Queen Elizabeth, which is given by Reginald Scot. The\r\n      narrative is edifying as peculiarly illustrative of the mode of marring a\r\n      curious tale in telling it, which was one of the virtues professed by\r\n      Caius when he hired himself to King Lear. Reginald Scot, incredulous on\r\n      the subject of witchcraft, seems to have given some weight to the belief\r\n      of those who thought that the spirits of famous men do, after death, take\r\n      up some particular habitations near cities, towns, and countries, and act\r\n      as tutelary and guardian spirits to the places which they loved while in\r\n      the flesh.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;But more particularly to illustrate this conjecture,&rdquo; says he, &ldquo;I could\r\n      name a person who hath lately appeared thrice since his decease, at least\r\n      some ghostly being or other that calls itself by the name of such a person\r\n      who was dead above a hundred years ago, and was in his lifetime accounted\r\n      as a prophet or predicter by the assistance of sublunary spirits; and now,\r\n      at his appearance, did also give strange predictions respecting famine and\r\n      plenty, war and bloodshed, and the end of the world. By the information of\r\n      the person that had communication with him, the last of his appearances\r\n      was in the following manner:&mdash;&ldquo;I had been,&rdquo; said he, &ldquo;to sell a horse\r\n      at the next market town, but not attaining my price, as I returned home by\r\n      the way I met this man, who began to be familiar with me, asking what\r\n      news, and how affairs moved through the country. I answered as I thought\r\n      fit; withal, I told him of my horse, whom he began to cheapen, and\r\n      proceeded with me so far that the price was agreed upon. So he turned back\r\n      with me, and told me that if I would go along with him I should receive my\r\n      money. On our way we went, I upon my horse, and he on another milk-white\r\n      beast After much travel I asked him where he dwelt and what his name was.\r\n      He told me that his dwelling was a mile off, at a place called <i>Farran</i>,\r\n      of which place I had never heard, though I knew all the country round\r\n      about.<a href="#linknote-29" name="linknoteref-29" id="linknoteref-29"><small>29</small></a>\r\n      He also told me that he himself was that person of the family of\r\n      Learmonths<a href="#linknote-30" name="linknoteref-30" id="linknoteref-30"><small>30</small></a>\r\n      so much spoken of as a prophet. At which I began to be somewhat fearful,\r\n      perceiving we were on a road which I never had been on before, which\r\n      increased my fear and amazement more. Well, on we went till he brought me\r\n      under ground, I knew not how, into the presence of a beautiful woman, who\r\n      paid the money without a word speaking. He conducted me out again through\r\n      a large and long entry, where I saw above six hundred men in armour laid\r\n      prostrate on the ground as if asleep. At last I found myself in the open\r\n      field by the help of the moonlight, in the very place where I first met\r\n      him, and made a shift to get home by three in the morning. But the money I\r\n      had received was just double of what I esteemed it when the woman paid me,\r\n      of which at this instant I have several pieces to show, consisting of\r\n      ninepennies, thirteen pence-halfpennies,&rdquo; &amp;c.<a href="#linknote-31"\r\n       name="linknoteref-31" id="linknoteref-31"><small>31</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-29" id="linknote-29"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      29 (<a href="#linknoteref-29">return</a>)<br /> [ In this the author is in\r\n      the same ignorance as his namesake Reginald, though having at least as\r\n      many opportunities of information.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-30" id="linknote-30"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      30 (<a href="#linknoteref-30">return</a>)<br /> [ In popular tradition, the\r\n      name of Thomas the Rhymer was always averred to be Learmonth. though he\r\n      neither uses it himself, nor is described by his son other than Le Rymour.\r\n      The Learmonths of Dairsie, in Fife, claimed descent from the prophet.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-31" id="linknote-31"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      31 (<a href="#linknoteref-31">return</a>)<br /> [ &ldquo;Discourse of Devils and\r\n      Spirits appended to the Discovery of Witchcraft,&rdquo; by Reginald Scot, Esq.,\r\n      book ii. chap. 3, sec. 10.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It is a great pity that this horse-dealer, having specimens of the fairy\r\n      coin, of a quality more permanent than usual, had not favoured us with an\r\n      account of an impress so valuable to medalists. It is not the less\r\n      edifying, as we are deprived of the more picturesque parts of the story,\r\n      to learn that Thomas&rsquo;s payment was as faithful as his prophecies. The\r\n      beautiful lady who bore the purse must have been undoubtedly the Fairy\r\n      Queen, whose affection, though, like that of his own heroine Yseult, we\r\n      cannot term it altogether laudable, seems yet to have borne a faithful and\r\n      firm character.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      I have dwelt at some length on the story of Thomas the Rhymer, as the\r\n      oldest tradition of the kind which has reached us in detail, and as\r\n      pretending to show the fate of the first Scottish poet, whose existence,\r\n      and its date, are established both by history and records; and who, if we\r\n      consider him as writing in the Anglo-Norman language, was certainly one\r\n      among the earliest of its versifiers. But the legend is still more\r\n      curious, from its being the first and most distinguished instance of a man\r\n      alleged to have obtained supernatural knowledge by means of the fairies.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Whence or how this singular community derived their more common popular\r\n      name, we may say has not as yet been very clearly established. It is the\r\n      opinion of the learned that the Persian word Peri, expressing an unearthly\r\n      being, of a species very similar, will afford the best derivation, if we\r\n      suppose it to have reached Europe through the medium of the Arabians, in\r\n      whose alphabet the letter P does not exist, so that they pronounce the\r\n      word Feri instead of Peri. Still there is something uncertain in this\r\n      etymology. We hesitate to ascribe either to the Persians or the Arabians\r\n      the distinguishing name of an ideal commonwealth, the notion of which they\r\n      certainly did not contribute to us. Some are, therefore, tempted to\r\n      suppose that the elves may have obtained their most frequent name from\r\n      their being <i>par excellence</i> a <i>fair</i> or <i>comely</i> people, a\r\n      quality which they affected on all occasions; while the superstition of\r\n      the Scottish was likely enough to give them a name which might propitiate\r\n      the vanity for which they deemed the race remarkable; just as, in other\r\n      instances, they called the fays &ldquo;men of peace,&rdquo; &ldquo;good neighbours,&rdquo; and by\r\n      other titles of the like import. It must be owned, at the same time, that\r\n      the words <i>fay</i> and <i>fairy</i> may have been mere adoptions of the\r\n      French <i>fee</i> and <i>feerie</i>, though these terms, on the other side\r\n      of the Channel, have reference to a class of spirits corresponding, not to\r\n      our fairies, but with the far different Fata of the Italians. But this is\r\n      a question which we willingly leave for the decision of better\r\n      etymologists than ourselves.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="link2H_4_0006" id="link2H_4_0006"> </a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <div style="height: 4em;">\r\n      <br /><br /><br /><br />\r\n    </div>\r\n    <h2>\r\n      LETTER V.\r\n    </h2>\r\n<pre xml:space="preserve">\r\n    Those who dealt in fortune-telling, mystical cures by charms, and\r\n    the like, often claimed an intercourse with Fairyland&mdash;Hudhart or\r\n    Hudikin&mdash;Pitcairn&rsquo;s &ldquo;Scottish Criminal Trials&rdquo;&mdash;Story of Bessie\r\n    Dunlop and her Adviser&mdash;Her Practice of Medicine&mdash;And of Discovery\r\n    of Theft&mdash;Account of her Familiar, Thome Reid&mdash;Trial of Alison\r\n    Pearson&mdash;Account of her Familiar, William Sympson&mdash;Trial of the Lady\r\n    Fowlis, and of Hector Munro, her Stepson&mdash;Extraordinary species of\r\n    Charm used by the latter&mdash;Confession of John Stewart, a Juggler, of\r\n    his Intercourse with the Fairies&mdash;Trial and Confession of Isobel\r\n    Gowdie&mdash;Use of Elf-arrow Heads&mdash;Parish of Aberfoyle&mdash;Mr. Kirke, the\r\n    Minister of Aberfoyle&rsquo;s Work on Fairy Superstitions&mdash;He is himself\r\n    taken to Fairyland&mdash;Dr. Grahame&rsquo;s interesting Work, and his\r\n    Information on Fairy Superstitions&mdash;Story of a Female in East\r\n    Lothian carried off by the Fairies&mdash;Another instance from Pennant.\r\n</pre>\r\n    <p class="pfirst">\r\n      <span class="dropcap" style="font-size: 4.00em">T</span>o return to Thomas\r\n      the Rhymer, with an account of whose legend I concluded last letter, it\r\n      would seem that the example which it afforded of obtaining the gift of\r\n      prescience, and other supernatural powers, by means of the fairy people,\r\n      became the common apology of those who attempted to cure diseases, to tell\r\n      fortunes, to revenge injuries, or to engage in traffic with the invisible\r\n      world, for the purpose of satisfying their own wishes, curiosity, or\r\n      revenge, or those of others. Those who practised the petty arts of\r\n      deception in such mystic cases, being naturally desirous to screen their\r\n      own impostures, were willing to be supposed to derive from the fairies, or\r\n      from mortals transported to fairyland the power necessary to effect the\r\n      displays of art which they pretended to exhibit. A confession of direct\r\n      communication and league with Satan, though the accused were too\r\n      frequently compelled by torture to admit and avow such horrors, might, the\r\n      poor wretches hoped, be avoided by the avowal of a less disgusting\r\n      intercourse with sublunary spirits, a race which might be described by\r\n      negatives, being neither angels, devils, nor the souls of deceased men;\r\n      nor would it, they might flatter themselves, be considered as any criminal\r\n      alliance, that they held communion with a race not properly hostile to\r\n      man, and willing, on certain conditions, to be useful and friendly to him.\r\n      Such an intercourse was certainly far short of the witch&rsquo;s renouncing her\r\n      salvation, delivering herself personally to the devil, and at once\r\n      ensuring condemnation in this world, together with the like doom in the\r\n      next.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Accordingly, the credulous, who, in search of health, knowledge,\r\n      greatness, or moved by any of the numberless causes for which men seek to\r\n      look into futurity, were anxious to obtain superhuman assistance, as well\r\n      as the numbers who had it in view to dupe such willing clients, became\r\n      both cheated and cheaters, alike anxious to establish the possibility of a\r\n      harmless process of research into futurity, for laudable, or at least\r\n      innocent objects, as healing diseases and the like; in short, of the\r\n      existence of white magic, as it was called, in opposition to that black\r\n      art exclusively and directly derived from intercourse with Satan. Some\r\n      endeavoured to predict a man&rsquo;s fortune in marriage or his success in life\r\n      by the aspect of the stars; others pretended to possess spells, by which\r\n      they could reduce and compel an elementary spirit to enter within a stone,\r\n      a looking-glass, or some other local place of abode, and confine her there\r\n      by the power of an especial charm, conjuring her to abide and answer the\r\n      questions of her master. Of these we shall afterwards say something; but\r\n      the species of evasion now under our investigation is that of the fanatics\r\n      or impostors who pretended to draw information from the equivocal spirits\r\n      called fairies; and the number of instances before us is so great as\r\n      induces us to believe that the pretence of communicating with Elfland, and\r\n      not with the actual demon, was the manner in which the persons accused of\r\n      witchcraft most frequently endeavoured to excuse themselves, or at least\r\n      to alleviate the charges brought against them of practising sorcery. But\r\n      the Scottish law did not acquit those who accomplished even praiseworthy\r\n      actions, such as remarkable cures by mysterious remedies; and the\r\n      proprietor of a patent medicine who should in those days have attested his\r\n      having wrought such miracles as we see sometimes advertised, might perhaps\r\n      have forfeited his life before he established the reputation of his drop,\r\n      elixir, or pill.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Sometimes the soothsayers, who pretended to act on this information from\r\n      sublunary spirits, soared to higher matters than the practice of physic,\r\n      and interfered in the fate of nations. When James I. was murdered at Perth\r\n      in 1437, a Highland woman prophesied the course and purpose of the\r\n      conspiracy, and had she been listened to, it might have been disconcerted.\r\n      Being asked her source of knowledge, she answered Hudhart had told her;\r\n      which might either be the same with Hudkin, a Dutch spirit somewhat\r\n      similar to Friar Rush or Robin Goodfellow,<a href="#linknote-32"\r\n       name="linknoteref-32" id="linknoteref-32"><small>32</small></a> or with\r\n      the red-capped demon so powerful in the case of Lord Soulis, and other\r\n      wizards, to whom the Scots assigned rather more serious influence.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-32" id="linknote-32"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      32 (<a href="#linknoteref-32">return</a>)<br /> [ Hudkin is a very familiar\r\n      devil, who will do nobody hurt, except he receive injury; but he cannot\r\n      abide that, nor yet be mocked. He talketh with men friendly, sometimes\r\n      visibly, sometimes invisibly. There go as many tales upon this Hudkin in\r\n      some parts of Germany as there did in England on Robin Goodfellow.&mdash;&ldquo;Discourse\r\n      concerning Devils,&rdquo; annexed to &ldquo;The Discovery of Witchcraft,&rdquo; by Reginald\r\n      Scot, book i. chap. 21.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The most special account which I have found of the intercourse between\r\n      Fairyland and a female professing to have some influence in that court,\r\n      combined with a strong desire to be useful to the distressed of both\r\n      sexes, occurs in the early part of a work to which I have been exceedingly\r\n      obliged in the present and other publications.<a href="#linknote-33"\r\n       name="linknoteref-33" id="linknoteref-33"><small>33</small></a> The\r\n      details of the evidence, which consists chiefly of the unfortunate woman&rsquo;s\r\n      own confession, are more full than usual, and comprehend some curious\r\n      particulars. To spare technical repetitions, I must endeavour to select\r\n      the principal facts in evidence in detail, so far as they bear upon the\r\n      present subject.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-33" id="linknote-33"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      33 (<a href="#linknoteref-33">return</a>)<br /> [ The curious collection of\r\n      trials, from &ldquo;The Criminal Records of Scotland,&rdquo; now in the course of\r\n      publication, by Robert Pitcairn, Esq., affords so singular a picture of\r\n      the manners and habits of our ancestors, while yet a semibarbarous people,\r\n      that it is equally worth the attention of the historian, the antiquary,\r\n      the philosopher, and the poet.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      On the 8th November, 1576, Elizabeth or Bessie Dunlop, spouse to Andro\r\n      Jak, in Lyne, in the Barony of Dalry, Ayrshire, was accused of sorcery and\r\n      witchcraft and abuse of the people. Her answers to the interrogatories of\r\n      the judges or prosecutors ran thus: It being required of her by what art\r\n      she could tell of lost goods or prophesy the event of illness, she replied\r\n      that of herself she had no knowledge or science of such matters, but that\r\n      when questions were asked at her concerning such matters, she was in the\r\n      habit of applying to one Thome Reid, who died at the battle of Pinkie\r\n      (10th September, 1547), as he himself affirmed, and who resolved her any\r\n      questions which she asked at him. This person she described as a\r\n      respectable elderly-looking man, grey-bearded, and wearing a grey coat,\r\n      with Lombard sleeves of the auld fashion. A pair of grey breeches and\r\n      white stockings gartered above the knee, a black bonnet on his head, close\r\n      behind and plain before, with silken laces drawn through the lips thereof,\r\n      and a white wand in his hand, completed the description of what we may\r\n      suppose a respectable-looking man of the province and period. Being\r\n      demanded concerning her first interview with this mysterious Thome Reid,\r\n      she gave rather an affecting account of the disasters with which she was\r\n      then afflicted, and a sense of which perhaps aided to conjure up the\r\n      imaginary counsellor. She was walking between her own house and the yard\r\n      of Monkcastle, driving her cows to the common pasture, and making heavy\r\n      moan with herself, weeping bitterly for her cow that was dead, her husband\r\n      and child that were sick of the land-ill (some contagious sickness of the\r\n      time), while she herself was in a very infirm state, having lately borne a\r\n      child. On this occasion she met Thome Reid for the first time, who saluted\r\n      her courteously, which she returned. &ldquo;Sancta Maria, Bessie!&rdquo; said the\r\n      apparition, &ldquo;why must thou make such dole and weeping for any earthly\r\n      thing?&rdquo; &ldquo;Have I not reason for great sorrow,&rdquo; said she, &ldquo;since our\r\n      property is going to destruction, my husband is on the point of death, my\r\n      baby will not live, and I am myself at a weak point? Have I not cause to\r\n      have a sore heart?&rdquo; &ldquo;Bessie,&rdquo; answered the spirit, &ldquo;thou hast displeased\r\n      God in asking something that thou should not, and I counsel you to amend\r\n      your fault. I tell thee, thy child shall die ere thou get home; thy two\r\n      sheep shall also die; but thy husband shall recover, and be as well and\r\n      feir as ever he was.&rdquo; The good woman was something comforted to hear that\r\n      her husband was to be spared in such her general calamity, but was rather\r\n      alarmed to see her ghostly counsellor pass from her and disappear through\r\n      a hole in the garden wall, seemingly too narrow to admit of any living\r\n      person passing through it. Another time he met her at the Thorn of\r\n      Dawmstarnik, and showed his ultimate purpose by offering her plenty of\r\n      every thing if she would but deny Christendom and the faith she took at\r\n      the font-stone. She answered, that rather than do that she would be torn\r\n      at horses&rsquo; heels, but that she would be conformable to his advice in less\r\n      matters. He parted with her in some displeasure. Shortly afterwards he\r\n      appeared in her own house about noon, which was at the time occupied by\r\n      her husband and three tailors. But neither Andrew Jak nor the three\r\n      tailors were sensible of the presence of the phantom warrior who was slain\r\n      at Pinkie; so that, without attracting their observation, he led out the\r\n      good-wife to the end of the house near the kiln. Here he showed her a\r\n      company of eight women and four men. The women were busked in their\r\n      plaids, and very seemly. The strangers saluted her, and said, &ldquo;Welcome,\r\n      Bessie; wilt thou go with us?&rdquo; But Bessie was silent, as Thome Reid had\r\n      previously recommended. After this she saw their lips move, but did not\r\n      understand what they said; and in a short time they removed from thence\r\n      with a hideous ugly howling sound, like that of a hurricane. Thome Reid\r\n      then acquainted her that these were the good wights (fairies) dwelling in\r\n      the court of Elfland, who came to invite her to go thither with them.\r\n      Bessie answered that, before she went that road, it would require some\r\n      consideration. Thome answered, &ldquo;Seest thou not me both meat-worth,\r\n      clothes-worth, and well enough in person?&rdquo; and engaged she should be\r\n      easier than ever she was. But she replied, she dwelt with her husband and\r\n      children, and would not leave them; to which Thome Reid replied, in very\r\n      ill-humour, that if such were her sentiments, she would get little good of\r\n      him.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Although they thus disagreed on the principal object of Thome Reid&rsquo;s\r\n      visits, Bessie Dunlop affirmed he continued to come to her frequently, and\r\n      assist her with his counsel; and that if any one consulted her about the\r\n      ailments of human beings or of cattle, or the recovery of things lost and\r\n      stolen, she was, by the advice of Thome Reid, always able to answer the\r\n      querists. She was also taught by her (literally ghostly) adviser how to\r\n      watch the operation of the ointments he gave her, and to presage from them\r\n      the recovery or death of the patient. She said Thome gave her herbs with\r\n      his own hand, with which she cured John Jack&rsquo;s bairn and Wilson&rsquo;s of the\r\n      Townhead. She also was helpful to a waiting-woman of the young Lady\r\n      Stanlie, daughter of the Lady Johnstone, whose disease, according to the\r\n      opinion of the infallible Thome Reid, was &ldquo;a cauld blood that came about\r\n      her heart,&rdquo; and frequently caused her to swoon away. For this Thome mixed\r\n      a remedy as generous as the balm of Gilead itself. It was composed of the\r\n      most potent ale, concocted with spices and a little white sugar, to be\r\n      drunk every morning before taking food. For these prescriptions Bessie\r\n      Dunlop&rsquo;s fee was a peck of meal and some cheese. The young woman\r\n      recovered. But the poor old Lady Kilbowie could get no help for her leg,\r\n      which had been crooked for years; for Thome Reid said the marrow of the\r\n      limb was perished and the blood benumbed, so that she would never recover,\r\n      and if she sought further assistance, it would be the worse for her. These\r\n      opinions indicate common sense and prudence at least, whether we consider\r\n      them as originating with the <i>umquhile</i> Thome Reid, or with the\r\n      culprit whom he patronized. The judgments given in the case of stolen\r\n      goods were also well chosen; for though they seldom led to recovering the\r\n      property, they generally alleged such satisfactory reasons for its not\r\n      being found as effectually to cover the credit of the prophetess. Thus\r\n      Hugh Scott&rsquo;s cloak could not be returned, because the thieves had gained\r\n      time to make it into a kirtle. James Jamieson and James Baird would, by\r\n      her advice, have recovered their plough-irons, which had been stolen, had\r\n      it not been the will of fate that William Dougal, sheriff&rsquo;s officer, one\r\n      of the parties searching for them, should accept a bribe of three pounds\r\n      not to find them. In short, although she lost a lace which Thome Reid gave\r\n      her out of his own hand, which, tied round women in childbirth, had the\r\n      power of helping their delivery, Bessy Dunlop&rsquo;s profession of a wise woman\r\n      seems to have flourished indifferently well till it drew the evil eye of\r\n      the law upon her.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      More minutely pressed upon the subject of her familiar, she said she had\r\n      never known him while among the living, but was aware that the person so\r\n      calling himself was one who had, in his lifetime, actually been known in\r\n      middle earth as Thome Reid, officer to the Laird of Blair, and who died at\r\n      Pinkie. Of this she was made certain, because he sent her on errands to\r\n      his son, who had succeeded in his office, and to others his relatives,\r\n      whom he named, and commanded them to amend certain trespasses which he had\r\n      done while alive, furnishing her with sure tokens by which they should\r\n      know that it was he who had sent her. One of these errands was somewhat\r\n      remarkable. She was to remind a neighbour of some particular which she was\r\n      to recall to his memory by the token that Thome Reid and he had set out\r\n      together to go to the battle which took place on the Black Saturday; that\r\n      the person to whom the message was sent was inclined rather to move in a\r\n      different direction, but that Thome Reid heartened him to pursue his\r\n      journey, and brought him to the Kirk of Dalry, where he bought a parcel of\r\n      figs, and made a present of them to his companion, tying them in his\r\n      handkerchief; after which they kept company till they came to the field\r\n      upon the fatal Black Saturday, as the battle of Pinkie was long called.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Of Thome&rsquo;s other habits, she said that he always behaved with the\r\n      strictest propriety, only that he pressed her to go to Elfland with him,\r\n      and took hold of her apron as if to pull her along. Again, she said she\r\n      had seen him in public places, both in the churchyard at Dalry and on the\r\n      street of Edinburgh, where he walked about among other people, and handled\r\n      goods that were exposed to sale, without attracting any notice. She\r\n      herself did not then speak to him, for it was his command that, upon such\r\n      occasions, she should never address him unless he spoke first to her. In\r\n      his theological opinions, Mr. Reid appeared to lean to the Church of Rome,\r\n      which, indeed, was most indulgent to the fairy folk. He said that the <i>new\r\n      law, i.e.,</i> the Reformation, was not good, and that the old faith\r\n      should return again, but not exactly as it had been before. Being\r\n      questioned why this visionary sage attached himself to her more than to\r\n      others, the accused person replied, that when she was confined in\r\n      childbirth of one of her boys, a stout woman came into her hut, and sat\r\n      down on a bench by her bed, like a mere earthly gossip; that she demanded\r\n      a drink, and was accommodated accordingly; and thereafter told the invalid\r\n      that the child should die, but that her husband, who was then ailing,\r\n      should recover. This visit seems to have been previous to her meeting\r\n      Thome Reid near Monkcastle garden, for that worthy explained to her that\r\n      her stout visitant was Queen of Fairies, and that he had since attended\r\n      her by the express command of that lady, his queen and mistress. This\r\n      reminds us of the extreme doting attachment which the Queen of the Fairies\r\n      is represented to have taken for Dapper in &ldquo;The Alchemist.&rdquo; Thome Reid\r\n      attended her, it would seem, on being summoned thrice, and appeared to her\r\n      very often within four years. He often requested her to go with him on his\r\n      return to Fairyland, and when she refused, he shook his head, and said she\r\n      would repent it.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      If the delicacy of the reader&rsquo;s imagination be a little hurt at imagining\r\n      the elegant Titania in the disguise of a <i>stout</i> woman, a heavy\r\n      burden for a clumsy bench, drinking what Christopher Sly would have called\r\n      very sufficient small-beer with a peasant&rsquo;s wife, the following\r\n      description of the fairy host may come more near the idea he has formed of\r\n      that invisible company:&mdash;Bessie Dunlop declared that as she went to\r\n      tether her nag by the side of Restalrig Loch (Lochend, near the eastern\r\n      port of Edinburgh), she heard a tremendous sound of a body of riders\r\n      rushing past her with such a noise as if heaven and earth would come\r\n      together; that the sound swept past her and seemed to rush into the lake\r\n      with a hideous rumbling noise. All this while she saw nothing; but Thome\r\n      Reid showed her that the noise was occasioned by the wights, who were\r\n      performing one of their cavalcades upon earth.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The intervention of Thome Reid as a partner in her trade of petty sorcery\r\n      did not avail poor Bessie Dunlop, although his affection to her was\r\n      apparently entirely platonic&mdash;the greatest familiarity on which he\r\n      ventured was taking hold of her gown as he pressed her to go with him to\r\n      Elfland. Neither did it avail her that the petty sorcery which she\r\n      practised was directed to venial or even beneficial purposes. The sad\r\n      words on the margin of the record, &ldquo;Convict and burnt,&rdquo; sufficiently\r\n      express the tragic conclusion of a curious tale.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Alison Pearson, in Byrehill, was, 28th May, 1588, tried for invocation of\r\n      the spirits of the devil, specially in the vision of one Mr. William\r\n      Sympson, her cousin and her mother&rsquo;s brother&rsquo;s son, who she affirmed was a\r\n      great scholar and doctor of medicine, dealing with charms and abusing the\r\n      ignorant people. Against this poor woman her own confession, as in the\r\n      case of Bessie Dunlop, was the principal evidence.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      As Bessie Dunlop had Thome Reid, Alison Pearson had also a familiar in the\r\n      court of Elfland. This was her relative, William Sympson aforesaid, born\r\n      in Stirling, whose father was king&rsquo;s smith in that town. William had been\r\n      taken away, she said, by a man of Egypt (a Gipsy), who carried him to\r\n      Egypt along with him; that he remained there twelve years, and that his\r\n      father died in the meantime for opening a priest&rsquo;s book and looking upon\r\n      it. She declared that she had renewed her acquaintance with her kinsman so\r\n      soon as he returned. She further confessed that one day as she passed\r\n      through Grange Muir she lay down in a fit of sickness, and that a green\r\n      man came to her, and said if she would be faithful he might do her good.\r\n      In reply she charged him, in the name of God and by the law he lived upon,\r\n      if he came for her soul&rsquo;s good to tell his errand. On this the green man\r\n      departed. But he afterwards appeared to her with many men and women with\r\n      him, and against her will she was obliged to pass with them farther than\r\n      she could tell, with piping, mirth, and good cheer; also that she\r\n      accompanied them into Lothian, where she saw puncheons of wine with tasses\r\n      or drinking-cups. She declared that when she told of these things she was\r\n      sorely tormented, and received a blow that took away the power of her left\r\n      side, and left on it an ugly mark which had no feeling. She also confessed\r\n      that she had seen before sunrise the good neighbours make their salves\r\n      with pans and fires. Sometimes, she said, they came in such fearful forms\r\n      as frightened her very much. At other times they spoke her fair, and\r\n      promised her that she should never want if faithful, but if she told of\r\n      them and their doings, they threatened to martyr her. She also boasted of\r\n      her favour with the Queen of Elfland and the good friends she had at that\r\n      court, notwithstanding that she was sometimes in disgrace there, and had\r\n      not seen the queen for seven years. She said William Sympson is with the\r\n      fairies, and that he lets her know when they are coming; and that he\r\n      taught her what remedies to use, and how to apply them. She declared that\r\n      when a whirlwind blew the fairies were commonly there, and that her cousin\r\n      Sympson confessed that every year the tithe of them were taken away to\r\n      hell. The celebrated Patrick Adamson, an excellent divine and accomplished\r\n      scholar, created by James VI. Archbishop of St. Andrews, swallowed the\r\n      prescriptions of this poor hypochondriac with good faith and will, eating\r\n      a stewed fowl, and drinking out at two draughts a quart of claret,\r\n      medicated with the drugs she recommended. According to the belief of the\r\n      time, this Alison Pearson transferred the bishop&rsquo;s indisposition from\r\n      himself to a white palfrey, which died in consequence. There is a very\r\n      severe libel on him for this and other things unbecoming his order, with\r\n      which he was charged, and from which we learn that Lethington and\r\n      Buccleuch were seen by Dame Pearson in the Fairyland.<a href="#linknote-34"\r\n       name="linknoteref-34" id="linknoteref-34"><small>34</small></a> This poor\r\n      woman&rsquo;s kinsman, Sympson, did not give better shelter to her than Thome\r\n      Reid had done to her predecessor. The margin of the court-book again bears\r\n      the melancholy and brief record, &ldquo;<i>Convicta et combusta</i>.&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-34" id="linknote-34"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      34 (<a href="#linknoteref-34">return</a>)<br /> [ See &ldquo;Scottish Poems,&rdquo;\r\n       edited by John G. Dalzell, p. 321.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The two poor women last mentioned are the more to be pitied as, whether\r\n      enthusiasts or impostors, they practised their supposed art exclusively\r\n      for the advantage of mankind. The following extraordinary detail involves\r\n      persons of far higher quality, and who sought to familiars for more\r\n      baneful purposes.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Katherine Munro, Lady Fowlis, by birth Katherine Ross of Balnagowan, of\r\n      high rank, both by her own family and that of her husband, who was the\r\n      fifteenth Baron of Fowlis, and chief of the warlike clan of Munro, had a\r\n      stepmother&rsquo;s quarrel with Robert Munro, eldest son of her husband, which\r\n      she gratified by forming a scheme for compassing his death by unlawful\r\n      arts. Her proposed advantage in this was, that the widow of Robert, when\r\n      he was thus removed, should marry with her brother, George Ross of\r\n      Balnagowan; and for this purpose, her sister-in-law, the present Lady\r\n      Balnagowan, was also to be removed. Lady Fowlis, if the indictment had a\r\n      syllable of truth, carried on her practices with the least possible\r\n      disguise. She assembled persons of the lowest order, stamped with an\r\n      infamous celebrity as witches; and, besides making pictures or models in\r\n      clay, by which they hoped to bewitch Robert Munro and Lady Balnagowan,\r\n      they brewed, upon one occasion, poison so strong that a page tasting of it\r\n      immediately took sickness. Another earthen jar (Scottic <i>pig</i>) of\r\n      the same deleterious liquor was prepared by the Lady Fowlis, and sent with\r\n      her own nurse for the purpose of administering it to Robert Munro. The\r\n      messenger having stumbled in the dark, broke the jar, and a rank grass\r\n      grew on the spot where it fell, which sheep and cattle abhorred to touch;\r\n      but the nurse, having less sense than the brute beasts, and tasting of the\r\n      liquor which had been spilled, presently died. What is more to our present\r\n      purpose, Lady Fowlis made use of the artillery of Elfland in order to\r\n      destroy her stepson and sister-in-law. Laskie Loncart, one of the\r\n      assistant hags, produced two of what the common people call elf-arrow\r\n      heads, being, in fact, the points of flint used for arming the ends of\r\n      arrow-shafts in the most ancient times, but accounted by the superstitious\r\n      the weapons by which the fairies were wont to destroy both man and beast.\r\n      The pictures of the intended victims were then set up at the north end of\r\n      the apartment, and Christian Ross Malcolmson, an assistant hag, shot two\r\n      shafts at the image of Lady Balnagowan, and three against the picture of\r\n      Robert Munro, by which shots they were broken, and Lady Fowlis commanded\r\n      new figures to be modelled. Many similar acts of witchcraft and of\r\n      preparing poisons were alleged against Lady Fowlis.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Her son-in-law, Hector Munro, one of his stepmother&rsquo;s prosecutors, was,\r\n      for reasons of his own, active in a similar conspiracy against the life of\r\n      his own brother. The rites that he practised were of an uncouth,\r\n      barbarous, and unusual nature. Hector, being taken ill, consulted on his\r\n      case some of the witches or soothsayers, to whom this family appears to\r\n      have been partial. The answer was unanimous that he must die unless the\r\n      principal man of his blood should suffer death in his stead. It was agreed\r\n      that the vicarious substitute for Hector must mean George Munro, brother\r\n      to him by the half-blood (the son of the Katharine Lady Fowlis before\r\n      commemorated). Hector sent at least seven messengers for this young man,\r\n      refusing to receive any of his other friends till he saw the substitute\r\n      whom he destined to take his place in the grave.
