When George at length\r\n      arrived, Hector, by advice of a notorious witch, called Marion\r\n      MacIngarach, and of his own foster-mother, Christian Neil Dalyell,\r\n      received him with peculiar coldness and restraint. He did not speak for\r\n      the space of an hour, till his brother broke silence and asked, &ldquo;How he\r\n      did?&rdquo; Hector replied, &ldquo;That he was the better George had come to visit\r\n      him,&rdquo; and relapsed into silence, which seemed singular when compared with\r\n      the anxiety he had displayed to see his brother; but it was, it seems, a\r\n      necessary part of the spell. After midnight the sorceress Marion\r\n      MacIngarach, the chief priestess or Nicneven of the company, went forth\r\n      with her accomplices, carrying spades with them. They then proceeded to\r\n      dig a grave not far from the seaside, upon a piece of land which formed\r\n      the boundary betwixt two proprietors. The grave was made as nearly as\r\n      possible to the size of their patient Hector Munro, the earth dug out of\r\n      the grave being laid aside for the time. After ascertaining that the\r\n      operation of the charm on George Munro, the destined victim, should be\r\n      suspended for a time, to avoid suspicion, the conspirators proceeded to\r\n      work their spell in a singular, impressive, and, I believe, unique manner.\r\n      The time being January, 1588, the patient, Hector Munro, was borne forth\r\n      in a pair of blankets, accompanied with all who were entrusted with the\r\n      secret, who were warned to be strictly silent till the chief sorceress\r\n      should have received her information from the angel whom they served.\r\n      Hector Munro was carried to his grave and laid therein, the earth being\r\n      filled in on him, and the grave secured with stakes as at a real funeral.\r\n      Marion MacIngarach, the Hecate of the night, then sat down by the grave,\r\n      while Christian Neil Dalyell, the foster-mother, ran the breadth of about\r\n      nine ridges distant, leading a boy in her hand, and, coming again to the\r\n      grave where Hector Munro was interred alive, demanded of the witch which\r\n      victim she would choose, who replied that she chose Hector to live and\r\n      George to die in his stead. This form of incantation was thrice repeated\r\n      ere Mr. Hector was removed from his chilling bed in a January grave and\r\n      carried home, all remaining mute as before. The consequence of a process\r\n      which seems ill-adapted to produce the former effect was that Hector Munro\r\n      recovered, and after the intervention of twelve months George Munro, his\r\n      brother, died. Hector took the principal witch into high favour, made her\r\n      keeper of his sheep, and evaded, it is said, to present her to trial when\r\n      charged at Aberdeen to produce her. Though one or two inferior persons\r\n      suffered death on account of the sorceries practised in the house of\r\n      Fowlis, the Lady Katharine and her stepson Hector had both the unusual\r\n      good fortune to be found not guilty. Mr. Pitcairn remarks that the juries,\r\n      being composed of subordinate persons not suitable to the rank or family\r\n      of the person tried, has all the appearance of having been packed on\r\n      purpose for acquittal. It might also, in some interval of good sense,\r\n      creep into the heads of Hector Munro&rsquo;s assize that the enchantment being\r\n      performed in January, 1588, and the deceased being only taken ill of his\r\n      fatal disease in April, 1590, the distance between the events might seem\r\n      too great to admit the former being regarded as the cause of the latter.<a\r\n      href="#linknote-35" name="linknoteref-35" id="linknoteref-35"><small>35</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-35" id="linknote-35"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      35 (<a href="#linknoteref-35">return</a>)<br /> [ Pitcairn&rsquo;s &ldquo;Trials,&rdquo; vol.\r\n      i. pp. 191-201.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Another instance of the skill of a sorcerer being traced to the\r\n      instructions of the elves is found in the confession of John Stewart,\r\n      called a vagabond, but professing skill in palmistry and jugglery, and\r\n      accused of having assisted Margaret Barclay, or Dein, to sink or cast away\r\n      a vessel belonging to her own good brother. It being demanded of him by\r\n      what means he professed himself to have knowledge of things to come, the\r\n      said John confessed that the space of twenty-six years ago, he being\r\n      travelling on All-Hallow Even night, between the towns of Monygoif (so\r\n      spelled) and Clary, in Galway, he met with the King of the Fairies and his\r\n      company, and that the King of the Fairies gave him a stroke with a white\r\n      rod over the forehead, which took from him the power of speech and the use\r\n      of one eye, which he wanted for the space of three years. He declared that\r\n      the use of speech and eyesight was restored to him by the King of Fairies\r\n      and his company, on an Hallowe&rsquo;en night, at the town of Dublin, in\r\n      Ireland, and that since that time he had joined these people every\r\n      Saturday at seven o&rsquo;clock, and remained with them all the night; also,\r\n      that they met every Hallow-tide, sometimes on Lanark Hill (Tintock,\r\n      perhaps), sometimes on Kilmaurs Hill, and that he was then taught by them.\r\n      He pointed out the spot of his forehead on which, he said, the King of the\r\n      Fairies struck him with a white rod, whereupon the prisoner, being\r\n      blindfolded, they pricked the spot with a large pin, whereof he expressed\r\n      no sense or feeling. He made the usual declaration, that he had seen many\r\n      persons at the Court of Fairy, whose names he rehearsed particularly, and\r\n      declared that all such persons as are taken away by sudden death go with\r\n      the King of Elfland. With this man&rsquo;s evidence we have at present no more\r\n      to do, though we may revert to the execrable proceedings which then took\r\n      place against this miserable juggler and the poor women who were accused\r\n      of the same crime. At present it is quoted as another instance of a\r\n      fortune-teller referring to Elfland as the source of his knowledge.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      At Auldearne, a parish and burgh of barony in the county of Nairne, the\r\n      epidemic terror of witches seems to have gone very far. The confession of\r\n      a woman called Isobel Gowdie, of date April, 1662, implicates, as usual,\r\n      the Court of Fairy, and blends the operations of witchcraft with the\r\n      facilities afforded by the fairies. These need be the less insisted upon\r\n      in this place, as the arch-fiend, and not the elves, had the immediate\r\n      agency in the abominations which she narrates. Yet she had been, she said,\r\n      in the Dounie Hills, and got meat there from the Queen of Fairies more\r\n      than she could eat. She added, that the queen is bravely clothed in white\r\n      linen and in white and brown cloth, that the King of Fairy is a brave man;\r\n      and there were elf-bulls roaring and <i>skoilling</i> at the entrance of\r\n      their palace, which frightened her much. On another occasion this frank\r\n      penitent confesses her presence at a rendezvous of witches, Lammas, 1659,\r\n      where, after they had rambled through the country in different shapes&mdash;of\r\n      cats, hares, and the like&mdash;eating, drinking, and wasting the goods of\r\n      their neighbours into whose houses they could penetrate, they at length\r\n      came to the dounie Hills, where the mountain opened to receive them, and\r\n      they entered a fair big room, as bright as day. At the entrance ramped and\r\n      roared the large fairy bulls, which always alarmed Isobel Gowdie. These\r\n      animals are probably the water-bulls, famous both in Scottish and Irish\r\n      tradition, which are not supposed to be themselves altogether <i>canny</i>\r\n      or safe to have concern with. In their caverns the fairies manufactured\r\n      those elf-arrow heads with which the witches and they wrought so much\r\n      evil. The elves and the arch-fiend laboured jointly at this task, the\r\n      former forming and sharpening the dart from the rough flint, and the\r\n      latter perfecting and finishing (or, as it is called, <i>dighting</i>) it.\r\n      Then came the sport of the meeting. The witches bestrode either\r\n      corn-straws, bean-stalks, or rushes, and calling, &ldquo;Horse and Hattock, in\r\n      the Devil&rsquo;s name!&rdquo; which is the elfin signal for mounting, they flew\r\n      wherever they listed. If the little whirlwind which accompanies their\r\n      transportation passed any mortal who neglected to bless himself, all such\r\n      fell under the witches&rsquo; power, and they acquired the right of shooting at\r\n      him. The penitent prisoner gives the names of many whom she and her\r\n      sisters had so slain, the death for which she was most sorry being that of\r\n      William Brown, in the Milntown of Mains. A shaft was also aimed at the\r\n      Reverend Harrie Forbes, a minister who was present at the examination of\r\n      Isobel, the confessing party. The arrow fell short, and the witch would\r\n      have taken aim again, but her master forbade her, saying the reverend\r\n      gentleman&rsquo;s life was not subject to their power. To this strange and very\r\n      particular confession we shall have occasion to recur when witchcraft is\r\n      the more immediate subject. What is above narrated marks the manner in\r\n      which the belief in that crime was blended with the fairy superstition.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      To proceed to more modern instances of persons supposed to have fallen\r\n      under the power of the fairy race, we must not forget the Reverend Robert\r\n      Kirke, minister of the Gospel, the first translator of the Psalms into\r\n      Gaelic verse. He was, in the end of the seventeenth century, successively\r\n      minister of the Highland parishes of Balquidder and Aberfoyle, lying in\r\n      the most romantic district of Perthshire, and within the Highland line.\r\n      These beautiful and wild regions, comprehending so many lakes, rocks,\r\n      sequestered valleys, and dim copsewoods, are not even yet quite abandoned\r\n      by the fairies, who have resolutely maintained secure footing in a region\r\n      so well suited for their residence. Indeed, so much was this the case\r\n      formerly, that Mr. Kirke, while in his latter charge of Aberfoyle, found\r\n      materials for collecting and compiling his Essay on the &ldquo;Subterranean and\r\n      for the most part Invisible People heretofore going under the name of\r\n      Elves, Fawnes, and Fairies, or the like."<a href="#linknote-36"\r\n       name="linknoteref-36" id="linknoteref-36"><small>36</small></a> In this\r\n      discourse, the author, &ldquo;with undoubting mind,&rdquo; describes the fairy race as\r\n      a sort of astral spirits, of a kind betwixt humanity and angels&mdash;says,\r\n      that they have children, nurses, marriages, deaths, and burials, like\r\n      mortals in appearance; that, in some respect, they represent mortal men,\r\n      and that individual apparitions, or double-men, are found among them,\r\n      corresponding with mortals existing on earth. Mr. Kirke accuses them of\r\n      stealing the milk from the cows, and of carrying away, what is more\r\n      material, the women in pregnancy, and new-born children from their nurses.\r\n      The remedy is easy in both cases. The milk cannot be stolen if the mouth\r\n      of the calf, before he is permitted to suck, be rubbed with a certain\r\n      balsam, very easily come by; and the woman in travail is safe if a piece\r\n      of cold iron is put into the bed. Mr. Kirke accounts for this by informing\r\n      us that the great northern mines of iron, lying adjacent to the place of\r\n      eternal punishment, have a savour odious to these &ldquo;fascinating creatures.&rdquo;\r\n       They have, says the reverend author, what one would not expect, many light\r\n      toyish books (novels and plays, doubtless), others on Rosycrucian\r\n      subjects, and of an abstruse mystical character; but they have no Bibles\r\n      or works of devotion. The essayist fails not to mention the elf-arrow\r\n      heads, which have something of the subtlety of thunderbolts, and can\r\n      mortally wound the vital parts without breaking the skin. These wounds, he\r\n      says, he has himself observed in beasts, and felt the fatal lacerations\r\n      which he could not see.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-36" id="linknote-36"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      36 (<a href="#linknoteref-36">return</a>)<br /> [ The title continues:&mdash;&ldquo;Among\r\n      the Low Country Scots, as they are described by those who have the second\r\n      sight, and now, to occasion farther enquiry, collected and compared by a\r\n      circumspect enquirer residing among the Scottish-Irish (<i>i.e.</i>, the\r\n      Gael, or Highlanders) in Scotland.&rdquo; It was printed with the author&rsquo;s name\r\n      in 1691, and reprinted, Edinburgh, 1815, for Longman &amp; Co.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It was by no means to be supposed that the elves, so jealous and irritable\r\n      a race as to be incensed against those who spoke of them under their\r\n      proper names, should be less than mortally offended at the temerity of the\r\n      reverend author, who had pryed so deeply into their mysteries, for the\r\n      purpose of giving them to the public. Although, therefore, the learned\r\n      divine&rsquo;s monument, with his name duly inscribed, is to be seen at the east\r\n      end of the churchyard at Aberfoyle, yet those acquainted with his real\r\n      history do not believe that he enjoys the natural repose of the tomb. His\r\n      successor, the Rev. Dr. Grahame, has informed us of the general belief\r\n      that, as Mr. Kirke was walking one evening in his night-gown upon a <i>Dun-shi,</i>\r\n      or fairy mount, in the vicinity of the manse or parsonage, behold! he sunk\r\n      down in what seemed to be a fit of apoplexy, which the unenlightened took\r\n      for death, while the more understanding knew it to be a swoon produced by\r\n      the supernatural influence of the people whose precincts he had violated.\r\n      After the ceremony of a seeming funeral, the form of the Rev. Robert Kirke\r\n      appeared to a relation, and commanded him to go to Grahame of Duchray,\r\n      ancestor of the present General Graham Stirling. &ldquo;Say to Duchray, who is\r\n      my cousin as well as your own, that I am not dead, but a captive in\r\n      Fairyland, and only one chance remains for my liberation. When the\r\n      posthumous child, of which my wife has been delivered since my\r\n      disappearance, shall be brought to baptism, I will appear in the room,\r\n      when, if Duchray shall throw over my head the knife or dirk which he holds\r\n      in his hand, I may be restored to society; but if this opportunity is\r\n      neglected, I am lost for ever.&rdquo; Duchray was apprised of what was to be\r\n      done. The ceremony took place, and the apparition of Mr. Kirke was visibly\r\n      seen while they were seated at table; but Grahame of Duchray, in his\r\n      astonishment, failed to perform the ceremony enjoined, and it is to be\r\n      feared that Mr. Kirke still &ldquo;drees his weird in Fairyland,&rdquo; the Elfin\r\n      state declaring to him, as the Ocean to poor Falconer, who perished at sea\r\n      after having written his popular poem of &ldquo;The Shipwreck&rdquo;&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;Thou hast proclaimed our power&mdash;be thou our prey!&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Upon this subject the reader may consult a very entertaining little\r\n      volume, called &ldquo;Sketches of Perthshire,"<a href="#linknote-37"\r\n       name="linknoteref-37" id="linknoteref-37"><small>37</small></a> by the\r\n      Rev. Dr. Grahame of Aberfoyle. The terrible visitation of fairy vengeance\r\n      which has lighted upon Mr. Kirke has not intimidated his successor, an\r\n      excellent man and good antiquary, from affording us some curious\r\n      information on fairy superstition. He tells us that these capricious elves\r\n      are chiefly dangerous on a Friday, when, as the day of the Crucifixion,\r\n      evil spirits have most power, and mentions their displeasure at any one\r\n      who assumes their accustomed livery of green, a colour fatal to several\r\n      families in Scotland, to the whole race of the gallant Grahames in\r\n      particular; insomuch that we have heard that in battle a Grahame is\r\n      generally shot through the green check of his plaid; moreover, that a\r\n      veteran sportsman of the name, having come by a bad fall, he thought it\r\n      sufficient to account for it, that he had a piece of green whip-cord to\r\n      complete the lash of his hunting-whip. I remember, also, that my late\r\n      amiable friend, James Grahame, author of &ldquo;The Sabbath,&rdquo; would not break\r\n      through this ancient prejudice of his clan, but had his library table\r\n      covered with blue or black cloth, rather than use the fated colour\r\n      commonly employed on such occasions.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-37" id="linknote-37"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      37 (<a href="#linknoteref-37">return</a>)<br /> [ Edinburgh, 1812.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      To return from the Perthshire fairies, I may quote a story of a nature\r\n      somewhat similar to that of Mas Robert Kirke. The life of the excellent\r\n      person who told it was, for the benefit of her friends and the poor,\r\n      protracted to an unusual duration; so I conceive that this adventure,\r\n      which took place in her childhood, might happen before the middle of last\r\n      century. She was residing with some relations near the small seaport town\r\n      of North Berwick, when the place and its vicinity were alarmed by the\r\n      following story:&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      An industrious man, a weaver in the little town, was married to a\r\n      beautiful woman, who, after bearing two or three children, was so\r\n      unfortunate as to die during the birth of a fourth child. The infant was\r\n      saved, but the mother had expired in convulsions; and as she was much\r\n      disfigured after death, it became an opinion among her gossips that, from\r\n      some neglect of those who ought to have watched the sick woman, she must\r\n      have been carried off by the elves, and this ghastly corpse substituted in\r\n      the place of the body. The widower paid little attention to these rumours,\r\n      and, after bitterly lamenting his wife for a year of mourning, began to\r\n      think on the prudence of forming a new marriage, which, to a poor artisan\r\n      with so young a family, and without the assistance of a housewife, was\r\n      almost a matter of necessity. He readily found a neighbour with whose good\r\n      looks he was satisfied, whilst her character for temper seemed to warrant\r\n      her good usage of his children. He proposed himself and was accepted, and\r\n      carried the names of the parties to the clergyman (called, I believe, Mr.\r\n      Matthew Reid) for the due proclamation of banns. As the man had really\r\n      loved his late partner, it is likely that this proposed decisive\r\n      alteration of his condition brought back many reflections concerning the\r\n      period of their union, and with these recalled the extraordinary rumours\r\n      which were afloat at the time of her decease, so that the whole forced\r\n      upon him the following lively dream:&mdash;As he lay in his bed, awake as\r\n      he thought, he beheld, at the ghostly hour of midnight, the figure of a\r\n      female dressed in white, who entered his hut, stood by the side of his\r\n      bed, and appeared to him the very likeness of his late wife. He conjured\r\n      her to speak, and with astonishment heard her say, like the minister of\r\n      Aberfoyle, that she was not dead, but the unwilling captive of the Good\r\n      Neighbours. Like Mr. Kirke, too, she told him that if all the love which\r\n      he once had for her was not entirely gone, an opportunity still remained\r\n      of recovering her, or <i>winning her back</i>, as it was usually termed,\r\n      from the comfortless realms of Elfland. She charged him on a certain day\r\n      of the ensuing week that he should convene the most respectable\r\n      housekeepers in the town, with the clergyman at their head, and should\r\n      disinter the coffin in which she was supposed to have been buried. &ldquo;The\r\n      clergyman is to recite certain prayers, upon which,&rdquo; said the apparition,\r\n      &ldquo;I will start from the coffin and fly with great speed round the church,\r\n      and you must have the fleetest runner of the parish (naming a man famed\r\n      for swiftness) to pursue me, and such a one, the smith, renowned for his\r\n      strength, to hold me fast after I am overtaken; and in that case I shall,\r\n      by the prayers of the church, and the efforts of my loving husband and\r\n      neighbours, again recover my station in human society.&rdquo; In the morning the\r\n      poor widower was distressed with the recollection of his dream, but,\r\n      ashamed and puzzled, took no measures in consequence. A second night, as\r\n      is not very surprising, the visitation was again repeated. On the third\r\n      night she appeared with a sorrowful and displeased countenance, upbraided\r\n      him with want of love and affection, and conjured him, for the last time,\r\n      to attend to her instructions, which, if he now neglected, she would never\r\n      have power to visit earth or communicate with him again. In order to\r\n      convince him there was no delusion, he &ldquo;saw in his dream&rdquo; that she took up\r\n      the nursling at whose birth she had died, and gave it suck; she spilled\r\n      also a drop or two of her milk on the poor man&rsquo;s bed-clothes, as if to\r\n      assure him of the reality of the vision.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The next morning the terrified widower carried a statement of his\r\n      perplexity to Mr. Matthew Reid, the clergyman. This reverend person,\r\n      besides being an excellent divine in other respects, was at the same time\r\n      a man of sagacity, who understood the human passions. He did not attempt\r\n      to combat the reality of the vision which had thrown his parishioner into\r\n      this tribulation, but he contended it could be only an illusion of the\r\n      devil. He explained to the widower that no created being could have the\r\n      right or power to imprison or detain the soul of a Christian&mdash;conjured\r\n      him not to believe that his wife was otherwise disposed of than according\r\n      to God&rsquo;s pleasure&mdash;assured him that Protestant doctrine utterly\r\n      denies the existence of any middle state in the world to come&mdash;and\r\n      explained to him that he, as a clergyman of the Church of Scotland,\r\n      neither could nor dared authorize opening graves or using the intervention\r\n      of prayer to sanction rites of a suspicious character. The poor man,\r\n      confounded and perplexed by various feelings, asked his pastor what he\r\n      should do. &ldquo;I will give you my best advice,&rdquo; said the clergyman. &ldquo;Get your\r\n      new bride&rsquo;s consent to be married to-morrow, or to-day, if you can; I will\r\n      take it on me to dispense with the rest of the banns, or proclaim them\r\n      three times in one day. You will have a new wife, and, if you think of the\r\n      former, it will be only as of one from whom death has separated you, and\r\n      for whom you may have thoughts of affection and sorrow, but as a saint in\r\n      Heaven, and not as a prisoner in Elfland.&rdquo; The advice was taken, and the\r\n      perplexed widower had no more visitations from his former spouse.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      An instance, perhaps the latest which has been made public, of\r\n      communication with the Restless People&mdash;(a more proper epithet than\r\n      that of <i>Daoine Shi</i>, or Men of Peace, as they are called in Gaelic)&mdash;came\r\n      under Pennant&rsquo;s notice so late as during that observant traveller&rsquo;s tour\r\n      in 1769. Being perhaps the latest news from the invisible commonwealth, we\r\n      give the tourist&rsquo;s own words.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;A poor visionary who had been working in his cabbage-garden (in\r\n      Breadalbane) imagined that he was raised suddenly up into the air, and\r\n      conveyed over a wall into an adjacent corn-field; that he found himself\r\n      surrounded by a crowd of men and women, many of whom he knew to have been\r\n      dead for some years, and who appeared to him skimming over the tops of the\r\n      unbending corn, and mingling together like bees going to hive; that they\r\n      spoke an unknown language, and with a hollow sound; that they very roughly\r\n      pushed him to and fro, but on his uttering the name of God all vanished,\r\n      but a female sprite, who, seizing him by the shoulder, obliged him to\r\n      promise an assignation at that very hour that day seven-night; that he\r\n      then found his hair was all tied in double knots (well known by the name\r\n      of elf-locks), and that he had almost lost his speech; that he kept his\r\n      word with the spectre, whom he soon saw floating through the air towards\r\n      him; that he spoke to her, but she told him she was at that time in too\r\n      much haste to attend to him, but bid him go away and no harm should befall\r\n      him, and so the affair rested when I left the country. But it is\r\n      incredible the mischief these <i>gri somnia</i> did in the neighbourhood.\r\n      The friends and neighbours of the deceased, whom the old dreamer had\r\n      named, were in the utmost anxiety at finding them in such bad company in\r\n      the other world; the almost extinct belief of the old idle tales began to\r\n      gain ground, and the good minister will have many a weary discourse and\r\n      exhortation before he can eradicate the absurd ideas this idle story has\r\n      revived."<a href="#linknote-38" name="linknoteref-38" id="linknoteref-38"><small>38</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-38" id="linknote-38"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      38 (<a href="#linknoteref-38">return</a>)<br /> [ Pennant&rsquo;s &ldquo;Tour in\r\n      Scotland,&rdquo; vol. i. p. 110.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It is scarcely necessary to add that this comparatively recent tale is\r\n      just the counterpart of the story of Bessie Dunlop, Alison Pearson, and of\r\n      the Irish butler who was so nearly carried off, all of whom found in\r\n      Elfland some friend, formerly of middle earth, who attached themselves to\r\n      the child of humanity, and who endeavoured to protect a fellow-mortal\r\n      against their less philanthropic companions.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      These instances may tend to show how the fairy superstition, which, in its\r\n      general sense of worshipping the <i>Dii Campestres</i>, was much the older\r\n      of the two, came to bear upon and have connexion with that horrid belief\r\n      in witchcraft which cost so many innocent persons and crazy impostors\r\n      their lives for the supposed commission of impossible crimes. In the next\r\n      chapter I propose to trace how the general disbelief in the fairy creed\r\n      began to take place, and gradually brought into discredit the supposed\r\n      feats of witchcraft, which afforded pretext for such cruel practical\r\n      consequences.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="link2H_4_0007" id="link2H_4_0007"> </a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <div style="height: 4em;">\r\n      <br /><br /><br /><br />\r\n    </div>\r\n    <h2>\r\n      LETTER VI.\r\n    </h2>\r\n<pre xml:space="preserve">\r\n    Immediate Effect of Christianity on Articles of Popular\r\n    Superstition&mdash;Chaucer&rsquo;s Account of the Roman Catholic Priests\r\n    banishing the Fairies&mdash;Bishop Corbett imputes the same Effect to the\r\n    Reformation&mdash;His Verses on that Subject&mdash;His Iter\r\n    Septentrionale&mdash;Robin Goodfellow and other Superstitions mentioned\r\n    by Reginald Scot&mdash;Character of the English Fairies&mdash;The Tradition\r\n    had become obsolete in that Author&rsquo;s Time&mdash;That of Witches remained\r\n    in vigour&mdash;But impugned by various Authors after the Reformation, as\r\n    Wierus, Naudus, Scot, and others&mdash;Demonology defended by Bodinus,\r\n    Remigius, &amp;c.&mdash;Their mutual Abuse of each other&mdash;Imperfection of\r\n    Physical Science at this Period, and the Predominance of Mysticism\r\n    in that Department.\r\n</pre>\r\n    <p class="pfirst">\r\n      <span class="dropcap" style="font-size: 4.00em">A</span>lthough the\r\n      influence of the Christian religion was not introduced to the nations of\r\n      Europe with such radiance as to dispel at once those clouds of\r\n      superstition which continued to obscure the understanding of hasty and\r\n      ill-instructed converts, there can be no doubt that its immediate\r\n      operation went to modify the erroneous and extravagant articles of\r\n      credulity which lingered behind the old pagan faith, and which gave way\r\n      before it, in proportion as its light became more pure and refined from\r\n      the devices of men.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The poet Chaucer, indeed, pays the Church of Rome, with its monks and\r\n      preaching friars, the compliment of having, at an early period, expelled\r\n      from the land all spirits of an inferior and less holy character. The\r\n      verses are curious as well as picturesque, and may go some length to\r\n      establish the existence of doubts concerning the general belief in fairies\r\n      among the well-instructed in the time of Edward III.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The fairies of whom the bard of Woodstock talks are, it will be observed,\r\n      the ancient Celtic breed, and he seems to refer for the authorities of his\r\n      tale to Bretagne, or Armorica, a genuine Celtic colony:&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;In old time of the King Artour, Of which that Bretons speken great\r\n      honour, All was this land fulfilled of faerie; The Elf queen, with her\r\n      joly company, Danced full oft in many a grene mead. This was the old\r\n      opinion, as I rede&mdash; I speake of many hundred years ago, But now can\r\n      no man see no elves mo. For now the great charity and prayers Of\r\n      limitours,<a href="#linknote-39" name="linknoteref-39" id="linknoteref-39"><small>39</small></a>\r\n      and other holy freres, That searchen every land and every stream, As thick\r\n      as motes in the sunne-beam, Blessing halls, chambers, kitchenes, and\r\n      boures, Cities and burghes, castles high and towers, Thropes and barnes,\r\n      sheep-pens and dairies, This maketh that there ben no fairies. For there\r\n      as wont to walken was an elf, There walketh now the limitour himself, In\r\n      under nichtes and in morwenings, And saith his mattins and his holy\r\n      things, As he goeth in his limitation. Women may now go safely up and\r\n      doun; In every bush, and under every tree, There is no other incubus than\r\n      he, And he ne will don them no dishonour."<a href="#linknote-40"\r\n       name="linknoteref-40" id="linknoteref-40"><small>40</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-39" id="linknote-39"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      39 (<a href="#linknoteref-39">return</a>)<br /> [ Friars limited to beg\r\n      within a certain district.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-40" id="linknote-40"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      40 (<a href="#linknoteref-40">return</a>)<br /> [ &ldquo;Wife of Bath&rsquo;s Tale.&rdquo;]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      When we see the opinion which Chaucer has expressed of the regular clergy\r\n      of his time, in some of his other tales, we are tempted to suspect some\r\n      mixture of irony in the compliment which ascribes the exile of the\r\n      fairies, with whih the land was &ldquo;fulfilled&rdquo; in King Arthur&rsquo;s time, to the\r\n      warmth and zeal of the devotion of the limitary friars. Individual\r\n      instances of scepticism there might exist among scholars, but a more\r\n      modern poet, with a vein of humour not unworthy of Geoffrey himself, has\r\n      with greater probability delayed the final banishment of the fairies from\r\n      England, that is, from popular faith, till the reign of Queen Elizabeth,\r\n      and has represented their expulsion as a consequence of the change of\r\n      religion. Two or three verses of this lively satire may be very well worth\r\n      the reader&rsquo;s notice, who must, at the same time, be informed that the\r\n      author, Dr. Corbett, was nothing less than the Bishop of Oxford and\r\n      Norwich in the beginning of the seventeenth century. The poem is named &ldquo;A\r\n      proper new Ballad, entitled the Fairies&rsquo; Farewell, to be sung or whistled\r\n      to the tune of the Meadow Brow by the learned; by the unlearned to the\r\n      tune of Fortune:&rdquo;&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n<pre xml:space="preserve">\r\n     &ldquo;Farewell, rewards and fairies,\r\n       Good housewives now may say,\r\n     For now foul sluts in dairies\r\n       Do fare as well as they;\r\n     And though they sweep their hearths no less\r\n       Than maids were wont to do,\r\n     Yet who of late for cleanliness\r\n       Finds sixpence in her shoe?\r\n\r\n     &ldquo;Lament, lament, old abbies,\r\n       The fairies&rsquo; lost command;\r\n     They did but change priests&rsquo; babies,\r\n       But some have changed your land;\r\n     And all your children sprung from hence\r\n       Are now grown Puritans,\r\n     Who live as changelings ever since\r\n       For love of your domains.\r\n\r\n     &ldquo;At morning and at evening both,\r\n       You merry were and glad,\r\n     So little care of sleep and sloth\r\n       Those pretty ladies had.\r\n     When Tom came home from labour.\r\n       Or Cis to milking rose,\r\n     Then merrily, merrily went their tabor,\r\n       And merrily went their toes.\r\n\r\n     &ldquo;Witness those rings and roundelays\r\n       Of theirs, which yet remain,\r\n     Were footed, in Queen Mary&rsquo;s days,\r\n       On many a grassy plain;\r\n     But since of late Elizabeth,\r\n       And later James came in,\r\n     They never danced on any heath\r\n       As when the time hath bin.\r\n\r\n     &ldquo;By which we note, the fairies\r\n       Were of the old profession,\r\n     Their songs were Ave Maries,\r\n       Their dances were procession.\r\n     But now, alas! they all are dead,\r\n       Or gone beyond the seas;\r\n     Or farther for religion fled,\r\n       Or else they take their ease.&rdquo;\r\n </pre>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The remaining part of the poem is dedicated to the praise and glory of old\r\n      William Chourne of Staffordshire, who remained a true and stanch evidence\r\n      in behalf of the departed elves, and kept, much it would seem to the\r\n      amusement of the witty bishop, an inexhaustible record of their pranks and\r\n      feats, whence the concluding verse&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n<pre xml:space="preserve">\r\n&ldquo;To William all give audience,\r\n  And pray ye for his noddle,\r\nFor all the fairies&rsquo; evidence\r\n  Were lost if that were addle."<a href="#linknote-41" name="linknoteref-41"\r\n       id="linknoteref-41">41</a>\r\n</pre>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-41" id="linknote-41"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      41 (<a href="#linknoteref-41">return</a>)<br /> [ Corbett&rsquo;s Poems, edited\r\n      by Octavuis Gilchrist, p. 213.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      This William Chourne appears to have attended Dr. Corbett&rsquo;s party on the\r\n      <i>iter septentrionale</i>, &ldquo;two of which were, and two desired to be,\r\n      doctors;&rdquo; but whether William was guide, friend, or domestic seems\r\n      uncertain. The travellers lose themselves in the mazes of Chorley Forest\r\n      on their way to Bosworth, and their route becomes so confused that they\r\n      return on their steps and labour&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n<pre xml:space="preserve">\r\n     &ldquo;As in a conjuror&rsquo;s circle&mdash;William found\r\n     A mean for our deliverance,&mdash;&lsquo;Turn your cloaks,&rsquo;\r\n     Quoth he, &lsquo;for Puck is busy in these oaks;\r\n     If ever you at Bosworth would be found,\r\n     Then turn your cloaks, for this is fairy ground.&rsquo;\r\n     But ere this witchcraft was performed, we meet\r\n     A very man who had no cloven feet.\r\n     Though William, still of little faith, has doubt,\r\n     &lsquo;Tis Robin, or some sprite that walks about.\r\n     &lsquo;Strike him,&rsquo; quoth he, &lsquo;and it will turn to air&mdash;\r\n     Cross yourselves thrice and strike it.&rsquo;&mdash;&lsquo;Strike that dare,&rsquo;\r\n     Thought I, &lsquo;for sure this massy forester,\r\n     In strokes will prove the better conjuror.&rsquo;\r\n     But &lsquo;twas a gentle keeper, one that knew\r\n     Humanity and manners, where they grew,\r\n     And rode along so far, till he could say,\r\n     &lsquo;See, yonder Bosworth stands, and this your way.&rsquo;&rdquo;<a href="#linknote-42"\r\n       name="linknoteref-42" id="linknoteref-42">42</a>\r\n</pre>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-42" id="linknote-42"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      42 (<a href="#linknoteref-42">return</a>)<br /> [ Corbett&rsquo;s Poems, p. 191.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In this passage the bishop plainly shows the fairies maintained their\r\n      influence in William&rsquo;s imagination, since the courteous keeper was\r\n      mistaken by their associate champion for Puck or Robin Goodfellow. The\r\n      spells resorted to to get rid of his supposed delusions are alternatively\r\n      that of turning the cloak&mdash;(recommended in visions of the\r\n      second-sight or similar illusions as a means of obtaining a certainty\r\n      concerning the being which is before imperfectly seen<a href="#linknote-43"\r\n       name="linknoteref-43" id="linknoteref-43"><small>43</small></a>)&mdash;and\r\n      that of exorcising the spirit with a cudgel; which last, Corbett prudently\r\n      thinks, ought not to be resorted to unless under an absolute conviction\r\n      that the exorcist is the stronger party. Chaucer, therefore, could not be\r\n      serious in averring that the fairy superstitions were obsolete in his day,\r\n      since they were found current three centuries afterwards.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-43" id="linknote-43"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      43 (<a href="#linknoteref-43">return</a>)<br /> [ A common instance is that\r\n      of a person haunted with a resemblance whose face he cannot see. If he\r\n      turn his cloak or plaid, he will obtain the full sight which he desires,\r\n      and may probably find it to be his own fetch, or wraith, or\r\n      double-ganger.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It is not the less certain that, as knowledge and religion became more\r\n      widely and brightly displayed over any country, the superstitious fancies\r\n      of the people sunk gradually in esteem and influence; and in the time of\r\n      Queen Elizabeth the unceasing labour of many and popular preachers, who\r\n      declaimed against the &ldquo;splendid miracles&rdquo; of the Church of Rome, produced\r\n      also its natural effect upon the other stock of superstitions.\r\n      &ldquo;Certainly,&rdquo; said Reginald Scot, talking of times before his own, &ldquo;some\r\n      one knave in a white sheet hath cozened and abused many thousands,\r\n      specially when Robin Goodfellow kept such a coil in the country. In our\r\n      childhood our mothers&rsquo; maids have so terrified us with an ugly devil\r\n      having horns on his head, fire in his mouth, and a tail at his breech;\r\n      eyes like a basin, fangs like a dog, claws like a bear, a skin like a\r\n      negro, and a voice roaring like a lion, whereby we start and are afraid\r\n      when we hear one cry, Boh! and they have so frayd us with bull-beggars,\r\n      spirits, witches, urchins, elves, hags, fairies, satyrs, Pans, faunes,\r\n      sylvans, Kitt-with-the-candlestick, tritons, centaurs, dwarfs, giants,\r\n      imps, calcars, conjurers, nymphs, changelings, incubus, Robin Goodfellow,\r\n      the spoorn, the man-in-the-oak, the hellwain, the fire-drake, the puckle,\r\n      Tom Thumb, Hobgoblin, Tom Tumbler, Boneless, and such other bugbears, that\r\n      we are afraid of our own shadows, insomuch that some never fear the devil\r\n      but on a dark night; and then a polled sheep is a perilous beast, and many\r\n      times is taken for our father&rsquo;s soul, specially in a churchyard, where a\r\n      right hardy man heretofore durst not to have passed by night but his hair\r\n      would stand upright. Well, thanks be to God, this wretched and cowardly\r\n      infidelity, since the preaching of the Gospel, is in part forgotten, and\r\n      doubtless the rest of these illusions will in a short time, by God&rsquo;s\r\n      grace, be detected and vanish away."<a href="#linknote-44"\r\n       name="linknoteref-44" id="linknoteref-44"><small>44</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-44" id="linknote-44"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      44 (<a href="#linknoteref-44">return</a>)<br /> [ Reginald Scot&rsquo;s\r\n      &ldquo;Discovery of Witchcraft,&rdquo; book vii. chap. 15.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It would require a better demonologist than I am to explain the various\r\n      obsolete superstitions which Reginald Scot has introduced as articles of\r\n      the old English faith, into the preceding passage. I might indeed say the\r\n      Phuca is a Celtic superstition, from which the word Pook or Puckle was\r\n      doubtless derived; and I might conjecture that the man-in-the-oak was the\r\n      same with the Erl-Knig of the Germans; and that the hellwain were a kind\r\n      of wandering spirits, the descendants of a champion named Hellequin, who\r\n      are introduced into the romance of Richard sans Peur. But most antiquaries\r\n      will be at fault concerning the spoorn, Kitt-with-the-candlestick,\r\n      Boneless, and some others. The catalogue, however, serves to show what\r\n      progress the English have made in two centuries, in forgetting the very\r\n      names of objects which had been the sources of terror to their ancestors\r\n      of the Elizabethan age.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Before leaving the subject of fairy superstition in England we may remark\r\n      that it was of a more playful and gentle, less wild and necromantic\r\n      character, than that received among the sister people. The amusements of\r\n      the southern fairies were light and sportive; their resentments were\r\n      satisfied with pinching or scratching the objects of their displeasure;\r\n      their peculiar sense of cleanliness rewarded the housewives with the\r\n      silver token in the shoe; their nicety was extreme concerning any\r\n      coarseness or negligence which could offend their delicacy; and I cannot\r\n      discern, except, perhaps, from the insinuations of some scrupulous\r\n      divines, that they were vassals to or in close alliance with the\r\n      infernals, as there is too much reason to believe was the case with their\r\n      North British sisterhood.<a href="#linknote-45" name="linknoteref-45"\r\n       id="linknoteref-45"><small>45</small></a> The common nursery story cannot\r\n      be forgotten, how, shortly after the death of what is called a nice tidy\r\n      housewife, the Elfin band was shocked to see that a person of different\r\n      character, with whom the widower had filled his deserted arms, instead of\r\n      the nicely arranged little loaf of the whitest bread, and a basin of sweet\r\n      cream, duly placed for their refreshment by the deceased, had substituted\r\n      a brown loaf and a cobb of herrings. Incensed at such a coarse regale, the\r\n      elves dragged the peccant housewife out of bed, and pulled her down the\r\n      wooden stairs by the heels, repeating, at the same time, in scorn of her\r\n      churlish hospitality&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n<pre xml:space="preserve">\r\n&ldquo;Brown bread and herring cobb!\r\n Thy fat sides shall have many a bob!&rdquo;\r\n </pre>\r\n    <p>\r\n      But beyond such playful malice they had no desire to extend their\r\n      resentment.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-45" id="linknote-45"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      45 (<a href="#linknoteref-45">return</a>)<br /> [ Dr. Jackson, in his\r\n      &ldquo;Treatise on Unbelief,&rdquo; opines for the severe opinion. &ldquo;Thus are the\r\n      Fayries, from difference of events ascribed to them, divided into good and\r\n      bad, when as it is but one and the same malignant fiend that meddles in\r\n      both; seeking sometimes to be feared, otherwhiles to be loued as God, for\r\n      the bodily harmes or good turnes supposed to be in his power.&rdquo;&mdash;Jackson\r\n      on Unbelief, p. 178, edit. 1625.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The constant attendant upon the English Fairy court was the celebrated\r\n      Puck, or Robin Goodfellow, who to the elves acted in some measure as the\r\n      jester or clown of the company&mdash;(a character then to be found in the\r\n      establishment of every person of quality)&mdash;or to use a more modern\r\n      comparison, resembled the Pierrot of the pantomime. His jests were of the\r\n      most simple and at the same time the broadest comic character&mdash;to\r\n      mislead a clown on his path homeward, to disguise himself like a stool, in\r\n      order to induce an old gossip to commit the egregious mistake of sitting\r\n      down on the floor when she expected to repose on a chair, were his special\r\n      enjoyments. If he condescended to do some work for the sleeping family, in\r\n      which he had some resemblance to the Scottish household spirit called a\r\n      Brownie, the selfish Puck was far from practising this labour on the\r\n      disinterested principle of the northern goblin, who, if raiment or food\r\n      was left in his way and for his use, departed from the family in\r\n      displeasure. Robin Goodfellow, on the contrary, must have both his food\r\n      and his rest, as Milton informs us, amid his other notices of country\r\n      superstitions, in the poem of L&rsquo;Allegro. And it is to be noticed that he\r\n      represents these tales of the fairies, told round the cottage hearth, as\r\n      of a cheerful rather than a serious cast; which illustrates what I have\r\n      said concerning the milder character of the southern superstitions, as\r\n      compared with those of the same class in Scotland&mdash;the stories of\r\n      which are for the most part of a frightful and not seldom of a disgusting\r\n      quality.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Poor Robin, however, between whom and King Oberon Shakespeare contrives to\r\n      keep a degree of distinct subordination, which for a moment deceives us by\r\n      its appearance of reality, notwithstanding his turn for wit and humour,\r\n      had been obscured by oblivion even in the days of Queen Bess. We have\r\n      already seen, in a passage quoted from Reginald Scot, that the belief was\r\n      fallen into abeyance; that which follows from the same author affirms more\r\n      positively that Robin&rsquo;s date was over:&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;Know ye this, by the way, that heretofore Robin Goodfellow and Hobgoblin\r\n      were as terrible, and also as credible, to the people as hags and witches\r\n      be now; and in time to come a witch will be as much derided and condemned,\r\n      and as clearly perceived, as the illusion and knavery of Robin Goodfellow,\r\n      upon whom there have gone as many and as credible tales as witchcraft,\r\n      saving that it hath not pleased the translators of the Bible to call\r\n      spirits by the name of Robin Goodfellow, as they have diviners,\r\n      soothsayers, poisoners, and cozeners by the name of witches."<a\r\n      href="#linknote-46" name="linknoteref-46" id="linknoteref-46"><small>46</small></a>\r\n      In the same tone Reginald Scot addresses the reader in the preface:&mdash;&ldquo;To\r\n      make a solemn suit to you that are partial readers to set aside\r\n      partiality, to take in good part my writings, and with indifferent eyes to\r\n      look upon my book, were labour lost and time ill-employed; for I should no\r\n      more prevail herein than if, a hundred years since, I should have\r\n      entreated your predecessors to believe that Robin Goodfellow, that great\r\n      and ancient bull-beggar, had been but a cozening merchant, and no devil\r\n      indeed. But Robin Goodfellow ceaseth now to be much feared, and Popery is\r\n      sufficiently discovered; nevertheless, witches&rsquo; charms and conjurers&rsquo;\r\n      cozenage are yet effectual.&rdquo; This passage seems clearly to prove that the\r\n      belief in Robin Goodfellow and his fairy companions was now out of date;\r\n      while that as to witchcraft, as was afterwards but too well shown, kept\r\n      its ground against argument and controversy, and survived &ldquo;to shed more\r\n      blood.&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-46" id="linknote-46"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      46 (<a href="#linknoteref-46">return</a>)<br /> [ Reginald Scot&rsquo;s\r\n      &ldquo;Discovery of Witchcraft,&rdquo; book vii. chap, ii.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      We are then to take leave of this fascinating article of the popular\r\n      creed, having in it so much of interest to the imagination that we almost\r\n      envy the credulity of those who, in the gentle moonlight of a summer night\r\n      in England, amid the tangled glades of a deep forest, or the turfy swell\r\n      of her romantic commons, could fancy they saw the fairies tracing their\r\n      sportive ring. But it is in vain to regret illusions which, however\r\n      engaging, must of necessity yield their place before the increase of\r\n      knowledge, like shadows at the advance of morn. These superstitions have\r\n      already survived their best and most useful purpose, having been embalmed\r\n      in the poetry of Milton and of Shakespeare, as well as writers only\r\n      inferior to these great names. Of Spenser we must say nothing, because in\r\n      his &ldquo;Faery Queen&rdquo; the title is the only circumstance which connects his\r\n      splendid allegory with the popular superstition, and, as he uses it, means\r\n      nothing more than an Utopia or nameless country.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      With the fairy popular creed fell, doubtless, many subordinate articles of\r\n      credulity in England, but the belief in witches kept its ground. It was\r\n      rooted in the minds of the common people, as well by the easy solution it\r\n      afforded of much which they found otherwise hard to explain, as in\r\n      reverence to the Holy Scriptures, in which the word <i>witch,</i> being\r\n      used in several places, conveyed to those who did not trouble themselves\r\n      about the nicety of the translation from the Eastern tongues, the\r\n      inference that the same species of witches were meant as those against\r\n      whom modern legislation had, in most European nations, directed the\r\n      punishment of death. These two circumstances furnished the numerous\r\n      believers in witchcraft with arguments in divinity and law which they\r\n      conceived irrefragable. They might say to the theologist, Will you not\r\n      believe in witches? the Scriptures aver their existence;&mdash;to the\r\n      jurisconsult, Will you dispute the existence of a crime against which our\r\n      own statute-book, and the code of almost all civilized countries, have\r\n      attested, by laws upon which hundreds and thousands have been convicted,\r\n      many or even most of whom have, by their judicial confessions,\r\n      acknowledged their guilt and the justice of their punishment? It is a\r\n      strange scepticism, they might add, which rejects the evidence of\r\n      Scripture, of human legislature, and of the accused persons themselves.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Notwithstanding these specious reasons, the sixteenth and seventeenth\r\n      centuries were periods when the revival of learning, the invention of\r\n      printing, the fearless investigations of the Reformers into subjects\r\n      thought formerly too sacred for consideration of any save the clergy, had\r\n      introduced a system of doubt, enquiry, disregard of authority, when\r\n      unsupported by argument, and unhesitating exercise of the private\r\n      judgment, on subjects which had occupied the bulls of popes and decrees of\r\n      councils. In short, the spirit of the age was little disposed to spare\r\n      error, however venerable, or countenance imposture, however sanctioned by\r\n      length of time and universal acquiescence. Learned writers arose in\r\n      different countries to challenge the very existence of this imaginary\r\n      crime, to rescue the reputation of the great men whose knowledge, superior\r\n      to that of their age, had caused them to be suspected of magic, and to put\r\n      a stop to the horrid superstition whose victims were the aged, ignorant,\r\n      and defenceless, and which could only be compared to that which sent\r\n      victims of old through the fire to Moloch.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The courageous interposition of those philosophers who opposed science and\r\n      experience to the prejudices of superstition and ignorance, and in doing\r\n      so incurred much misrepresentation, and perhaps no little ill-will, in the\r\n      cause of truth and humanity, claim for them some distinction in a work on\r\n      Demonology. The pursuers of exact science to its coy retreats, were sure\r\n      to be the first to discover that the most remarkable phenomena in Nature\r\n      are regulated by certain fixed laws, and cannot rationally be referred to\r\n      supernatural agency, the sufficing cause to which superstition attributes\r\n      all that is beyond her own narrow power of explanation. Each advance in\r\n      natural knowledge teaches us that it is the pleasure of the Creator to\r\n      govern the world by the laws which he has imposed, and which are not in\r\n      our times interrupted or suspended.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The learned Wier, or Wierus, was a man of great research in physical\r\n      science, and studied under the celebrated Cornelius Agrippa, against whom\r\n      the charge of sorcery was repeatedly alleged by Paulus Jovius and other\r\n      authors, while he suffered, on the other hand, from the persecution of the\r\n      inquisitors of the Church, whose accusation against this celebrated man\r\n      was, that he denied the existence of spirits, a charge very inconsistent\r\n      with that of sorcery, which consists in corresponding with them. Wierus,\r\n      after taking his degree as a doctor of medicine, became physician to the\r\n      Duke of Cleves, at whose court he practised for thirty years with the\r\n      highest reputation. This learned man, disregarding the scandal which, by\r\n      so doing, he was likely to bring upon himself, was one of the first who\r\n      attacked the vulgar belief, and boldly assailed, both by serious arguments\r\n      and by ridicule, the vulgar credulity on the subject of wizards and\r\n      witches.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Gabriel Naud, or Naudus, as he termed himself, was a perfect scholar and\r\n      man of letters, busied during his whole life with assembling books\r\n      together, and enjoying the office of librarian to several persons of high\r\n      rank, amongst others, to Queen Christina of Sweden. He was, besides, a\r\n      beneficed clergyman, leading a most unblemished life, and so temperate as\r\n      never to taste any liquor stronger than water; yet did he not escape the\r\n      scandal which is usually flung by their prejudiced contemporaries upon\r\n      those disputants whom it is found more easy to defame than to answer. He\r\n      wrote an interesting work, entitled &ldquo;Apologie pour les Grands Homines\r\n      Accuss de Magie;&rdquo; and as he exhibited a good deal of vivacity of talent,\r\n      and an earnestness in pleading his cause, which did not always spare some\r\n      of the superstitions of Rome herself, he was charged by his contemporaries\r\n      as guilty of heresy and scepticism, when justice could only accuse him of\r\n      an incautious eagerness to make good his argument.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Among persons who, upon this subject, purged their eyes with rue and\r\n      euphrasie, besides the Rev. Dr. Harsnet and many others (who wrote rather\r\n      on special cases of Demonology than on the general question), Reginald\r\n      Scot ought to be distinguished. Webster assures us that he was a &ldquo;person\r\n      of competent learning, pious, and of a good family.&rdquo; He seems to have been\r\n      a zealous Protestant, and much of his book, as well as that of Harsnet, is\r\n      designed to throw upon the Papists in particular those tricks in which, by\r\n      confederacy and imposture, the popular ideas concerning witchcraft,\r\n      possession, and other supernatural fancies, were maintained and kept in\r\n      exercise; but he also writes on the general question with some force and\r\n      talent, considering that his subject is incapable of being reduced into a\r\n      regular form, and is of a nature particularly seductive to an excursive\r\n      talent. He appears to have studied legerdemain for the purpose of showing\r\n      how much that is apparently unaccountable can nevertheless be performed\r\n      without the intervention of supernatural assistance, even when it is\r\n      impossible to persuade the vulgar that the devil has not been consulted on\r\n      the occasion. Scot also had intercourse with some of the celebrated\r\n      fortune-tellers, or Philomaths, of the time; one of whom he brings forward\r\n      to declare the vanity of the science which he himself had once professed.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      To defend the popular belief of witchcraft there arose a number of\r\n      advocates, of whom Bodin and some others neither wanted knowledge nor\r\n      powers of reasoning. They pressed the incredulous party with the charge\r\n      that they denied the existence of a crime against which the law had\r\n      denounced a capital punishment. As that law was understood to emanate from\r\n      James himself, who was reigning monarch during the hottest part of the\r\n      controversy, the English authors who defended the opposite side were\r\n      obliged to entrench themselves under an evasion, to avoid maintaining an\r\n      argument unpalatable to a degree to those in power, and which might\r\n      perchance have proved unsafe to those who used it. With a certain degree\r\n      of sophistry they answered that they did not doubt the possibility of\r\n      witches, but only demurred to what is their nature, and how they came to\r\n      be such&mdash;according to the scholastic jargon, that the question in\r\n      respect to witches was not <i>de existentia</i>, but only <i>de modo\r\n      existendi</i>.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      By resorting to so subtle an argument those who impugned the popular\r\n      belief were obliged, with some inconsistency, to grant that witchcraft had\r\n      existed, and might exist, only insisting that it was a species of\r\n      witchcraft consisting of they knew not what, but certainly of something\r\n      different from that which legislators, judges, and juries had hitherto\r\n      considered the statute as designed to repress.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In the meantime (the rather that the debate was on a subject particularly\r\n      difficult of comprehension) the debating parties grew warm, and began to\r\n      call names. Bodin, a lively Frenchman of an irritable habit, explained the\r\n      zeal of Wierus to protect the tribe of sorcerers from punishment, by\r\n      stating that he himself was a conjurer and the scholar of Cornelius\r\n      Agrippa, and might therefore well desire to save the lives of those\r\n      accused of the same league with Satan. Hence they threw on their\r\n      antagonists the offensive names of witch-patrons and witch-advocates, as\r\n      if it were impossible for any to hold the opinion of Naudus, Wierus,\r\n      Scot, &amp;c., without patronizing the devil and the witches against their\r\n      brethren of mortality. Assailed by such heavy charges, the philosophers\r\n      themselves lost patience, and retorted abuse in their turn, calling Bodin,\r\n      Delrio, and others who used their arguments, witch-advocates, and the\r\n      like, as the affirming and defending the existence of the crime seemed to\r\n      increase the number of witches, and assuredly augmented the list of\r\n      executions. But for a certain time the preponderance of the argument lay\r\n      on the side of the Demonologists, and we may briefly observe the causes\r\n      which gave their opinions, for a period, greater influence than their\r\n      opponents on the public mind.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It is first to be observed that Wierus, for what reason cannot well be\r\n      conjectured, except to show the extent of his cabalistical knowledge, had\r\n      introduced into his work against witchcraft the whole Stenographia of\r\n      Trithemius, which he had copied from the original in the library of\r\n      Cornelius Agrippa; and which, suspicious from the place where he found it,\r\n      and from the long catalogue of fiends which it contained, with the charms\r\n      for raising and for binding them to the service of mortals, was considered\r\n      by Bodin as containing proof that Wierus himself was a sorcerer; not one\r\n      of the wisest, certainly, since he thus unnecessarily placed at the\r\n      disposal of any who might buy the book the whole secrets which formed his\r\n      stock-in-trade.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Secondly, we may notice that, from the state of physical science at the\r\n      period when Van Helmont, Paracelsus, and others began to penetrate into\r\n      its recesses, it was an unknown, obscure, and ill-defined region, and did\r\n      not permit those who laboured in it to give that precise and accurate\r\n      account of their discoveries which the progress of reasoning\r\n      experimentally and from analysis has enabled the late discoverers to do\r\n      with success. Natural magic&mdash;a phrase used to express those phenomena\r\n      which could be produced by a knowledge of the properties of matter&mdash;had\r\n      so much in it that was apparently uncombined and uncertain, that the art\r\n      of chemistry was accounted mystical, and an opinion prevailed that the\r\n      results now known to be the consequence of laws of matter, could not be\r\n      traced through their various combinations even by those who knew the\r\n      effects themselves. Physical science, in a word, was cumbered by a number\r\n      of fanciful and incorrect opinions, chiefly of a mystical character. If,\r\n      for instance, it was observed that a flag and a fern never grew near each\r\n      other, the circumstance was imputed to some antipathy between these\r\n      vegetables; nor was it for some time resolved by the natural rule, that\r\n      the flag has its nourishment in marshy ground, whereas the fern loves a\r\n      deep dryish soil. The attributes of the divining-rod were fully credited;\r\n      the discovery of the philosopher&rsquo;s stone was daily hoped for; and\r\n      electricity, magnetism, and other remarkable and misconceived phenomena\r\n      were appealed to as proof of the reasonableness of their expectations.\r\n      Until such phenomena were traced to their sources, imaginary and often\r\n      mystical causes were assigned to them, for the same reason that, in the\r\n      wilds of a partially discovered country, according to the satirist,\r\n    </p>\r\n<pre xml:space="preserve">\r\n&ldquo;Geographers on pathless downs\r\n Place elephants for want of towns.&rdquo;\r\n </pre>\r\n    <p>\r\n      This substitution of mystical fancies for experimental reasoning gave, in\r\n      the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, a doubtful and twilight\r\n      appearance to the various branches of physical philosophy. The learned and\r\n      sensible Dr. Webster, for instance, writing in detection of supposed\r\n      witchcraft, assumes, as a string of undeniable facts, opinions which our\r\n      more experienced age would reject as frivolous fancies; &ldquo;for example, the\r\n      effects of healing by the weapon-salve, the sympathetic powder, the curing\r\n      of various diseases by apprehensions, amulets, or by transplantation.&rdquo; All\r\n      of which undoubted wonders he accuses the age of desiring to throw on the\r\n      devil&rsquo;s back&mdash;an unnecessary load certainly, since such things do not\r\n      exist, and it is therefore in vain to seek to account for them. It\r\n      followed that, while the opposers of the ordinary theory might have struck\r\n      the deepest blows at the witch hypothesis by an appeal to common sense,\r\n      they were themselves hampered by articles of philosophical belief which\r\n      they must have been sensible contained nearly as deep draughts upon human\r\n      credulity as were made by the Demonologists, against whose doctrine they\r\n      protested. This error had a doubly bad effect, both as degrading the\r\n      immediate department in which it occurred, and as affording a protection\r\n      for falsehood in other branches of science. The champions who, in their\r\n      own province, were obliged by the imperfect knowledge of the times to\r\n      admit much that was mystical and inexplicable&mdash;those who opined, with\r\n      Bacon, that warts could be cured by sympathy&mdash;who thought, with\r\n      Napier, that hidden treasures could be discovered by the mathematics&mdash;who\r\n      salved the weapon instead of the wound, and detected murders as well as\r\n      springs of water by the divining-rod, could not consistently use, to\r\n      confute the believers in witches, an argument turning on the impossible or\r\n      the incredible.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Such were the obstacles arising from the vanity of philosophers and the\r\n      imperfection of their science, which suspended the strength of their\r\n      appeal to reason and common sense against the condemning of wretches to a\r\n      cruel death on account of crimes which the nature of things rendered in\r\n      modern times totally impossible. We cannot doubt that they suffered\r\n      considerably in the contest, which was carried on with much anger and\r\n      malevolence; but the good seed which they had sown remained uncorrupted in\r\n      the soil, to bear fruit so soon as the circumstances should be altered\r\n      which at first impeded its growth. In the next letter I shall take a view\r\n      of the causes which helped to remove these impediments, in addition, it\r\n      must always be remembered, to the general increase of knowledge and\r\n      improvement of experimental philosophy.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="link2H_4_0008" id="link2H_4_0008"> </a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <div style="height: 4em;">\r\n      <br /><br /><br /><br />\r\n    </div>\r\n    <h2>\r\n      LETTER VII.\r\n    </h2>\r\n<pre xml:space="preserve">\r\n       Penal Laws unpopular when rigidly exercised&mdash;Prosecution of Witches\r\n    placed in the hand of Special Commissioners, <i>ad\r\n    inquirendum</i>&mdash;Prosecution for Witchcraft not frequent in the Elder\r\n    Period of the Roman Empire&mdash;Nor in the Middle Ages&mdash;Some Cases took\r\n    place, however&mdash;The Maid of Orleans&mdash;The Duchess of\r\n    Gloucester&mdash;Richard the Third&rsquo;s Charge against the Relations of the\r\n    Queen Dowager&mdash;But Prosecutions against Sorcerers became more common\r\n    in the end of the Fourteenth Century&mdash;Usually united with the Charge\r\n    of Heresy&mdash;Monstrelet&rsquo;s Account of the Persecution against the\r\n    Waldenses, under pretext of Witchcraft&mdash;Florimond&rsquo;s Testimony\r\n    concerning the Increase of Witches in his own Time&mdash;Bull of Pope\r\n    Innocent VIII.&mdash;Various Prosecutions in Foreign Countries under this\r\n    severe Law&mdash;Prosecutions in Labourt by the Inquisitor De Lancre and\r\n    his Colleague&mdash;Lycanthropy&mdash;Witches in Spain&mdash;In Sweden&mdash;and\r\n    particularly those Apprehended at Mohra.\r\n</pre>\r\n    <p class="pfirst">\r\n      <span class="dropcap" style="font-size: 4.00em">P</span>enal laws, like\r\n      those of the Middle Ages, denounced against witchcraft, may be at first\r\n      hailed with unanimous acquiescence and approbation, but are uniformly\r\n      found to disgust and offend at least the more sensible part of the public\r\n      when the punishments become frequent and are relentlessly inflicted. Those\r\n      against treason are no exception. Each reflecting government will do well\r\n      to shorten that melancholy reign of terror which perhaps must necessarily\r\n      follow on the discovery of a plot or the defeat of an insurrection. They\r\n      ought not, either in humanity or policy, to wait till the voice of the\r\n      nation calls to them, as Mecnas to Augustus, &ldquo;<i>Surge tandem carnifex</i>!&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It is accordingly remarkable, in different countries, how often at some\r\n      particular period of their history there occurred an epidemic of terror of\r\n      witches, which, as fear is always cruel and credulous, glutted the public\r\n      with seas of innocent blood; and how uniformly men loathed the gore after\r\n      having swallowed it, and by a reaction natural to the human mind desired,\r\n      in prudence, to take away or restrict those laws which had been the source\r\n      of carnage, in order that their posterity might neither have the will nor\r\n      the means to enter into similar excesses.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      A short review of foreign countries, before we come to notice the British\r\n      Islands and their Colonies, will prove the truth of this statement. In\r\n      Catholic countries on the Continent, the various kingdoms adopted readily\r\n      that part of the civil law, already mentioned, which denounces sorcerers\r\n      and witches as rebels to God, and authors of sedition in the empire. But\r\n      being considered as obnoxious equally to the canon and civil law,\r\n      Commissions of Inquisition were especially empowered to weed out of the\r\n      land the witches and those who had intercourse with familiar spirits, or\r\n      in any other respect fell under the ban of the Church, as well as the\r\n      heretics who promulgated or adhered to false doctrine. Special warrants\r\n      were thus granted from time to time in behalf of such inquisitors,\r\n      authorizing them to visit those provinces of Germany, France, or Italy\r\n      where any report concerning witches or sorcery had alarmed the public\r\n      mind; and those Commissioners, proud of the trust reposed in them, thought\r\n      it becoming to use the utmost exertions on their part, that the subtlety\r\n      of the examinations, and the severity of the tortures they inflicted,\r\n      might wring the truth out of all suspected persons, until they rendered\r\n      the province in which they exercised their jurisdiction a desert from\r\n      which the inhabitants fled. It would be impossible to give credit to the\r\n      extent of this delusion, had not some of the inquisitors themselves been\r\n      reporters of their own judicial exploits: the same hand which subscribed\r\n      the sentence has recorded the execution.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In the earlier period of the Church of Rome witchcraft is frequently\r\n      alluded to, and a capital punishment assigned to those who were supposed\r\n      to have accomplished by sorcery the death of others, or to have attempted,\r\n      by false prophecies or otherwise, under pretext of consulting with the\r\n      spiritual world, to make innovation in the state. But no general\r\n      denunciation against witchcraft itself, as a league with the Enemy of Man,\r\n      or desertion of the Deity, and a crime <i>sui generis</i>, appears to have\r\n      been so acted upon, until the later period of the sixteenth century, when\r\n      the Papal system had attained its highest pitch of power and of\r\n      corruption. The influence of the Churchmen was in early times secure, and\r\n      they rather endeavoured, by the fabrication of false miracles, to prolong\r\n      the blind veneration of the people, than to vex others and weary\r\n      themselves by secret investigations into dubious and mystical trespasses,\r\n      in which probably the higher and better instructed members of the clerical\r\n      order put as little faith at that time as they do now. Did there remain a\r\n      mineral fountain, respected for the cures which it had wrought, a huge\r\n      oak-tree, or venerated mount, which beauty of situation had recommended to\r\n      traditional respect, the fathers of the Roman Church were in policy\r\n      reluctant to abandon such impressive spots, or to represent them as\r\n      exclusively the rendezvous of witches or of evil spirits. On the contrary,\r\n      by assigning the virtues of the spring or the beauty of the tree to the\r\n      guardianship of some saint, they acquired, as it were, for the defence of\r\n      their own doctrine, a frontier fortress which they wrested from the enemy,\r\n      and which it was at least needless to dismantle, if it could be\r\n      conveniently garrisoned and defended. Thus the Church secured possession\r\n      of many beautiful pieces of scenery, as Mr. Whitfield is said to have\r\n      grudged to the devil the monopoly of all the fine tunes.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It is true that this policy was not uniformly observed. The story of the\r\n      celebrated Jeanne d&rsquo;Arc, called the Maid of Orleans, preserves the memory\r\n      of such a custom, which was in that case turned to the prejudice of the\r\n      poor woman who observed it.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It is well known that this unfortunate female fell into the hands of the\r\n      English, after having, by her courage and enthusiasm manifested on many\r\n      important occasions, revived the drooping courage of the French, and\r\n      inspired them with the hope of once more freeing their country. The\r\n      English vulgar regarded her as a sorceress&mdash;the French as an inspired\r\n      heroine; while the wise on both sides considered her as neither the one\r\n      nor the other, but a tool used by the celebrated Dunois to play the part\r\n      which he assigned her. The Duke of Bedford, when the ill-starred Jeanne\r\n      fell into his hands, took away her life in order to stigmatize her memory\r\n      with sorcery and to destroy the reputation she had acquired among the\r\n      French. The mean recurrence to such a charge against such a person had no\r\n      more success than it deserved, although Jeanne was condemned both by the\r\n      Parliament of Bordeux and the University of Paris. Her indictment accused\r\n      her of having frequented an ancient oak-tree, and a fountain arising under\r\n      it, called the Fated or Fairy Oak of Bourlemont. Here she was stated to\r\n      have repaired during the hours of divine service, dancing, skipping, and\r\n      making gestures, around the tree and fountain, and hanging on the branches\r\n      chaplets and garlands of flowers, gathered for the purpose, reviving,\r\n      doubtless, the obsolete idolatry which in ancient times had been rendered\r\n      on the same spot to the <i>Genius Loci</i>. The charmed sword and blessed\r\n      banner, which she had represented as signs of her celestial mission, were\r\n      in this hostile charge against her described as enchanted implements,\r\n      designed by the fiends and fairies whom she worshipped to accomplish her\r\n      temporary success. The death of the innocent, high-minded, and perhaps\r\n      amiable enthusiast, was not, we are sorry to say, a sacrifice to a\r\n      superstitious fear of witchcraft, but a cruel instance of wicked policy\r\n      mingled with national jealousy and hatred.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      To the same cause, about the same period, we may impute the trial of the\r\n      Duchess of Gloucester, wife of the good Duke Humphrey, accused of\r\n      consulting witches concerning the mode of compassing the death of her\r\n      husband&rsquo;s nephew, Henry VI. The Duchess was condemned to do penance, and\r\n      thereafter banished to the Isle of Man, while several of her accomplices\r\n      died in prison or were executed.
