But in this instance also the alleged\r\n      witchcraft was only the ostensible cause of a procedure which had its real\r\n      source in the deep hatred between the Duke of Gloucester and Cardinal\r\n      Beaufort, his half-brother. The same pretext was used by Richard III. when\r\n      he brought the charge of sorcery against the Queen Dowager, Jane Shore,\r\n      and the queen&rsquo;s kinsmen; and yet again was by that unscrupulous prince\r\n      directed against Morton, afterwards Archbishop of Canterbury, and other\r\n      adherents of the Earl of Richmond. The accusation in both cases was only\r\n      chosen as a charge easily made and difficult to be eluded or repelled.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      But in the meanwhile, as the accusation of witchcraft thus afforded to\r\n      tyranny or policy the ready means of assailing persons whom it might not\r\n      have been possible to convict of any other crime, the aspersion itself was\r\n      gradually considered with increase of terror as spreading wider and\r\n      becoming more contagious. So early as the year 1398 the University of\r\n      Paris, in laying down rules for the judicial prosecuting of witches,\r\n      express their regret that the crime was growing more frequent than in any\r\n      former age. The more severe enquiries and frequent punishments by which\r\n      the judges endeavoured to check the progress of this impious practice seem\r\n      to have increased the disease, as indeed it has been always remarked that\r\n      those morbid affections of mind which depend on the imagination are sure\r\n      to become more common in proportion as public attention is fastened on\r\n      stories connected with their display.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In the same century schisms arising from different causes greatly alarmed\r\n      the Church of Rome. The universal spirit of enquiry which was now afloat,\r\n      taking a different direction in different countries, had in almost all of\r\n      them stirred up a sceptical dissatisfaction with the dogmas of the Church&mdash;such\r\n      views being rendered more credible to the poorer classes through the\r\n      corruption of manners among the clergy, too many of whom wealth and ease\r\n      had caused to neglect that course of morality which best recommends\r\n      religious doctrine. In almost every nation in Europe there lurked in the\r\n      crowded cities, or the wild solitude of the country, sects who agreed\r\n      chiefly in their animosity to the supremacy of Rome and their desire to\r\n      cast off her domination. The Waldenses and Albigenses were parties\r\n      existing in great numbers through the south of France. The Romanists\r\n      became extremely desirous to combine the doctrine of the heretics with\r\n      witchcraft, which, according to their account, abounded especially where\r\n      the Protestants were most numerous; and, the bitterness increasing, they\r\n      scrupled not to throw the charge of sorcery, as a matter of course, upon\r\n      those who dissented from the Catholic standard of faith. The Jesuit Delrio\r\n      alleges several reasons for the affinity which he considers as existing\r\n      between the Protestant and the sorcerer; he accuses the former of\r\n      embracing the opinion of Wierus and other defenders of the devil (as he\r\n      calls all who oppose his own opinions concerning witchcraft), thus\r\n      fortifying the kingdom of Satan against that of the Church.<a\r\n      href="#linknote-47" name="linknoteref-47" id="linknoteref-47"><small>47</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-47" id="linknote-47"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      47 (<a href="#linknoteref-47">return</a>)<br /> [ Delrio, &ldquo;De Magia.&rdquo; See\r\n      the Preface.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      A remarkable passage in Monstrelet puts in a clear view the point aimed at\r\n      by the Catholics in thus confusing and blending the doctrines of heresy\r\n      and the practice of witchcraft, and how a meeting of inoffensive\r\n      Protestants could be cunningly identified with a Sabbath of hags and\r\n      fiends.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;In this year (1459), in the town of Arras and county of Artois, arose,\r\n      through a terrible and melancholy chance, an opinion called, I know not\r\n      why, the Religion of Vaudoisie. This sect consisted, it is said, of\r\n      certain persons, both men and women, who, under cloud of night, by the\r\n      power of the devil, repaired to some solitary spot, amid woods and\r\n      deserts, where the devil appeared before them in a human form&mdash;save\r\n      that his visage is never perfectly visible to them&mdash;read to the\r\n      assembly a book of his ordinances, informing them how he would be obeyed;\r\n      distributed a very little money and a plentiful meal, which was concluded\r\n      by a scene of general profligacy; after which each one of the party was\r\n      conveyed home to her or his own habitation.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;On accusations of access to such acts of madness,&rdquo; continues Monstrelet,\r\n      &ldquo;several creditable persons of the town of Arras were seized and\r\n      imprisoned along with some foolish women and persons of little\r\n      consequence. These were so horribly tortured that some of them admitted\r\n      the truth of the whole accusations, and said, besides, that they had seen\r\n      and recognised in their nocturnal assembly many persons of rank, prelates,\r\n      seigneurs, and governors of bailliages and cities, being such names as the\r\n      examinators had suggested to the persons examined, while they constrained\r\n      them by torture to impeach the persons to whom they belonged. Several of\r\n      those who had been thus informed against were arrested, thrown into\r\n      prison, and tortured for so long a time that they also were obliged to\r\n      confess what was charged against them. After this those of mean condition\r\n      were executed and inhumanly burnt, while the richer and more powerful of\r\n      the accused ransomed themselves by sums of money, to avoid the punishment\r\n      and the shame attending it. Many even of those also confessed being\r\n      persuaded to take that course by the interrogators, who promised them\r\n      indemnity for life and fortune. Some there were, of a truth, who suffered\r\n      with marvellous patience and constancy the torments inflicted on them, and\r\n      would confess nothing imputed to their charge; but they, too, had to give\r\n      large sums to the judges, who exacted that such of them as,\r\n      notwithstanding their mishandling, were still able to move, should banish\r\n      themselves from that part of the country.&rdquo; Monstrelet winds up this\r\n      shocking narrative by informing us &ldquo;that it ought not to be concealed that\r\n      the whole accusation was a stratagem of wicked men for their own covetous\r\n      purposes, and in order, by these false accusations and forced confessions,\r\n      to destroy the life, fame, and fortune of wealthy persons.&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Delrio himself confesses that Franciscus Balduinus gives an account of the\r\n      pretended punishment, but real persecution, of these Waldenses, in similar\r\n      terms with Monstrelet, whose suspicions are distinctly spoken out, and\r\n      adds that the Parliament of Paris, having heard the affair by appeal, had\r\n      declared the sentence illegal and the judges iniquitous, by an arrt dated\r\n      20th May, 1491. The Jesuit Delrio quotes the passage, but adheres with\r\n      lingering reluctance to the truth of the accusation. &ldquo;The Waldenses (of\r\n      whom the Albigenses are a species) were,&rdquo; he says, &ldquo;never free from the\r\n      most wretched excess of fascination;&rdquo; and finally, though he allows the\r\n      conduct of the judges to have been most odious, he cannot prevail on\r\n      himself to acquit the parties charged by such interested accusers with\r\n      horrors which should hardly have been found proved even upon the most\r\n      distinct evidence. He appeals on this occasion to Florimond&rsquo;s work on\r\n      Antichrist. The introduction of that work deserves to be quoted, as\r\n      strongly illustrative of the condition to which the country was reduced,\r\n      and calculated to make an impression the very reverse probably of that\r\n      which the writer would have desired:&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;All those who have afforded us some signs of the approach of Antichrist\r\n      agree that the increase of sorcery and witchcraft is to distinguish the\r\n      melancholy period of his advent; and was ever age so afflicted with them\r\n      as ours? The seats destined for criminals before our judicatories are\r\n      blackened with persons accused of this guilt. There are not judges enough\r\n      to try them. Our dungeons are gorged with them. No day passes that we do\r\n      not render our tribunals bloody by the dooms which we pronounce, or in\r\n      which we do not return to our homes discountenanced and terrified at the\r\n      horrible contents of the confessions which it has been our duty to hear.\r\n      And the devil is accounted so good a master that we cannot commit so great\r\n      a number of his slaves to the flames but what there shall arise from their\r\n      ashes a number sufficient to supply their place."<a href="#linknote-48"\r\n       name="linknoteref-48" id="linknoteref-48"><small>48</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-48" id="linknote-48"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      48 (<a href="#linknoteref-48">return</a>)<br /> [ Florimond, &ldquo;Concerning\r\n      the Antichrist,&rdquo; cap. 7, n. 5, quoted by Delrio, &ldquo;De Magia,&rdquo; p. 820.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      This last statement, by which it appears that the most active and\r\n      unsparing inquisition was taking place, corresponds with the historical\r\n      notices of repeated persecutions upon this dreadful charge of sorcery. A\r\n      bull of Pope Innocent VIII. rang the tocsin against this formidable crime,\r\n      and set forth in the most dismal colours the guilt, while it stimulated\r\n      the inquisitors to the unsparing discharge of their duty in searching out\r\n      and punishing the guilty. &ldquo;It is come to our ears,&rdquo; says the bull, &ldquo;that\r\n      numbers of both sexes do not avoid to have intercourse with the infernal\r\n      fiends, and that by their sorceries they afflict both man and beast; that\r\n      they blight the marriage-bed, destroy the births of women, and the\r\n      increase of cattle; they blast the corn on the ground, the grapes of the\r\n      vineyard, the fruits of the trees, the grass and herbs of the field.&rdquo; For\r\n      which reasons the inquisitors were armed with the apostolic power, and\r\n      called upon to &ldquo;convict, imprison, and punish,&rdquo; and so forth.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Dreadful were the consequences of this bull all over the Continent,\r\n      especially in Italy, Germany, and France,<a href="#linknote-49"\r\n       name="linknoteref-49" id="linknoteref-49"><small>49</small></a> About 1485\r\n      Cumanus burnt as witches forty-one poor women in one year in the county of\r\n      Burlia. In the ensuing years he continued the prosecution with such\r\n      unremitting zeal that many fled from the country.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-49" id="linknote-49"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      49 (<a href="#linknoteref-49">return</a>)<br /> [ Dr. Hutchinson quotes &ldquo;H.\r\n      Institor,&rdquo; 105, 161.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Alciatus states that an inquisitor, about the same period, burnt an\r\n      hundred sorcerers in Piedmont, and persevered in his inquiries till human\r\n      patience was exhausted, and the people arose and drove him out of the\r\n      country, after which the jurisdiction was deferred to the archbishop. That\r\n      prelate consulted Alciatus himself, who had just then obtained his\r\n      doctor&rsquo;s degree in civil law, to which he was afterwards an honour. A\r\n      number of unfortunate wretches were brought for judgment, fitter,\r\n      according to the civilian&rsquo;s opinion, for a course of hellebore than for\r\n      the stake. Some were accused of having dishonoured the crucifix and denied\r\n      their salvation; others of having absconded to keep the Devil&rsquo;s Sabbath,\r\n      in spite of bolts and bars; others of having merely joined in the choral\r\n      dances around the witches&rsquo; tree of rendezvous. Several of their husbands\r\n      and relatives swore that they were in bed and asleep during these\r\n      pretended excursions. Alciatus recommended gentle and temperate measures;\r\n      and the minds of the country became at length composed.<a\r\n      href="#linknote-50" name="linknoteref-50" id="linknoteref-50"><small>50</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-50" id="linknote-50"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      50 (<a href="#linknoteref-50">return</a>)<br /> [ Alciat. &ldquo;Parerg. Juris,&rdquo;\r\n       lib. viii. chap. 22.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In 1488, the country four leagues around Constance was laid waste by\r\n      lightning and tempest, and two women being, by fair means or foul, made to\r\n      confess themselves guilty as the cause of the devastation, suffered death.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      About 1515, 500 persons were executed at Geneva, under the character of\r\n      &ldquo;Protestant witches,&rdquo; from which we may suppose many suffered for heresy.\r\n      Forty-eight witches were burnt at Ravensburgh within four years, as\r\n      Hutchison reports, on the authority of Mengho, the author of the &ldquo;Malleus\r\n      Malleficarum.&rdquo; In Lorraine the learned inquisitor, Remigius, boasts that\r\n      he put to death 900 people in fifteen years. As many were banished from\r\n      that country, so that whole towns were on the point of becoming desolate.\r\n      In 1524, 1,000 persons were put to death in one year at Como, in Italy,\r\n      and about 100 every year after for several years.<a href="#linknote-51"\r\n       name="linknoteref-51" id="linknoteref-51"><small>51</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-51" id="linknote-51"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      51 (<a href="#linknoteref-51">return</a>)<br /> [ Bart. de Spina, de\r\n      Strigilibus.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In the beginning of the next century the persecution of witches broke out\r\n      in France with a fury which was hardly conceivable, and multitudes were\r\n      burnt amid that gay and lively people. Some notion of the extreme\r\n      prejudice of their judges may be drawn from the words of one of the\r\n      inquisitors themselves. Pierre de Lancre, royal councillor in the\r\n      Parliament of Bourdeaux, with whom the President Espaignel was joined in a\r\n      commission to enquire into certain acts of sorcery, reported to have been\r\n      committed in Labourt and its neighbourhood, at the foot of the Pyrenees,\r\n      about the month of May, 1619. A few extracts from the preface will best\r\n      evince the state of mind in which he proceeded to the discharge of his\r\n      commission.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      His story assumes the form of a narrative of a direct war between Satan on\r\n      the one side and the Royal Commissioners on the other, &ldquo;because,&rdquo; says\r\n      Councillor de Lancre, with self-complaisance, &ldquo;nothing is so calculated to\r\n      strike terror into the fiend and his dominions as a commission with such\r\n      plenary powers.&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      At first, Satan endeavoured to supply his vassals who were brought before\r\n      the judges with strength to support the examinations, so that if, by\r\n      intermission of the torture, the wretches should fall into a doze, they\r\n      declared, when they were recalled from it to the question, that the\r\n      profound stupor &ldquo;had something of Paradise in it, being gilded,&rdquo; said the\r\n      judge, &ldquo;with the immediate presence of the devil;&rdquo; though, in all\r\n      probability, it rather derived its charms from the natural comparison\r\n      between the insensibility of exhaustion and the previous agony of acute\r\n      torture. The judges took care that the fiend seldom obtained any advantage\r\n      in the matter by refusing their victims, in most cases, any interval of\r\n      rest or sleep. Satan then proceeded, in the way of direct defiance, to\r\n      stop the mouth of the accused openly, and by mere force, with something\r\n      like a visible obstruction in their throat. Notwithstanding this, to put\r\n      the devil to shame, some of the accused found means, in spite of him, to\r\n      confess and be hanged, or rather burnt. The fiend lost much credit by his\r\n      failure on this occasion. Before the formidable Commissioners arrived, he\r\n      had held his <i>cour plnire</i> before the gates of Bourdeaux, and in\r\n      the square of the palace of Galienne, whereas he was now insulted publicly\r\n      by his own vassals, and in the midst of his festival of the Sabbath the\r\n      children and relations of the witches who had suffered not sticking to say\r\n      to him, &ldquo;Out upon you! Your promise was that our mothers who were\r\n      prisoners should not die; and look how you have kept your word with us!\r\n      They have been burnt, and are a heap of ashes.&rdquo; To appease this mutiny\r\n      Satan had two evasions. He produced illusory fires, and encouraged the\r\n      mutinous to walk through them, assuring them that the judicial pile was as\r\n      frigid and inoffensive as those which he exhibited to them. Again, taking\r\n      his refuge in lies, of which he is well known to be the father, he stoutly\r\n      affirmed that their parents, who seemed to have suffered, were safe in a\r\n      foreign country, and that if their children would call on them they would\r\n      receive an answer. They made the invocation accordingly, and Satan\r\n      answered each of them in a tone which resembled the voice of the lamented\r\n      parent almost as successfully as Monsieur Alexandra could have done.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Proceeding to a yet more close attack, the Commissioners, on the eve of\r\n      one of the Fiend&rsquo;s Sabbaths, placed the gibbet on which they executed\r\n      their victims just on the spot where Satan&rsquo;s gilded chair was usually\r\n      stationed. The devil was much offended at such an affront, and yet had so\r\n      little power in the matter that he could only express his resentment by\r\n      threats that he would hang Messieurs D&rsquo;Amon and D&rsquo;Urtubbe, gentlemen who\r\n      had solicited and promoted the issuing of the Commission, and would also\r\n      burn the Commissioners themselves in their own fire. We regret to say that\r\n      Satan was unable to execute either of these laudable resolutions. Ashamed\r\n      of his excuses, he abandoned for three or four sittings his attendance on\r\n      the Sabbaths, sending as his representative an imp of subordinate account,\r\n      and in whom no one reposed confidence. When he took courage again to face\r\n      his parliament, the Arch-fiend covered his defection by assuring them that\r\n      he had been engaged in a lawsuit with the Deity, which he had gained with\r\n      costs, and that six score of infant children were to be delivered up to\r\n      him in name of damages, and the witches were directed to procure such\r\n      victims accordingly. After this grand fiction he confined himself to the\r\n      petty vengeance of impeding the access of confessors to the condemned,\r\n      which was the more easy as few of them could speak the Basque language. I\r\n      have no time to detail the ingenious method by which the learned\r\n      Councillor de Lancre explains why the district of Labourt should be\r\n      particularly exposed to the pest of sorcery. The chief reason seems to be\r\n      that it is a mountainous, a sterile, and a border country, where the men\r\n      are all fishers and the women smoke tobacco and wear short petticoats.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      To a person who, in this presumptuous, trifling, and conceited spirit, has\r\n      composed a quarto volume full of the greatest absurdities and grossest\r\n      obscenities ever impressed on paper, it was the pleasure of the most\r\n      Christian Monarch to consign the most absolute power which could be\r\n      exercised on these poor people; and he might with as much prudence have\r\n      turned a ravenous wolf upon an undefended flock, of whom the animal was\r\n      the natural enemy, as they were his natural prey. The priest, as well as\r\n      the ignorant peasant, fell under the suspicion of this fell Commission;\r\n      and De Lancre writes, with much complacency, that the accused were brought\r\n      to trial to the number of forty in one day&mdash;with what chance of\r\n      escape, when the judges were blinded with prejudice, and could only hear\r\n      the evidence and the defence through the medium of an interpreter, the\r\n      understanding of the reader may easily anticipate.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Among other gross transgressions of the most ordinary rules, it may be\r\n      remarked that the accused, in what their judges called confessions,\r\n      contradicted each other at every turn respecting the description of the\r\n      Domdaniel in which they pretended to have been assembled, and the fiend\r\n      who presided there. All spoke to a sort of gilded throne; but some saw a\r\n      hideous wild he-goat seated there; some a man disfigured and twisted, as\r\n      suffering torture; some, with better taste, beheld a huge indistinct form,\r\n      resembling one of those mutilated trunks of trees found in ancient\r\n      forests. But De Lancre was no &ldquo;Daniel come to judgment,&rdquo; and the\r\n      discrepancy of evidence, which saved the life and fame of Susannah, made\r\n      no impression in favour of the sorcerers of Labourt.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Instances occur in De Lancre&rsquo;s book of the trial and condemnation of\r\n      persons accused of the crime of <i>lycanthropy</i>, a superstition which\r\n      was chiefly current in France, but was known in other countries, and is\r\n      the subject of great debate between Wier, Naud, Scot, on the one hand,\r\n      and their demonological adversaries on the other. The idea, said the one\r\n      party, was that a human being had the power, by sorcery, of transforming\r\n      himself into the shape of a wolf, and in that capacity, being seized with\r\n      a species of fury, he rushed out and made havoc among the flocks, slaying\r\n      and wasting, like the animal whom he represented, far more than he could\r\n      devour. The more incredulous reasoners would not allow of a real\r\n      transformation, whether with or without the enchanted hide of a wolf,\r\n      which in some cases was supposed to aid the metamorphosis, and contended\r\n      that lycanthropy only subsisted as a woful species of disease, a\r\n      melancholy state of mind, broken with occasional fits of insanity, in\r\n      which the patient imagined that he committed the ravages of which he was\r\n      accused. Such a person, a mere youth, was tried at Besanon, who gave\r\n      himself out for a servant, or yeoman pricker, of the Lord of the Forest&mdash;so\r\n      he called his superior&mdash;who was judged to be the devil. He was, by\r\n      his master&rsquo;s power, transformed into the likeness and performed the usual\r\n      functions of a wolf, and was attended in his course by one larger, which\r\n      he supposed the Lord of the Forest himself. These wolves, he said, ravaged\r\n      the flocks, and throttled the dogs which stood in their defence. If either\r\n      had not seen the other, he howled, after the manner of the animal, to call\r\n      his comrade to his share of the prey; if he did not come upon this signal,\r\n      he proceeded to bury it the best way he could.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Such was the general persecution under Messieurs Espiagnel and De Lancre.\r\n      Many similar scenes occurred in France, till the edict of Louis XIV.\r\n      discharging all future prosecutions for witchcraft, after which the crime\r\n      itself was heard of no more.<a href="#linknote-52" name="linknoteref-52"\r\n       id="linknoteref-52"><small>52</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-52" id="linknote-52"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      52 (<a href="#linknoteref-52">return</a>)<br /> [ The reader may sup full\r\n      on such wild horrors in the <i>causes clbres</i>.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      While the spirit of superstition was working such horrors in France, it\r\n      was not, we may believe, more idle in other countries of Europe. In Spain,\r\n      particularly, long the residence of the Moors, a people putting deep faith\r\n      in all the day-dreams of witchcraft, good and evil genii, spells and\r\n      talismans, the ardent and devotional temper of the old Christians dictated\r\n      a severe research after sorcerers as well as heretics, and relapsed Jews\r\n      or Mahommedans. In former times, during the subsistence of the Moorish\r\n      kingdoms in Spain, a school was supposed to be kept open in Toboso for the\r\n      study, it is said, of magic, but more likely of chemistry, algebra, and\r\n      other sciences, which, altogether mistaken by the ignorant and vulgar, and\r\n      imperfectly understood even by those who studied them, were supposed to be\r\n      allied to necromancy, or at least to natural magic. It was, of course, the\r\n      business of the Inquisition to purify whatever such pursuits had left of\r\n      suspicious Catholicism, and their labours cost as much blood on\r\n      accusations of witchcraft and magic as for heresy and relapse.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Even the colder nations of Europe were subject to the same epidemic terror\r\n      for witchcraft, and a specimen of it was exhibited in the sober and\r\n      rational country of Sweden about the middle of last century, an account of\r\n      which, being translated into English by a respectable clergyman, Doctor\r\n      Horneck, excited general surprise how a whole people could be imposed upon\r\n      to the degree of shedding much blood, and committing great cruelty and\r\n      injustice, on account of the idle falsehoods propagated by a crew of lying\r\n      children, who in this case were both actors and witnesses.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The melancholy truth that &ldquo;the human heart is deceitful above all things,\r\n      and desperately wicked,&rdquo; is by nothing proved so strongly as by the\r\n      imperfect sense displayed by children of the sanctity of moral truth. Both\r\n      the gentlemen and the mass of the people, as they advance in years, learn\r\n      to despise and avoid falsehood; the former out of pride, and from a\r\n      remaining feeling, derived from the days of chivalry, that the character\r\n      of a liar is a deadly stain on their honour; the other, from some general\r\n      reflection upon the necessity of preserving a character for integrity in\r\n      the course of life, and a sense of the truth of the common adage, that\r\n      &ldquo;honesty is the best policy.&rdquo; But these are acquired habits of thinking.\r\n      The child has no natural love of truth, as is experienced by all who have\r\n      the least acquaintance with early youth. If they are charged with a fault\r\n      while they can hardly speak, the first words they stammer forth are a\r\n      falsehood to excuse it. Nor is this all: the temptation of attracting\r\n      attention, the pleasure of enjoying importance, the desire to escape from\r\n      an unpleasing task, or accomplish a holiday, will at any time overcome the\r\n      sentiment of truth, so weak is it within them. Hence thieves and\r\n      housebreakers, from a surprisingly early period, find means of rendering\r\n      children useful in their mystery; nor are such acolytes found to evade\r\n      justice with less dexterity than the more advanced rogues. Where a number\r\n      of them are concerned in the same mischief, there is something resembling\r\n      virtue in the fidelity with which the common secret is preserved.\r\n      Children, under the usual age of their being admitted to give evidence,\r\n      were necessarily often examined in witch trials; and it is terrible to see\r\n      how often the little impostors, from spite or in mere gaiety of spirit,\r\n      have by their art and perseverance made shipwreck of men&rsquo;s lives. But it\r\n      would be hard to discover a case which, supported exclusively by the\r\n      evidence of children (the confessions under torture excepted), and\r\n      obviously existing only in the young witnesses&rsquo; own imagination, has been\r\n      attended with such serious consequences, or given cause to so extensive\r\n      and fatal a delusion, as that which occurred in Sweden.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The scene was the Swedish village of Mohra, in the province of Elfland,\r\n      which district had probably its name from some remnant of ancient\r\n      superstition. The delusion had come to a great height ere it reached the\r\n      ears of government, when, as was the general procedure, Royal\r\n      Commissioners were sent down, men well fitted for the duty entrusted to\r\n      them; that is, with ears open to receive the incredibilities with which\r\n      they were to be crammed, and hearts hardened against every degree of\r\n      compassion to the accused. The complaints of the common people, backed by\r\n      some persons of better condition, were that a number of persons, renowned\r\n      as witches, had drawn several hundred children of all classes under the\r\n      devil&rsquo;s authority. They demanded, therefore, the punishment of these\r\n      agents of hell, reminding the judges that the province had been clear of\r\n      witches since the burning of some on a former occasion. The accused were\r\n      numerous, so many as threescore and ten witches and sorcerers being seized\r\n      in the village of Mohra; three-and-twenty confessed their crimes, and were\r\n      sent to Faluna, where most of them were executed. Fifteen of the children\r\n      were also led to death. Six-and-thirty of those who were young were forced\r\n      to run the gauntlet, as it is called, and were, besides, lashed weekly at\r\n      the church doors for a whole year. Twenty of the youngest were condemned\r\n      to the same discipline for three days only.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The process seems to have consisted in confronting the children with the\r\n      witches, and hearing the extraordinary story which the former insisted\r\n      upon maintaining. The children, to the number of three hundred, were found\r\n      more or less perfect in a tale as full of impossible absurdities as ever\r\n      was told around a nursery fire. Their confession ran thus:&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      They were taught by the witches to go to a cross way, and with certain\r\n      ceremonies to invoke the devil by the name of Antecessor, begging him to\r\n      carry them off to Blockula, meaning, perhaps, the Brockenberg, in the\r\n      Hartz forest, a mountain infamous for being the common scene of witches&rsquo;\r\n      meetings, and to which Goethe represents the spirit Mephistopheles as\r\n      conducting his pupil Faustus. The devil courteously appeared at the call\r\n      of the children in various forms, but chiefly as a mad Merry-Andrew, with\r\n      a grey coat, red and blue stockings, a red beard, a high-crowned hat, with\r\n      linen of various colours wrapt round it, and garters of peculiar length.\r\n      He set each child on some beast of his providing, and anointed them with a\r\n      certain unguent composed of the scrapings of altars and the filings of\r\n      church clocks. There is here a discrepancy of evidence which in another\r\n      court would have cast the whole. Most of the children considered their\r\n      journey to be corporeal and actual. Some supposed, however, that their\r\n      strength or spirit only travelled with the fiend, and that their body\r\n      remained behind. Very few adopted this last hypothesis, though the parents\r\n      unanimously bore witness that the bodies of the children remained in bed,\r\n      and could not be awakened out of a deep sleep, though they shook them for\r\n      the purpose of awakening them. So strong was, nevertheless, the belief of\r\n      nurses and mothers in their actual transportation, that a sensible\r\n      clergyman, mentioned in the preface, who had resolved he would watch his\r\n      son the whole night and see what hag or fiend would take him from his\r\n      arms, had the utmost difficulty, notwithstanding, in convincing his mother\r\n      that the child had not been transported to Blockula during the very night\r\n      he held him in his embrace.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The learned translator candidly allows, &ldquo;out of so great a multitude as\r\n      were accused, condemned, and executed, there might be some who suffered\r\n      unjustly, and owed their death more to the malice of their enemies than to\r\n      their skill in the black art, I will readily admit. Nor will I deny,&rdquo; he\r\n      continues, &ldquo;but that when the news of these transactions and accounts, how\r\n      the children bewitched fel into fits and strange unusual postures, spread\r\n      abroad in the kingdom, some fearful and credulous people, if they saw\r\n      their children any way disordered, might think they were bewitched or\r\n      ready to be carried away by imps."<a href="#linknote-53"\r\n       name="linknoteref-53" id="linknoteref-53"><small>53</small></a> The\r\n      learned gentleman here stops short in a train of reasoning, which,\r\n      followed out, would have deprived the world of the benefit of his\r\n      translation. For if it was possible that some of these unfortunate persons\r\n      fell a sacrifice to the malice of their neighbours or the prejudices of\r\n      witnesses, as he seems ready to grant, is it not more reasonable to\r\n      believe that the whole of the accused were convicted on similar grounds,\r\n      than to allow, as truth, the slightest part of the gross and vulgar\r\n      impossibilities upon which alone their execution can be justified?\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-53" id="linknote-53"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      53 (<a href="#linknoteref-53">return</a>)<br /> [ Translator&rsquo;s preface to\r\n      Horneck&rsquo;s &ldquo;Account of what happened in the Kingdom of Sweden.&rdquo; See\r\n      appendix to Glanville&rsquo;s work.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The Blockula, which was the object of their journey, was a house having a\r\n      fine gate painted with divers colours, with a paddock, in which they\r\n      turned the beasts to graze which had brought them to such scenes of\r\n      revelry. If human beings had been employed they were left slumbering\r\n      against the wall of the house. The plan of the devil&rsquo;s palace consisted of\r\n      one large banqueting apartment and several withdrawing-rooms. Their food\r\n      was homely enough, being broth made of coleworts and bacon, with bread and\r\n      butter, and milk and cheese. The same acts of wickedness and profligacy\r\n      were committed at Blockula which are usually supposed to take place upon\r\n      the devil&rsquo;s Sabbath elsewhere; but there was this particular, that the\r\n      witches had sons and daughters by the fiends, who were married together,\r\n      and produced an offspring of toads and serpents.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      These confessions being delivered before the accused witches, they at\r\n      first stoutly denied them. At last some of them burst into tears, and\r\n      acquiesced in the horrors imputed to them. They said the practice of\r\n      carrying off children had been enlarged very lately (which shows the whole\r\n      rumours to have arisen recently); and the despairing wretches confirmed\r\n      what the children said, with many other extravagant circumstances, as the\r\n      mode of elongating a goat&rsquo;s back by means of a spit, on which we care not\r\n      to be particular. It is worth mentioning that the devil, desirous of\r\n      enjoying his own reputation among his subjects, pretended at one time to\r\n      be dead, and was much lamented at Blockula&mdash;but he soon revived\r\n      again.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Some attempts these witches had made to harm individuals on middle earth,\r\n      but with little success. One old sorceress, indeed, attempted to strike a\r\n      nail, given her by the devil for that purpose, into the head of the\r\n      minister of Elfland; but as the skull was of unusual solidity, the\r\n      reverend gentleman only felt a headache from her efforts. They could not\r\n      be persuaded to exhibit any of their tricks before the Commissioners,\r\n      excusing themselves by alleging that their witchcraft had left them, and\r\n      that the devil had amused them with the vision of a burning pit, having a\r\n      hand thrust out of it.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The total number who lost their lives on this singular occasion was\r\n      fourscore and four persons, including fifteen children; and at this\r\n      expense of blood was extinguished a flame that arose as suddenly, burned\r\n      as fiercely, and decayed as rapidly, as any portent of the kind within the\r\n      annals of superstition. The Commissioners returned to Court with the high\r\n      approbation of all concerned; prayers were ordered through the churches\r\n      weekly, that Heaven would be pleased to restrain the powers of the devil,\r\n      and deliver the poor creatures who hitherto had groaned under it, as well\r\n      as the innocent children, who were carried off by hundreds at once.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      If we could ever learn the true explanation of this story, we should\r\n      probably find that the cry was led by some clever mischievous boy, who\r\n      wished to apologise to his parents for lying an hour longer in the morning\r\n      by alleging he had been at Blockula on the preceding night; and that the\r\n      desire to be as much distinguished as their comrade had stimulated the\r\n      bolder and more acute of his companions to the like falsehoods; whilst\r\n      those of weaker minds assented, either from fear of punishment or the\r\n      force of dreaming over at night the horrors which were dinned into their\r\n      ears all day. Those who were ingenuous, as it was termed, in their\r\n      confessions, received praise and encouragement; and those who denied or\r\n      were silent, and, as it was considered, impenitent, were sure to bear the\r\n      harder share of the punishment which was addressed to all. It is worth\r\n      while also to observe, that the smarter children began to improve their\r\n      evidence and add touches to the general picture of Blockula. &ldquo;Some of the\r\n      children talked much of a white angel, which used to forbid them what the\r\n      devil bid them do, and told them that these doings should not last long.\r\n      And (they added) this better being would place himself sometimes at the\r\n      door betwixt the witches and the children, and when they came to Blockula\r\n      he pulled the children back, but the witches went in.&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      This additional evidence speaks for itself, and shows the whole tale to be\r\n      the fiction of the children&rsquo;s imagination, which some of them wished to\r\n      improve upon. The reader may consult &ldquo;An Account of what happened in the\r\n      Kingdom of Sweden in the years 1669 and 1670, and afterwards translated\r\n      out of High Dutch into English by Dr. Antony Horneck,&rdquo; attached to\r\n      Glanville&rsquo;s &ldquo;Sadducismus Triumphatus.&rdquo; The translator refers to the\r\n      evidence of Baron Sparr, Ambassador from the Court of Sweden to the Court\r\n      of England in 1672; and that of Baron Lyonberg, Envoy Extraordinary of the\r\n      same power, both of whom attest the confession and execution of the\r\n      witches. The King of Sweden himself answered the express inquiries of the\r\n      Duke of Holstein with marked reserve. &ldquo;His judges and commissioners,&rdquo; he\r\n      said, &ldquo;had caused divers men, women, and children, to be burnt and\r\n      executed on such pregnant evidence as was brought before them. But whether\r\n      the actions confessed and proved against them were real, or only the\r\n      effects of strong imagination, he was not as yet able to determine&rdquo;&mdash;a\r\n      sufficient reason, perhaps, why punishment should have been at least\r\n      deferred by the interposition of the royal authority.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      We must now turn our eyes to Britain, in which our knowledge as to such\r\n      events is necessarily more extensive, and where it is in a high degree\r\n      more interesting to our present purpose.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="link2H_4_0009" id="link2H_4_0009"> </a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <div style="height: 4em;">\r\n      <br /><br /><br /><br />\r\n    </div>\r\n    <h2>\r\n      LETTER VIII.\r\n    </h2>\r\n<pre xml:space="preserve">\r\n    The Effects of the Witch Superstition are to be traced in the Laws\r\n    of a Kingdom&mdash;Usually punished in England as a Crime connected with\r\n    Politics&mdash;Attempt at Murder for Witchcraft not in itself\r\n    Capital&mdash;Trials of Persons of Rank for Witchcraft, connected with\r\n    State Crimes&mdash;Statutes of Henry VIII&mdash;How Witchcraft was regarded by\r\n    the three Leading Sects of Religion in the Sixteenth Century; first,\r\n    by the Catholics; second, by the Calvinists; third, by the Church of\r\n    England and Lutherans&mdash;Impostures unwarily countenanced by\r\n    individual Catholic Priests, and also by some Puritanic\r\n    Clergymen&mdash;Statute of 1562, and some cases upon it&mdash;Case of\r\n    Dugdale&mdash;Case of the Witches of Warbois, and the execution of the\r\n    Family of Samuel&mdash;That of Jane Wenham, in which some Church of\r\n    England Clergymen insisted on the Prosecution&mdash;Hutchison&rsquo;s Rebuke to\r\n    them&mdash;James the First&rsquo;s Opinion of Witchcraft&mdash;His celebrated\r\n    Statute, 1 Jac. I.&mdash;Canon passed by the Convocation against\r\n    Possession&mdash;Case of Mr. Fairfax&rsquo;s Children&mdash;Lancashire Witches in\r\n    1613&mdash;Another Discovery in 1634&mdash;Webster&rsquo;s Account of the manner in\r\n    which the Imposture was managed&mdash;Superiority of the Calvinists is\r\n    followed by a severe Prosecution of Witches&mdash;Executions in Suffolk,\r\n    &amp;c. to a dreadful extent&mdash;Hopkins, the pretended Witchfinder, the\r\n    cause of these Cruelties&mdash;His Brutal Practices&mdash;His\r\n    Letter&mdash;Execution of Mr. Lowis&mdash;Hopkins Punished&mdash;Restoration of\r\n    Charles&mdash;Trial of Coxe&mdash;Of Dunny and Callendar before Lord\r\n    Hales&mdash;Royal Society and Progress of Knowledge&mdash;Somersetshire\r\n    Witches&mdash;Opinions of the Populace&mdash;A Woman Swum for Witchcraft at\r\n    Oakly&mdash;- Murder at Tring&mdash;Act against Witchcraft abolished, and the\r\n    belief in the Crime becomes forgotten&mdash;Witch Trials in New\r\n    England&mdash;Dame Glover&rsquo;s Trial&mdash;Affliction of the Parvises, and\r\n    frightful Increase of the Prosecutions&mdash;Suddenly put a stop to&mdash;The\r\n    Penitence of those concerned in them.\r\n</pre>\r\n    <p class="pfirst">\r\n      <span class="dropcap" style="font-size: 4.00em">O</span>ur account of\r\n      Demonology in England must naturally, as in every other country, depend\r\n      chiefly on the instances which history contains of the laws and\r\n      prosecutions against witchcraft. Other superstitions arose and decayed,\r\n      were dreaded or despised, without greater embarrassment, in the provinces\r\n      in which they have a temporary currency, than that cowards and children go\r\n      out more seldom at night, while the reports of ghosts and fairies are\r\n      peculiarly current. But when the alarm of witchcraft arises, Superstition\r\n      dips her hand in the blood of the persons accused, and records in the\r\n      annals of jurisprudence their trials and the causes alleged in vindication\r\n      of their execution. Respecting other fantastic allegations, the proof is\r\n      necessarily transient and doubtful, depending upon the inaccurate\r\n      testimony of vague report and of doting tradition. But in cases of\r\n      witchcraft we have before us the recorded evidence upon which judge and\r\n      jury acted, and can form an opinion with some degree of certainty of the\r\n      grounds, real or fanciful, on which they acquitted or condemned. It is,\r\n      therefore, in tracing, this part of Demonology, with its accompanying\r\n      circumstances, that we have the best chance of obtaining an accurate view\r\n      of our subject.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The existence of witchcraft was, no doubt, received and credited in\r\n      England, as in the countries on the Continent, and originally punished\r\n      accordingly. But after the fourteenth century the practices which fell\r\n      under such a description were thought unworthy of any peculiar\r\n      animadversion, unless they were connected with something which would have\r\n      been of itself a capital crime, by whatever means it had been either\r\n      essayed or accomplished. Thus the supposed paction between a witch and the\r\n      demon was perhaps deemed in itself to have terrors enough to prevent its\r\n      becoming an ordinary crime, and was not, therefore, visited with any\r\n      statutory penalty. But to attempt or execute bodily harm to others through\r\n      means of evil spirits, or, in a word, by the black art, was actionable at\r\n      common law as much as if the party accused had done the same harm with an\r\n      arrow or pistol-shot. The destruction or abstraction of goods by the like\r\n      instruments, supposing the charge proved, would, in like manner, be\r\n      punishable. <i>A fortiori</i>, the consulting soothsayers, familiar\r\n      spirits, or the like, and the obtaining and circulating pretended\r\n      prophecies to the unsettlement of the State and the endangering of the\r\n      King&rsquo;s title, is yet a higher degree of guilt. And it may be remarked that\r\n      the inquiry into the date of the King&rsquo;s life bears a close affinity with\r\n      the desiring or compassing the death of the Sovereign, which is the\r\n      essence of high treason. Upon such charges repeated trials took place in\r\n      the courts of the English, and condemnations were pronounced, with\r\n      sufficient justice, no doubt, where the connexion between the resort to\r\n      sorcerers and the design to perpetrate a felony could be clearly proved.\r\n      We would not, indeed, be disposed to go the length of so high an authority\r\n      as Selden, who pronounces (in his &ldquo;Table-Talk&rdquo;) that if a man heartily\r\n      believed that he could take the life of another by waving his hat three\r\n      times and crying Buzz! and should, under this fixed opinion, wave his hat\r\n      and cry Buzz! accordingly, he ought to be executed as a murderer. But a\r\n      false prophecy of the King&rsquo;s death is not to be dealt with exactly on the\r\n      usual principle; because, however idle in itself, the promulgation of such\r\n      a prediction has, in times such as we are speaking of, a strong tendency\r\n      to work its completion.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Many persons, and some of great celebrity, suffered for the charge of\r\n      trafficking with witches, to the prejudice of those in authority. We have\r\n      already mentioned the instance of the Duchess of Gloucester, in Henry the\r\n      Sixth&rsquo;s reign, and that of the Queen Dowager&rsquo;s kinsmen, in the\r\n      Protectorate of Richard, afterwards the Third. In 1521, the Duke of\r\n      Buckingham was beheaded, owing much to his having listened to the\r\n      predictions of one Friar Hopkins. In the same reign, the Maid of Kent, who\r\n      had been esteemed a prophetess, was put to death as a cheat. She suffered\r\n      with seven persons who had managed her fits for the support of the\r\n      Catholic religion, and confessed her fraud upon the scaffold. About seven\r\n      years after this, Lord Hungerford was beheaded for consulting certain\r\n      soothsayers concerning the length of Henry the Eighth&rsquo;s life. But these\r\n      cases rather relate to the purpose for which the sorcery was employed,\r\n      than to the fact of using it.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Two remarkable statutes were passed in the year 1541; one against false\r\n      prophecies, the other against the act of conjuration, witchcraft, and\r\n      sorcery, and at the same time against breaking and destroying crosses. The\r\n      former enactment was certainly made to ease the suspicious and wayward\r\n      fears of the tetchy King Henry. The prohibition against witchcraft might\r\n      be also dictated by the king&rsquo;s jealous doubts of hazard to the succession.\r\n      The enactment against breaking crosses was obviously designed to check the\r\n      ravages of the Reformers, who in England as well as elsewhere desired to\r\n      sweep away Popery with the besom of destruction. This latter statute was\r\n      abrogated in the first year of Edward VI., perhaps as placing an undue\r\n      restraint on the zeal of good Protestants against idolatry.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      At length, in 1562, a formal statute against sorcery, as penal in itself,\r\n      was actually passed; but as the penalty was limited to the pillory for the\r\n      first transgression, the legislature probably regarded those who might be\r\n      brought to trial as impostors rather than wizards. There are instances of\r\n      individuals tried and convicted as impostors and cheats, and who\r\n      acknowledged themselves such before the court and people; but in their\r\n      articles of visitation the prelates directed enquiry to be made after\r\n      those who should use enchantments, witchcraft, sorcery, or any like craft,\r\n      <i>invented by the devil</i>.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      But it is here proper to make a pause for the purpose of enquiring in what\r\n      manner the religious disputes which occupied all Europe about this time\r\n      influenced the proceedings of the rival sects in relation to Demonology.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The Papal Church had long reigned by the proud and absolute humour which\r\n      she had assumed, of maintaining every doctrine which her rulers had\r\n      adopted in dark ages; but this pertinacity at length made her citadel too\r\n      large to be defended at every point by a garrison whom prudence would have\r\n      required to abandon positions which had been taken in times of darkness,\r\n      and were unsuited to the warfare of a more enlightened age. The sacred\r\n      motto of the Vatican was, &ldquo;<i>Vestigia nulla retrorsum</i>;&rdquo; and this\r\n      rendered it impossible to comply with the more wise and moderate of her\r\n      own party, who would otherwise have desired to make liberal concessions to\r\n      the Protestants, and thus prevent, in its commencement, a formidable\r\n      schism in the Christian world.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      To the system of Rome the Calvinists offered the most determined\r\n      opposition, affecting upon every occasion and on all points to observe an\r\n      order of church-government, as well as of worship, expressly in the teeth\r\n      of its enactments;&mdash;in a word, to be a good Protestant, they held it\r\n      almost essential to be in all things diametrically opposite to the\r\n      Catholic form and faith. As the foundation of this sect was laid in\r\n      republican states, as its clerical discipline was settled on a democratic\r\n      basis, and as the countries which adopted that form of government were\r\n      chiefly poor, the preachers having lost the rank and opulence enjoyed by\r\n      the Roman Church, were gradually thrown on the support of the people.\r\n      Insensibly they became occupied with the ideas and tenets natural to the\r\n      common people, which, if they have usually the merit of being honestly\r\n      conceived and boldly expressed, are not the less often adopted with\r\n      credulity and precipitation, and carried into effect with unhesitating\r\n      harshness and severity.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Betwixt these extremes the Churchmen of England endeavoured to steer a\r\n      middle course, retaining a portion of the ritual and forms of Rome, as in\r\n      themselves admirable, and at any rate too greatly venerated by the people\r\n      to be changed merely for opposition&rsquo;s sake. Their comparatively\r\n      undilapidated revenue, the connexion of their system with the state, with\r\n      views of ambition as ample as the station of a churchman ought to command,\r\n      rendered them independent of the necessity of courting their flocks by any\r\n      means save regular discharge of their duty; and the excellent provisions\r\n      made for their education afforded them learning to confute ignorance and\r\n      enlighten prejudice.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Such being the general character of the three Churches, their belief in\r\n      and persecution of such crimes as witchcraft and sorcery were necessarily\r\n      modelled upon the peculiar tenets which each system professed, and gave\r\n      rise to various results in the countries where they were severally\r\n      received.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The Church of Rome, as we have seen, was unwilling, in her period of\r\n      undisputed power, to call in the secular arm to punish men for witchcraft&mdash;a\r\n      crime which fell especially under ecclesiastical cognizance, and could,\r\n      according to her belief, be subdued by the spiritual arm alone. The\r\n      learned men at the head of the establishment might safely despise the\r\n      attempt at those hidden arts as impossible; or, even if they were of a\r\n      more credulous disposition, they might be unwilling to make laws by which\r\n      their own enquiries in the mathematics, algebra, chemistry, and other\r\n      pursuits vulgarly supposed to approach the confines of magic art, might be\r\n      inconveniently restricted. The more selfish part of the priesthood might\r\n      think that a general belief in the existence of witches should be\r\n      permitted to remain, as a source both of power and of revenue&mdash;that\r\n      if there were no possessions, there could be no exorcism-fees&mdash;and,\r\n      in short, that a wholesome faith in all the absurdities of the vulgar\r\n      creed as to supernatural influences was necessary to maintain the\r\n      influence of Diana of Ephesus. They suffered spells to be manufactured,\r\n      since every friar had the power of reversing them; they permitted poison\r\n      to be distilled, because every convent had the antidote, which was\r\n      disposed of to all who chose to demand it. It was not till the universal\r\n      progress of heresy, in the end of the fifteenth century, that the bull of\r\n      Pope Innocent VIII., already quoted, called to convict, imprison, and\r\n      condemn the sorcerers, chiefly because it was the object to transfer the\r\n      odium of these crimes to the Waldenses, and excite and direct the public\r\n      hatred against the new sect by confounding their doctrines with the\r\n      influences of the devil and his fiends. The bull of Pope Innocent was\r\n      afterwards, in the year 1523, enforced by Adrian VI. with a new one, in\r\n      which excommunication was directed against <i>sorcerers and heretics</i>.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      While Rome thus positively declared herself against witches and sorcerers,\r\n      the Calvinists, in whose numbers must be included the greater part of the\r\n      English Puritans, who, though they had not finally severed from the\r\n      communion of the Anglican Church, yet disapproved of her ritual and\r\n      ceremonies as retaining too much of the Papal stamp, ranked themselves, in\r\n      accordance with their usual policy, in diametrical opposition to the\r\n      doctrine of the Mother Church. They assumed in the opposite sense whatever\r\n      Rome pretended to as a proof of her omnipotent authority. The exorcisms,\r\n      forms, and rites, by which good Catholics believed that incarnate fiends\r\n      could be expelled and evil spirits of every kind rebuked&mdash;these, like\r\n      the holy water, the robes of the priest, and the sign of the cross, the\r\n      Calvinists considered either with scorn and contempt as the tools of\r\n      deliberate quackery and imposture, or with horror and loathing, as the fit\r\n      emblems and instruments of an idolatrous system.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Such of them as did not absolutely deny the supernatural powers of which\r\n      the Romanists made boast, regarded the success of the exorcising priest,\r\n      to whatever extent they admitted it, as at best a casting out of devils by\r\n      the power of Beelzebub, the King of the Devils. They saw also, and\r\n      resented bitterly, the attempt to confound any dissent from the doctrines\r\n      of Rome with the proneness to an encouragement of rites of sorcery. On the\r\n      whole, the Calvinists, generally speaking, were of all the contending\r\n      sects the most suspicious of sorcery, the most undoubting believers in its\r\n      existence, and the most eager to follow it up with what they conceived to\r\n      be the due punishment of the most fearful of crimes.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The leading divines of the Church of England were, without doubt,\r\n      fundamentally as much opposed to the doctrines of Rome as those who\r\n      altogether disclaimed opinions and ceremonies merely because she had\r\n      entertained them. But their position in society tended strongly to keep\r\n      them from adopting, on such subjects as we are now discussing, either the\r\n      eager credulity of the vulgar mind or the fanatic ferocity of their\r\n      Calvinistic rivals. We have no purpose to discuss the matter in detail&mdash;enough\r\n      has probably been said to show generally why the Romanist should have\r\n      cried out a miracle respecting an incident which the Anglican would have\r\n      contemptuously termed an imposture; while the Calvinist, inspired with a\r\n      darker zeal, and, above all, with the unceasing desire of open controversy\r\n      with the Catholics, would have styled the same event an operation of the\r\n      devil.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It followed that, while the divines of the Church of England possessed the\r\n      upper hand in the kingdom, witchcraft, though trials and even\r\n      condemnations for that offence occasionally occurred, did not create that\r\n      epidemic terror which the very suspicion of the offence carried with it\r\n      elsewhere; so that Reginald Scot and others alleged it was the vain\r\n      pretences and empty forms of the Church of Rome, by the faith reposed in\r\n      them, which had led to the belief of witchcraft or sorcery in general. Nor\r\n      did prosecutions on account of such charges frequently involve a capital\r\n      punishment, while learned judges were jealous of the imperfection of the\r\n      evidence to support the charge, and entertained a strong and growing\r\n      suspicion that legitimate grounds for such trials seldom actually existed.\r\n      On the other hand, it usually happened that wherever the Calvinist\r\n      interest became predominant in Britain, a general persecution of sorcerers\r\n      and witches seemed to take place of consequence. Fearing and hating\r\n      sorcery more than other Protestants, connecting its ceremonies and usages\r\n      with those of the detested Catholic Church, the Calvinists were more eager\r\n      than other sects in searching after the traces of this crime, and, of\r\n      course, unusually successful, as they might suppose, in making discoveries\r\n      of guilt, and pursuing it to the expiation of the fagot. In a word, a\r\n      principle already referred to by Dr. Francis Hutchison will be found to\r\n      rule the tide and the reflux of such cases in the different churches. The\r\n      numbers of witches, and their supposed dealings with Satan, will increase\r\n      or decrease according as such doings are accounted probable or impossible.\r\n      Under the former supposition, charges and convictions will be found\r\n      augmented in a terrific degree. When the accusations are disbelieved and\r\n      dismissed as not worthy of attention, the crime becomes unfrequent, ceases\r\n      to occupy the public mind, and affords little trouble to the judges.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The passing of Elizabeth&rsquo;s statute against witchcraft in 1562 does not\r\n      seem to have been intended to increase the number of trials, or cases of\r\n      conviction at least; and the fact is, it did neither the one nor the\r\n      other. Two children were tried in 1574 for counterfeiting possession, and\r\n      stood in the pillory for impostors. Mildred Norrington, called the Maid of\r\n      Westwell, furnished another instance of possession; but she also confessed\r\n      her imposture, and publicly showed her fits and tricks of mimicry. The\r\n      strong influence already possessed by the Puritans may probably be\r\n      sufficient to account for the darker issue of certain cases, in which both\r\n      juries and judges in Elizabeth&rsquo;s time must be admitted to have shown\r\n      fearful severity.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      These cases of possession were in some respects sore snares to the priests\r\n      of the Church of Rome, who, while they were too sagacious not to be aware\r\n      that the pretended fits, contortions, strange sounds, and other\r\n      extravagances, produced as evidence of the demon&rsquo;s influence on the\r\n      possessed person, were nothing else than marks of imposture by some idle\r\n      vagabond, were nevertheless often tempted to admit them as real, and take\r\n      the credit of curing them. The period was one when the Catholic Church had\r\n      much occasion to rally around her all the respect that remained to her in\r\n      a schismatic and heretical kingdom; and when her fathers and doctors\r\n      announced the existence of such a dreadful disease, and of the power of\r\n      the church&rsquo;s prayers, relics, and ceremonies, to cure it, it was difficult\r\n      for a priest, supposing him more tender of the interest of his order than\r\n      that of truth, to avoid such a tempting opportunity as a supposed case of\r\n      possession offered for displaying the high privilege in which his\r\n      profession made him a partaker, or to abstain from conniving at the\r\n      imposture, in order to obtain for his church the credit of expelling the\r\n      demon. It was hardly to be wondered at, if the ecclesiastic was sometimes\r\n      induced to aid the fraud of which such motives forbade him to be the\r\n      detector. At this he might hesitate the less, as he was not obliged to\r\n      adopt the suspected and degrading course of holding an immediate\r\n      communication <i>in limine</i> with the impostor, since a hint or two,\r\n      dropped in the supposed sufferer&rsquo;s presence, might give him the necessary\r\n      information what was the most exact mode of performing his part, and if\r\n      the patient was possessed by a devil of any acuteness or dexterity, he\r\n      wanted no further instruction how to play it. Such combinations were\r\n      sometimes detected, and brought more discredit on the Church of Rome than\r\n      was counterbalanced by any which might be more cunningly managed. On this\r\n      subject the reader may turn to Dr. Harsnett&rsquo;s celebrated book on Popish\r\n      Impostures, wherein he gives the history of several notorious cases of\r\n      detected fraud, in which Roman ecclesiastics had not hesitated to mingle\r\n      themselves. That of Grace Sowerbutts, instructed by a Catholic priest to\r\n      impeach her grandmother of witchcraft, was a very gross fraud.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Such cases were not, however, limited to the ecclesiastics of Rome. We\r\n      have already stated that, as extremes usually approach each other, the\r\n      Dissenters, in their violent opposition to the Papists, adopted some of\r\n      their ideas respecting demoniacs; and we have now to add that they also\r\n      claimed, by the vehemence of prayer and the authority of their own sacred\r\n      commission, that power of expelling devils which the Church of Rome\r\n      pretended to exercise by rites, ceremonies, and relics. The memorable case\r\n      of Richard Dugdale, called the Surrey Impostor, was one of the most\r\n      remarkable which the Dissenters brought forward. This youth was supposed\r\n      to have sold his soul to the devil, on condition of being made the best\r\n      dancer in Lancashire, and during his possession played a number of\r\n      fantastic tricks, not much different from those exhibited by expert\r\n      posture-masters of the present day. This person threw himself into the\r\n      hands of the Dissenters, who, in their eagerness, caught at an opportunity\r\n      to relieve an afflicted person, whose case the regular clergy appeared to\r\n      have neglected. They fixed a committee of their number, who weekly\r\n      attended the supposed sufferer, and exercised themselves in appointed days\r\n      of humiliation and fasting during the course of a whole year. All respect\r\n      for the demon seems to have abandoned the reverend gentlemen, after they\r\n      had relieved guard in this manner for some little time, and they got so\r\n      regardless of Satan as to taunt him with the mode in which he executed his\r\n      promise to teach his vassal dancing. The following specimen of raillery is\r\n      worth commemoration:&mdash;&ldquo;What, Satan! is this the dancing that Richard\r\n      gave himself to thee for? &amp;c. Canst thou dance no better? &amp;c.\r\n      Ransack the old records of all past times and places in thy memory; canst\r\n      thou not there find out some better way of trampling? Pump thine invention\r\n      dry; cannot the universal seed-plot of subtile wiles and stratagems spring\r\n      up one new method of cutting capers? Is this the top of skill and pride,\r\n      to shuffle feet and brandish knees thus, and to trip like a doe and skip\r\n      like a squirrel? And wherein differ thy leapings from the hoppings of a\r\n      frog, or the bouncings of a goat, or friskings of a dog, or gesticulations\r\n      of a monkey? And cannot a palsy shake such a loose leg as that? Dost thou\r\n      not twirl like a calf that hath the turn, and twitch up thy houghs just\r\n      like a springhault tit?"<a href="#linknote-54" name="linknoteref-54"\r\n       id="linknoteref-54"><small>54</small></a> One might almost conceive the\r\n      demon replying to this raillery in the words of Dr. Johnson, &ldquo;This\r\n      merriment of parsons is extremely offensive.&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-54" id="linknote-54"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      54 (<a href="#linknoteref-54">return</a>)<br /> [ Hutchison on Witchcraft,\r\n      p. 162.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The dissenters were probably too honest, however simple, to achieve a\r\n      complete cure on Dugdale by an amicable understanding; so, after their\r\n      year of vigil, they relinquished their task by degrees. Dugdale, weary of\r\n      his illness, which now attracted little notice, attended a regular\r\n      physician, and was cured of that part of his disease which was not\r\n      affected in a regular way <i>par ordonnance du mdecin</i>. But the\r\n      reverend gentlemen who had taken his case in hand still assumed the credit\r\n      of curing him, and if anything could have induced them to sing <i>Te Deum</i>,\r\n      it would have been this occasion. They said that the effect of their\r\n      public prayers had been for a time suspended, until seconded by the\r\n      continued earnestness of their private devotions!\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The ministers of the Church of England, though, from education,\r\n      intercourse with the world, and other advantages, they were less prone to\r\n      prejudice than those of other sects, are yet far from being entirely free\r\n      of the charge of encouraging in particular instances the witch\r\n      superstition. Even while Dr. Hutchison pleads that the Church of England\r\n      has the least to answer for in that matter, he is under the necessity of\r\n      acknowledging that some regular country clergymen so far shared the rooted\r\n      prejudices of congregations, and of the government which established laws\r\n      against it, as to be active in the persecution of the suspected, and even\r\n      in countenancing the superstitious signs by which in that period the\r\n      vulgar thought it possible to ascertain the existence of the afflictions\r\n      by witchcraft, and obtain the knowledge of the perpetrator. A singular\r\n      case is mentioned of three women, called the Witches of Warbois. Indeed,\r\n      their story is a matter of solemn enough record; for Sir Samuel Cromwell,\r\n      having received the sum of forty pounds as lord of the manor, out of the\r\n      estate of the poor persons who suffered, turned it into a rent-charge of\r\n      forty shillings yearly, for the endowment of an annual lecture on the\r\n      subject of witchcraft, to be preached by a doctor or bachelor of divinity\r\n      of Queen&rsquo;s College, Cambridge. The accused, one Samuel and his wife, were\r\n      old and very poor persons, and their daughter a young woman. The daughter\r\n      of a Mr. Throgmorton, seeing the poor old woman in a black knitted cap, at\r\n      a time when she was not very well, took a whim that she had bewitched her,\r\n      and was ever after exclaiming against her. The other children of this\r\n      fanciful family caught up the same cry, and the eldest of them at last got\r\n      up a vastly pretty drama, in which she herself furnished all the scenes\r\n      and played all the parts.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Such imaginary scenes, or <i>make-believe</i> stories, are the common\r\n      amusement of lively children; and most readers may remember having had\r\n      some Utopia of their own. But the nursery drama of Miss Throgmorton had a\r\n      horrible conclusion. This young lady and her sisters were supposed to be\r\n      haunted by nine spirits, dispatched by the wicked Mother Samuel for that\r\n      purpose. The sapient parents heard one part of the dialogue, when the\r\n      children in their fits returned answers, as was supposed, to the spirits\r\n      who afflicted them; and when the patients from time to time recovered,\r\n      they furnished the counterpart by telling what the spirits had said to\r\n      them. The names of the spirits were Pluck, Hardname, Catch, Blue, and\r\n      three Smacks, who were cousins. Mrs. Joan Throgmorton, the eldest (who,\r\n      like other young women of her age, about fifteen, had some disease on her\r\n      nerves, and whose fancy ran apparently on love and gallantry), supposed\r\n      that one of the Smacks was her lover, did battle for her with the less\r\n      friendly spirits, and promised to protect her against Mother Samuel\r\n      herself; and the following curious extract will show on what a footing of\r\n      familiarity the damsel stood with her spiritual gallant: &ldquo;From whence come\r\n      you, Mr. Smack?&rdquo; says the afflicted young lady; &ldquo;and what news do you\r\n      bring?&rdquo; Smack, nothing abashed, informed her he came from fighting with\r\n      Pluck: the weapons, great cowl-staves; the scene, a ruinous bakehouse in\r\n      Dame Samuel&rsquo;s yard. &ldquo;And who got the mastery, I pray you?&rdquo; said the\r\n      damsel. Smack answered, he had broken Pluck&rsquo;s head. &ldquo;I would,&rdquo; said the\r\n      damsel, &ldquo;he had broken your neck also.&rdquo; &ldquo;Is that the thanks I am to have\r\n      for my labour?&rdquo; said the disappointed Smack. &ldquo;Look you for thanks at my\r\n      hand?&rdquo; said the distressed maiden. &ldquo;I would you were all hanged up against\r\n      each other, with your dame for company, for you are all naught.&rdquo; On this\r\n      repulse, exit Smack, and enter Pluck, Blue, and Catch, the first with his\r\n      head broken, the other limping, and the third with his arm in a sling, all\r\n      trophies of Smack&rsquo;s victory. They disappeared after having threatened\r\n      vengeance upon the conquering Smack. However, he soon afterwards appeared\r\n      with his laurels. He told her of his various conflicts. &ldquo;I wonder,&rdquo; said\r\n      Mrs. Joan, or Jane, &ldquo;that you are able to beat them; you are little, and\r\n      they very big.&rdquo; &ldquo;He cared not for that,&rdquo; he replied; &ldquo;he would beat the\r\n      best two of them, and his cousins Smacks would beat the other two.&rdquo; This\r\n      most pitiful mirth, for such it certainly is, was mixed with tragedy\r\n      enough. Miss Throgmorton and her sisters railed against Darne Samuel; and\r\n      when Mr. Throgmorton brought her to his house by force, the little fiends\r\n      longed to draw blood of her, scratch her, and torture her, as the\r\n      witch-creed of that period recommended; yet the poor woman incurred deeper\r\n      suspicion when she expressed a wish to leave a house where she was so\r\n      coarsely treated and lay under such odious suspicions.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It was in vain that this unhappy creature endeavoured to avert their\r\n      resentment by submitting to all the ill-usage they chose to put upon her;\r\n      in vain that she underwent unresistingly the worst usage at the hand of\r\n      Lady Cromwell, her landlady, who, abusing her with the worst epithets,\r\n      tore her cap from her head, clipped out some of her hair, and gave it to\r\n      Mrs. Throgmorton to burn it for a counter-charm. Nay, Mother Samuel&rsquo;s\r\n      complaisance in the latter case only led to a new charge. It happened that\r\n      the Lady Cromwell, on her return home, dreamed of her day&rsquo;s work, and\r\n      especially of the old dame and her cat; and, as her ladyship died in a <i>year\r\n      and quarter</i> from that very day, it was sagaciously concluded that she\r\n      must have fallen a victim to the witcheries of the terrible Dame Samuel.\r\n      Mr. Throgmorton also compelled the old woman and her daughter to use\r\n      expressions which put their lives in the power of these malignant\r\n      children, who had carried on the farce so long that they could not well\r\n      escape from their own web of deceit but by the death of these helpless\r\n      creatures. For example, the prisoner, Dame Samuel, was induced to say to\r\n      the supposed spirit, &ldquo;As I am a witch, and a causer of Lady Cromwell&rsquo;s\r\n      death, I charge thee to come out of the maiden.&rdquo; The girl lay still; and\r\n      this was accounted a proof that the poor woman, who, only subdued and\r\n      crushed by terror and tyranny, did as she was bidden, was a witch. One is\r\n      ashamed of an English judge and jury when it must be repeated that the\r\n      evidence of these enthusiastic and giddy-pated girls was deemed sufficient\r\n      to the condemnation of three innocent persons. Goody Samuel, indeed, was\r\n      at length worried into a confession of her guilt by the various vexations\r\n      which were practised on her. But her husband and daughter continued to\r\n      maintain their innocence. The last showed a high spirit and proud value\r\n      for her character. She was advised by some, who pitied her youth, to gain\r\n      at least a respite by pleading pregnancy; to which she answered\r\n      disdainfully, &ldquo;No, I will not be both held witch and strumpet!&rdquo; The\r\n      mother, to show her sanity of mind and the real value of her confession,\r\n      caught at the advice recommended to her daughter. As her years put such a\r\n      plea out of the question, there was a laugh among the unfeeling audience,\r\n      in which the poor old victim joined loudly and heartily. Some there were\r\n      who thought it no joking matter, and were inclined to think they had a\r\n      Joanna Southcote before them, and that the devil must be the father. These\r\n      unfortunate Samuels were condemned at Huntingdon, before Mr. Justice\r\n      Fenner, 4th April, 1593. It was a singular case to be commemorated by an\r\n      annual lecture, as provided by Sir Samuel Cromwell, for the purposes of\r\n      justice were never so perverted, nor her sword turned to a more flagrant\r\n      murder.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      We may here mention, though mainly for the sake of contrast, the\r\n      much-disputed case of Jane Wenham, the Witch of Walkerne, as she was\r\n      termed, which was of a much later date.
