Some of the country clergy were\r\n      carried away by the land-flood of superstition in this instance also and\r\n      not only encouraged the charge, but gave their countenance to some of the\r\n      ridiculous and indecent tricks resorted to as proofs of witchcraft by the\r\n      lowest vulgar. But the good sense of the judge, seconded by that of other\r\n      reflecting and sensible persons, saved the country from the ultimate\r\n      disgrace attendant on too many of these unhallowed trials. The usual sort\r\n      of evidence was brought against this poor woman, by pretences of bewitched\r\n      persons vomiting fire&mdash;a trick very easy to those who chose to\r\n      exhibit such a piece of jugglery amongst such as rather desire to be taken\r\n      in by it than to detect the imposture. The witchfinder practised upon her\r\n      the most vulgar and ridiculous tricks or charms; and out of a perverted\r\n      examination they drew what they called a confession, though of a forced\r\n      and mutilated character. Under such proof the jury brought her in guilty,\r\n      and she was necessarily condemned to die. More fortunate, however, than\r\n      many persons placed in the like circumstances, Jane Wenham was tried\r\n      before a sensible and philosophic judge, who could not understand that the\r\n      life of an Englishwoman, however mean, should be taken away by a set of\r\n      barbarous tricks and experiments, the efficacy of which depended on\r\n      popular credulity. He reprieved the witch before he left the assize-town.\r\n      The rest of the history is equally a contrast to some we have told and\r\n      others we shall have to recount. A humane and high-spirited gentleman,\r\n      Colonel Plummer of Gilston, putting at defiance popular calumny, placed\r\n      the poor old woman in a small house near his own and under his immediate\r\n      protection. Here she lived and died, in honest and fair reputation,\r\n      edifying her visitors by her accuracy and attention in repeating her\r\n      devotions; and, removed from her brutal and malignant neighbours, never\r\n      afterwards gave the slightest cause of suspicion or offence till her dying\r\n      day. As this was one of the last cases of conviction in England, Dr\r\n      Hutchison has been led to dilate upon it with some strength of eloquence\r\n      as well as argument.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      He thus expostulates with some of the better class who were eager for the\r\n      prosecution:&mdash;&ldquo;(1) What single fact of sorcery did this Jane Wenham\r\n      do? What charm did she use, or what act of witchcraft could you prove upon\r\n      her? Laws are against evil actions that can be proved to be of the\r\n      person&rsquo;s doing. What single fact that was against the statute could you\r\n      fix upon her? I ask (2) Did she so much as speak an imprudent word, or do\r\n      an immoral action, that you could put into the narrative of her case? When\r\n      she was denied a few turnips, she laid them down very submissively; when\r\n      she was called witch and bitch, she only took the proper means for the\r\n      vindication of her good name; when she saw this storm coming upon her she\r\n      locked herself in her own house and tried to keep herself out of your\r\n      cruel hands; when her door was broken open, and you gave way to that\r\n      barbarous usage that she met with, she protested her innocence, fell upon\r\n      her knees, and begged she might not go to gaol, and, in her innocent\r\n      simplicity, would have let you swim her; and at her trial she declared\r\n      herself a clear woman. This was her behaviour. And what could any of us\r\n      have done better, excepting in that case where she complied with you too\r\n      much, and offered to let you swim her?\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;(3) When you used the meanest of paganish and popish superstitions&mdash;when\r\n      you scratched and mangled and ran pins into her flesh, and used that\r\n      ridiculous trial of the bottle, &amp;c.&mdash;whom did you consult, and\r\n      from whom did you expect your answers? Who was your father? and into whose\r\n      hands did you put yourselves? and (if the true sense of the statute had\r\n      been turned upon you) which way would you have defended yourselves? (4)\r\n      Durst you have used her in this manner if she had been rich? and doth not\r\n      her poverty increase rather than lessen your guilt in what you did?\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;And therefore, instead of closing your book with a <i>liberavimus animas\r\n      nostras</i>, and reflecting upon the court, I ask you (5) Whether you have\r\n      not more reason to give God thanks that you met with a wise judge, and a\r\n      sensible gentleman, who kept you from shedding innocent blood, and\r\n      reviving the meanest and cruelest of all superstitions amongst us?"<a\r\n      href="#linknote-55" name="linknoteref-55" id="linknoteref-55"><small>55</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-55" id="linknote-55"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      55 (<a href="#linknoteref-55">return</a>)<br /> [ Hutchison&rsquo;s &ldquo;Essay on\r\n      Witchcraft,&rdquo; p. 166.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      But although individuals of the English Church might on some occasions be\r\n      justly accused of falling into lamentable errors on a subject where error\r\n      was so general, it was not an usual point of their professional character;\r\n      and it must be admitted that the most severe of the laws against\r\n      witchcraft originated with a Scottish King of England, and that the only\r\n      extensive persecution following that statute occurred during the time of\r\n      the Civil Wars, when the Calvinists obtained for a short period a\r\n      predominating influence in the councils of Parliament.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      James succeeded to Elizabeth amidst the highest expectations on the part\r\n      of his new people, who, besides their general satisfaction at coming once\r\n      more under the rule of a king, were also proud of his supposed abilities\r\n      and real knowledge of books and languages, and were naturally, though\r\n      imprudently, disposed to gratify him by deferring to his judgment in\r\n      matters wherein his studies were supposed to have rendered him a special\r\n      proficient. Unfortunately, besides the more harmless freak of becoming a\r\n      prentice in the art of poetry, by which words and numbers were the only\r\n      sufferers, the monarch had composed a deep work upon Demonology, embracing\r\n      in their fullest extent the most absurd and gross of the popular errors on\r\n      this subject. He considered his crown and life as habitually aimed at by\r\n      the sworn slaves of Satan. Several had been executed for an attempt to\r\n      poison him by magical arts; and the turbulent Francis Stewart, Earl of\r\n      Bothwell, whose repeated attempts on his person had long been James&rsquo;s\r\n      terror, had begun his course of rebellion by a consultation with the weird\r\n      sisters and soothsayers. Thus the king, who had proved with his pen the\r\n      supposed sorcerers to be the direct enemies of the Deity, and who\r\n      conceived he knew them from experience to be his own&mdash;who, moreover,\r\n      had upon much lighter occasions (as in the case of Vorstius) showed no\r\n      hesitation at throwing his royal authority into the scale to aid his\r\n      arguments&mdash;very naturally used his influence, when it was at the\r\n      highest, to extend and enforce the laws against a crime which he both\r\n      hated and feared.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The English statute against witchcraft, passed in the very first year of\r\n      that reign, is therefore of a most special nature, describing witchcraft\r\n      by all the various modes and ceremonies in which, according to King\r\n      James&rsquo;s fancy, that crime could be perpetrated; each of which was declared\r\n      felony, without benefit of clergy.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      This gave much wider scope to prosecution on the statute than had existed\r\n      under the milder acts of Elizabeth. Men might now be punished for the\r\n      practice of witchcraft, as itself a crime, without necessary reference to\r\n      the ulterior objects of the perpetrator. It is remarkable that in the same\r\n      year, when the legislature rather adopted the passions and fears of the\r\n      king than expressed their own by this fatal enactment, the Convocation of\r\n      the Church evinced a very different spirit; for, seeing the ridicule\r\n      brought on their sacred profession by forward and presumptuous men, in the\r\n      attempt to relieve demoniacs from a disease which was commonly occasioned\r\n      by natural causes, if not the mere creature of imposture, they passed a\r\n      canon, establishing that no minister or ministers should in future attempt\r\n      to expel any devil or devils, without the license of his bishop; thereby\r\n      virtually putting a stop to a fertile source of knavery among the people,\r\n      and disgraceful folly among the inferior churchmen.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The new statute of James does not, however, appear to have led at first to\r\n      many prosecutions. One of the most remarkable was (<i>proh pudor!</i>)\r\n      instigated by a gentleman, a scholar of classical taste, and a beautiful\r\n      poet, being no other than Edward Fairfax of Fayston, in Knaresborough\r\n      Forest, the translator of Tasso&rsquo;s &ldquo;Jerusalem Delivered.&rdquo; In allusion to\r\n      his credulity on such subjects, Collins has introduced the following\r\n      elegant lines:&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n<pre xml:space="preserve">\r\n&ldquo;How have I sate while piped the pensive wind,\r\n  To hear thy harp, by British Fairfax strung;\r\nPrevailing poet, whose undoubting mind\r\n  Believed the magic wonders which he sung!&rdquo;\r\n </pre>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Like Mr. Throgmorton in the Warbois case, Mr. Fairfax accused six of his\r\n      neighbours of tormenting his children by fits of an extraordinary kind, by\r\n      imps, and by appearing before the afflicted in their own shape during the\r\n      crisis of these operations. The admitting this last circumstance to be a\r\n      legitimate mode of proof, gave a most cruel advantage against the accused,\r\n      for it could not, according to the ideas of the demonologists, be confuted\r\n      even by the most distinct <i>alibi</i>. To a defence of that sort it was\r\n      replied that the afflicted person did not see the actual witch, whose\r\n      corporeal presence must indeed have been obvious to every one in the room\r\n      as well as to the afflicted, but that the evidence of the sufferers\r\n      related to the appearance of their <i>spectre</i>, or apparition; and this\r\n      was accounted a sure sign of guilt in those whose forms were so manifested\r\n      during the fits of the afflicted, and who were complained of and cried out\r\n      upon by the victim. The obvious tendency of this doctrine, as to visionary\r\n      or spectral evidence, as it was called, was to place the life and fame of\r\n      the accused in the power of any hypochondriac patient or malignant\r\n      impostor, who might either seem to see, or aver she saw, the <i>spectrum</i>\r\n      of the accused old man or old woman, as if enjoying and urging on the\r\n      afflictions which she complained of; and, strange to tell, the fatal\r\n      sentence was to rest, not upon the truth of the witnesses&rsquo; eyes, but that\r\n      of their imagination. It happened fortunately for Fairfax&rsquo;s memory, that\r\n      the objects of his prosecution were persons of good character, and that\r\n      the judge was a man of sense, and made so wise and skilful a charge to the\r\n      jury, that they brought in a verdict of not guilty.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The celebrated case of &ldquo;the Lancashire witches&rdquo; (whose name was and will\r\n      be long remembered, partly from Shadwell&rsquo;s play, but more from the\r\n      ingenious and well-merited compliment to the beauty of the females of that\r\n      province which it was held to contain), followed soon after. Whether the\r\n      first notice of this sorcery sprung from the idle head of a mischievous\r\n      boy, is uncertain; but there is no doubt that it was speedily caught up\r\n      and fostered for the purpose of gain. The original story ran thus:&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      These Lancaster trials were at two periods, the one in 1613, before Sir\r\n      James Altham and Sir Edward Bromley, Barons of Exchequer, when nineteen\r\n      witches were tried at once at Lancaster, and another of the name of\r\n      Preston at York. The report against these people is drawn up by Thomas\r\n      Potts. An obliging correspondent sent me a sight of a copy of this curious\r\n      and rare book. The chief personage in the drama is Elizabeth Southam, a\r\n      witch redoubted under the name of Dembdike, an account of whom may be seen\r\n      in Mr. Roby&rsquo;s &ldquo;Antiquities of Lancaster,&rdquo; as well as a description of\r\n      Maulkins&rsquo; Tower, the witches&rsquo; place of meeting. It appears that this\r\n      remote county was full of Popish recusants, travelling priests, and so\r\n      forth; and some of their spells are given in which the holy names and\r\n      things alluded to form a strange contrast with the purpose to which they\r\n      were applied, as to secure a good brewing of ale or the like. The public\r\n      imputed to the accused parties a long train of murders, conspiracies,\r\n      charms, mischances, hellish and damnable practices, &ldquo;apparent,&rdquo; says the\r\n      editor, &ldquo;on their own examinations and confessions,&rdquo; and, to speak the\r\n      truth, visible nowhere else. Mother Dembdike had the good luck to die\r\n      before conviction. Among other tales, we have one of two <i>female</i>\r\n      devils, called Fancy and Tib. It is remarkable that some of the\r\n      unfortunate women endeavoured to transfer the guilt from themselves to\r\n      others with whom they had old quarrels, which confessions were held good\r\n      evidence against those who made them, and against the alleged accomplice\r\n      also. Several of the unhappy women were found not guilty, to the great\r\n      displeasure of the ignorant people of the county. Such was the first\r\n      edition of the Lancashire witches. In that which follows the accusation\r\n      can be more clearly traced to the most villanous conspiracy.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      About 1634 a boy called Edmund Robinson, whose father, a very poor man,\r\n      dwelt in Pendle Forest, the scene of the alleged witching, declared that\r\n      while gathering <i>bullees</i> (wild plums, perhaps) in one of the glades\r\n      of the forest, he saw two greyhounds, which he imagined to belong to\r\n      gentlemen in that neighbourhood. The boy reported that, seeing nobody\r\n      following them, he proposed to have a course; but though a hare was\r\n      started, the dogs refused to run. On this, young Robinson was about to\r\n      punish them with a switch, when one Dame Dickenson, a neighbour&rsquo;s wife,\r\n      started up instead of the one greyhound; a little boy instead of the\r\n      other. The witness averred that Mother Dickenson offered him money to\r\n      conceal what he had seen, which he refused, saying &ldquo;Nay, thou art a\r\n      witch.&rdquo; Apparently she was determined he should have full evidence of the\r\n      truth of what he said, for, like the Magician Queen in the Arabian Tales,\r\n      she pulled out of her pocket a bridle and shook it over the head of the\r\n      boy who had so lately represented the other greyhound. He was directly\r\n      changed into a horse; Mother Dickenson mounted, and took Robinson before\r\n      her. They then rode to a large house or barn called Hourstoun, into which\r\n      Edmund Robinson entered with others. He there saw six or seven persons\r\n      pulling at halters, from which, as they pulled them, meat ready dressed\r\n      came flying in quantities, together with lumps of butter, porringers of\r\n      milk, and whatever else might, in the boy&rsquo;s fancy, complete a rustic\r\n      feast. He declared that while engaged in the charm they made such ugly\r\n      faces and looked so fiendish that he was frightened. There was more to the\r\n      same purpose&mdash;as the boy&rsquo;s having seen one of these hags sitting\r\n      half-way up his father&rsquo;s chimney, and some such goodly matter. But it\r\n      ended in near a score of persons being committed to prison; and the\r\n      consequence was that young Robinson was carried from church to church in\r\n      the neighbourhood, that he might recognise the faces of any persons he had\r\n      seen at the rendezvous of witches. Old Robinson, who had been an evidence\r\n      against the former witches in 1613, went along with his son, and knew,\r\n      doubtless, how to make his journey profitable; and his son probably took\r\n      care to recognise none who might make a handsome consideration. &ldquo;This\r\n      boy,&rdquo; says Webster, &ldquo;was brought into the church at Kildwick, a parish\r\n      church, where I, being then curate there, was preaching at the time, to\r\n      look about him, which made some little disturbance for the time.&rdquo; After\r\n      prayers Mr. Webster sought and found the boy, and two very unlikely\r\n      persons, who, says he, &ldquo;did conduct him and manage the business: I did\r\n      desire some discourse with the boy in private, but that they utterly\r\n      denied. In the presence of a great many many people I took the boy near me\r\n      and said, &lsquo;Good boy, tell me truly and in earnest, didst thou hear and see\r\n      such strange things of the motions of the witches as many do report that\r\n      thou didst relate, or did not some person teach thee to say such things of\r\n      thyself?&rsquo; But the two men did pluck the boy from me, and said he had been\r\n      examined by two able justices of peace, and they never asked him such a\r\n      question. To whom I replied, &lsquo;The persons accused had the more wrong.&rsquo;&rdquo;\r\n       The boy afterwards acknowledged, in his more advanced years, that he was\r\n      instructed and suborned to swear these things against the accused persons\r\n      by his father and others, and was heard often to confess that on the day\r\n      which he pretended to see the said witches at the house or barn, he was\r\n      gathering plums in a neighbour&rsquo;s orchard.<a href="#linknote-56"\r\n       name="linknoteref-56" id="linknoteref-56"><small>56</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-56" id="linknote-56"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      56 (<a href="#linknoteref-56">return</a>)<br /> [ Webster on Witchcraft,\r\n      edition 1677, p. 278.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      There was now approaching a time when the law against witchcraft,\r\n      sufficiently bloody in itself, was to be pushed to more violent\r\n      extremities than the quiet scepticism of the Church of England clergy gave\r\n      way to. The great Civil War had been preceded and anticipated by the\r\n      fierce disputes of the ecclesiastical parties. The rash and ill-judged\r\n      attempt to enforce upon the Scottish a compliance with the government and\r\n      ceremonies of the High Church divines, and the severe prosecutions in the\r\n      Star Chamber and Prerogative Courts, had given the Presbyterian system for\r\n      a season a great degree of popularity in England; and as the King&rsquo;s party\r\n      declined during the Civil War, and the state of church-government was\r\n      altered, the influence of the Calvinistic divines increased. With much\r\n      strict morality and pure practice of religion, it is to be regretted these\r\n      were still marked by unhesitating belief in the existence of sorcery, and\r\n      a keen desire to extend and enforce the legal penalties against it. Wier\r\n      has considered the clergy of every sect as being too eager in this species\r\n      of persecution: <i>Ad gravem hanc impietatem, connivent theologi plerique\r\n      omnes</i>. But it is not to be denied that the Presbyterian ecclesiastics\r\n      who, in Scotland, were often appointed by the Privy Council Commissioners\r\n      for the trial of witchcraft, evinced a very extraordinary degree of\r\n      credulity in such cases, and that the temporary superiority of the same\r\n      sect in England was marked by enormous cruelties of this kind. To this\r\n      general error we must impute the misfortune that good men, such as Calamy\r\n      and Baxter, should have countenanced or defended such proceedings as those\r\n      of the impudent and cruel wretch called Matthew Hopkins, who, in those\r\n      unsettled times, when men did what seemed good in their own eyes, assumed\r\n      the title of Witchfinder General, and, travelling through the counties of\r\n      Essex, Sussex, Norfolk, and Huntingdon, pretended to discover witches,\r\n      superintending their examination by the most unheard-of tortures, and\r\n      compelling forlorn and miserable wretches to admit and confess matters\r\n      equally absurd and impossible; the issue of which was the forfeiture of\r\n      their lives. Before examining these cases more minutely, I will quote\r\n      Baxter&rsquo;s own words; for no one can have less desire to wrong a devout and\r\n      conscientious man, such as that divine most unquestionably was, though\r\n      borne aside on this occasion by prejudice and credulity.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;The hanging of a great number of witches in 1645 and 1646 is famously\r\n      known. Mr. Calamy went along with the judges on the circuit to hear their\r\n      confessions, and see there was no fraud or wrong done them. I spoke with\r\n      many understanding, pious, learned, and credible persons that lived in the\r\n      counties, and some that went to them in the prisons, and heard their sad\r\n      confessions. Among the rest an old <i>reading parson</i>, named Lowis, not\r\n      far from Framlingham, was one that was hanged, who confessed that he had\r\n      two imps, and that one of them was always putting him upon doing mischief;\r\n      and he, being near the sea, as he saw a ship under sail, it moved him to\r\n      send it to sink the ship; and he consented, and saw the ship sink before\r\n      them.&rdquo; Mr. Baxter passes on to another story of a mother who gave her\r\n      child an imp like a mole, and told her to keep it in a can near the fire,\r\n      and she would never want; and more such stuff as nursery-maids tell\r\n      froward children to keep them quiet.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It is remarkable that in this passage Baxter names the Witchfinder General\r\n      rather slightly as &ldquo;one Hopkins,&rdquo; and without doing him the justice due to\r\n      one who had discovered more than one hundred witches, and brought them to\r\n      confessions, which that good man received as indubitable. Perhaps the\r\n      learned divine was one of those who believed that the Witchfinder General\r\n      had cheated the devil out of a certain memorandum-book, in which Satan,\r\n      for the benefit of his memory certainly, had entered all the witches&rsquo;\r\n      names in England, and that Hopkins availed himself of this record.<a\r\n      href="#linknote-57" name="linknoteref-57" id="linknoteref-57"><small>57</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-57" id="linknote-57"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      57 (<a href="#linknoteref-57">return</a>)<br /> [ This reproach is noticed\r\n      in a very rare tract, which was bought at Mr. Lort&rsquo;s sale, by the\r\n      celebrated collector Mr. Bindley, and is now in the author&rsquo;s possession.\r\n      Its full title is, &ldquo;The Discovery of Witches, in Answer to several Queries\r\n      lately delivered to the Judge of Assize for the County of Norfolk; and now\r\n      published by Matthew Hopkins, Witchfinder, for the Benefit of the whole\r\n      Kingdom. Printed for R. Royston, at the Angel, in Inn Lane. 1647.&rdquo;]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It may be noticed that times of misrule and violence seem to create\r\n      individuals fitted to take advantage from them, and having a character\r\n      suited to the seasons which raise them into notice and action; just as a\r\n      blight on any tree or vegetable calls to life a peculiar insect to feed\r\n      upon and enjoy the decay which it has produced. A monster like Hopkins\r\n      could only have existed during the confusion of civil dissension. He was\r\n      perhaps a native of Manningtree, in Essex; at any rate, he resided there\r\n      in the year 1644, when an epidemic outcry of witchcraft arose in that\r\n      town. Upon this occasion he had made himself busy, and, affecting more\r\n      zeal and knowledge than other men, learned his trade of a witchfinder, as\r\n      he pretends, from experiment. He was afterwards permitted to perform it as\r\n      a legal profession, and moved from one place to another, with an assistant\r\n      named Sterne, and a female. In his defence against an accusation of\r\n      fleecing the country, he declares his regular charge was twenty shillings\r\n      a town, including charges of living and journeying thither and back again\r\n      with his assistants. He also affirms that he went nowhere unless called\r\n      and invited. His principal mode of discovery was to strip the accused\r\n      persons naked, and thrust pins into various parts of their body, to\r\n      discover the witch&rsquo;s mark, which was supposed to be inflicted by the devil\r\n      as a sign of his sovereignty, and at which she was also said to suckle her\r\n      imps. He also practised and stoutly defended the trial by swimming, when\r\n      the suspected person was wrapped in a sheet, having the great toes and\r\n      thumbs tied together, and so dragged through a pond or river. If she sank,\r\n      it was received in favour of the accused; but if the body floated (which\r\n      must have occurred ten times for once, if it was placed with care on the\r\n      surface of the water), the accused was condemned, on the principle of King\r\n      James, who, in treating of this mode of trial, lays down that, as witches\r\n      have renounced their baptism, so it is just that the element through which\r\n      the holy rite is enforced should reject them, which is a figure of speech,\r\n      and no argument. It was Hopkins&rsquo;s custom to keep the poor wretches waking,\r\n      in order to prevent them from having encouragement from the devil, and,\r\n      doubtless, to put infirm, terrified, overwatched persons in the next state\r\n      to absolute madness; and for the same purpose they were dragged about by\r\n      their keepers till extreme weariness and the pain of blistered feet might\r\n      form additional inducements to confession. Hopkins confesses these last\r\n      practices of keeping the accused persons waking, and forcing them to walk\r\n      for the same purpose, had been originally used by him. But as his tract is\r\n      a professed answer to charges of cruelty and oppression, he affirms that\r\n      both practices were then disused, and that they had not of late been\r\n      resorted to.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The boast of the English nation is a manly independence and common-sense,\r\n      which will not long permit the license of tyranny or oppression on the\r\n      meanest and most obscure sufferers. Many clergymen and gentlemen made head\r\n      against the practices of this cruel oppressor of the defenceless, and it\r\n      required courage to do so when such an unscrupulous villain had so much\r\n      interest.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Mr. Gaul, a clergyman, of Houghton, in Huntingdonshire, had the courage to\r\n      appear in print on the weaker side; and Hopkins, in consequence, assumed\r\n      the assurance to write to some functionaries of the place the following\r\n      letter, which is an admirable medley of impudence, bullying, and\r\n      cowardice:&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;My service to your worship presented.&mdash;I have this day received a\r\n      letter to come to a town called Great Houghton to search for evil-disposed\r\n      persons called witches (though I hear your minister is far against us,\r\n      through ignorance). I intend to come, God willing, the sooner to hear his\r\n      singular judgment in the behalf of such parties. I have known a minister\r\n      in Suffolk as much against this discovery in a pulpit, and forced to\r\n      recant it by the Committee<a href="#linknote-58" name="linknoteref-58"\r\n       id="linknoteref-58"><small>58</small></a> in the same place. I much marvel\r\n      such evil men should have any (much more any of the clergy, who should\r\n      daily speak terror to convince such offenders) stand up to take their\r\n      parts against such as are complainants for the king, and sufferers\r\n      themselves, with their families and estates. I intend to give your town a\r\n      visit suddenly. I will come to Kimbolton this week, and it will be ten to\r\n      one but I will come to your town first; but I would certainly know before\r\n      whether your town affords many sticklers for such cattle, or is willing to\r\n      give and allow us good welcome and entertainment, as others where I have\r\n      been, else I shall waive your shire (not as yet beginning in any part of\r\n      it myself), and betake me to such places where I do and may punish (not\r\n      only) without control, but with thanks and recompense. So I humbly take my\r\n      leave, and rest your servant to be commanded,\r\n    </p>\r\n    <h3>\r\n      &ldquo;MATTHEW HOPKINS.&rdquo;\r\n     </h3>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-58" id="linknote-58"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      58 (<a href="#linknoteref-58">return</a>)<br /> [ Of Parliament.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The sensible and courageous Mr. Gaul describes the tortures employed by\r\n      this fellow as equal to any practised in the Inquisition. &ldquo;Having taken\r\n      the suspected witch, she is placed in the middle of a room, upon a stool\r\n      or table, cross-legged, or in some other uneasy posture, to which, if she\r\n      submits not, she is then bound with cords; there she is watched and kept\r\n      without meat or sleep for four-and-twenty hours, for, they say, they shall\r\n      within that time see her imp come and suck. A little hole is likewise made\r\n      in the door for the imps to come in at; and lest they should come in some\r\n      less discernible shape, they that watch are taught to be ever and anon\r\n      sweeping the room, and if they see any spiders or flies, to kill them; and\r\n      if they cannot kill them, they may be sure they are their imps.&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      If torture of this kind was applied to the Reverend Mr. Lewis, whose death\r\n      is too slightly announced by Mr. Baxter, we can conceive him, or any man,\r\n      to have indeed become so weary of his life as to acknowledge that, by\r\n      means of his imps, he sunk a vessel, without any purpose of gratification\r\n      to be procured to himself by such iniquity. But in another cause a judge\r\n      would have demanded some proof of the <i>corpus delecti</i>, some evidence\r\n      of a vessel being lost at the period, whence coming and whither bound; in\r\n      short, something to establish that the whole story was not the idle\r\n      imagination of a man who might have been entirely deranged, and certainly\r\n      was so at the time he made the admission. John Lewis was presented to the\r\n      vicarage of Brandiston, near Framlington, in Suffolk, 6th May, 1596, where\r\n      he lived about fifty years, till executed as a wizard on such evidence as\r\n      we have seen. Notwithstanding the story of his alleged confession, he\r\n      defended himself courageously at his trial, and was probably condemned\r\n      rather as a royalist and malignant than for any other cause. He showed at\r\n      the execution considerable energy, and to secure that the funeral service\r\n      of the church should be said over his body, he read it aloud for himself\r\n      while on the road to the gibbet.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      We have seen that in 1647 Hopkins&rsquo;s tone became lowered, and he began to\r\n      disavow some of the cruelties he had formerly practised. About the same\r\n      time a miserable old woman had fallen into the cruel hands of this\r\n      miscreant near Hoxne, a village in Suffolk, and had confessed all the\r\n      usual enormities, after being without food or rest a sufficient time. &ldquo;Her\r\n      imp,&rdquo; she said, &ldquo;was called Nan.&rdquo; A gentleman in the neighbourhood, whose\r\n      widow survived to authenticate the story, was so indignant that he went to\r\n      the house, took the woman out of such inhuman hands, dismissed the\r\n      witchfinders, and after due food and rest the poor old woman could\r\n      recollect nothing of the confession, but that she gave a favourite pullet\r\n      the name of Nan. For this Dr. Hutchison may be referred to, who quotes a\r\n      letter from the relict of the humane gentleman.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In the year 1645 a Commission of Parliament was sent down, comprehending\r\n      two clergymen in esteem with the leading party, one of whom, Mr.\r\n      Fairclough of Kellar, preached before the rest on the subject of\r\n      witchcraft; and after this appearance of enquiry the inquisitions and\r\n      executions went on as before. But the popular indignation was so strongly\r\n      excited against Hopkins, that some gentlemen seized on him, and put him to\r\n      his own favourite experiment of swimming, on which, as he happened to\r\n      float, he stood convicted of witchcraft, and so the country was rid of\r\n      him. Whether he was drowned outright or not does not exactly appear, but\r\n      he has had the honour to be commemorated by the author of Hudibras:&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n<pre xml:space="preserve">\r\n     &ldquo;Hath not this present Parliament\r\n     A leiger to the devil sent,\r\n     Fully empower&rsquo;d to treat about\r\n     Finding revolted witches out?\r\n     And has he not within a year\r\n     Hang&rsquo;d threescore of them in one shire?\r\n     Some only for not being drown&rsquo;d,\r\n     And some for sitting above ground\r\n     Whole days and nights upon their breeches,\r\n     And feeling pain, were hang&rsquo;d for witches.\r\n     And some for putting knavish tricks\r\n     Upon green geese or turkey chicks;\r\n     Or pigs that suddenly deceased\r\n     Of griefs unnatural, as he guess&rsquo;d,\r\n     Who proved himself at length a witch,\r\n     And made a rod for his own breech.&rdquo; <a href="#linknote-59"\r\n       name="linknoteref-59" id="linknoteref-59">59</a>\r\n</pre>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-59" id="linknote-59"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      59 (<a href="#linknoteref-59">return</a>)<br /> [ &ldquo;Hudibras,&rdquo; part ii.\r\n      canto 3.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The understanding reader will easily conceive that this alteration of the\r\n      current in favour of those who disapproved of witch-prosecutions, must\r\n      have received encouragement from some quarter of weight and influence; yet\r\n      it may sound strangely enough that this spirit of lenity should have been\r\n      the result of the peculiar principles of those sectarians of all\r\n      denominations, classed in general as Independents, who, though they had\r\n      originally courted the Presbyterians as the more numerous and prevailing\r\n      party, had at length shaken themselves loose of that connexion, and\r\n      finally combated with and overcome them. The Independents were\r\n      distinguished by the wildest license in their religious tenets, mixed with\r\n      much that was nonsensical and mystical. They disowned even the title of a\r\n      regular clergy, and allowed the preaching of any one who could draw\r\n      together a congregation that would support him, or who was willing,\r\n      without recompense, to minister to the spiritual necessities of his\r\n      hearers. Although such laxity of discipline afforded scope to the wildest\r\n      enthusiasm, and room for all possible varieties of doctrine, it had, on\r\n      the other hand, this inestimable recommendation, that it contributed to a\r\n      degree of general toleration which was at that time unknown to any other\r\n      Christian establishment. The very genius of a religion which admitted of\r\n      the subdivision of sects <i>ad infinitum</i>, excluded a legal prosecution\r\n      of any one of these for heresy or apostasy. If there had even existed a\r\n      sect of Manichans, who made it their practice to adore the Evil\r\n      Principle, it may be doubted whether the other sectaries would have\r\n      accounted them absolute outcasts from the pale of the church; and,\r\n      fortunately, the same sentiment induced them to regard with horror the\r\n      prosecutions against witchcraft. Thus the Independents, when, under\r\n      Cromwell, they attained a supremacy over the Presbyterians, who to a\r\n      certain point had been their allies, were disposed to counteract the\r\n      violence of such proceedings under pretence of witchcraft, as had been\r\n      driven forward by the wretched Hopkins, in Essex, Norfolk, and Suffolk,\r\n      for three or four years previous to 1647.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The return of Charles II. to his crown and kingdom, served in some measure\r\n      to restrain the general and wholesale manner in which the laws against\r\n      witchcraft had been administered during the warmth of the Civil War. The\r\n      statute of the 1st of King James, nevertheless, yet subsisted; nor is it\r\n      in the least likely, considering the character of the prince, that he, to\r\n      save the lives of a few old men or women, would have run the risk of\r\n      incurring the odium of encouraging or sparing a crime still held in horror\r\n      by a great part of his subjects. The statute, however, was generally\r\n      administered by wise and skilful judges, and the accused had such a chance\r\n      of escape as the rigour of the absurd law permitted.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Nonsense, it is too obvious, remained in some cases predominant. In the\r\n      year 1663 an old dame, named Julian Coxe, was convicted chiefly on the\r\n      evidence of a huntsman, who declared on his oath, that he laid his\r\n      greyhounds on a hare, and coming up to the spot where he saw them mouth\r\n      her, there he found, on the other side of a bush, Julian Coxe lying\r\n      panting and breathless, in such a manner as to convince him that she had\r\n      been the creature which afforded him the course. The unhappy woman was\r\n      executed on this evidence.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Two years afterwards (1664), it is with regret we must quote the venerable\r\n      and devout Sir Matthew Hales, as presiding at a trial, in consequence of\r\n      which Amy Dunny and Rose Callender were hanged at Saint Edmondsbury. But\r\n      no man, unless very peculiarly circumstanced, can extricate himself from\r\n      the prejudices of his nation and age. The evidence against the accused was\r\n      laid, 1st, on the effect of spells used by ignorant persons to counteract\r\n      the supposed witchcraft; the use of which was, under the statute of James\r\n      I., as criminal as the act of sorcery which such counter-charms were meant\r\n      to neutralize, 2ndly, The two old women, refused even the privilege of\r\n      purchasing some herrings, having expressed themselves with angry\r\n      impatience, a child of the herring-merchant fell ill in consequence.\r\n      3rdly, A cart was driven against the miserable cottage of Amy Dunny. She\r\n      scolded, of course; and shortly after the cart&mdash;(what a good driver\r\n      will scarce comprehend)&mdash;stuck fast in a gate, where its wheels\r\n      touched neither of the posts, and yet was moved easily forward on one of\r\n      the posts (by which it was <i>not</i> impeded) being cut down. 4thly, One\r\n      of the afflicted girls being closely muffled, went suddenly into a fit\r\n      upon being touched by one of the supposed witches. But upon another trial\r\n      it was found that the person so blindfolded fell into the same rage at the\r\n      touch of an unsuspected person. What perhaps sealed the fate of the\r\n      accused was the evidence of the celebrated Sir Thomas Browne, &ldquo;that the\r\n      fits were natural, but heightened by the power of the devil co-operating\r\n      with the malice of witches;&rdquo;&mdash;a strange opinion, certainly, from the\r\n      author of a treatise on &ldquo;Vulgar Errors!&rdquo;<a href="#linknote-60"\r\n       name="linknoteref-60" id="linknoteref-60"><small>60</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-60" id="linknote-60"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      60 (<a href="#linknoteref-60">return</a>)<br /> [ See the account of Sir T.\r\n      Browne in No. XIV. of the &ldquo;Family Library&rdquo; (&ldquo;Lives of British\r\n      Physicians&rdquo;), p. 60.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      But the torch of science was now fairly lighted, and gleamed in more than\r\n      one kingdom of the world, shooting its rays on every side, and catching at\r\n      all means which were calculated to increase the illumination. The Royal\r\n      Society, which had taken its rise at Oxford from a private association who\r\n      met in Dr. Wilkin&rsquo;s chambers about the year 1652, was, the year after the\r\n      Restoration, incorporated by royal charter, and began to publish their\r\n      Transactions, and give a new and more rational character to the pursuits\r\n      of philosophy.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In France, where the mere will of the government could accomplish greater\r\n      changes, the consequence of an enlarged spirit of scientific discovery\r\n      was, that a decisive stop was put to the witch-prosecutions which had\r\n      heretofore been as common in that kingdom as in England. About the year\r\n      1672 there was a general arrest of very many shepherds and others in\r\n      Normandy, and the Parliament of Rouen prepared to proceed in the\r\n      investigation with the usual severity. But an order, or <i>arret</i>, from\r\n      the king (Louis XIV.), with advice of his council, commanding all these\r\n      unfortunate persons to be set at liberty and protected, had the most\r\n      salutary effects all over the kingdom. The French Academy of Sciences was\r\n      also founded; and, in imitation, a society of learned Germans established\r\n      a similar institution at Leipsic. Prejudices, however old, were overawed\r\n      and controlled&mdash;much was accounted for on natural principles that had\r\n      hitherto been imputed to spiritual agency&mdash;everything seemed to\r\n      promise that farther access to the secrets of nature might be opened to\r\n      those who should prosecute their studies experimentally and by analysis&mdash;and\r\n      the mass of ancient opinions which overwhelmed the dark subject of which\r\n      we treat began to be derided and rejected by men of sense and education.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In many cases the prey was now snatched from the spoiler. A pragmatical\r\n      justice of peace in Somersetshire commenced a course of enquiry after\r\n      offenders against the statute of James I., and had he been allowed to\r\n      proceed, Mr. Hunt might have gained a name as renowned for witch-finding\r\n      as that of Mr. Hopkins; but his researches were stopped from higher\r\n      authority&mdash;the lives of the poor people arrested (twelve in number)\r\n      were saved, and the country remained at quiet, though the supposed witches\r\n      were suffered to live. The examinations attest some curious particulars,\r\n      which may be found in <i>Sadducismus Triumphatus</i>: for among the usual\r\n      string of froward, fanciful, or, as they were called, afflicted children,\r\n      brought forward to club their startings, starings, and screamings, there\r\n      appeared also certain remarkable confessions of the accused, from which we\r\n      learn that the Somerset Satan enlisted his witches, like a wily recruiting\r\n      sergeant, with one shilling in hand and twelve in promises; that when the\r\n      party of weird-sisters passed to the witch-meeting they used the magic\r\n      words, <i>Thout, tout, throughout, and about</i>; and that when they\r\n      departed they exclaimed, <i>Rentum, Tormentum</i>! We are further informed\r\n      that his Infernal Highness, on his departure, leaves a smell, and that (in\r\n      nursery-maid&rsquo;s phrase) not a pretty one, behind him. Concerning this fact\r\n      we have a curious exposition by Mr. Glanville. &ldquo;This,&rdquo;&mdash;according to\r\n      that respectable authority, &ldquo;seems to imply the reality of the business,\r\n      those ascititious particles which he held together in his sensible shape\r\n      being loosened at the vanishing, and so offending the nostrils by their\r\n      floating and diffusing themselves in the open air."<a href="#linknote-61"\r\n       name="linknoteref-61" id="linknoteref-61"><small>61</small></a> How much\r\n      are we bound to regret that Mr. Justice Hunt&rsquo;s discovery &ldquo;of this hellish\r\n      kind of witches,&rdquo; in itself so clear and plain, and containing such\r\n      valuable information, should have been smothered by meeting with\r\n      opposition and discouragement from some then in authority!\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-61" id="linknote-61"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      61 (<a href="#linknoteref-61">return</a>)<br /> [ Glanville&rsquo;s &ldquo;Collection\r\n      of Relations.&rdquo;]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Lord Keeper Guildford was also a stifler of the proceedings against\r\n      witches. Indeed, we may generally remark, during the latter part of the\r\n      seventeenth century, that where the judges were men of education and\r\n      courage, sharing in the information of the times, they were careful to\r\n      check the precipitate ignorance and prejudice of the juries, by giving\r\n      them a more precise idea of the indifferent value of confessions by the\r\n      accused themselves, and of testimony derived from the pretended visions of\r\n      those supposed to be bewitched. Where, on the contrary, judges shared with\r\n      the vulgar in their ideas of such fascination, or were contented to leave\r\n      the evidence with the jury, fearful to withstand the general cry too\r\n      common on such occasions, a verdict of guilty often followed.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      We are informed by Roger North that a case of this kind happened at the\r\n      assizes in Exeter, where his brother, the Lord Chief Justice, did not\r\n      interfere with the crown trials, and the other judge left for execution a\r\n      poor old woman, condemned, as usual, on her own confession, and on the\r\n      testimony of a neighbour, who deponed that he saw a cat jump into the\r\n      accused person&rsquo;s cottage window at twilight, one evening, and that he\r\n      verily believed the said cat to be the devil; on which precious testimony\r\n      the poor wretch was accordingly hanged. On another occasion, about the\r\n      same time, the passions of the great and little vulgar were so much\r\n      excited by the aquittal of an aged village dame, whom the judge had taken\r\n      some pains to rescue, that Sir John Long, a man of rank and fortune, came\r\n      to the judge in the greatest perplexity, requesting that the hag might not\r\n      be permitted to return to her miserable cottage on his estates, since all\r\n      his tenants had in that case threatened to leave him. In compassion to a\r\n      gentleman who apprehended ruin from a cause so whimsical, the dangerous\r\n      old woman was appointed to be kept by the town where she was acquitted, at\r\n      the rate of half-a-crown a week, paid by the parish to which she belonged.\r\n      But behold! in the period betwixt the two assizes Sir John Long and his\r\n      farmers had mustered courage enough to petition that this witch should be\r\n      sent back to them in all her terrors, because they could support her among\r\n      them at a shilling a week cheaper than they were obliged to pay to the\r\n      town for her maintenance. In a subsequent trial before Lord Chief Justice\r\n      North himself, that judge detected one of those practices which, it is to\r\n      be feared, were too common at the time, when witnesses found their\r\n      advantage in feigning themselves bewitched. A woman, supposed to be the\r\n      victim of the male sorcerer at the bar, vomited pins in quantities, and\r\n      those straight, differing from the crooked pins usually produced at such\r\n      times, and less easily concealed in the mouth. The judge, however,\r\n      discovered, by cross-examining a candid witness, that in counterfeiting\r\n      her fits of convulsion the woman sunk her head on her breast, so as to\r\n      take up with her lips the pins which she had placed ready in her\r\n      stomacher. The man was acquitted, of course. A frightful old hag, who was\r\n      present, distinguished herself so much by her benedictions on the judge,\r\n      that he asked the cause of the peculiar interest which she took in the\r\n      acquittal. &ldquo;Twenty years ago,&rdquo; said the poor woman, &ldquo;they would have\r\n      hanged me for a witch, but could not; and now, but for your lordship, they\r\n      would have murdered my innocent son."<a href="#linknote-62"\r\n       name="linknoteref-62" id="linknoteref-62"><small>62</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-62" id="linknote-62"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      62 (<a href="#linknoteref-62">return</a>)<br /> [ Roger North&rsquo;s &ldquo;Life of\r\n      Lord-Keeper Guilford.&rdquo;]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Such scenes happened frequently on the assizes, while country gentlemen,\r\n      like the excellent Sir Roger de Coverley, retained a private share in the\r\n      terror with which their tenants, servants, and retainers regarded some old\r\n      Moll White, who put the hounds at fault and ravaged the fields with hail\r\n      and hurricanes. Sir John Reresby, after an account of a poor woman tried\r\n      for a witch at York in 1686 and acquitted, as he thought, very properly,\r\n      proceeds to tell us that, notwithstanding, the sentinel upon the jail\r\n      where she was confined avowed &ldquo;that he saw a scroll of paper creep from\r\n      under the prison-door, and then change itself first into a monkey and then\r\n      into a turkey, which the under-keeper confirmed. This,&rdquo; says Sir John, &ldquo;I\r\n      have heard from the mouth of both, and now leave it to be believed or\r\n      disbelieved as the reader may be inclined."<a href="#linknote-63"\r\n       name="linknoteref-63" id="linknoteref-63"><small>63</small></a> We may see\r\n      that Reresby, a statesman and a soldier, had not as yet &ldquo;plucked the old\r\n      woman out of his heart.&rdquo; Even Addison himself ventured no farther in his\r\n      incredulity respecting this crime than to contend that although witchcraft\r\n      might and did exist, there was no such thing as a modern instance\r\n      competently proved.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-63" id="linknote-63"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      63 (<a href="#linknoteref-63">return</a>)<br /> [ &ldquo;Memoirs of Sir John\r\n      Reresby,&rdquo; p. 237.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      As late as 1682 three unhappy women named Susan Edwards, Mary Trembles,\r\n      and Temperance Lloyd were hanged at Exeter for witchcraft, and, as usual,\r\n      on their own confession. This is believed to be the last execution of the\r\n      kind in England under form of judicial sentence. But the ancient\r\n      superstition, so interesting to vulgar credulity, like sediment clearing\r\n      itself from water, sunk down in a deeper shade upon the ignorant and\r\n      lowest classes of society in proportion as the higher regions were\r\n      purified from its influence. The populace, including the ignorant of every\r\n      class, were more enraged against witches when their passions were once\r\n      excited in proportion to the lenity exercised towards the objects of their\r\n      indignation by those who administered the laws. Several cases occurred in\r\n      which the mob, impressed with a conviction of the guilt of some destitute\r\n      old creatures, took the law into their own hands, and proceeding upon such\r\n      evidence as Hopkins would have had recourse to, at once, in their own\r\n      apprehension, ascertained their criminality and administered the deserved\r\n      punishment.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The following instance of such illegal and inhuman proceedings occurred at\r\n      Oakly, near Bedford, on 12th July, 1707. There was one woman, upwards of\r\n      sixty years of age, who, being under an imputation of witchcraft, was\r\n      desirous to escape from so foul a suspicion, and to conciliate the\r\n      good-will of her neighbours, by allowing them to duck her. The parish\r\n      officers so far consented to their humane experiment as to promise the\r\n      poor woman a guinea if she should clear herself by sinking. The\r\n      unfortunate object was tied up in a wet sheet, her thumbs and great toes\r\n      were bound together, her cap torn off, and all her apparel searched for\r\n      pins; for there is an idea that a single pin spoils the operation of the\r\n      charm. She was then dragged through the river Ouse by a rope tied round\r\n      her middle. Unhappily for the poor woman, her body floated, though her\r\n      head remained under water. The experiment was made three times with the\r\n      same effect. The cry to hang or drown the witch then became general, and\r\n      as she lay half-dead on the bank they loaded the wretch with reproaches,\r\n      and hardly forbore blows. A single humane bystander took her part, and\r\n      exposed himself to rough usage for doing so. Luckily one of the mob\r\n      themselves at length suggested the additional experiment of weighing the\r\n      witch against the church Bible. The friend of humanity caught at this\r\n      means of escape, supporting the proposal by the staggering argument that\r\n      the Scripture, being the work of God himself, must outweigh necessarily\r\n      all the operations or vassals of the devil. The reasoning was received as\r\n      conclusive, the more readily as it promised a new species of amusement.\r\n      The woman was then weighed against a church Bible of twelve pounds jockey\r\n      weight, and as she was considerably preponderant, was dismissed with\r\n      honour. But many of the mob counted her acquittal irregular, and would\r\n      have had the poor dame drowned or hanged on the result of her ducking, as\r\n      the more authentic species of trial.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      At length a similar piece of inhumanity, which had a very different\r\n      conclusion, led to the final abolition of the statute of James I. as\r\n      affording countenance for such brutal proceedings. An aged pauper, named\r\n      Osborne, and his wife, who resided near Tring, in Staffordshire, fell\r\n      under the suspicion of the mob on account of supposed witchcraft. The\r\n      overseers of the poor, understanding that the rabble entertained a purpose\r\n      of swimming these infirm creatures, which indeed they had expressed in a\r\n      sort of proclamation, endeavoured to oppose their purpose by securing the\r\n      unhappy couple in the vestry-room, which they barricaded. They were\r\n      unable, however, to protect them in the manner they intended. The mob\r\n      forced the door, seized the accused, and, with ineffable brutality,\r\n      continued dragging the wretches through a pool of water till the woman\r\n      lost her life. A brute in human form, who had superintended the murder,\r\n      went among the spectators, and requested money for the sport he had shown\r\n      them! The life of the other victim was with great difficulty saved. Three\r\n      men were tried for their share in this inhuman action. Only one of them,\r\n      named Colley, was condemned and hanged. When he came to execution, the\r\n      rabble, instead of crowding round the gallows as usual, stood at a\r\n      distance, and abused those who were putting to death, they said, an honest\r\n      fellow for ridding the parish of an accursed witch. This abominable murder\r\n      was committed July 30, 1751.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The repetition of such horrors, the proneness of the people to so cruel\r\n      and heart-searing a superstition, was traced by the legislature to its\r\n      source, namely, the yet unabolished statute of James I. Accordingly, by\r\n      the 9th George II. cap. 5, that odious law, so long the object of horror\r\n      to all ancient and poverty-stricken females in the kingdom, was abrogated,\r\n      and all criminal procedure on the subject of sorcery or witchcraft\r\n      discharged in future throughout Great Britain; reserving for such as\r\n      should pretend to the skill of fortune-tellers, discoverers of stolen\r\n      goods, or the like, the punishment of the correction-house, as due to\r\n      rogues and vagabonds. Since that period witchcraft has been little heard\r\n      of in England, and although the belief in its existence has in remote\r\n      places survived the law that recognised the evidence of the crime, and\r\n      assigned its punishment&mdash;yet such faith is gradually becoming\r\n      forgotten since the rabble have been deprived of all pretext to awaken it\r\n      by their own riotous proceedings. Some rare instances have occurred of\r\n      attempts similar to that for which Colley suffered; and I observe one is\r\n      preserved in that curious register of knowledge, Mr. Hone&rsquo;s &ldquo;Popular\r\n      Amusements,&rdquo; from which it appears that as late as the end of last century\r\n      this brutality was practised, though happily without loss of life.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The Irish statute against witchcraft still exists, as it would seem.\r\n      Nothing occurred in that kingdom which recommended its being formally\r\n      annulled; but it is considered as obsolete, and should so wild a thing be\r\n      attempted in the present day, no procedure, it is certain, would now be\r\n      permitted to lie upon it.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      If anything were wanted to confirm the general proposition that the\r\n      epidemic terror of witchcraft increases and becomes general in proportion\r\n      to the increase of prosecutions against witches, it would be sufficient to\r\n      quote certain extraordinary occurrences in New England. Only a brief\r\n      account can be here given of the dreadful hallucination under which the\r\n      colonists of that province were for a time deluded and oppressed by a\r\n      strange contagious terror, and how suddenly and singularly it was cured,\r\n      even by its own excess; but it is too strong evidence of the imaginary\r\n      character of this hideous disorder to be altogether suppressed.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      New England, as is well known, was peopled mainly by emigrants who had\r\n      been disgusted with the government of Charles I. in church and state,\r\n      previous to the great Civil War. Many of the more wealthy settlers were\r\n      Presbyterians and Calvinists; others, fewer in number and less influential\r\n      from their fortune, were Quakers, Anabaptists, or members of the other\r\n      sects who were included under the general name of Independents. The\r\n      Calvinists brought with them the same zeal for religion and strict\r\n      morality which everywhere distinguished them. Unfortunately, they were not\r\n      wise according to their zeal, but entertained a proneness to believe in\r\n      supernatural and direct personal intercourse between the devil and his\r\n      vassals, an error to which, as we have endeavoured to show, their brethren\r\n      in Europe had from the beginning been peculiarly subject. In a country\r\n      imperfectly cultivated, and where the partially improved spots were\r\n      embosomed in inaccessible forests, inhabited by numerous tribes of\r\n      savages, it was natural that a disposition to superstition should rather\r\n      gain than lose ground, and that to other dangers and horrors with which\r\n      they were surrounded, the colonists should have added fears of the devil,\r\n      not merely as the Evil Principle tempting human nature to sin, and thus\r\n      endangering our salvation, but as combined with sorcerers and witches to\r\n      inflict death and torture upon children and others.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The first case which I observe was that of four children of a person\r\n      called John Goodwin, a mason. The eldest, a girl, had quarrelled with the\r\n      laundress of the family about some linen which was amissing. The mother of\r\n      the laundress, an ignorant, testy, and choleric old Irishwoman, scolded\r\n      the accuser; and shortly after, the elder Goodwin, her sister and two\r\n      brothers, were seized with such strange diseases that all their neighbours\r\n      concluded they were bewitched. They conducted themselves as those supposed\r\n      to suffer under maladies created by such influence were accustomed to do.\r\n      They stiffened their necks so hard at one time that the joints could not\r\n      be moved; at another time their necks were so flexible and supple that it\r\n      seemed the bone was dissolved. They had violent convulsions, in which\r\n      their jaws snapped with the force of a spring-trap set for vermin. Their\r\n      limbs were curiously contorted, and to those who had a taste for the\r\n      marvellous, seemed entirely dislocated and displaced. Amid these\r\n      distortions, they cried out against the poor old woman, whose name was\r\n      Glover, alleging that she was in presence with them adding to their\r\n      torments. The miserable Irishwoman, who hardly could speak the English\r\n      language, repeated her Pater Noster and Ave Maria like a good Catholic;\r\n      but there were some words which she had forgotten. She was therefore\r\n      supposed to be unable to pronounce the whole consistently and correctly,\r\n      and condemned and executed accordingly.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      But the children of Goodwin found the trade they were engaged in to be too\r\n      profitable to be laid aside, and the eldest in particular continued all\r\n      the external signs of witchcraft and possession. Some of these were\r\n      excellently calculated to flatter the self-opinion and prejudices of the\r\n      Calvinist ministers by whom she was attended, and accordingly bear in\r\n      their very front the character of studied and voluntary imposture. The\r\n      young woman, acting, as was supposed, under the influence of the devil,\r\n      read a Quaker treatise with ease and apparent satisfaction; but a book\r\n      written against the poor inoffensive Friends the devil would not allow his\r\n      victim to touch, She could look on a Church of England Prayer-book, and\r\n      read the portions of Scripture which it contains without difficulty or\r\n      impediment; but the spirit which possessed her threw her into fits if she\r\n      attempted to read the same Scriptures from the Bible, as if the awe which\r\n      it is supposed the fiends entertain for Holy Writ depended, not on the\r\n      meaning of the words, but the arrangement of the page, and the type in\r\n      which they were printed. This singular species of flattery was designed to\r\n      captivate the clergyman through his professional opinions; others were\r\n      more strictly personal. The afflicted damsel seems to have been somewhat\r\n      of the humour of the Inamorata of Messrs. Smack, Pluck, Catch, and\r\n      Company, and had, like her, merry as well as melancholy fits. She often\r\n      imagined that her attendant spirits brought her a handsome pony to ride\r\n      off with them to their rendezvous. On such occasions she made a spring\r\n      upwards, as if to mount her horse, and then, still seated on her chair,\r\n      mimicked with dexterity and agility the motions of the animal pacing,\r\n      trotting, and galloping, like a child on the nurse&rsquo;s knee; but when she\r\n      cantered in this manner upstairs, she affected inability to enter the\r\n      clergyman&rsquo;s study, and when she was pulled into it by force, used to\r\n      become quite well, and stand up as a rational being. &ldquo;Reasons were given\r\n      for this,&rdquo; says the simple minister, &ldquo;that seem more kind than true.&rdquo;\r\n       Shortly after this, she appears to have treated the poor divine with a\r\n      species of sweetness and attention, which gave him greater embarrassment\r\n      than her former violence. She used to break in upon him at his studies to\r\n      importune him to come downstairs, and thus advantaged doubtless the\r\n      kingdom of Satan by the interruption of his pursuits. At length the\r\n      Goodwins were, or appeared to be, cured. But the example had been given\r\n      and caught, and the blood of poor Dame Glover, which had been the\r\n      introduction to this tale of a hobby-horse, was to be the forerunner of\r\n      new atrocities and fearfully more general follies.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      This scene opened by the illness of two girls, a daughter and niece of Mr.\r\n      Parvis, the minister of Salem, who fell under an affliction similar to\r\n      that of the Goodwins. Their mouths were stopped, their throats choked,\r\n      their limbs racked, thorns were stuck into their flesh, and pins were\r\n      ejected from their stomachs. An Indian and his wife, servants of the\r\n      family, endeavouring, by some spell of their own, to discover by whom the\r\n      fatal charm had been imposed on their master&rsquo;s children, drew themselves\r\n      under suspicion, and were hanged. The judges and juries persevered,\r\n      encouraged by the discovery of these poor Indians&rsquo; guilt, and hoping they\r\n      might thus expel from the colony the authors of such practices. They\r\n      acted, says Mather, the historian, under a conscientious wish to do\r\n      justly; but the cases of witchcraft and possession increased as if they\r\n      were transmitted by contagion, and the same sort of spectral evidence\r\n      being received which had occasioned the condemnation of the Indian woman\r\n      Titu, became generally fatal. The afflicted persons failed not to see the\r\n      spectres, as they were termed, of the persons by whom they were tormented.\r\n      Against this species of evidence no <i>alibi</i> could be offered, because\r\n      it was admitted, as we have said elsewhere, that the real persons of the\r\n      accused were not there present; and everything rested upon the assumption\r\n      that the afflicted persons were telling the truth, since their evidence\r\n      could not be redargued. These spectres were generally represented as\r\n      offering their victims a book, on signing which they would be freed from\r\n      their torments. Sometimes the devil appeared in person, and added his own\r\n      eloquence to move the afflicted persons to consent.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      At first, as seems natural enough, the poor and miserable alone were\r\n      involved; but presently, when such evidence was admitted as\r\n      incontrovertible, the afflicted began to see the spectral appearances of\r\n      persons of higher condition and of irreproachable lives, some of whom were\r\n      arrested, some made their escape, while several were executed. The more\r\n      that suffered the greater became the number of afflicted persons, and the\r\n      wider and the more numerous were the denunciations against supposed\r\n      witches. The accused were of all ages. A child of five years old was\r\n      indicted by some of the afflicted, who imagined they saw this juvenile\r\n      wizard active in tormenting them, and appealed to the mark of little teeth\r\n      on their bodies, where they stated it had bitten them. A poor dog was also\r\n      hanged as having been alleged to be busy in this infernal persecution.\r\n      These gross insults on common reason occasioned a revulsion in public\r\n      feeling, but not till many lives had been sacrificed. By this means\r\n      nineteen men and women were executed, besides a stouthearted man named\r\n      Cory, who refused to plead, and was accordingly pressed to death according\r\n      to the old law. On this horrible occasion a circumstance took place\r\n      disgusting to humanity, which must yet be told, to show how superstition\r\n      can steel the heart of a man against the misery of his fellow-creature.\r\n      The dying man, in the mortal agony, thrust out his tongue, which the\r\n      sheriff crammed with his cane back again into his mouth. Eight persons\r\n      were condemned besides those who had actually suffered, and no less than\r\n      two hundred were in prison and under examination.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Men began then to ask whether the devil might not artfully deceive the\r\n      afflicted into the accusation of good and innocent persons by presenting\r\n      witches and fiends in the resemblance of blameless persons, as engaged in\r\n      the tormenting of their diseased country-folk. This argument was by no\r\n      means inconsistent with the belief in witchcraft, and was the more readily\r\n      listened to on that account. Besides, men found that no rank or condition\r\n      could save them from the danger of this horrible accusation if they\r\n      continued to encourage the witnesses in such an unlimited course as had\r\n      hitherto been granted to them. Influenced by these reflections, the\r\n      settlers awoke as from a dream, and the voice of the public, which had so\r\n      lately demanded vengeance on all who were suspected of sorcery, began now,\r\n      on the other hand, to lament the effusion of blood, under the strong\r\n      suspicion that part of it at least had been innocently and unjustly\r\n      sacrificed. In Mather&rsquo;s own language, which we use as that of a man deeply\r\n      convinced of the reality of the crime, &ldquo;experience showed that the more\r\n      were apprehended the more were still afflicted by Satan, and the number of\r\n      confessions increasing did but increase the number of the accused, and the\r\n      execution of some made way to the apprehension of others. For still the\r\n      afflicted complained of being tormented by new objects as the former were\r\n      removed, so that some of those that were concerned grew amazed at the\r\n      number and condition of those that were accused, and feared that Satan, by\r\n      his wiles, had enwrapped innocent persons under the imputation of that\r\n      crime; and at last, as was evidently seen, there must be a stop put, or\r\n      the generation of the kingdom of God would fall under condemnation."<a\r\n      href="#linknote-64" name="linknoteref-64" id="linknoteref-64"><small>64</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-64" id="linknote-64"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      64 (<a href="#linknoteref-64">return</a>)<br /> [ Mather&rsquo;s &ldquo;Magnalia,&rdquo; book\r\n      vi. chap. lxxxii. The zealous author, however, regrets the general gaol\r\n      delivery on the score of sorcery and thinks, had the times been calm, the\r\n      case might have required a farther investigation, and that, on the whole,\r\n      the matter was ended too abruptly But, the temper of the times considered,\r\n      he admits candidly that it is better to act moderately in matters capital,\r\n      and to let the guilty escape, than run the risk of destroying the\r\n      innocent.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The prosecutions were therefore suddenly stopped, the prisoners dismissed,\r\n      the condemned pardoned, and even those who had confessed, the number of\r\n      whom was very extraordinary, were pardoned amongst others; and the author\r\n      we have just quoted thus records the result:&mdash;&ldquo;When this prosecution\r\n      ceased, the Lord so chained up Satan that the afflicted grew presently\r\n      well. The accused were generally quiet, and for five years there was no\r\n      such molestation among us.&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      To this it must be added that the congregation of Salem compelled Mr.\r\n      Parvis, in whose family the disturbance had begun, and who, they alleged,\r\n      was the person by whom it was most fiercely driven on in the commencement,\r\n      to leave his settlement amongst them. Such of the accused as had confessed\r\n      the acts of witchcraft imputed to them generally denied and retracted\r\n      their confessions, asserting them to have been made under fear of torture,\r\n      influence of persuasion, or other circumstances exclusive of their free\r\n      will. Several of the judges and jurors concerned in the sentence of those\r\n      who were executed published their penitence for their rashness in\r\n      convicting these unfortunate persons; and one of the judges, a man of the\r\n      most importance in the colony, observed, during the rest of his life, the\r\n      anniversary of the first execution as a day of solemn fast and humiliation\r\n      for his own share in the transaction. Even the barbarous Indians were\r\n      struck with wonder at the infatuation of the English colonists on this\r\n      occasion, and drew disadvantageous comparisons between them and the\r\n      French, among whom, as they remarked, &ldquo;the Great Spirit sends no witches.&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The system of witchcraft, as believed in Scotland, must next claim our\r\n      attention, as it is different in some respects from that of England, and\r\n      subsisted to a later period, and was prosecuted with much more severity.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="link2H_4_0010" id="link2H_4_0010"> </a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <div style="height: 4em;">\r\n      <br /><br /><br /><br />\r\n    </div>\r\n    <h2>\r\n      LETTER IX.\r\n    </h2>\r\n<pre xml:space="preserve">\r\n    Scottish Trials&mdash;Earl of Mar&mdash;Lady Glammis&mdash;William Barton&mdash;Witches\r\n    of Auldearne&mdash;Their Rites and Charms&mdash;Their Transformation into\r\n    Hares&mdash;Satan&rsquo;s Severity towards them&mdash;Their Crimes&mdash;Sir George\r\n    Mackenzie&rsquo;s Opinion of Witchcraft&mdash;Instances of Confessions made by\r\n    the Accused, in despair, and to avoid future annoyance and\r\n    persecution&mdash;Examination by Pricking&mdash;The Mode of Judicial Procedure\r\n    against Witches, and nature of the Evidence admissible, opened a\r\n    door to Accusers, and left the Accused no chance of escape&mdash;The\r\n    Superstition of the Scottish Clergy in King James VI.&lsquo;s time led\r\n    them, like their Sovereign, to encourage Witch-Prosecutions&mdash;Case of\r\n    Bessie Graham&mdash;Supposed Conspiracy to Shipwreck James in his Voyage\r\n    to Denmark&mdash;Meetings of the Witches, and Rites performed to\r\n    accomplish their purpose&mdash;Trial of Margaret Barclay in 1618&mdash;Case of\r\n    Major Weir&mdash;Sir John Clerk among the first who declined acting as\r\n    Commissioner on the Trial of a Witch&mdash;Paisley and Pittenweem\r\n    Witches&mdash;A Prosecution in Caithness prevented by the Interference of\r\n    the King&rsquo;s Advocate in 1718&mdash;The Last Sentence of Death for\r\n    Witchcraft pronounced in Scotland in 1722&mdash;Remains of the Witch\r\n    Superstition&mdash;Case of supposed Witchcraft, related from the Author&rsquo;s\r\n    own knowledge, which took place so late as 1800.\r\n</pre>\r\n    <p class="pfirst">\r\n      <span class="dropcap" style="font-size: 4.00em">F</span>or many years the\r\n      Scottish nation had been remarkable for a credulous belief in witchcraft,\r\n      and repeated examples were supplied by the annals of sanguinary executions\r\n      on this sad accusation. Our acquaintance with the slender foundation on\r\n      which Boetius and Buchanan reared the early part of their histories may\r\n      greatly incline us to doubt whether a king named Duffus ever reigned in\r\n      Scotland, and, still more, whether he died by the agency of a gang of\r\n      witches, who inflicted torments upon an image made in his name, for the\r\n      sake of compassing his death.
