In the tale of Macbeth, which is another\r\n      early instance of Demonology in Scottish history, the weird-sisters, who\r\n      were the original prophetesses, appeared to the usurper in a dream, and\r\n      are described as <i>vol</i>, or sibyls, rather than as witches, though\r\n      Shakspeare has stamped the latter character indelibly upon them.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      One of the earliest real cases of importance founded upon witchcraft was,\r\n      like those of the Duchess of Gloucester and others in the sister country,\r\n      mingled with an accusation of a political nature, which, rather than the\r\n      sorcery, brought the culprits to their fate. The Earl of Mar, brother of\r\n      James III. of Scotland, fell under the king&rsquo;s suspicion for consulting\r\n      with witches and sorcerers how to shorten the king&rsquo;s days. On such a\r\n      charge, very inexplicitly stated, the unhappy Mar was bled to death in his\r\n      own lodgings without either trial or conviction; immediately after which\r\n      catastrophe twelve women of obscure rank and three or four wizards, or\r\n      warlocks, as they were termed, were burnt at Edinburgh, to give a colour\r\n      to the Earl&rsquo;s guilt.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In the year 1537 a noble matron fell a victim to a similar charge. This\r\n      was Janet Douglas, Lady Glammis, who, with her son, her second husband,\r\n      and several others, stood accused of attempting James&rsquo;s life by poison,\r\n      with a view to the restoration of the Douglas family, of which Lady\r\n      Glammis&rsquo;s brother, the Earl of Angus, was the head. She died much pitied\r\n      by the people, who seem to have thought the articles against her forged\r\n      for the purpose of taking her life, her kindred and very name being so\r\n      obnoxious to the King.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Previous to this lady&rsquo;s execution there would appear to have been but few\r\n      prosecuted to death on the score of witchcraft, although the want of the\r\n      justiciary records of that period leaves us in uncertainty. But in the end\r\n      of the fifteenth and beginning of the sixteenth centuries, when such\r\n      charges grew general over Europe, cases of the kind occurred very often in\r\n      Scotland, and, as we have already noticed, were sometimes of a peculiar\r\n      character. There is, indeed, a certain monotony in most tales of the kind.\r\n      The vassals are usually induced to sell themselves at a small price to the\r\n      Author of Ill, who, having commonly to do with women, drives a very hard\r\n      bargain. On the contrary, when he was pleased to enact the female on a\r\n      similar occasion, he brought his gallant, one William Barton, a fortune of\r\n      no less than fifteen pounds, which, even supposing it to have been the\r\n      Scottish denomination of coin, was a very liberal endowment compared with\r\n      his niggardly conduct towards the fair sex on such an occasion. Neither\r\n      did he pass false coin on this occasion, but, on the contrary, generously\r\n      gave Burton a merk, to keep the fifteen pounds whole. In observing on\r\n      Satan&rsquo;s conduct in this matter, Master George Sinclair observes that it is\r\n      fortunate the Enemy is but seldom permitted to bribe so high (as 15\r\n      Scots); for were this the case, he might find few men or women capable of\r\n      resisting his munificence. I look upon this as one of the most severe\r\n      reflections on our forefathers&rsquo; poverty which is extant.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In many of the Scottish witches&rsquo; trials, as to the description of Satan&rsquo;s\r\n      Domdaniel, and the Sabbath which he there celebrates, the northern\r\n      superstition agrees with that of England. But some of the confessions\r\n      depart from the monotony of repetition, and add some more fanciful\r\n      circumstances than occur in the general case. Isobel Gowdie&rsquo;s confession,\r\n      already mentioned, is extremely minute, and some part of it at least may\r\n      be quoted, as there are other passages not very edifying. The witches of\r\n      Auldearne, according to this penitent, were so numerous, that they were\r\n      told off into squads, or <i>covines</i>, as they were termed, to each of\r\n      which were appointed two officers. One of these was called the Maiden of\r\n      the Covine, and was usually, like Tam o&rsquo; Shanter&rsquo;s Nannie, a girl of\r\n      personal attractions, whom Satan placed beside himself, and treated with\r\n      particular attention, which greatly provoked the spite of the old hags,\r\n      who felt themselves insulted by the preference.<a href="#linknote-65"\r\n       name="linknoteref-65" id="linknoteref-65"><small>65</small></a> When\r\n      assembled, they dug up graves, and possessed themselves of the carcases\r\n      (of unchristened infants in particular), whose joints and members they\r\n      used in their magic unguents and salves. When they desired to secure for\r\n      their own use the crop of some neighbour, they made a pretence of\r\n      ploughing it with a yoke of paddocks. These foul creatures drew the\r\n      plough, which was held by the devil himself. The plough-harness and soams\r\n      were of quicken grass, the sock and coulter were made out of a riglen&rsquo;s\r\n      horn, and the covine attended on the operation, praying the devil to\r\n      transfer to them the fruit of the ground so traversed, and leave the\r\n      proprietors nothing but thistles and briars. The witches&rsquo; sports, with\r\n      their elfin archery, I have already noticed (page 136). They entered the\r\n      house of the Earl of Murray himself, and such other mansions as were not\r\n      fenced against them by vigil and prayer, and feasted on the provisions\r\n      they found there.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-65" id="linknote-65"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      65 (<a href="#linknoteref-65">return</a>)<br /> [ This word Covine seems to\r\n      signify a subdivision or squad. The tree near the front of an ancient\r\n      castle was called the <i>Covine tree</i>, probably because the lord\r\n      received his company there.\r\n    </p>\r\n<pre xml:space="preserve">\r\n&ldquo;He is lord of the hunting horn,\r\n  And king of the Covine tree;\r\nHe&rsquo;s well loo&rsquo;d in the western waters,\r\n  But best of his ain minnie.&rdquo;]\r\n</pre>\r\n    <p>\r\n      As these witches were the countrywomen of the weird sisters in Macbeth,\r\n      the reader may be desirous to hear some of their spells, and of the poetry\r\n      by which they were accompanied and enforced. They used to hash the flesh\r\n      of an unchristened child, mixed with that of dogs and sheep, and place it\r\n      in the house of those whom they devoted to destruction in body or goods,\r\n      saying or singing&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;We put this intill this hame, In our lord the Devil&rsquo;s name; The first\r\n      hands that handle thee, Burn&rsquo;d and scalded may they be! We will destroy\r\n      houses and hald, With the sheep and nolt into the fauld; And little sall\r\n      come to the fore, Of all the rest of the little store!&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Metamorphoses were, according to Isobel, very common among them, and the\r\n      forms of crows, cats, hares, and other animals, were on such occasions\r\n      assumed. In the hare shape Isobel herself had a bad adventure. She had\r\n      been sent by the devil to Auldearne in that favourite disguise, with some\r\n      message to her neighbours, but had the misfortune to meet Peter Papley of\r\n      Killhill&rsquo;s servants going to labour, having his hounds with them. The\r\n      hounds sprung on the disguised witch, &ldquo;and I,&rdquo; says Isobel, &ldquo;run a very\r\n      long time, but being hard pressed, was forced to take to my own house, the\r\n      door being open, and there took refuge behind a chest.&rdquo; But the hounds\r\n      came in and took the other side of the chest, so that Isobel only escaped\r\n      by getting into another house, and gaining time to say the disenchanting\r\n      rhyme:&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;Hare, hare, God send thee care! I am in a hare&rsquo;s likeness now; But I\r\n      shall be a woman even now&mdash; Hare, hare, God send thee care!&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Such accidents, she said, were not uncommon, and the witches were\r\n      sometimes bitten by the dogs, of which the marks remained after their\r\n      restoration to human shape. But none had been killed on such occasions.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The ceremonial of the Sabbath meetings was very strict. The Foul Fiend was\r\n      very rigid in exacting the most ceremonious attention from his votaries,\r\n      and the title of Lord when addressed by them. Sometimes, however, the\r\n      weird sisters, when whispering amongst themselves, irreverently spoke of\r\n      their sovereign by the name of Black John; upon such occasions the Fiend\r\n      rushed on them like a schoolmaster who surprises his pupils in delict, and\r\n      beat and buffeted them without mercy or discretion, saying, &ldquo;I ken weel\r\n      eneugh what you are saying of me.&rdquo; Then might be seen the various tempers\r\n      of those whom he commanded. Alexander Elder, in Earlseat, often fell under\r\n      his lord&rsquo;s displeasure for neglect of duty, and, being weak and simple,\r\n      could never defend himself save with tears, cries, and entreaties for\r\n      mercy; but some of the women, according to Isobel Gowdie&rsquo;s confession, had\r\n      more of the spirit which animated the old dame of Kellyburn Braes.\r\n      Margaret Wilson, in Auldearne, would &ldquo;defend herself finely,&rdquo; and make her\r\n      hands save her head, after the old Scottish manner. Bessie Wilson could\r\n      also speak very crustily with her tongue, and &ldquo;belled the cat&rdquo; with the\r\n      devil stoutly. The others chiefly took refuge in crying &ldquo;Pity! mercy!&rdquo; and\r\n      such like, while Satan kept beating them with wool cards and other sharp\r\n      scourges, without attending to their entreaties or complaints. There were\r\n      attendant devils and imps, who served the witches. They were usually\r\n      distinguished by their liveries, which were sad-dun, grass-green,\r\n      sea-green, and yellow. The witches were taught to call these imps by\r\n      names, some of which might belong to humanity, while others had a\r\n      diabolical sound. These were Robert the Jakis, Saunders the Red Reaver,\r\n      Thomas the Feary, Swein, an old Scandinavian Duerg probably; the Roaring\r\n      Lion, Thief of Hell, Wait-upon-Herself, MacKeeler, Robert the Rule,\r\n      Hendrie Craig, and Rorie. These names, odd and uncouth enough, are better\r\n      imagined at least than those which Hopkins contrived for the imps which he\r\n      discovered&mdash;such as Pyewacket, Peck-in-the-Crown, Sack-and-Sugar,\r\n      News, Vinegar-Tom, and Grizell Greedigut, the broad vulgarity of which\r\n      epithets shows what a flat imagination he brought to support his impudent\r\n      fictions.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The devil, who commanded the fair sisterhood, being fond of mimicking the\r\n      forms of the Christian church, used to rebaptize the witches with their\r\n      blood, and in his own great name. The proud-stomached Margaret Wilson, who\r\n      scorned to take a blow unrepaid, even from Satan himself, was called\r\n      Pickle-nearest-the-Wind; her compeer, Bessie Wilson, was\r\n      Throw-the-Cornyard; Elspet Nishe&rsquo;s was Bessie Bald; Bessie Hay&rsquo;s nickname\r\n      was Able-and-Stout; and Jane Mairten, the Maiden of the Covine, was called\r\n      Ower-the-Dike-with-it.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Isobel took upon herself, and imputed to her sisters, as already\r\n      mentioned, the death of sundry persons shot with elf-arrows, because they\r\n      had omitted to bless themselves as the aerial flight of the hags swept\r\n      past them.<a href="#linknote-66" name="linknoteref-66" id="linknoteref-66"><small>66</small></a>\r\n      She had herself the temerity to shoot at the Laird of Park as he was\r\n      riding through a ford, but missed him through the influence of the running\r\n      stream, perhaps, for which she thanks God in her confession; and adds,\r\n      that at the time she received a great cuff from Bessie Hay for her\r\n      awkwardness. They devoted the male children of this gentleman (of the\r\n      well-known family of Gordon of Park, I presume) to wasting illness, by the\r\n      following lines, placing at the same time in the fire figures composed of\r\n      clay mixed with paste, to represent the object:&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;We put this water amongst this meal, For long dwining<a\r\n      href="#linknote-67" name="linknoteref-67" id="linknoteref-67"><small>67</small></a>\r\n      and ill heal; We put it in into the fire, To burn them up stook and stour.<a\r\n      href="#linknote-68" name="linknoteref-68" id="linknoteref-68"><small>68</small></a>\r\n      That they be burned with our will, Like any stikkle<a href="#linknote-69"\r\n       name="linknoteref-69" id="linknoteref-69"><small>69</small></a> in a\r\n      kiln.&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-66" id="linknote-66"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      66 (<a href="#linknoteref-66">return</a>)<br /> [ See p. 136.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-67" id="linknote-67"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      67 (<a href="#linknoteref-67">return</a>)<br /> [ Pining.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-68" id="linknote-68"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      68 (<a href="#linknoteref-68">return</a>)<br /> [ We should read perhaps,\r\n      &ldquo;limb and lire.&rdquo;]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-69" id="linknote-69"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      69 (<a href="#linknoteref-69">return</a>)<br /> [ Stubble.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Such was the singular confession of Isobel Gowdie, made voluntarily, it\r\n      would seem, and without compulsion of any kind, judicially authenticated\r\n      by the subscription of the notary, clergymen, and gentlemen present;\r\n      adhered to after their separate <i>diets</i>, as they are called, of\r\n      examination, and containing no variety or contradiction in its details.\r\n      Whatever might be her state of mind in other respects, she seems to have\r\n      been perfectly conscious of the perilous consequence of her disclosures to\r\n      her own person. &ldquo;I do not deserve,&rdquo; says she, &ldquo;to be seated here at ease\r\n      and unharmed, but rather to be stretched on an iron rack: nor can my\r\n      crimes be atoned for, were I to be drawn asunder by wild horses.&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It only remains to suppose that this wretched creature was under the\r\n      dominion of some peculiar species of lunacy, to which a full perusal of\r\n      her confession might perhaps guide a medical person of judgment and\r\n      experience. Her case is interesting, as throwing upon the rites and\r\n      ceremonies of the Scottish witches a light which we seek in vain\r\n      elsewhere.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Other unfortunate persons were betrayed to their own reproof by other\r\n      means than the derangement of mind which seems to have operated on Isobel\r\n      Gowdie. Some, as we have seen, endeavoured to escape from the charge of\r\n      witchcraft by admitting an intercourse with the fairy people; an excuse\r\n      which was never admitted as relevant. Others were subjected to cruel\r\n      tortures, by which our ancestors thought the guilty might be brought to\r\n      confession, but which far more frequently compelled the innocent to bear\r\n      evidence against themselves. On this subject the celebrated Sir George\r\n      Mackenzie, &ldquo;that noble wit of Scotland,&rdquo; as he is termed by Dryden, has\r\n      some most judicious reflections, which we shall endeavour to abstract as\r\n      the result of the experience of one who, in his capacity of Lord Advocate,\r\n      had often occasion to conduct witch-trials, and who, not doubting the\r\n      existence of the crime, was of opinion that, on account of its very\r\n      horror, it required the clearest and most strict probation.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      He first insists on the great improbability of the fiend, without riches\r\n      to bestow, and avowedly subjected to a higher power, being able to enlist\r\n      such numbers of recruits, and the little advantage which he himself would\r\n      gain by doing so. But, 2dly, says Mackenzie, &ldquo;the persons ordinarily\r\n      accused of this crime are poor ignorant men, or else women, who understand\r\n      not the nature of what they are accused of; and many mistake their own\r\n      fears and apprehensions for witchcraft, of which I shall give two\r\n      instances. One, of a poor weaver who, after he had confessed witchcraft,\r\n      being asked how he saw the devil, made answer, &lsquo;Like flies dancing about\r\n      the candle.&rsquo; Another, of a woman, who asked seriously, when she was\r\n      accused, if a woman might be a witch and not know it? And it is dangerous\r\n      that persons, of all others the most simple, should be tried for a crime\r\n      of all others the most mysterious. 3rdly, These poor creatures, when they\r\n      are defamed, become so confounded with fear and the close prison in which\r\n      they are kept, and so starved for want of meat and drink, either of which\r\n      wants is enough to disarm the strongest reason, that hardly wiser and more\r\n      serious people than they would escape distraction; and when men are\r\n      confounded with fear and apprehension, they will imagine things the most\r\n      ridiculous and absurd&rdquo; of which instances are given. 4thly, &ldquo;Most of these\r\n      poor creatures are tortured by their keepers, who, being persuaded they do\r\n      God good service, think it their duty to vex and torment poor prisoners\r\n      delivered up to them as rebels to heaven and enemies to men; and I know&rdquo;\r\n       (continues Sir George), &ldquo;<i>ex certissima scientia</i>, that most of all\r\n      that ever were taken were tormented in this manner, and this usage was the\r\n      ground of all their confession; and albeit the poor miscreants cannot\r\n      prove this usage, the actors being the only witnesses, yet the judge\r\n      should be jealous of it, as that which did at first elicit the confession,\r\n      and for fear of which they dare not retract it.&rdquo; 5thly, This learned\r\n      author gives us an instance how these unfortunate creatures might be\r\n      reduced to confession by the very infamy which the accusation cast upon\r\n      them, and which was sure to follow, condemning them for life to a state of\r\n      necessity, misery, and suspicion, such as any person of reputation would\r\n      willingly exchange for a short death, however painful.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;I went when I was a justice-deput to examine some women who had confessed\r\n      judicially, and one of them, who was a silly creature, told me under\r\n      secresie, that she had not confest because she was guilty, but being a\r\n      poor creature who wrought for her meat, and being defamed for a witch, she\r\n      knew she would starve, for no person thereafter would either give her meat\r\n      or lodging, and that all men would beat her and hound dogs at her, and\r\n      that therefore she desired to be out of the world; whereupon she wept most\r\n      bitterly, and upon her knees called God to witness to what she said.\r\n      Another told me that she was afraid the devil would challenge a right to\r\n      her, after she was said to be his servant, and would haunt her, as the\r\n      minister said, when he was desiring her to confess, and therefore she\r\n      desired to die. And really ministers are oft times indiscreet in their\r\n      zeal to have poor creatures to confess in this; and I recommend to judges\r\n      that the wisest ministers should be sent to them, and those who are sent\r\n      should be cautious in this particular."<a href="#linknote-70"\r\n       name="linknoteref-70" id="linknoteref-70"><small>70</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-70" id="linknote-70"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      70 (<a href="#linknoteref-70">return</a>)<br /> [ Mackenzie&rsquo;s &ldquo;Criminal\r\n      Law,&rdquo; p. 45.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      As a corollary to this affecting story, I may quote the case of a woman in\r\n      Lauder jail, who lay there with other females on a charge of witchcraft.\r\n      Her companions in prison were adjudged to die, and she too had, by a\r\n      confession as full as theirs, given herself up as guilty. She therefore\r\n      sent for the minister of the town, and entreated to be put to death with\r\n      the others who had been appointed to suffer upon the next Monday. The\r\n      clergyman, however, as well as others, had adopted a strong persuasion\r\n      that this confession was made up in the pride of her heart, for the\r\n      destruction of her own life, and had no foundation in truth. We give the\r\n      result in the minister&rsquo;s words:&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;Therefore much pains was taken on her by ministers and others on\r\n      Saturday, Sunday, and Monday morning, that she might resile from that\r\n      confession which was suspected to be but a temptation of the devil, to\r\n      destroy both her soul and body; yea, it was charged home upon her by the\r\n      ministers, that there was just ground of jealousy that her confession was\r\n      not sincere, and she was charged before the Lord to declare the truth, and\r\n      not to take her blood upon her own head. Yet she stiffly adhered to what\r\n      she had said, and cried always to be put away with the rest. Whereupon, on\r\n      Monday morning, being called before the judges, and confessing before them\r\n      what she had said, she was found guilty and condemned to die with the rest\r\n      that same day. Being carried forth to the place of execution, she remained\r\n      silent during the first, second, and third prayer, and then perceiving\r\n      that there remained no more but to rise and go to the stake, she lifted up\r\n      her body, and with a loud voice cried out, &lsquo;Now all you that see me this\r\n      day, know that I am now to die as a witch by my own confession, and I free\r\n      all men, especially the ministers and magistrates, of the guilt of my\r\n      blood. I take it wholly upon myself&mdash;my blood be upon my own head;\r\n      and as I must make answer to the God of Heaven presently, I declare I am\r\n      as free of witchcraft as any child; but being delated by a malicious\r\n      woman, and put in prison under the name of a witch, disowned by my husband\r\n      and friends, and seeing no ground of hope of my coming out of prison, or\r\n      ever coming in credit again, through the temptation of the devil I made up\r\n      that confession on purpose to destroy my own life, being weary of it, and\r\n      choosing rather to die than live;&rsquo;&mdash;and so died. Which lamentable\r\n      story, as it did then astonish all the spectators, none of which could\r\n      restrain themselves from tears; so it may be to all a demonstration of\r\n      Satan&rsquo;s subtlety, whose design is still to destroy all, partly by tempting\r\n      many to presumption, and some others to despair. These things to be of\r\n      truth, are attested by an eye and ear witness who is yet alive, a faithful\r\n      minister of the gospel."<a href="#linknote-71" name="linknoteref-71"\r\n       id="linknoteref-71"><small>71</small></a> It is strange the inference does\r\n      not seem to have been deduced, that as one woman out of very despair\r\n      renounced her own life, the same might have been the case in many other\r\n      instances, wherein the confessions of the accused constituted the\r\n      principal if not sole evidence of the guilt.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-71" id="linknote-71"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      71 (<a href="#linknoteref-71">return</a>)<br /> [ Sinclair&rsquo;s &ldquo;Satan&rsquo;s\r\n      Invisible World Discovered,&rdquo; p. 43.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      One celebrated mode of detecting witches and torturing them at the same\r\n      time, to draw forth confession, was by running pins into their body, on\r\n      pretence of discovering the devil&rsquo;s stigma, or mark, which was said to be\r\n      inflicted by him upon all his vassals, and to be insensible to pain. This\r\n      species of search, the practice of the infamous Hopkins, was in Scotland\r\n      reduced to a trade; and the young witchfinder was allowed to torture the\r\n      accused party, as if in exercise of a lawful calling, although Sir George\r\n      Mackenzie stigmatises it as a horrid imposture. I observe in the\r\n      Collections of Mr. Pitcairn, that at the trial of Janet Peaston of\r\n      Dalkeith the magistrates and ministers of that market town caused John\r\n      Kincaid of Tranent, the common pricker, to exercise his craft upon her,\r\n      &ldquo;who found two marks of what he called the devil&rsquo;s making, and which\r\n      appeared indeed to be so, for she could not feel the pin when it was put\r\n      into either of the said marks, nor did they (the marks) bleed when they\r\n      were taken out again; and when she was asked where she thought the pins\r\n      were put in, she pointed to a part of her body distant from the real\r\n      place. They were pins of three inches in length.&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Besides the fact that the persons of old people especially sometimes\r\n      contain spots void of sensibility, there is also room to believe that the\r\n      professed prickers used a pin the point or lower part of which was, on\r\n      being pressed down, sheathed in the upper, which was hollow for the\r\n      purpose, and that which appeared to enter the body did not pierce it at\r\n      all. But, were it worth while to dwell on a subject so ridiculous, we\r\n      might recollect that in so terrible an agony of shame as is likely to\r\n      convulse a human being under such a trial, and such personal insults, the\r\n      blood is apt to return to the heart, and a slight wound, as with a pin,\r\n      may be inflicted without being followed by blood. In the latter end of the\r\n      seventeenth century this childish, indecent, and brutal practice began to\r\n      be called by its right name. Fountainhall has recorded that in 1678 the\r\n      Privy Council received the complaint of a poor woman who had been abused\r\n      by a country magistrate and one of those impostors called prickers. They\r\n      expressed high displeasure against the presumption of the parties\r\n      complained against, and treated the pricker as a common cheat.<a\r\n      href="#linknote-72" name="linknoteref-72" id="linknoteref-72"><small>72</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-72" id="linknote-72"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      72 (<a href="#linknoteref-72">return</a>)<br /> [ Fountainhall&rsquo;s\r\n      &ldquo;Decisions,&rdquo; vol. i. p. 15.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      From this and other instances it appears that the predominance of the\r\n      superstition of witchcraft, and the proneness to persecute those accused\r\n      of such practices in Scotland, were increased by the too great readiness\r\n      of subordinate judges to interfere in matters which were, in fact, beyond\r\n      their jurisdiction. The Supreme Court of Justiciary was that in which the\r\n      cause properly and exclusively ought to have been tried. But, in practice,\r\n      each inferior judge in the country, the pettiest bailie in the most\r\n      trifling burgh, the smallest and most ignorant baron of a rude territory,\r\n      took it on him to arrest, imprison, and examine, in which examinations, as\r\n      we have already seen, the accused suffered the grossest injustice. The\r\n      copies of these examinations, made up of extorted confessions, or the\r\n      evidence of inhabile witnesses, were all that were transmitted to the\r\n      Privy Council, who were to direct the future mode of procedure. Thus no\r\n      creature was secure against the malice or folly of some defamatory\r\n      accusation, if there was a timid or superstitious judge, though of the\r\n      meanest denomination, to be found within the district.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      But, secondly, it was the course of the Privy Council to appoint\r\n      commissions of the gentlemen of the country, and particularly of the\r\n      clergymen, though not likely, from their education, to be freed from\r\n      general prejudice, and peculiarly liable to be affected by the clamour of\r\n      the neighbourhood againt the delinquent. Now, as it is well known that\r\n      such a commission could not be granted in a case of murder in the county\r\n      where the crime was charged, there seems no good reason why the trial of\r\n      witches, so liable to excite the passions, should not have been uniformly\r\n      tried by a court whose rank and condition secured them from the suspicion\r\n      of partiality. But our ancestors arranged it otherwise, and it was the\r\n      consequence that such commissioners very seldom, by acquitting the persons\r\n      brought before them, lost an opportunity of destroying a witch.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Neither must it be forgotten that the proof led in support of the\r\n      prosecution was of a kind very unusual in jurisprudence. The lawyers\r\n      admitted as evidence what they called <i>damnum minatum, et malum secutum</i>&mdash;some\r\n      mischief, that is to say, following close upon a threat, or wish of\r\n      revenge, uttered by the supposed witch, which, though it might be\r\n      attributed to the most natural course of events, was supposed necessarily\r\n      to be in consequence of the menaces of the accused.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Sometimes this vague species of evidence was still more loosely adduced,\r\n      and allegations of danger threatened and mischief ensuing were admitted,\r\n      though the menaces had not come from the accused party herself. On 10th\r\n      June, 1661, as John Stewart, one of a party of stout burghers of Dalkeith\r\n      appointed to guard an old woman called Christian Wilson from that town to\r\n      Niddrie, was cleaning his gun, he was slyly questioned by Janet Cocke,\r\n      another confessing witch, who probably saw his courage was not entirely\r\n      constant, &ldquo;What would you think if the devil raise a whirlwind, and take\r\n      her from you on the road to-morrow?&rdquo; Sure enough, on their journey to\r\n      Niddrie the party actually were assailed by a sudden gust of wind (not a\r\n      very uncommon event in that climate), which scarce permitted the valiant\r\n      guard to keep their feet, while the miserable prisoner was blown into a\r\n      pool of water, and with difficulty raised again. There is some ground to\r\n      hope that this extraordinary evidence was not admitted upon the trial.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      There is a story told of an old wizard, whose real name was Alexander\r\n      Hunter, though he was more generally known by the nickname of Hatteraick,\r\n      which it had pleased the devil to confer upon him. The man had for some\r\n      time adopted the credit of being a conjurer, and curing the diseases of\r\n      man and beast by spells and charms. One summer&rsquo;s day, on a green\r\n      hill-side, the devil appeared to him in shape of a grave &ldquo;Mediciner,&rdquo;\r\n       addressing him thus roundly, &ldquo;Sandie, you have too long followed my trade\r\n      without acknowledging me for a master. You must now enlist with me and\r\n      become my servant, and I will teach you your trade better.&rdquo; Hatteraick\r\n      consented to the proposal, and we shall let the Rev. Mr. George Sinclair\r\n      tell the rest of the tale.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;After this he grew very famous through the country for his charming and\r\n      curing of diseases in men and beasts, and turned a vagrant fellow like a\r\n      jockie,<a href="#linknote-73" name="linknoteref-73" id="linknoteref-73"><small>73</small></a>\r\n      gaining meal, and flesh, and money by his charms, such was the ignorance\r\n      of many at that time. Whatever house he came to none durst refuse\r\n      Hatteraick an alms, rather for his ill than his good. One day he came to\r\n      the yait (gate) of Samuelston, when some friends after dinner were going\r\n      to horse. A young gentleman, brother to the lady, seeing him, switcht him\r\n      about the ears, saying&mdash;&lsquo;You warlock carle, what have you to do\r\n      here?&rsquo; Whereupon the fellow goes away grumbling, and was overheard to say,\r\n      &lsquo;You shall dear buy this ere it be long.&rsquo; This was <i>damnum minatum</i>.\r\n      The young gentleman conveyed his friends a far way off, and came home that\r\n      way again, where he supped. After supper, taking his horse and crossing\r\n      Tyne water to go home, he rides through a shady piece of a haugh, commonly\r\n      called Allers, and the evening being somewhat dark, he met with some\r\n      persons there that begat a dreadful consternation in him, which for the\r\n      most part he would never reveal. This was <i>malum secutum</i>. When he\r\n      came home the servants observed terror and fear in his countenance. The\r\n      next day he became distracted, and was bound for several days. His sister,\r\n      the Lady Samuelston, hearing of it, was heard say, &lsquo;Surely that knave\r\n      Hatteraick is the cause of his trouble; call for him in all haste.&rsquo; When\r\n      he had come to her, &lsquo;Sandie,&rsquo; says she, &lsquo;what is this you have done to my\r\n      brother William?&rsquo; &lsquo;I told him,&rsquo; says he, &lsquo;I should make him repent of his\r\n      striking me at the yait lately.&rsquo; She, giving the rogue fair words, and\r\n      promising him his pockful of meal, with beef and cheese, persuaded the\r\n      fellow to cure him again. He undertook the business. &lsquo;But I must first,&rsquo;\r\n      says he, &lsquo;have one of his sarks&rsquo; (shirts), which was soon gotten. What\r\n      pranks he played with it cannot be known, but within a short while the\r\n      gentleman recovered his health. When Hatteraick came to receive his wages\r\n      he told the lady, &lsquo;Your brother William shall quickly go off the country,\r\n      but shall never return,&rsquo; She, knowing the fellow&rsquo;s prophecies to hold\r\n      true, caused the brother to make a disposition to her of all his\r\n      patrimony, to the defrauding of his younger brother, George. After that\r\n      this warlock had abused the country for a long time, he was at last\r\n      apprehended at Dunbar, and brought into Edinburgh, and burnt upon the\r\n      Castlehill."<a href="#linknote-74" name="linknoteref-74"\r\n       id="linknoteref-74"><small>74</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-73" id="linknote-73"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      73 (<a href="#linknoteref-73">return</a>)<br /> [ Or Scottish wandering\r\n      beggar.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-74" id="linknote-74"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      74 (<a href="#linknoteref-74">return</a>)<br /> [ Sinclair&rsquo;s &ldquo;Satan&rsquo;s\r\n      Invisible World Discovered,&rdquo; p. 98.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Now, if Hatteraick was really put to death on such evidence, it is worth\r\n      while to consider what was its real amount. A hot-tempered swaggering\r\n      young gentleman horsewhips a beggar of ill fame for loitering about the\r\n      gate of his sister&rsquo;s house. The beggar grumbles, as any man would. The\r\n      young man, riding in the night, and probably in liquor, through a dark\r\n      shady place, is frightened by, he would not, and probably could not, tell\r\n      what, and has a fever fit. His sister employs the wizard to take off the\r\n      spell according to his profession; and here is <i>damnum minatum, et malum\r\n      secutum</i>, and all legal cause for burning a man to ashes! The vagrant\r\n      Hatteraick probably knew something of the wild young man which might soon\r\n      oblige him to leave the country; and the selfish Lady Samuelston, learning\r\n      the probability of his departure, committed a fraud which ought to have\r\n      rendered her evidence inadmissible.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Besides these particular disadvantages, to which the parties accused of\r\n      this crime in Scotland were necessarily exposed, both in relation to the\r\n      judicature by which they were tried and the evidence upon which they were\r\n      convicted, their situation was rendered intolerable by the detestation in\r\n      which they were held by all ranks. The gentry hated them because the\r\n      diseases and death of their relations and children were often imputed to\r\n      them; the grossly superstitious vulgar abhorred them with still more\r\n      perfect dread and loathing. And amongst those natural feelings, others of\r\n      a less pardonable description found means to shelter themselves. In one\r\n      case, we are informed by Mackenzie, a poor girl was to die for witchcraft,\r\n      of whom the real crime was that she had attracted too great a share, in\r\n      the lady&rsquo;s opinion, of the attention of the laird.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Having thus given some reasons why the prosecutions for witchcraft in\r\n      Scotland were so numerous and fatal, we return to the general history of\r\n      the trials recorded from the reign of James V. to the union of the\r\n      kingdoms. Through the reign of Queen Mary these trials for sorcery became\r\n      numerous, and the crime was subjected to heavier punishment by the 73rd\r\n      Act of her 9th Parliament. But when James VI. approached to years of\r\n      discretion, the extreme anxiety which he displayed to penetrate more\r\n      deeply into mysteries which others had regarded as a very millstone of\r\n      obscurity, drew still larger attention to the subject. The sovereign had\r\n      exhausted his talents of investigation on the subject of witchcraft, and\r\n      credit was given to all who acted in defence of the opinions of the\r\n      reigning prince. This natural tendency to comply with the opinions of the\r\n      sovereign was much augmented by the disposition of the Kirk to the same\r\n      sentiments. We have already said that these venerable persons entertained,\r\n      with good faith, the general erroneous belief respecting witchcraft&mdash;regarding\r\n      it indeed as a crime which affected their own order more nearly than\r\n      others in the state, since, especially called to the service of heaven,\r\n      they were peculiarly bound to oppose the incursions of Satan. The works\r\n      which remain behind them show, among better things, an unhesitating belief\r\n      in what were called by them &ldquo;special providences;&rdquo; and this was equalled,\r\n      at least, by their credulity as to the actual interference of evil spirits\r\n      in the affairs of this world. They applied these principles of belief to\r\n      the meanest causes. A horse falling lame was a snare of the devil to keep\r\n      the good clergyman from preaching; the arrival of a skilful farrier was\r\n      accounted a special providence to defeat the purpose of Satan. This was,\r\n      doubtless, in a general sense true, since nothing can happen without the\r\n      foreknowledge and will of Heaven; but we are authorized to believe that\r\n      the period of supernatural interference has long passed away, and that the\r\n      great Creator is content to execute his purposes by the operation of those\r\n      laws which influence the general course of nature. Our ancient Scottish\r\n      divines thought otherwise. Surrounded, as they conceived themselves, by\r\n      the snares and temptations of hell, and relying on the aid of Heaven, they\r\n      entered into war with the kingdom of Satan, as the crusaders of old\r\n      invaded the land of Palestine, with the same confidence in the justice of\r\n      their cause and similar indifference concerning the feelings of those whom\r\n      they accounted the enemies of God and man. We have already seen that even\r\n      the conviction that a woman was innocent of the crime of witchcraft did\r\n      not induce a worthy clergyman to use any effort to withdraw her from the\r\n      stake; and in the same collection<a href="#linknote-75"\r\n       name="linknoteref-75" id="linknoteref-75"><small>75</small></a> there\r\n      occur some observable passages of God&rsquo;s providence to a godly minister in\r\n      giving him &ldquo;full clearness&rdquo; concerning Bessie Grahame, suspected of\r\n      witchcraft. The whole detail is a curious illustration of the spirit of\r\n      credulity which well-disposed men brought with them to such\r\n      investigations, and how easily the gravest doubts were removed rather than\r\n      a witch should be left undetected.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-75" id="linknote-75"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      75 (<a href="#linknoteref-75">return</a>)<br /> [ &ldquo;Satan&rsquo;s Invisible\r\n      World,&rdquo; by Mr. George Sinclair. The author was Professor of Moral\r\n      Philosophy in the University of Glasgow, and afterwards minister of\r\n      Eastwood, in Renfrewshire.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Bessie Grahame had been committed, it would seem, under suspicions of no\r\n      great weight, since the minister, after various conferences, found her\r\n      defence so successful, that he actually pitied her hard usage, and wished\r\n      for her delivery from prison, especially as he doubted whether a civil\r\n      court would send her to an assize, or whether an assize would be disposed\r\n      to convict her. While the minister was in this doubt, a fellow named Begg\r\n      was employed as a skilful pricker; by whose authority it is not said, he\r\n      thrust a great brass pin up to the head in a wart on the woman&rsquo;s back,\r\n      which he affirmed to be the devil&rsquo;s mark. A commission was granted for\r\n      trial; but still the chief gentlemen in the county refused to act, and the\r\n      clergyman&rsquo;s own doubts were far from being removed. This put the worthy\r\n      man upon a solemn prayer to God, &ldquo;that if he would find out a way for\r\n      giving the minister full clearness of her guilt, he would acknowledge it\r\n      as a singular favour and mercy.&rdquo; This, according to his idea, was\r\n      accomplished in the following manner, which he regarded as an answer to\r\n      his prayer. One evening the clergyman, with Alexander Simpson, the\r\n      kirk-officer, and his own servant, had visited Bessie in her cell, to urge\r\n      her to confession, but in vain. As they stood on the stair-head behind the\r\n      door, they heard the prisoner, whom they had left alone in her place of\r\n      confinement, discoursing with another person, who used a low and ghostly\r\n      tone, which the minister instantly recognised as the Foul Fiend&rsquo;s voice.\r\n      But for this discovery we should have been of opinion that Bessie Grahame\r\n      talked to herself, as melancholy and despairing wretches are in the habit\r\n      of doing. But as Alexander Simpson pretended to understand the sense of\r\n      what was said within the cell, and the minister himself was pretty sure he\r\n      heard two voices at the same time, he regarded the overhearing this\r\n      conversation as the answer of the Deity to his petition, and thenceforth\r\n      was troubled with no doubts either as to the reasonableness and propriety\r\n      of his prayer, or the guilt of Bessie Grahame, though she died obstinate,\r\n      and would not confess; nay, made a most decent and Christian end,\r\n      acquitting her judges and jury of her blood, in respect of the strong\r\n      delusion under which they laboured.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Although the ministers, whose opinions were but two strongly on this head\r\n      in correspondence with the prevailing superstitions of the people,\r\n      nourished in the early system of church government a considerable desire\r\n      to secure their own immunities and privileges as a national church, which\r\n      failed not at last to be brought into contact with the king&rsquo;s prerogative;\r\n      yet in the earlier part of his reign, James, when freed from the influence\r\n      of such a favourite as the profligate Stuart, Earl of Arran, was in his\r\n      personal qualities rather acceptable to the clergy of his kingdom and\r\n      period. At his departing from Scotland on his romantic expedition to bring\r\n      home a consort from Denmark, he very politically recommended to the clergy\r\n      to contribute all that lay in their power to assist the civil magistrates,\r\n      and preserve the public peace of the kingdom. The king after his return\r\n      acknowledged with many thanks the care which the clergy had bestowed in\r\n      this particular. Nor were they slack in assuming the merit to themselves,\r\n      for they often reminded him in their future discords that his kingdom had\r\n      never been so quiet as during his voyage to Denmark, when the clergy were\r\n      in a great measure intrusted with the charge of the public government.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      During the halcyon period of union between kirk and king their hearty\r\n      agreement on the subject of witchcraft failed not to heat the fires\r\n      against the persons suspected of such iniquity. The clergy considered that\r\n      the Roman Catholics, their principal enemies, were equally devoted to the\r\n      devil, the mass, and the witches, which in their opinion were mutually\r\n      associated together, and natural allies in the great cause of mischief. On\r\n      the other hand, the pedantic sovereign having exercised his learning and\r\n      ingenuity in the Demonologia, considered the execution of every witch who\r\n      was burnt as a necessary conclusion of his own royal syllogisms. The\r\n      juries were also afraid of the consequences of acquittal to themselves,\r\n      being liable to suffer under an assize of error should they be thought to\r\n      have been unjustly merciful; and as the witches tried were personally as\r\n      insignificant as the charge itself was odious, there was no restraint\r\n      whatever upon those in whose hands their fate lay, and there seldom wanted\r\n      some such confession as we have often mentioned, or such evidence as that\r\n      collected by the minister who overheard the dialogue between the witch and\r\n      her master, to salve their consciences and reconcile them to bring in a\r\n      verdict of guilty.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The execution of witches became for these reasons very common in Scotland,\r\n      where the king seemed in some measure to have made himself a party in the\r\n      cause, and the clergy esteemed themselves such from the very nature of\r\n      their profession. But the general spite of Satan and his adherents was\r\n      supposed to be especially directed against James, on account of his match\r\n      with Anne of Denmark&mdash;the union of a Protestant princess with a\r\n      Protestant prince, the King of Scotland and heir of England being, it\r\n      could not be doubted, an event which struck the whole kingdom of darkness\r\n      with alarm. James was self-gratified by the unusual spirit which he had\r\n      displayed on his voyage in quest of his bride, and well disposed to fancy\r\n      that he had performed it in positive opposition, not only to the indirect\r\n      policy of Elizabeth, but to the malevolent purpose of hell itself. His\r\n      fleet had been tempest-tost, and he very naturally believed that the\r\n      prince of the power of the air had been personally active on the occasion.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The principal person implicated in these heretical and treasonable\r\n      undertakings was one Agnes Simpson, or Samson, called the Wise Wife of\r\n      Keith, and described by Archbishop Spottiswood, not as one of the base or\r\n      ignorant class of ordinary witches, but a grave matron, composed and\r\n      deliberate in her answers, which were all to some purpose. This grave\r\n      dame, from the terms of her indictment, seems to have been a kind of white\r\n      witch, affecting to cure diseases by words and charms, a dangerous\r\n      profession considering the times in which she lived. Neither did she\r\n      always keep the right and sheltered side of the law in such delicate\r\n      operations. One article of her indictment proves this, and at the same\r\n      time establishes that the Wise Woman of Keith knew how to turn her\r\n      profession to account; for, being consulted in the illness of Isobel\r\n      Hamilton, she gave her opinion that nothing could amend her unless the\r\n      devil was raised; and the sick woman&rsquo;s husband, startling at the proposal,\r\n      and being indifferent perhaps about the issue, would not bestow the\r\n      necessary expenses, whereupon the Wise Wife refused to raise the devil,\r\n      and the patient died. This woman was principally engaged in an extensive\r\n      conspiracy to destroy the fleet of the queen by raising a tempest; and to\r\n      take the king&rsquo;s life by anointing his linen with poisonous materials, and\r\n      by constructing figures of clay, to be wasted and tormented after the\r\n      usual fashion of necromancy.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Amongst her associates was an unhappy lady of much higher degree. This was\r\n      Dame Euphane MacCalzean, the widow of a Senator of the College of Justice,\r\n      and a person infinitely above the rank of the obscure witches with whom\r\n      she was joined in her crime. Mr. Pitcairn supposes that this connexion may\r\n      have arisen from her devotion to the Catholic faith and her friendship for\r\n      the Earl of Bothwell.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The third person in this singular league of sorcerers was Doctor John\r\n      Fian, otherwise Cunninghame, who was schoolmaster at Tranent, and enjoyed\r\n      much hazardous reputation as a warlock. This man was made the hero of the\r\n      whole tale of necromancy, in an account of it published at London, and\r\n      entitled, &ldquo;News from Scotland,&rdquo; which has been lately reprinted by the\r\n      Roxburghe Club. It is remarkable that the Scottish witchcrafts were not\r\n      thought sufficiently horrible by the editor of this tract, without adding\r\n      to them the story of a philtre being applied to a cow&rsquo;s hair instead of\r\n      that of the young woman for whom it was designed, and telling how the\r\n      animal came lowing after the sorcerer to his schoolroom door, like a\r\n      second Pasipha, the original of which charm occurs in the story of\r\n      Apuleius.<a href="#linknote-76" name="linknoteref-76" id="linknoteref-76"><small>76</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-76" id="linknote-76"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      76 (<a href="#linknoteref-76">return</a>)<br /> [ &ldquo;Lucii Apuleii\r\n      Metamorphoses,&rdquo; lib. iii.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Besides these persons, there was one Barbara Napier, alias Douglas, a\r\n      person of some rank; Geillis Duncan, a very active witch; and about thirty\r\n      other poor creatures of the lowest condition&mdash;among the rest, and\r\n      doorkeeper to the conclave, a silly old ploughman, called as his nickname\r\n      Graymeal, who was cuffed by the devil for saying simply, &ldquo;God bless the\r\n      king!&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      When the monarch of Scotland sprung this strong covey of his favourite\r\n      game, they afforded the Privy Council and him sport for the greatest part\r\n      of the remaining winter. He attended on the examinations himself, and by\r\n      one means or or other, they were indifferently well dressed to his palate.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Agnes Sampson, the grave matron before mentioned, after being an hour\r\n      tortured by the twisting of a cord around her head, according to the\r\n      custom of the Buccaneers, confessed that she had consulted with one\r\n      Richard Grahame concerning the probable length of the king&rsquo;s life, and the\r\n      means of shortening it. But Satan, to whom they at length resorted for\r\n      advice, told them in French respecting King James, <i>Il est un homme de\r\n      Dieu</i>. The poor woman also acknowledged that she had held a meeting\r\n      with those of her sisterhood, who had charmed a cat by certain spells,\r\n      having four joints of men knit to its feet, which they threw into the sea\r\n      to excite a tempest. Another frolic they had when, like the weird sisters\r\n      in Macbeth, they embarked in sieves with much mirth and jollity, the Fiend\r\n      rolling himself before them upon the waves, dimly seen, and resembling a\r\n      huge haystack in size and appearance. They went on board of a foreign ship\r\n      richly laded with wines, where, invisible to the crew, they feasted till\r\n      the sport grew tiresome, and then Satan sunk the vessel and all on board.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Fian, or Cunninghame, was also visited by the sharpest tortures, ordinary\r\n      and extraordinary. The nails were torn from his fingers with smith&rsquo;s\r\n      pincers; pins were driven into the places which the nails usually\r\n      defended; his knees were crushed in <i>the boots</i>, his finger bones\r\n      were splintered in the pilniewinks. At length his constancy, hitherto\r\n      sustained, as the bystanders supposed, by the help of the devil, was\r\n      fairly overcome, and he gave an account of a great witch-meeting at North\r\n      Berwick, where they paced round the church <i>withershinns</i>, that is,\r\n      in reverse of the motion of the sun. Fian then blew into the lock of the\r\n      church-door, whereupon the bolts gave way, the unhallowed crew entered,\r\n      and their master the devil appeared to his servants in the shape of a\r\n      black man occupying the pulpit. He was saluted with an &ldquo;Hail, Master!&rdquo; but\r\n      the company were dissatisfied with his not having brought a picture of the\r\n      king, repeatedly promised, which was to place his majesty at the mercy of\r\n      this infernal crew. The devil was particularly upbraided on this subject\r\n      by divers respectable-looking females&mdash;no question, Euphane\r\n      MacCalzean, Barbara Napier, Agnes Sampson, and some other amateur witch\r\n      above those of the ordinary profession. The devil on this memorable\r\n      occasion forgot himself, and called Fian by his own name, instead of the\r\n      demoniacal <i>sobriquet</i> of Rob the Rowar, which had been assigned to\r\n      him as Master of the Rows or Rolls. This was considered as bad taste, and\r\n      the rule is still observed at every rendezvous of forgers, smugglers, or\r\n      the like, where it is accounted very indifferent manners to name an\r\n      individual by his own name, in case of affording ground of evidence which\r\n      may upon a day of trial be brought against him. Satan, something\r\n      disconcerted, concluded the evening with a divertisement and a dance after\r\n      his own manner. The former consisted in disinterring a new-buried corpse,\r\n      and dividing it in fragments among the company, and the ball was\r\n      maintained by well-nigh two hundred persons, who danced a ring dance,\r\n      singing this chant&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;Cummer, gang ye before; Cummer gang ye. Gif ye will not gang before,\r\n      Cummers, let me.&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      After this choral exhibition, the music seems to have been rather\r\n      imperfect, the number of dancers considered. Geillis Duncan was the only\r\n      instrumental performer, and she played on a Jew&rsquo;s harp, called in Scotland\r\n      a <i>trump</i>. Dr. Fian, muffled, led the ring, and was highly honoured,\r\n      generally acting as clerk or recorder, as above mentioned.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      King James was deeply interested in those mysterious meetings, and took\r\n      great delight to be present at the examinations of the accused. He sent\r\n      for Geillis Duncan, and caused her to play before him the same tune to\r\n      which Satan and his companions led the brawl in North Berwick churchyard.<a\r\n      href="#linknote-77" name="linknoteref-77" id="linknoteref-77"><small>77</small></a>\r\n      His ears were gratified in another way, for at this meeting it was said\r\n      the witches demanded of the devil why he did bear such enmity against the\r\n      king? who returned the flattering answer that the king was the greatest\r\n      enemy whom he had in the world.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-77" id="linknote-77"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      77 (<a href="#linknoteref-77">return</a>)<br /> [ The music of this witch\r\n      tune is unhappily lost. But that of another, believed to have been popular\r\n      on such occasions, is preserved.\r\n    </p>\r\n<pre xml:space="preserve">\r\n&ldquo;The silly bit chicken, gar cast her a pickle,\r\n And she will grow mickle,\r\n         And she will do good.&rdquo;]\r\n</pre>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Almost all these poor wretches were executed, nor did Euphane MacCalzean&rsquo;s\r\n      station in life save her from the common doom, which was strangling to\r\n      death, and burning to ashes thereafter. The majority of the jury which\r\n      tried Barbara Napier having acquitted her of attendance at the North\r\n      Berwick meeting, were themselves threatened with a trial for wilful error\r\n      upon an assize, and could only escape from severe censure and punishment\r\n      by pleading guilty, and submitting themselves to the king&rsquo;s pleasure. This\r\n      rigorous and iniquitous conduct shows a sufficient reason why there should\r\n      be so few acquittals from a charge of witchcraft where the juries were so\r\n      much at the mercy of the crown.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It would be disgusting to follow the numerous cases in which the same\r\n      uniform credulity, the same extorted confessions, the same prejudiced and\r\n      exaggerated evidence, concluded in the same tragedy at the stake and the\r\n      pile. The alterations and trenching which lately took place for the\r\n      purpose of improving the Castlehill of Edinburgh displayed the ashes of\r\n      the numbers who had perished in this manner, of whom a large proportion\r\n      must have been executed between 1590, when the great discovery was made\r\n      concerning Euphane MacCalzean and the Wise Wife of Keith and their\r\n      accomplices, and the union of the crowns.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Nor did King James&rsquo;s removal to England soften this horrible persecution.\r\n      In Sir Thomas Hamilton&rsquo;s Minutes of Proceedings in the Privy Council,\r\n      there occurs a singular entry, evincing plainly that the Earl of Mar, and\r\n      others of James&rsquo;s Council, were becoming fully sensible of the desperate\r\n      iniquity and inhumanity of these proceedings. I have modernized the\r\n      spelling that this appalling record may be legible to all my readers.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;1608, December 1. The Earl of Mar declared to the Council that some women\r\n      were taken in Broughton as witches, and being put to an assize and\r\n      convicted, albeit they persevered constant in their denial to the end, yet\r\n      they were burned quick [<i>alive</i>] after such a cruel manner that some\r\n      of them died in despair, renouncing and blaspheming [God]; and others,\r\n      half burned, brak out of the fire,<a href="#linknote-78"\r\n       name="linknoteref-78" id="linknoteref-78"><small>78</small></a> and were\r\n      cast quick in it again, till they were burned to the death.&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-78" id="linknote-78"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      78 (<a href="#linknoteref-78">return</a>)<br /> [ I am obliged to the\r\n      kindness of Mr. Pitcairn for this singular extract. The southern reader\r\n      must be informed that the jurisdiction or regality of Broughton embraced\r\n      Holyrood, Canongate, Leith, and other suburban parts of Edinburgh, and\r\n      bore the same relation to that city as the borough of Southwark to\r\n      London.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      This singular document shows that even in the reign of James, so soon as\r\n      his own august person was removed from Edinburgh, his dutiful Privy\r\n      Council began to think that they had supt full with horrors, and were\r\n      satiated with the excess of cruelty which dashed half-consumed wretches\r\n      back into the flames from which they were striving to escape.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      But the picture, however much it may have been disgusting and terrifying\r\n      to the Council at the time, and though the intention of the entry upon the\r\n      records was obviously for the purpose of preventing such horrid cruelties\r\n      in future, had no lasting effect on the course of justice, as the\r\n      severities against witches were most unhappily still considered necessary.\r\n      Through the whole of the sixteenth, and the greater part of the\r\n      seventeenth century, little abatement in the persecution of this\r\n      metaphysical crime of witchcraft can be traced in the kingdom. Even while\r\n      the Independents held the reins of government, Cromwell himself, and his\r\n      major-generals and substitutes, were obliged to please the common people\r\n      of Scotland by abandoning the victims accused of witchcraft to the power\r\n      of the law, though the journals of the time express the horror and disgust\r\n      with which the English sectarians beheld a practice so inconsistent with\r\n      their own humane principle of universal toleration.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Instead of plunging into a history of these events which, generally\r\n      speaking, are in detail as monotonous as they are melancholy, it may amuse\r\n      the reader to confine the narrative to a single trial, having in the\r\n      course of it some peculiar and romantic events. It is the tale of a\r\n      sailor&rsquo;s wife, more tragic in its event than that of the chestnut-muncher\r\n      in Macbeth.<a href="#linknote-79" name="linknoteref-79" id="linknoteref-79"><small>79</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-79" id="linknote-79"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      79 (<a href="#linknoteref-79">return</a>)<br /> [ A copy of the record of\r\n      the trial, which took place in Ayrshire, was sent to me by a friend who\r\n      withheld his name, so that I can only thank him in this general\r\n      acknowledgment.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Margaret Barclay, wife of Archibald Dein, burgess of Irvine, had been\r\n      slandered by her sister-in-law, Janet Lyal, the spouse of John Dein,\r\n      brother of Archibald, and by John Dein himself, as guilty of some act of\r\n      theft. Upon this provocation Margaret Barclay raised an action of slander\r\n      before the church court, which prosecution, after some procedure, the\r\n      kirk-session discharged by directing a reconciliation between the parties.\r\n      Nevertheless, although the two women shook hands before the court, yet the\r\n      said Margaret Barclay declared that she gave her hand only in obedience to\r\n      the kirk-session, but that she still retained her hatred and ill-will\r\n      against John Dein and his wife, Janet Lyal. About this time the bark of\r\n      John Dein was about to sail for France, and Andrew Train, or Tran, provost\r\n      of the burgh of Irvine, who was an owner of the vessel, went with him to\r\n      superintend the commercial part of the voyage. Two other merchants of some\r\n      consequence went in the same vessel, with a sufficient number of mariners.\r\n      Margaret Barclay, the revengeful person already mentioned, was heard to\r\n      imprecate curses upon the provost&rsquo;s argosy, praying to God that sea nor\r\n      salt-water might never bear the ship, and that <i>partans</i> (crabs)\r\n      might eat the crew at the bottom of the sea.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      When, under these auspices, the ship was absent on her voyage, a vagabond\r\n      fellow, named John Stewart, pretending to have knowledge of jugglery, and\r\n      to possess the power of a spaeman, came to the residence of Tran, the\r\n      provost, and dropped explicit hints that the ship was lost, and that the\r\n      good woman of the house was a widow. The sad truth was afterwards learned\r\n      on more certain information. Two of the seamen, after a space of doubt and\r\n      anxiety, arrived, with the melancholy tidings that the bark, of which John\r\n      Dein was skipper and Provost Tran part owner, had been wrecked on the\r\n      coast of England, near Padstow, when all on board had been lost, except\r\n      the two sailors who brought the notice. Suspicion of sorcery, in those\r\n      days easily awakened, was fixed on Margaret Barclay, who had imprecated\r\n      curses on the ship, and on John Stewart, the juggler, who had seemed to\r\n      know of the evil fate of the voyage before he could have become acquainted\r\n      with it by natural means.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Stewart, who was first apprehended, acknowledged that Margaret Barclay,\r\n      the other suspected person, had applied to him to teach her some magic\r\n      arts, &ldquo;in order that she might get gear, kye&rsquo;s milk, love of man, her\r\n      heart&rsquo;s desire on such persons as had done her wrong, and, finally, that\r\n      she might obtain the fruit of sea and land.&rdquo; Stewart declared that he\r\n      denied to Margaret that he possessed the said arts himself, or had the\r\n      power of communicating them. So far was well; but, true or false, he added\r\n      a string of circumstances, whether voluntarily declared or extracted by\r\n      torture, which tended to fix the cause of the loss of the bark on Margaret\r\n      Barclay. He had come, he said, to this woman&rsquo;s house in Irvine, shortly\r\n      after the ship set sail from harbour. He went to Margaret&rsquo;s house by\r\n      night, and found her engaged, with other two women, in making clay\r\n      figures; one of the figures was made handsome, with fair hair, supposed to\r\n      represent Provost Tran. They then proceeded to mould a figure of a ship in\r\n      clay, and during this labour the devil appeared to the company in the\r\n      shape of a handsome black lap-dog, such as ladies use to keep.<a\r\n      href="#linknote-80" name="linknoteref-80" id="linknoteref-80"><small>80</small></a>\r\n      He added that the whole party left the house together, and went into an\r\n      empty waste-house nearer the seaport, which house he pointed out to the\r\n      city magistrates. From this house they went to the sea-side, followed by\r\n      the black lap-dog aforesaid, and cast in the figures of clay representing\r\n      the ship and the men; after which the sea raged, roared, and became red\r\n      like the juice of madder in a dyer&rsquo;s cauldron.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-80" id="linknote-80"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      80 (<a href="#linknoteref-80">return</a>)<br /> [ This may remind the\r\n      reader of Cazotte&rsquo;s &ldquo;Diable Amoureux.&rdquo;]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      This confession having been extorted from the unfortunate juggler, the\r\n      female acquaintances of Margaret Barclay were next convened, that he might\r\n      point out her associates in forming the charm, when he pitched upon a\r\n      woman called Isobel Insh, or Taylor, who resolutely denied having ever\r\n      seen him before. She was imprisoned, however, in the belfry of the church.\r\n      An addition to the evidence against the poor old woman Insh was then\r\n      procured from her own daughter, Margaret Tailzeour, <i>a child of eight\r\n      years old</i>, who lived as servant with Margaret Barclay, the person\r\n      principally accused. This child, who was keeper of a baby belonging to\r\n      Margaret Barclay, either from terror or the innate love of falsehood which\r\n      we have observed as proper to childhood, declared that she was present\r\n      when the fatal models of clay were formed, and that, in plunging them in\r\n      the sea, Margaret Barclay her mistress, and her mother Isobel Insh, were\r\n      assisted by another woman, and a girl of fourteen years old, who dwelt at\r\n      the town-head. Legally considered, the evidence of this child was\r\n      contradictory and inconsistent with the confession of the juggler, for it\r\n      assigned other particulars and <i>dramatis person</i> in many respects\r\n      different. But all was accounted sufficiently regular, especially since\r\n      the girl failed not to swear to the presence of the black dog, to whose\r\n      appearance she also added the additional terrors of that of a black man.\r\n      The dog also, according to her account, emitted flashes from its jaws and\r\n      nostrils to illuminate the witches during the performance of the spell.\r\n      The child maintained this story even to her mother&rsquo;s face, only alleging\r\n      that Isobel Insh remained behind in the waste-house, and was not present\r\n      when the images were put into the sea. For her own countenance and\r\n      presence on the occasion, and to ensure her secrecy, her mistress promised\r\n      her a pair of new shoes.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      John Stewart, being re-examined and confronted with the child, was easily\r\n      compelled to allow that the &ldquo;little smatchet&rdquo; was there, and to give that\r\n      marvellous account of his correspondence with Elfland which we have\r\n      noticed elsewhere.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The conspiracy thus far, as they conceived, disclosed, the magistrates and\r\n      ministers wrought hard with Isobel Insh to prevail upon her to tell the\r\n      truth; and she at length acknowledged her presence at the time when the\r\n      models of the ship and mariners were destroyed, but endeavoured so to\r\n      modify her declaration as to deny all personal accession to the guilt.\r\n      This poor creature almost admitted the supernatural powers imputed to her,\r\n      promising Bailie Dunlop (also a mariner), by whom she was imprisoned,\r\n      that, if he would dismiss her, he should never make a bad voyage, but have\r\n      success in all his dealings by sea and land. She was finally brought to\r\n      promise that she would fully confess the whole that she knew of the affair\r\n      on the morrow.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      But finding herself in so hard a strait, the unfortunate woman made use of\r\n      the darkness to attempt an escape. With this view she got out by a back\r\n      window of the belfry, although, says the report, there were &ldquo;iron bolts,\r\n      locks, and fetters on her,&rdquo; and attained the roof of the church, where,\r\n      losing her footing, she sustained a severe fall and was greatly bruised.\r\n      Being apprehended, Bailie Dunlop again urged her to confess; but the poor\r\n      woman was determined to appeal to a more merciful tribunal, and maintained\r\n      her innocence to the last minute of her life, denying all that she had\r\n      formerly admitted, and dying five days after her fall from the roof of the\r\n      church. The inhabitants of Irvine attributed her death to poison.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The scene began to thicken, for a commission was granted for the trial of\r\n      the two remaining persons accused, namely, Stewart, the juggler, and\r\n      Margaret Barclay. The day of trial being arrived, the following singular\r\n      events took place, which we give as stated in the record:&mdash;\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;My Lord and Earl of Eglintoune (who dwells within the space of one mile\r\n      to the said burgh) having come to the said burgh at the earnest request of\r\n      the said justices, for giving to them of his lordship&rsquo;s countenance,\r\n      concurrence and assistance, in trying of the foresaid devilish practices,\r\n      conform to the tenor of the foresaid commission, the said John Stewart,\r\n      for his better preserving to the day of the assize, was put in a sure\r\n      lockfast booth, where no manner of person might have access to him till\r\n      the downsitting of the Justice Court, and for avoiding of putting violent\r\n      hands on himself, he was very strictly guarded and fettered by the arms,\r\n      as use is. And upon that same day of the assize, about half an hour before\r\n      the downsitting of the Justice Court, Mr. David Dickson, minister at\r\n      Irvine, and Mr. George Dunbar, minister of Air, having gone to him to\r\n      exhort him to call on his God for mercy for his bygone wicked and evil\r\n      life, and that God would of his infinite mercy loose him out of the bonds\r\n      of the devil, whom he had served these many years bygone, he acquiesced in\r\n      their prayer and godly exhortation, and uttered these words:&mdash;&ldquo;I am\r\n      so straitly guarded that it lies not in my power to get my hand to take\r\n      off my bonnet, nor to get bread to my mouth.&rdquo; And immediately after the\r\n      departing of the two ministers from him, the juggler being sent for at the\r\n      desire of my Lord of Eglintoune, to be confronted with a woman of the\r\n      burgh of Air, called Janet Bous, who was apprehended by the magistrates of\r\n      the burgh of Air for witchcraft, and sent to the burgh of Irvine purposely\r\n      for that affair, he was found by the burgh officers who went about him,\r\n      strangled and hanged by the cruik of the door, with a <i>tait</i> of hemp,\r\n      or a string made of hemp, supposed to have been his garter, or string of\r\n      his bonnet, not above the length of two span long, his knees not being\r\n      from the ground half a span, and was brought out of the house, his life\r\n      not being totally expelled. But notwithstanding of whatsoever means used\r\n      in the contrary for remeid of his life, he revived not, but so ended his\r\n      life miserably, by the help of the devil his master.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;And because there was then only in life the said Margaret Barclay, and\r\n      that the persons summoned to pass upon her assize and upon the assize of\r\n      the juggler who, by the help of the devil his master, had put violent\r\n      hands on himself, were all present within the said burgh; therefore, and\r\n      for eschewing of the like in the person of the said Margaret, our\r\n      sovereign lord&rsquo;s justices in that part particularly above-named,\r\n      constituted by commission after solemn deliberation and advice of the said\r\n      noble lord, whose concurrence and advice was chiefly required and taken in\r\n      this matter, concluded with all possible diligence before the downsitting\r\n      of the Justice Court to put the said Margaret in torture; in respect the\r\n      devil, by God&rsquo;s permission, had made her associates who were the lights of\r\n      the cause, to be their own <i>burrioes</i> (slayers). They used the\r\n      torture underwritten as being most safe and gentle (as the said noble lord\r\n      assured the said justices), by putting of her two bare legs in a pair of\r\n      stocks, and thereafter by onlaying of certain iron gauds (bars) severally\r\n      one by one, and then eiking and augmenting the weight by laying on more\r\n      gauds, and in easing of her by offtaking of the iron gauds one or more as\r\n      occasion offered, which iron gauds were but little short gauds, and broke\r\n      not the skin of her legs, &amp;c.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;After using of the which kind of <i>gentle torture</i>, the said Margaret\r\n      began, according to the increase of the pain, to cry and crave for God&rsquo;s\r\n      cause to take off her shins the foresaid irons, and she should declare\r\n      truly the whole matter.
