Which being removed, she began at her former\r\n      denial; and being of new essayed in torture as of befoir, she then uttered\r\n      these words: &lsquo;Take off, take off, and before God I shall show you the\r\n      whole form!&rsquo;\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      &ldquo;And the said irons being of new, upon her faithfull promise, removed, she\r\n      then desired my Lord of Eglintoune, the said four justices, and the said\r\n      Mr. David Dickson, minister of the burgh, Mr. George Dunbar, minister of\r\n      Ayr, and Mr. Mitchell Wallace, minister of Kilmarnock, and Mr. John\r\n      Cunninghame, minister of Dalry, and Hugh Kennedy, provost of Ayr, to come\r\n      by themselves and to remove all others, and she should declare truly, as\r\n      she should answer to God the whole matter. Whose desire in that being\r\n      fulfilled she made her confession in this manner, but (<i>i.e.,</i>\r\n      without) any kind of demand, freely, without interrogation; God&rsquo;s name by\r\n      earnest prayer being called upon for opening of her lips, and easing of\r\n      her heart, that she, by rendering of the truth, might glorify and magnify\r\n      his holy name, and disappoint the enemy of her salvation.&rdquo;&mdash;<i>Trial\r\n      of Margaret Barclay, &amp;c</i>., 1618.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Margaret Barclay, who was a young and lively person, had hitherto\r\n      conducted herself like a passionate and high-tempered woman innocently\r\n      accused, and the only appearance of conviction obtained against her was,\r\n      that she carried about her rowan-tree and coloured thread, to make, as she\r\n      said, her cow give milk, when it began to fail. But the <i>gentle torture</i>&mdash;a\r\n      strange junction of words&mdash;recommended as an anodyne by the good Lord\r\n      Eglinton&mdash;the placing, namely, her legs in the stocks, and loading\r\n      her bare shins with bars of iron, overcame her resolution; when, at her\r\n      screams and declarations that she was willing to tell all, the weights\r\n      were removed. She then told a story of destroying the ship of John Dein,\r\n      affirming that it was with the purpose of killing only her brother-in-law\r\n      and Provost Tran, and saving the rest of the crew. She at the same time\r\n      involved in the guilt Isobel Crawford. This poor woman was also\r\n      apprehended, and in great terror confessed the imputed crime, retorting\r\n      the principal blame on Margaret Barclay herself. The trial was then\r\n      appointed to proceed, when Alexander Dein, the husband of Margaret\r\n      Barclay, appeared in court with a lawyer to act in his wife&rsquo;s behalf.\r\n      Apparently, the sight of her husband awakened some hope and desire of\r\n      life, for when the prisoner was asked by the lawyer whether she wished to\r\n      be defended? she answered, &ldquo;As you please But all I have confest was in\r\n      agony of torture; and, before God, all I have spoken is false and untrue.&rdquo;\r\n       To which she pathetically added, &ldquo;Ye have been too long in coming.&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The jury, unmoved by these affecting circumstances, proceeded upon the\r\n      principle that the confession of the accused could not be considered as\r\n      made under the influence of torture, since the bars were not actually upon\r\n      her limbs at the time it was delivered, although they were placed at her\r\n      elbow ready to be again laid on her bare shins, if she was less explicit\r\n      in her declaration than her auditors wished. On this nice distinction they\r\n      in one voice found Margaret Barclay guilty. It is singular that she should\r\n      have again returned to her confession after sentence, and died affirming\r\n      it; the explanation of which, however, might be either that she had really\r\n      in her ignorance and folly tampered with some idle spells, or that an\r\n      apparent penitence for her offence, however imaginary, was the only mode\r\n      in which she could obtain any share of public sympathy at her death, or a\r\n      portion of the prayers of the clergy and congregation, which, in her\r\n      circumstances, she might be willing to purchase, even by confession of\r\n      what all believed respecting her. It is remarkable that she earnestly\r\n      entreated the magistrates that no harm should be done to Isobel Crawford,\r\n      the woman whom she had herself accused. This unfortunate young creature\r\n      was strangled at the stake, and her body burnt to ashes, having died with\r\n      many expressions of religion and penitence.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It was one fatal consequence of these cruel persecutions, that one pile\r\n      was usually lighted at the embers of another. Accordingly in the present\r\n      case, three victims having already perished by this accusation, the\r\n      magistrates, incensed at the nature of the crime, so perilous as it seemed\r\n      to men of a maritime life, and at the loss of several friends of their\r\n      own, one of &ldquo;whom had been their principal magistrate, did not forbear to\r\n      insist against Isobel Crawford, inculpated by Margaret Barclay&rsquo;s\r\n      confession. A new commission was granted for her trial, and after the\r\n      assistant minister of Irvine, Mr. David Dickson, had made earnest prayers\r\n      to God for opening her obdurate and closed heart, she was subjected to the\r\n      torture of iron bars laid upon her bare shins, her feet being in the\r\n      stocks, as in the case of Margaret Barclay.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      She endured this torture with incredible firmness, since she did\r\n      &ldquo;admirably, without any kind of din or exclamation, suffer above thirty\r\n      stone of iron to be laid on her legs, never shrinking thereat in any sort,\r\n      but remaining, as it were, steady.&rdquo; But in shifting the situation of the\r\n      iron bars, and removing them to another part of her shins, her constancy\r\n      gave way; she broke out into horrible cries (though not more than three\r\n      bars were then actually on her person) of&mdash;&ldquo;Tak aff&mdash;tak aff!&rdquo;\r\n       On being relieved from the torture, she made the usual confession of all\r\n      that she was charged with, and of a connexion with the devil which had\r\n      subsisted for several years. Sentence was given against her accordingly.\r\n      After this had been denounced, she openly denied all her former\r\n      confessions, and died without any sign of repentance, offering repeated\r\n      interruption to the minister in his prayer, and absolutely refusing to\r\n      pardon the executioner.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      This tragedy happened in the year 1613, and recorded, as it is, very\r\n      particularly and at considerable length, forms the most detailed specimen\r\n      I have met with of a Scottish trial for witchcraft&mdash;illustrating, in\r\n      particular, how poor wretches, abandoned, as they conceived, by God and\r\n      the world, deprived of all human sympathy, and exposed to personal\r\n      tortures of an acute description, became disposed to throw away the lives\r\n      that were rendered bitter to them by a voluntary confession of guilt,\r\n      rather than struggle hopelessly against so many evils. Four persons here\r\n      lost their lives, merely because the throwing some clay models into the\r\n      sea, a fact told differently by the witnesses who spoke of it,\r\n      corresponded with the season, for no day was fixed in which a particular\r\n      vessel was lost. It is scarce possible that, after reading such a story, a\r\n      man of sense can listen for an instant to the evidence founded on\r\n      confessions thus obtained, which has been almost the sole reason by which\r\n      a few individuals, even in modern times, have endeavoured to justify a\r\n      belief in the existence of witchcraft.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The result of the judicial examination of a criminal, when extorted by\r\n      such means, is the most suspicious of all evidence, and even when\r\n      voluntarily given, is scarce admissible without the corroboration of other\r\n      testimony.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      We might here take leave of our Scottish history of witchcraft by barely\r\n      mentioning that many hundreds, nay perhaps thousands, lost their lives\r\n      during two centuries on such charges and such evidence as proved the death\r\n      of those persons in the trial of the Irvine witches. One case, however, is\r\n      so much distinguished by fame among the numerous instances which occurred\r\n      in Scottish history, that we are under the necessity of bestowing a few\r\n      words upon those celebrated persons, Major Weir and his sister.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The case of this notorious wizard was remarkable chiefly from his being a\r\n      man of some condition (the son of a gentleman, and his mother a lady of\r\n      family in Clydesdale), which was seldom the case with those that fell\r\n      under similar accusations. It was also remarkable in his case that he had\r\n      been a Covenanter, and peculiarly attached to that cause. In the years of\r\n      the Commonwealth this man was trusted and employed by those who were then\r\n      at the head of affairs, and was in 1649 commander of the City-Guard of\r\n      Edinburgh, which procured him his title of Major. In this capacity he was\r\n      understood, as was indeed implied in the duties of that officer at the\r\n      period, to be very strict in executing severity upon such Royalists as\r\n      fell under his military charge. It appears that the Major, with a maiden\r\n      sister who had kept his house, was subject to fits of melancholic lunacy,\r\n      an infirmity easily reconcilable with the formal pretences which he made\r\n      to a high show of religious zeal. He was peculiar in his gift of prayer,\r\n      and, as was the custom of the period, was often called to exercise his\r\n      talent by the bedside of sick persons, until it came to be observed that,\r\n      by some association, which it is more easy to conceive than to explain, he\r\n      could not pray with the same warmth and fluency of expression unless when\r\n      he had in his hand a stick of peculiar shape and appearance, which he\r\n      generally walked with. It was noticed, in short, that when this stick was\r\n      taken from him, his wit and talent appeared to forsake him. This Major\r\n      Weir was seized by the magistrates on a strange whisper that became\r\n      current respecting vile practices, which he seems to have admitted without\r\n      either shame or contrition. The disgusting profligacies which he confessed\r\n      were of such a character that it may be charitably hoped most of them were\r\n      the fruits of a depraved imagination, though he appears to have been in\r\n      many respects a wicked and criminal hypocrite. When he had completed his\r\n      confession, he avowed solemnly that he had not confessed the hundredth\r\n      part of the crimes which he had committed. From this time he would answer\r\n      no interrogatory, nor would he have recourse to prayer, arguing that, as\r\n      he had no hope whatever of escaping Satan, there was no need of incensing\r\n      him by vain efforts at repentance. His witchcraft seems to have been taken\r\n      for granted on his own confession, as his indictment was chiefly founded\r\n      on the same document, in which he alleged he had never seen the devil, but\r\n      any feeling he had of him was in the dark. He received sentence of death,\r\n      which he suffered 12th April, 1670, at the Gallow-hill, between Leith and\r\n      Edinburgh. He died so stupidly sullen and impenitent as to justify the\r\n      opinion that he was oppressed with a kind of melancholy frenzy, the\r\n      consequence perhaps of remorse, but such as urged him not to repent, but\r\n      to despair. It seems probable that he was burnt alive. His sister, with\r\n      whom he was supposed to have had an incestuous connexion, was condemned\r\n      also to death, leaving a stronger and more explicit testimony of their\r\n      mutual sins than could be extracted from the Major. She gave, as usual,\r\n      some account of her connexion with the queen of the fairies, and\r\n      acknowledged the assistance she received from that sovereign in spinning\r\n      an unusual quantity of yam. Of her brother she said that one day a friend\r\n      called upon them at noonday with a fiery chariot, and invited them to\r\n      visit a friend at Dalkeith, and that while there her brother received\r\n      information of the event of the battle of Worcester. No one saw the style\r\n      of their equipage except themselves. On the scaffold this woman,\r\n      determining, as she said, to die &ldquo;with the greatest shame possible,&rdquo; was\r\n      with difficulty prevented from throwing off her clothes before the people,\r\n      and with scarce less trouble was she flung from the ladder by the\r\n      executioner. Her last words were in the tone of the sect to which her\r\n      brother had so long affected to belong: &ldquo;Many,&rdquo; she said, &ldquo;weep and lament\r\n      for a poor old wretch like me; but alas! few are weeping for a broken\r\n      Covenant.&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The Scottish prelatists, upon whom the Covenanters used to throw many\r\n      aspersions respecting their receiving proof against shot from the devil,\r\n      and other infernal practices, rejoiced to have an opportunity, in their\r\n      turn, to retort on their adversaries the charge of sorcery. Dr. Hickes,\r\n      the author of &ldquo;Thesaurus Septentrionalis,&rdquo; published on the subject of\r\n      Major Weir, and the case of Mitchell, who fired at the Archbishop of St.\r\n      Andrews his book called &ldquo;Ravaillac Redivivus,&rdquo; written with the unjust\r\n      purpose of attaching to the religious sect to which the wizard and\r\n      assassin belonged the charge of having fostered and encouraged the crimes\r\n      they committed or attempted.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It is certain that no story of witchcraft or necromancy, so many of which\r\n      occurred near and in Edinburgh, made such a lasting impression on the\r\n      public mind as that of Major Weir. The remains of the house in which he\r\n      and his sister lived are still shown at the head of the West Bow, which\r\n      has a gloomy aspect, well suited for a necromancer. It was at different\r\n      times a brazier&rsquo;s shop and a magazine for lint, and in my younger days was\r\n      employed for the latter use; but no family would inhabit the haunted walls\r\n      as a residence; and bold was the urchin from the High School who dared\r\n      approach the gloomy ruin at the risk of seeing the Major&rsquo;s enchanted staff\r\n      parading through the old apartments, or hearing the hum of the necromantic\r\n      wheel, which procured for his sister such a character as a spinner. At the\r\n      time I am writing this last fortress of superstitious renown is in the\r\n      course of being destroyed, in order to the modern improvements now\r\n      carrying on in a quarter long thought unimprovable.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      As knowledge and learning began to increase, the gentlemen and clergy of\r\n      Scotland became ashamed of the credulity of their ancestors, and witch\r\n      trials, although not discontinued, more seldom disgrace our records of\r\n      criminal jurisprudence.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Sir John Clerk, a scholar and an antiquary, the grandfather of the late\r\n      celebrated John Clerk of Eldin, had the honour to be amongst the first to\r\n      decline acting as a commissioner on the trial of a witch, to which he was\r\n      appointed so early as 1678,<a href="#linknote-81" name="linknoteref-81"\r\n       id="linknoteref-81"><small>81</small></a> alleging, drily, that he did not\r\n      feel himself warlock (that is, conjurer) sufficient to be a judge upon\r\n      such an inquisition. Allan Ramsay, his friend, and who must be supposed to\r\n      speak the sense of his many respectable patrons, had delivered his opinion\r\n      on the subject in the &ldquo;Gentle Shepherd,&rdquo; where Mause&rsquo;s imaginary\r\n      witchcraft constitutes the machinery of the poem.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-81" id="linknote-81"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      81 (<a href="#linknoteref-81">return</a>)<br /> [ See Fountainhall&rsquo;s\r\n      &ldquo;Decisions,&rdquo; vol. i. p. 15.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Yet these dawnings of sense and humanity were obscured by the clouds of\r\n      the ancient superstition on more than one distinguished occasion. In 1676,\r\n      Sir George Maxwell, of Pollock, apparently a man of melancholic and\r\n      valetudinary habits, believed himself bewitched to death by six witches,\r\n      one man and five women, who were leagued for the purpose of tormenting a\r\n      clay image in his likeness. The chief evidence on the subject was a\r\n      vagabond girl, pretending to be deaf and dumb. But as her imposture was\r\n      afterwards discovered and herself punished, it is reasonably to be\r\n      concluded that she had herself formed the picture or image of Sir George,\r\n      and had hid it where it was afterwards found in consequence of her own\r\n      information. In the meantime, five of the accused were executed, and the\r\n      sixth only escaped on account of extreme youth.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      A still more remarkable case occurred at Paisley in 1697, where a young\r\n      girl, about eleven years of age, daughter of John Shaw, of Bargarran, was\r\n      the principal evidence. This unlucky damsel, beginning her practices out\r\n      of a quarrel with a maid-servant, continued to imitate a case of\r\n      possession so accurately that no less than twenty persons were condemned\r\n      upon her evidence, of whom five were executed, besides one John Reed, who\r\n      hanged himself in prison, or, as was charitably said, was strangled by the\r\n      devil in person, lest he should make disclosures to the detriment of the\r\n      service. But even those who believed in witchcraft were now beginning to\r\n      open their eyes to the dangers in the present mode of prosecution. &ldquo;I\r\n      own,&rdquo; says the Rev. Mr. Bell in his MS. &ldquo;Treatise on Witchcraft,&rdquo; &ldquo;there\r\n      has been much harm done to worthy and innocent persons in the common way\r\n      of finding out witches, and in the means made use of for promoting the\r\n      discovery of such wretches and bringing them to justice; so that\r\n      oftentimes old age, poverty, features, and ill-fame, with such like\r\n      grounds not worthy to be represented to a magistrate, have yet moved many\r\n      to suspect and defame their neighbours, to the unspeakable prejudice of\r\n      Christian charity; a late instance whereof we had in the west, in the\r\n      business of the sorceries exercised upon the Laird of Bargarran&rsquo;s\r\n      daughter, anno 1697&mdash;a time when persons of more goodness and esteem\r\n      than most of their calumniators were defamed for witches, and which was\r\n      occasioned mostly by the forwardness and absurd credulity of diverse\r\n      otherwise worthy ministers of the gospel, and some topping professors in\r\n      and about the city of Glasgow."<a href="#linknote-82" name="linknoteref-82"\r\n       id="linknoteref-82"><small>82</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-82" id="linknote-82"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      82 (<a href="#linknoteref-82">return</a>)<br /> [ Law&rsquo;s &ldquo;Memorialls,&rdquo;\r\n       edited by C.K. Sliarpe, Esq.: Prefatory Notice, p. 93.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Those who doubted of the sense of the law or reasonableness of the\r\n      practice in such cases, began to take courage and state their objections\r\n      boldly. In the year 1704 a frightful instance of popular bigotry occurred\r\n      at Pittenweem. A strolling vagabond, who affected fits, laid an accusation\r\n      of witchcraft against two women, who were accordingly seized on, and\r\n      imprisoned with the usual severities. One of the unhappy creatures, Janet\r\n      Cornfoot by name, escaped from prison, but was unhappily caught, and\r\n      brought back to Pittenweem, where she fell into the hands of a ferocious\r\n      mob, consisting of rude seamen and fishers. The magistrates made no\r\n      attempts for her rescue, and the crowd exercised their brutal pleasure on\r\n      the poor old woman, pelted her with stones, swung her suspended on a rope\r\n      betwixt a ship and the shore, and finally ended her miserable existence by\r\n      throwing a door over her as she lay exhausted on the beach, and heaping\r\n      stones upon it till she was pressed to death. As even the existing laws\r\n      against witchcraft were transgressed by this brutal riot, a warm attack\r\n      was made upon the magistrates and ministers of the town by those who were\r\n      shocked at a tragedy of such a horrible cast, There were answers\r\n      published, in which the parties assailed were zealously defended. The\r\n      superior authorities were expected to take up the affair, but it so\r\n      happened; during the general distraction of the country concerning the\r\n      Union, that the murder went without the investigation which a crime so\r\n      horrid demanded. Still, however, it was something gained that the cruelty\r\n      was exposed to the public. The voice of general opinion was now appealed\r\n      to, and in the long run the sentiments which it advocates are commonly\r\n      those of good sense and humanity.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The officers in the higher branches of the law dared now assert their\r\n      official authority and reserve for their own decision cases of supposed\r\n      witchcraft which the fear of public clamour had induced them formerly to\r\n      leave in the hands of inferior judges, operated upon by all the prejudices\r\n      of the country and the populace.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In 1718, the celebrated lawyer, Robert Dundas of Arniston, then King&rsquo;s\r\n      Advocate, wrote a severe letter of censure to the Sheriff-depute of\r\n      Caithness, in the first place, as having neglected to communicate\r\n      officially certain precognitions which he had led respecting some recent\r\n      practices of witchcraft in his county. The Advocate reminded this local\r\n      judge that the duty of inferior magistrates, in such cases, was to advise\r\n      with the King&rsquo;s Counsel, first, whether they should be made subject of a\r\n      trial or not; and if so, before what court, and in what manner, it should\r\n      take place. He also called the magistrate&rsquo;s attention to a report, that\r\n      he, the Sheriff-depute, intended to judge in the case himself; &ldquo;a thing of\r\n      too great difficulty to be tried without very deliberate advice, and\r\n      beyond the jurisdiction of an inferior court.&rdquo; The Sheriff-depute sends,\r\n      with his apology, the <i>precognition</i><a href="#linknote-83"\r\n       name="linknoteref-83" id="linknoteref-83"><small>83</small></a> of the\r\n      affair, which is one of the most nonsensical in this nonsensical\r\n      department of the law. A certain carpenter, named William Montgomery, was\r\n      so infested with cats, which, as his servant-maid reported, &ldquo;spoke among\r\n      themselves,&rdquo; that he fell in a rage upon a party of these animals which\r\n      had assembled in his house at irregular hours, and betwixt his Highland\r\n      arms of knife, dirk, and broadsword, and his professional weapon of an\r\n      axe, he made such a dispersion that they were quiet for the night. In\r\n      consequence of his blows, two witches were said to have died. The case of\r\n      a third, named Nin-Gilbert, was still more remarkable. Her leg being\r\n      broken, the injured limb withered, pined, and finally fell off; on which\r\n      the hag was enclosed in prison, where she also died; and the question\r\n      which remained was, whether any process should be directed against persons\r\n      whom, in her compelled confession, she had, as usual, informed against.\r\n      The Lord Advocate, as may be supposed, quashed all further procedure.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-83" id="linknote-83"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      83 (<a href="#linknoteref-83">return</a>)<br /> [ The <i>precognition</i>\r\n      is the record of the preliminary evidence on which the public officers\r\n      charged in Scotland with duties entrusted to a grand jury in England,\r\n      incur the responsibility of sending an accused person to trial.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In 1720, an unlucky boy, the third son of James, Lord Torphichen, took it\r\n      into his head, under instructions, it is said, from a knavish governor, to\r\n      play the possessed and bewitched person, laying the cause of his distress\r\n      on certain old witches in Calder, near to which village his father had his\r\n      mansion. The women were imprisoned, and one or two of them died; but the\r\n      Crown counsel would not proceed to trial. The noble family also began to\r\n      see through the cheat. The boy was sent to sea, and though he is said at\r\n      one time to have been disposed to try his fits while on board, when the\r\n      discipline of the navy proved too severe for his cunning, in process of\r\n      time he became a good sailor, assisted gallantly in defence of the vessel\r\n      against the pirates of Angria, and finally was drowned in a storm.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In the year 1722, a Sheriff-depute of Sutherland, Captain David Ross of\r\n      Littledean, took it upon him, in flagrant violation of the then\r\n      established rules of jurisdiction, to pronounce the last sentence of death\r\n      for witchcraft which was ever passed in Scotland. The victim was an insane\r\n      old woman belonging to the parish of Loth, who had so little idea of her\r\n      situation as to rejoice at the sight of the fire which was destined to\r\n      consume her. She had a daughter lame both of hands and feet, a\r\n      circumstance attributed to the witch&rsquo;s having been used to transform her\r\n      into a pony, and get her shod by the devil. It does not appear that any\r\n      punishment was inflicted for this cruel abuse of the law on the person of\r\n      a creature so helpless; but the son of the lame daughter, he himself\r\n      distinguished by the same misfortune, was living so lately as to receive\r\n      the charity of the present Marchioness of Stafford, Countess of Sutherland\r\n      in her own right, to whom the poor of her extensive country are as well\r\n      known as those of the higher order.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Since this deplorable action there has been no judicial interference in\r\n      Scotland on account of witchcraft, unless to prevent explosions of popular\r\n      enmity against people suspected of such a crime, of which some instances\r\n      could be produced. The remains of the superstition sometimes occur; there\r\n      can be no doubt that the vulgar are still addicted to the custom of\r\n      scoring above the breath<a href="#linknote-84" name="linknoteref-84"\r\n       id="linknoteref-84"><small>84</small></a> (as it is termed), and other\r\n      counter-spells, evincing that the belief in witchcraft is only asleep, and\r\n      might in remote corners be again awakened to deeds of blood. An instance\r\n      or two may be quoted chiefly as facts known to the author himself.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-84" id="linknote-84"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      84 (<a href="#linknoteref-84">return</a>)<br /> [ Drawing blood, that is,\r\n      by two cuts in the form of a cross on the witch&rsquo;s forehead, confided in\r\n      all throughout Scotland as the most powerful counter charm.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In a remote part of the Highlands, an ignorant and malignant woman seems\r\n      really to have meditated the destruction of her neighbour&rsquo;s property, by\r\n      placing in a cow-house, or byre as we call it, a pot of baked clay\r\n      containing locks of hair, parings of nails, and other trumpery. This\r\n      precious spell was discovered, the design conjectured, and the witch would\r\n      have been torn to pieces had not a high-spirited and excellent lady in the\r\n      neighbourhood gathered some of her people (though these were not very fond\r\n      of the service), and by main force taken the unfortunate creature out of\r\n      the hands of the populace. The formidable spell is now in my possession.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      About two years since, as they were taking down the walls of a building\r\n      formerly used as a feeding-house for cattle, in the town of Dalkeith,\r\n      there was found below the threshold-stone the withered heart of some\r\n      animal stuck full of many scores of pins&mdash;a counter-charm, according\r\n      to tradition, against the operations of witchcraft on the cattle which are\r\n      kept within. Among the almost innumerable droves of bullocks which come\r\n      down every year from the Highlands for the south, there is scarce one but\r\n      has a curious knot upon his tail, which is also a precaution lest an evil\r\n      eye or an evil spell may do the animal harm.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The last Scottish story with which I will trouble you happened in or\r\n      shortly after the year 1800, and the whole circumstances are well known to\r\n      me. The dearth of the years in the end of the eighteenth and beginning of\r\n      this century was inconvenient to all, but distressing to the poor. A\r\n      solitary old woman, in a wild and lonely district, subsisted chiefly by\r\n      rearing chickens, an operation requiring so much care and attention that\r\n      the gentry, and even the farmers&rsquo; wives, often find it better to buy\r\n      poultry at a certain age than to undertake the trouble of bringing them\r\n      up. As the old woman in the present instance fought her way through life\r\n      better than her neighbours, envy stigmatized her as having some unlawful\r\n      mode of increasing the gains of her little trade, and apparently she did\r\n      not take much alarm at the accusation. But she felt, like others, the\r\n      dearth of the years alluded to, and chiefly because the farmers were\r\n      unwilling to sell grain in the very moderate quantities which she was able\r\n      to purchase, and without which her little stock of poultry must have been\r\n      inevitably starved. In distress on this account, the dame went to a\r\n      neighbouring farmer, a very good-natured, sensible, honest man, and\r\n      requested him as a favour to sell her a peck of oats at any price. &ldquo;Good\r\n      neighbour,&rdquo; he said, &ldquo;I am sorry to be obliged to refuse you, but my corn\r\n      is measured out for Dalkeith market; my carts are loaded to set out, and\r\n      to open these sacks again, and for so small a quantity, would cast my\r\n      accounts loose, and create much trouble and disadvantage; I dare say you\r\n      will get all you want at such a place, or such a place.&rdquo; On receiving this\r\n      answer, the old woman&rsquo;s temper gave way. She scolded the wealthy farmer,\r\n      and wished evil to his property, which was just setting off for the\r\n      market. They parted, after some angry language on both sides; and sure\r\n      enough, as the carts crossed the ford of the river beneath the farm-house,\r\n      off came the wheel from one of them, and five or six sacks of corn were\r\n      damaged by the water. The good farmer hardly knew what to think of this;\r\n      there were the two circumstances deemed of old essential and sufficient to\r\n      the crime of witchcraft&mdash;<i>Damnum minatum, et malum secutum</i>.\r\n      Scarce knowing what to believe, he hastened to consult the sheriff of the\r\n      county, as a friend rather than a magistrate, upon a case so\r\n      extraordinary. The official person showed him that the laws against\r\n      witchcraft were abrogated, and had little difficulty to bring him to\r\n      regard the matter in its true light of an accident.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It is strange, but true, that the accused herself was not to be reconciled\r\n      to the sheriffs doctrine so easily. He reminded her that, if she used her\r\n      tongue with so much license, she must expose herself to suspicions, and\r\n      that should coincidences happen to irritate her neighbours, she, might\r\n      suffer harm at a time when there was no one to protect her. He therefore\r\n      requested her to be more cautious in her language for her own sake,\r\n      professing, at the same time, his belief that her words and intentions\r\n      were perfectly harmless, and that he had no apprehension of being hurt by\r\n      her, let her wish her worst to him. She was rather more angry than pleased\r\n      at the well-meaning sheriffs scepticism. &ldquo;I would be laith to wish ony ill\r\n      either to you or yours, sir,&rdquo; she said; &ldquo;for I kenna how it is, but\r\n      something aye comes after my words when I am ill-guided and speak ower\r\n      fast.&rdquo; In short, she was obstinate in claiming an influence over the\r\n      destiny of others by words and wishes, which might have in other times\r\n      conveyed her to the stake, for which her expressions, their consequences,\r\n      and her disposition to insist upon their efficacy, would certainly of old\r\n      have made her a fit victim. At present the story is scarcely worth\r\n      mentioning, but as it contains material resembling those out of which many\r\n      tragic incidents have arisen.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      So low, in short, is now the belief in witchcraft, that perhaps it is only\r\n      received by those half-crazy individuals who feel a species of consequence\r\n      derived from accidental coincidences, which, were they received by the\r\n      community in general, would go near, as on former occasions, to cost the\r\n      lives of those who make their boast of them. At least one hypochondriac\r\n      patient is known to the author, who believes himself the victim of a gang\r\n      of witches, and ascribes his illness to their charms, so that he wants\r\n      nothing but an indulgent judge to awake again the old ideas of sorcery.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="link2H_4_0011" id="link2H_4_0011"> </a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <div style="height: 4em;">\r\n      <br /><br /><br /><br />\r\n    </div>\r\n    <h2>\r\n      LETTER X.\r\n    </h2>\r\n<pre xml:space="preserve">\r\n    Other Mystic Arts independent of Witchcraft&mdash;Astrology&mdash;Its\r\n    Influence during the 16th and 17th Centuries&mdash;Base Ignorance of\r\n    those who practised it&mdash;Lilly&rsquo;s History of his Life and\r\n    Times&mdash;Astrologer&rsquo;s Society&mdash;Dr. Lamb&mdash;Dr. Forman&mdash;Establishment of\r\n    the Royal Society&mdash;Partridge&mdash;Connexion of Astrologers with\r\n    Elementary Spirits&mdash;Dr. Dun&mdash;Irish Superstition of the\r\n    Banshie&mdash;Similar Superstition in the\r\n    Highlands&mdash;Brownie&mdash;Ghosts&mdash;Belief of Ancient Philosophers on that\r\n    Subject&mdash;Inquiry into the respect due to such Tales in Modern\r\n    Times&mdash;Evidence of a Ghost against a Murderer&mdash;Ghost of Sir George\r\n    Villiers&mdash;Story of Earl St. Vincent&mdash;Of a British General\r\n    Officer&mdash;Of an Apparition in France&mdash;Of the Second Lord\r\n    Lyttelton&mdash;Of Bill Jones&mdash;Of Jarvis Matcham&mdash;Trial of two\r\n    Highlanders for the Murder of Sergeant Davis, discovered by a\r\n    Ghost&mdash;Disturbances at Woodstock, anno 1649&mdash;Imposture called the\r\n    Stockwell Ghost&mdash;Similar Case in Scotland&mdash;Ghost appearing to an\r\n    Exciseman&mdash;Story of a Disturbed House discovered by the firmness of\r\n    the Proprietor&mdash;Apparition at Plymouth&mdash;A Club of\r\n    Philosophers&mdash;Ghost Adventure of a Farmer&mdash;Trick upon a Veteran\r\n    Soldier&mdash;Ghost Stories recommended by the Skill of the Authors who\r\n    compose them&mdash;Mrs. Veal&rsquo;s Ghost&mdash;Dunton&rsquo;s Apparition\r\n    Evidence&mdash;Effect of Appropriate Scenery to Encourage a Tendency to\r\n    Superstition&mdash;Differs at distant Periods of Life&mdash;Night at Glammis\r\n    Castle about 1791&mdash;Visit to Dunvegan in 1814.\r\n</pre>\r\n    <p class="pfirst">\r\n      <span class="dropcap" style="font-size: 4.00em">W</span>hile the vulgar\r\n      endeavoured to obtain a glance into the darkness of futurity by consulting\r\n      the witch or fortune-teller, the great were supposed to have a royal path\r\n      of their own, commanding a view from a loftier quarter of the same <i>terra\r\n      incognita</i>. This was represented as accessible by several routes.\r\n      Physiognomy, chiromancy, and other fantastic arts of prediction afforded\r\n      each its mystical assistance and guidance. But the road most flattering to\r\n      human vanity, while it was at the same time most seductive to human\r\n      credulity, was that of astrology, the queen of mystic sciences, who\r\n      flattered those who confided in her that the planets and stars in their\r\n      spheres figure forth and influence the fate of the creatures of mortality,\r\n      and that a sage acquainted with her lore could predict, with some approach\r\n      to certainty, the events of any man&rsquo;s career, his chance of success in\r\n      life or in marriage, his advance in favour of the great, or answer any\r\n      other horary questions, as they were termed, which he might be anxious to\r\n      propound, provided always he could supply the exact moment of his birth.\r\n      This, in the sixteenth and greater part of the seventeenth centuries, was\r\n      all that was necessary to enable the astrologer to erect a scheme of the\r\n      position of the heavenly bodies, which should disclose the life of the\r\n      interrogator, or Native, as he was called, with all its changes, past,\r\n      present, and to come.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Imagination was dazzled by a prospect so splendid; and we find that in the\r\n      sixteenth century the cultivation of this fantastic science was the\r\n      serious object of men whose understandings and acquirements admit of no\r\n      question. Bacon himself allowed the truth which might be found in a\r\n      well-regulated astrology, making thus a distinction betwixt the art as\r\n      commonly practised and the manner in which it might, as he conceived, be\r\n      made a proper use of. But a grave or sober use of this science, if even\r\n      Bacon could have taught such moderation, would not have suited the temper\r\n      of those who, inflamed by hopes of temporal aggrandizement, pretended to\r\n      understand and explain to others the language of the stars. Almost all the\r\n      other paths of mystic knowledge led to poverty; even the alchemist, though\r\n      talking loud and high of the endless treasures his art was to produce,\r\n      lived from day to day and from year to year upon hopes as unsubstantial as\r\n      the smoke of his furnace. But the pursuits of the astrologer were such as\r\n      called for instant remuneration. He became rich by the eager hopes and\r\n      fond credulity of those who consulted him, and that artist lived by duping\r\n      others, instead of starving, like others, by duping himself. The wisest\r\n      men have been cheated by the idea that some supernatural influence upheld\r\n      and guided them; and from the time of Wallenstein to that of Buonaparte,\r\n      ambition and success have placed confidence in the species of fatalism\r\n      inspired by a belief of the influence of their own star. Such being the\r\n      case, the science was little pursued by those who, faithful in their\r\n      remarks and reports, must soon have discovered its delusive vanity through\r\n      the splendour of its professions; and the place of such calm and\r\n      disinterested pursuers of truth was occupied by a set of men sometimes\r\n      ingenious, always forward and assuming, whose knowledge was imposition,\r\n      whose responses were, like the oracles of yore, grounded on the desire of\r\n      deceit, and who, if sometimes they were elevated into rank and fortune,\r\n      were more frequently found classed with rogues and vagabonds. This was the\r\n      more apt to be the case that a sufficient stock of impudence, and some\r\n      knowledge by rote of the terms of art, were all the store of information\r\n      necessary for establishing a conjurer. The natural consequence of the\r\n      degraded character of the professors was the degradation of the art\r\n      itself. Lilly, who wrote the history of his own life and times, notices in\r\n      that curious volume the most distinguished persons of his day, who made\r\n      pretensions to astrology, and almost without exception describes them as\r\n      profligate, worthless, sharking cheats, abandoned to vice, and imposing,\r\n      by the grossest frauds, upon the silly fools who consulted them. From what\r\n      we learn of his own history, Lilly himself, a low-born ignorant man, with\r\n      some gloomy shades of fanaticism in his temperament, was sufficiently\r\n      fitted to dupe others, and perhaps cheated himself merely by perusing, at\r\n      an advanced period of life, some of the astrological tracts devised by men\r\n      of less cunning, though perhaps more pretence to science, than he himself\r\n      might boast. Yet the public still continue to swallow these gross\r\n      impositions, though coming from such unworthy authority. The astrologers\r\n      embraced different sides of the Civil War, and the king on one side, with\r\n      the Parliamentary leaders on the other, were both equally curious to know,\r\n      and eager to believe, what Lilly, Wharton, or Gadbury had discovered from\r\n      the heavens touching the fortune of the strife. Lilly was a prudent\r\n      person, contriving with some address to shift the sails of his prophetic\r\n      bark so as to suit the current of the time, and the gale of fortune. No\r\n      person could better discover from various omens the course of Charles&rsquo;s\r\n      misfortunes, so soon as they had come to pass. In the time of the\r\n      Commonwealth he foresaw the perpetual destruction of the monarchy, and in\r\n      1660 this did not prevent his foreseeing the restoration of Charles II. He\r\n      maintained some credit even among the better classes, for Aubrey and\r\n      Ashmole both called themselves his friends, being persons extremely\r\n      credulous, doubtless, respecting the mystic arts. Once a year, too, the\r\n      astrologers had a public dinner or feast, where the knaves were patronised\r\n      by the company of such fools as claimed the title of Philomaths&mdash;that\r\n      is, lovers of the mathematics, by which name were still distinguished\r\n      those who encouraged the pursuit of mystical prescience, the most opposite\r\n      possible to exact science. Elias Ashmole, the &ldquo;most honourable Esquire,&rdquo;\r\n       to whom Lilly&rsquo;s life is dedicated, seldom failed to attend; nay, several\r\n      men of sense and knowledge honoured this rendezvous. Congreve&rsquo;s picture of\r\n      a man like Foresight, the dupe of astrology and its sister arts, was then\r\n      common in society. But the astrologers of the 17th century did not confine\r\n      themselves to the stars. There was no province of fraud which they did not\r\n      practise; they were scandalous as panders, and as quacks sold potions for\r\n      the most unworthy purposes. For such reasons the common people detested\r\n      the astrologers of the great as cordially as they did the more vulgar\r\n      witches of their own sphere.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Dr. Lamb, patronised by the Duke of Buckingham, who, like other overgrown\r\n      favourites, was inclined to cherish astrology, was in 1640 pulled to\r\n      pieces in the city of London by the enraged populace, and his\r\n      maid-servant, thirteen years afterwards, hanged as a witch at Salisbury.\r\n      In the villanous transaction of the poisoning of Sir Thomas Overbury, in\r\n      King James&rsquo;s time, much mention was made of the art and skill of Dr.\r\n      Forman, another professor of the same sort with Lamb, who was consulted by\r\n      the Countess of Essex on the best mode of conducting her guilty intrigue\r\n      with the Earl of Somerset. He was dead before the affair broke out, which\r\n      might otherwise have cost him the gibbet, as it did all others concerned,\r\n      with the exception only of the principal parties, the atrocious authors of\r\n      the crime. When the cause was tried, some little puppets were produced in\r\n      court, which were viewed by one party with horror, as representing the\r\n      most horrid spells. It was even said that the devil was about to pull down\r\n      the court-house on their being discovered. Others of the audience only saw\r\n      in them the baby figures on which the dressmakers then, as now, were\r\n      accustomed to expose new fashions.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The erection of the Royal Society, dedicated to far different purposes\r\n      than the pursuits of astrology, had a natural operation in bringing the\r\n      latter into discredit; and although the credulity of the ignorant and\r\n      uninformed continued to support some pretenders to that science, the name\r\n      of Philomath, assumed by these persons and their clients, began to sink\r\n      under ridicule and contempt. When Sir Richard Steele set up the paper\r\n      called the <i>Guardian</i>, he chose, under the title of Nestor Ironside,\r\n      to assume the character of an astrologer, and issued predictions\r\n      accordingly, one of which, announcing the death of a person called\r\n      Partridge, once a shoemaker, but at the time the conductor of an\r\n      Astrological Almanack, led to a controversy, which was supported with\r\n      great humour by Swift and other wags. I believe you will find that this,\r\n      with Swift&rsquo;s Elegy on the same person, is one of the last occasions in\r\n      which astrology has afforded even a jest to the good people of England.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      This dishonoured science has some right to be mentioned in a &ldquo;Treatise on\r\n      Demonology,&rdquo; because the earlier astrologers, though denying the use of\r\n      all necromancy&mdash;that is, unlawful or black magic&mdash;pretended\r\n      always to a correspondence with the various spirits of the elements, on\r\n      the principles of the Rosicrucian philosophy. They affirmed they could\r\n      bind to their service, and imprison in a ring, a mirror, or a stone, some\r\n      fairy, sylph, or salamander, and compel it to appear when called, and\r\n      render answers to such questions as the viewer should propose. It is\r\n      remarkable that the sage himself did not pretend to see the spirit; but\r\n      the task of viewer, or reader, was entrusted to a third party, a boy or\r\n      girl usually under the years of puberty. Dr. Dee, an excellent\r\n      mathematician, had a stone of this kind, and is said to have been imposed\r\n      upon concerning the spirits attached to it, their actions and answers, by\r\n      the report of one Kelly who acted as his viewer. The unfortunate Dee was\r\n      ruined by his associates both in fortune and reputation. His show-stone or\r\n      mirror is still preserved among other curiosities in the British Museum.\r\n      Some superstition of the same kind was introduced by the celebrated Count\r\n      Cagliostro, during the course of the intrigue respecting the diamond\r\n      necklace in which the late Marie Antoinette was so unfortunately\r\n      implicated.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Dismissing this general class of impostors, who are now seldom heard of,\r\n      we come now briefly to mention some leading superstitions once, perhaps,\r\n      common to all the countries of Europe, but now restricted to those which\r\n      continue to be inhabited by an undisturbed and native race. Of these, one\r\n      of the most beautiful is the Irish fiction which assigns to certain\r\n      families of ancient descent and distinguished rank the privilege of a\r\n      Banshie, as she is called, or household fairy, whose office it is to\r\n      appear, seemingly mourning, while she announces the approaching death of\r\n      some one of the destined race. The subject has been so lately and\r\n      beautifully investigated and illustrated by Mr. Crofton Croker and others,\r\n      that I may dispense with being very particular regarding it. If I am\r\n      rightly informed, the distinction of a banshie is only allowed to families\r\n      of the pure Milesian stock, and is never ascribed to any descendant of the\r\n      proudest Norman or boldest Saxon who followed the banner of Earl\r\n      Strongbow, much less to adventurers of later date who have obtained\r\n      settlements in the Green Isle.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Several families of the Highlands of Scotland anciently laid claim to the\r\n      distinction of an attendant spirit who performed the office of the Irish\r\n      banshie. Amongst them, however, the functions of this attendant genius,\r\n      whose form and appearance differed in different cases, were not limited to\r\n      announcing the dissolution of those whose days were numbered. The\r\n      Highlanders contrived to exact from them other points of service,\r\n      sometimes as warding off dangers of battle; at others, as guarding and\r\n      protecting the infant heir through the dangers of childhood; and sometimes\r\n      as condescending to interfere even in the sports of the chieftain, and\r\n      point out the fittest move to be made at chess, or the best card to be\r\n      played at any other game. Among those spirits who have deigned to vouch\r\n      their existence by appearance of late years, is that of an ancestor of the\r\n      family of MacLean of Lochbuy. Before the death of any of his race the\r\n      phantom-chief gallops along the sea-beach near to the castle, announcing\r\n      the event by cries and lamentations. The spectre is said to have rode his\r\n      rounds and uttered his death-cries within these few years, in consequence\r\n      of which the family and clan, though much shocked, were in no way\r\n      surprised to hear by next accounts that their gallant chief was dead at\r\n      Lisbon, where he served under Lord Wellington.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Of a meaner origin and occupation was the Scottish Brownie, already\r\n      mentioned as somewhat resembling Robin Goodfellow in the frolicsome days\r\n      of Old England. This spirit was easily banished, or, as it was styled,\r\n      hired away, by the offer of clothes or food; but many of the simple\r\n      inhabitants could little see the prudence of parting with such a useful\r\n      domestic drudge, who served faithfully, without fee and reward, food or\r\n      raiment. Neither was it all times safe to reject Brownie&rsquo;s assistance.\r\n      Thus, we are informed by Brand, that a young man in the Orkneys &ldquo;used to\r\n      brew, and sometimes read upon his Bible; to whom an old woman in the house\r\n      said, that Brownie was displeased with that book he read upon, which, if\r\n      he continued to do, they would get no more service of Brownie; but he,\r\n      being better instructed from that book, which was Brownie&rsquo;s eyesore and\r\n      the object of his wrath, when he brewed, would not suffer any sacrifice to\r\n      be given to Brownie; whereupon the first and second brewings were spoilt,\r\n      and for no use; for though the wort wrought well, yet in a little time it\r\n      left off working, and grew cold; but of the third broust, or brewing, he\r\n      had ale very good, though he would not give any sacrifice to Brownie, with\r\n      whom afterwards they were no more troubled.&rdquo; Another story of the same\r\n      kind is told of a lady in Uist, who refused, on religious grounds, the\r\n      usual sacrifice to this domestic spirit. The first and second brewings\r\n      failed, but the third succeeded; and thus, when Brownie lost the\r\n      perquisite to which he had been so long accustomed, he abandoned the\r\n      inhospitable house, where his services had so long been faithfully\r\n      rendered. The last place in the south of Scotland supposed to have been\r\n      honoured, or benefited, by the residence of a Brownie, was Bodsbeck in\r\n      Moffatdale, which has been the subject of an entertaining tale by Mr.\r\n      James Hogg, the self-instructed genius of Ettrick Forest.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      These particular superstitions, however, are too limited, and too much\r\n      obliterated from recollection, to call for special discussion. The general\r\n      faith in fairies has already undergone our consideration; but something\r\n      remains to be said upon another species of superstition, so general that\r\n      it may be called proper to mankind in every climate; so deeply rooted also\r\n      in human belief, that it is found to survive in states of society during\r\n      which all other fictions of the same order are entirely dismissed from\r\n      influence. Mr. Crabbe, with his usual felicity, has called the belief in\r\n      ghosts &ldquo;the last lingering fiction of the brain.&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Nothing appears more simple at the first view of the subject, than that\r\n      human memory should recall and bring back to the eye of the imagination,\r\n      in perfect similitude, even the very form and features of a person with\r\n      whom we have been long conversant, or which have been imprinted in our\r\n      minds with indelible strength by some striking circumstances touching our\r\n      meeting in life. The son does not easily forget the aspect of an\r\n      affectionate father; and, for reasons opposite but equally powerful, the\r\n      countenance of a murdered person is engraved upon the recollection of his\r\n      slayer. A thousand additional circumstances, far too obvious to require\r\n      recapitulation, render the supposed apparition of the dead the most\r\n      ordinary spectral phenomenon which is ever believed to occur among the\r\n      living. All that we have formerly said respecting supernatural appearances\r\n      in general, applies with peculiar force to the belief of ghosts; for\r\n      whether the cause of delusion exists in an excited imagination or a\r\n      disordered organic system, it is in this way that it commonly exhibits\r\n      itself. Hence Lucretius himself, the most absolute of sceptics, considers\r\n      the existence of ghosts, and their frequent apparition, as facts so\r\n      undeniable that he endeavours to account for them at the expense of\r\n      assenting to a class of phenomena very irreconcilable to his general\r\n      system. As he will not allow of the existence of the human soul, and at\r\n      the same time cannot venture to question the phenomena supposed to haunt\r\n      the repositories of the dead, he is obliged to adopt the belief that the\r\n      body consists of several coats like those of an onion, and that the\r\n      outmost and thinnest, being detached by death, continues to wander near\r\n      the place of sepulture, in the exact resemblance of the person while\r\n      alive.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      We have said there are many ghost stories which we do not feel at liberty\r\n      to challenge as impostures, because we are confident that those who relate\r\n      them on their own authority actually believe what they assert, and may\r\n      have good reason for doing so, though there is no real phantom after all.\r\n      We are far, therefore, from averring that such tales are necessarily\r\n      false. It is easy to suppose the visionary has been imposed upon by a\r\n      lively dream, a waking reverie, the excitation of a powerful imagination,\r\n      or the misrepresentation of a diseased organ of sight; and in one or other\r\n      of these causes, to say nothing of a system of deception which may in many\r\n      instances be probable, we apprehend a solution will be found for all cases\r\n      of what are called real ghost stories.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In truth, the evidence with respect to such apparitions is very seldom\r\n      accurately or distinctly questioned. A supernatural tale is in most cases\r\n      received as an agreeable mode of amusing society, and he would be rather\r\n      accounted a sturdy moralist than an entertaining companion who should\r\n      employ himself in assailing its credibility. It would indeed be a solecism\r\n      in manners, something like that of impeaching the genuine value of the\r\n      antiquities exhibited by a good-natured collector for the gratification of\r\n      his guests. This difficulty will appear greater should a company have the\r\n      rare good fortune to meet the person who himself witnessed the wonders\r\n      which he tells; a well-bred or prudent man will, under such circumstances,\r\n      abstain from using the rules of cross-examination practised in a court of\r\n      justice; and if in any case he presumes to do so, he is in danger of\r\n      receiving answers, even from the most candid and honourable persons, which\r\n      are rather fitted to support the credit of the story which they stand\r\n      committed to maintain, than to the pure service of unadorned truth. The\r\n      narrator is asked, for example, some unimportant question with respect to\r\n      the apparition; he answers it on the hasty suggestion of his own\r\n      imagination, tinged as it is with belief of the general fact, and by doing\r\n      so often gives a feature of minute evidence which was before wanting, and\r\n      this with perfect unconsciousness on his own part. It is a rare\r\n      occurrence, indeed, to find an opportunity of dealing with an actual\r\n      ghost-seer; such instances, however, I have certainly myself met with, and\r\n      that in the case of able, wise, candid, and resolute persons, of whose\r\n      veracity I had every reason to be confident. But in such instances shades\r\n      of mental aberration have afterwards occurred, which sufficiently\r\n      accounted for the supposed apparitions, and will incline me always to feel\r\n      alarmed in behalf of the continued health of a friend who should conceive\r\n      himself to have witnessed such a visitation.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The nearest approximation which can be generally made to exact evidence in\r\n      this case, is the word of some individual who has had the story, it may\r\n      be, from the person to whom it has happened, but most likely from his\r\n      family, or some friend of the family. Far more commonly the narrator\r\n      possesses no better means of knowledge than that of dwelling in the\r\n      country where the thing happened, or being well acquainted with the\r\n      outside of the mansion in the inside of which the ghost appeared.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In every point the evidence of such a second-hand retailer of the mystic\r\n      story must fall under the adjudged case in an English court. The judge\r\n      stopped a witness who was about to give an account of the murder upon\r\n      trial, as it was narrated to him by the ghost of the murdered person.\r\n      &ldquo;Hold, sir,&rdquo; said his lordship; &ldquo;the ghost is an excellent witness, and\r\n      his evidence the best possible; but he cannot be heard by proxy in this\r\n      court. Summon him hither, and I&rsquo;ll hear him in person; but your\r\n      communication is mere hearsay, which my office compels me to reject.&rdquo; Yet\r\n      it is upon the credit of one man, who pledges it upon that of three or\r\n      four persons, who have told it successively to each other, that we are\r\n      often expected to believe an incident inconsistent with the laws of\r\n      Nature, however agreeable to our love of the wonderful and the horrible.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In estimating the truth or falsehood of such stories it is evident we can\r\n      derive no proofs from that period of society when men affirmed boldly, and\r\n      believed stoutly, all the wonders which could be coined or fancied. That\r\n      such stories are believed and told by grave historians, only shows that\r\n      the wisest men cannot rise in all things above the general ignorance of\r\n      their age. Upon the evidence of such historians we might as well believe\r\n      the portents of ancient or the miracles of modern Rome. For example, we\r\n      read in Clarendon of the apparition of the ghost of Sir George Villiers to\r\n      an ancient dependant. This is no doubt a story told by a grave author, at\r\n      a time when such stories were believed by all the world; but does it\r\n      follow that our reason must acquiesce in a statement so positively\r\n      contradicted by the voice of Nature through all her works? The miracle of\r\n      raising a dead man was positively refused by our Saviour to the Jews, who\r\n      demanded it as a proof of his mission, because they had already sufficient\r\n      grounds of conviction; and, as they believed them not, it was irresistibly\r\n      argued by the Divine Person whom they tempted, that neither would they\r\n      believe if one arose from the dead. Shall we suppose that a miracle\r\n      refused for the conversion of God&rsquo;s chosen people was sent on a vain\r\n      errand to save the life of a profligate spendthrift? I lay aside, you\r\n      observe, entirely the not unreasonable supposition that Towers, or\r\n      whatever was the ghost-seer&rsquo;s name, desirous to make an impression upon\r\n      Buckingham, as an old servant of his house, might be tempted to give him\r\n      his advice, of which we are not told the import, in the character of his\r\n      father&rsquo;s spirit, and authenticate the tale by the mention of some token\r\n      known to him as a former retainer of the family. The Duke was\r\n      superstitious, and the ready dupe of astrologers and soothsayers. The\r\n      manner in which he had provoked the fury of the people must have warned\r\n      every reflecting person of his approaching fate; and, the age considered,\r\n      it was not unnatural that a faithful friend should take this mode of\r\n      calling his attention to his perilous situation. Or, if we suppose that\r\n      the incident was not a mere pretext to obtain access to the Duke&rsquo;s ear,\r\n      the messenger may have been impressed upon by an idle dream&mdash;in a\r\n      word, numberless conjectures might be formed for accounting for the event\r\n      in a natural way, the most extravagant of which is more probable than that\r\n      the laws of Nature were broken through in order to give a vain and\r\n      fruitless warning to an ambitious minion.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It is the same with all those that are called accredited ghost stories\r\n      usually told at the fireside. They want evidence. It is true that the\r\n      general wish to believe, rather than power of believing, has given some\r\n      such stories a certain currency in society. I may mention, as one of the\r\n      class of tales I mean, that of the late Earl St. Vincent, who watched,\r\n      with a friend, it is said, a whole night, in order to detect the cause of\r\n      certain nocturnal disturbances which took place in a certain mansion. The\r\n      house was under lease to Mrs. Ricketts, his sister. The result of his\r\n      lordship&rsquo;s vigil is said to have been that he heard the noises without\r\n      being able to detect the causes, and insisted on his sister giving up the\r\n      house. This is told as a real story, with a thousand different\r\n      circumstances. But who has heard or seen an authentic account from Earl\r\n      St. Vincent, or from his &ldquo;companion of the watch,&rdquo; or from his lordship&rsquo;s\r\n      sister? And as in any other case such sure species of direct evidence\r\n      would be necessary to prove the facts, it seems unreasonable to believe\r\n      such a story on slighter terms. When the particulars are precisely fixed\r\n      and known, it might be time to enquire whether Lord St. Vincent, amid the\r\n      other eminent qualities of a first-rate seaman, might not be in some\r\n      degree tinged with their tendency to superstition; and still farther,\r\n      whether, having ascertained the existence of disturbances not immediately\r\n      or easily detected, his lordship might not advise his sister rather to\r\n      remove than to remain in a house so haunted, though he might believe that\r\n      poachers or smugglers were the worst ghosts by whom it was disturbed.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The story of two highly respectable officers in the British army, who are\r\n      supposed to have seen the spectre of the brother of one of them in a hut,\r\n      or barrack, in America, is also one of those accredited ghost tales, which\r\n      attain a sort of brevet rank as true, from the mention of respectable\r\n      names as the parties who witnessed the vision. But we are left without a\r\n      glimpse when, how, and in what terms, this story obtained its currency; as\r\n      also by whom, and in what manner, it was first circulated; and among the\r\n      numbers by whom it has been quoted, although all agree in the general\r\n      event, scarcely two, even of those who pretend to the best information,\r\n      tell the story in the same way.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Another such story, in which the name of a lady of condition is made use\r\n      of as having seen an apparition in a country-seat in France, is so far\r\n      better borne out than those I have mentioned, that I have seen a narrative\r\n      of the circumstances attested by the party principally concerned. That the\r\n      house was disturbed seems to be certain, but the circumstances (though\r\n      very remarkable) did not, in my mind, by any means exclude the probability\r\n      that the disturbance and appearances were occasioned by the dexterous\r\n      management of some mischievously-disposed persons.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The remarkable circumstance of Thomas, the second Lord Lyttelton,\r\n      prophesying his own death within a few minutes, upon the information of an\r\n      apparition, has been always quoted as a true story. But of late it has\r\n      been said and published, that the unfortunate nobleman had previously\r\n      determined to take poison, and of course had it in his own power to\r\n      ascertain the execution of the prediction. It was no doubt singular that a\r\n      man, who meditated his exit from the world, should have chosen to play\r\n      such a trick on his friends. But it is still more credible that a\r\n      whimsical man should do so wild a thing, than that a messenger should be\r\n      sent from the dead to tell a libertine at what precise hour he should\r\n      expire.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      To this list other stories of the same class might be added. But it is\r\n      sufficient to show that such stories as these, having gained a certain\r\n      degree of currency in the world, and bearing creditable names on their\r\n      front, walk through society unchallenged, like bills through a bank when\r\n      they bear respectable indorsations, although, it may be, the signatures\r\n      are forged after all. There is, indeed, an unwillingness very closely to\r\n      examine such subjects, for the secret fund of superstition in every man&rsquo;s\r\n      bosom is gratified by believing them to be true, or at least induces him\r\n      to abstain from challenging them as false. And no doubt it must happen\r\n      that the transpiring of incidents, in which men have actually seen, or\r\n      conceived that they saw, apparitions which were invisible to others,\r\n      contributes to the increase of such stories&mdash;which do accordingly\r\n      sometimes meet us in a shape of veracity difficult to question.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The following story was narrated to me by my friend, Mr. William Clerk,\r\n      chief clerk to the Jury Court, Edinburgh, when he first learned it, now\r\n      nearly thirty years ago, from a passenger in the mail-coach. With Mr.\r\n      Clerk&rsquo;s consent, I gave the story at that time to poor Mat Lewis, who\r\n      published it with a ghost-ballad which he adjusted on the same theme. From\r\n      the minuteness of the original detail, however, the narrative is better\r\n      calculated for prose than verse; and more especially as the friend to whom\r\n      it was originally communicated is one of the most accurate, intelligent,\r\n      and acute persons whom I have known in the course of my life, I am willing\r\n      to preserve the precise story in this place.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It was about the eventful year 1800, when the Emperor Paul laid his\r\n      ill-judged embargo on British trade, that my friend Mr. William Clerk, on\r\n      a journey to London, found himself in company, in the mail-coach, with a\r\n      seafaring man of middle age and respectable appearance, who announced\r\n      himself as master of a vessel in the Baltic trade, and a sufferer by the\r\n      embargo. In the course of the desultory conversation which takes place on\r\n      such occasions the seaman observed, in compliance with a common\r\n      superstition, &ldquo;I wish we may have good luck on our journey&mdash;there is\r\n      a magpie.&rdquo; &ldquo;And why should that be unlucky?&rdquo; said my friend. &ldquo;I cannot\r\n      tell you that,&rdquo; replied the sailor; &ldquo;but all the world agrees that one\r\n      magpie bodes bad luck&mdash;two are not so bad, but three are the devil. I\r\n      never saw three magpies but twice, and once I had near lost my vessel, and\r\n      the second I fell from a horse, and was hurt.&rdquo; This conversation led Mr.\r\n      Clerk to observe that he supposed he believed also in ghosts, since he\r\n      credited such auguries. &ldquo;And if I do,&rdquo; said the sailor, &ldquo;I may have my own\r\n      reasons for doing so;&rdquo; and he spoke this in a deep and serious manner,\r\n      implying that he felt deeply what he was saying. On being further urged,\r\n      he confessed that, if he could believe his own eyes, there was one ghost\r\n      at least which he had seen repeatedly. He then told his story as I now\r\n      relate it.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Our mariner had in his youth gone mate of a slave vessel from Liverpool,\r\n      of which town he seemed to be a native. The captain of the vessel was a\r\n      man of a variable temper, sometimes kind and courteous to his men, but\r\n      subject to fits of humour, dislike, and passion, during which he was very\r\n      violent, tyrannical, and cruel. He took a particular dislike at one sailor\r\n      aboard, an elderly man, called Bill Jones, or some such name. He seldom\r\n      spoke to this person without threats and abuse, which the old man, with\r\n      the license which sailors take on merchant vessels, was very apt to\r\n      return. On one occasion Bill Jones appeared slow in getting out on the\r\n      yard to hand a sail. The captain, according to custom, abused the seaman\r\n      as a lubberly rascal, who got fat by leaving his duty to other people. The\r\n      man made a saucy answer, almost amounting to mutiny, on which, in a\r\n      towering passion, the captain ran down to his cabin, and returned with a\r\n      blunderbuss loaded with slugs, with which he took deliberate aim at the\r\n      supposed mutineer, fired, and mortally wounded him. The man was handed\r\n      down from the yard, and stretched on the deck, evidently dying. He fixed\r\n      his eyes on the captain, and said, &ldquo;Sir, you have done for me, but <i>I\r\n      will never leave you</i>&rdquo; The captain, in return, swore at him for a fat\r\n      lubber, and said he would have him thrown into the slave-kettle, where\r\n      they made food for the negroes, and see how much fat he had got. The man\r\n      died. His body was actually thrown into the slave-kettle, and the narrator\r\n      observed, with a <i>navet</i> which confirmed the extent of his own\r\n      belief in the truth of what he told, &ldquo;There was not much fat about him\r\n      after all.&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The captain told the crew they must keep absolute silence on the subject\r\n      of what had passed; and as the mate was not willing to give an explicit\r\n      and absolute promise, he ordered him to be confined below. After a day or\r\n      two he came to the mate, and demanded if he had an intention to deliver\r\n      him up for trial when the vessel got home. The mate, who was tired of\r\n      close confinement in that sultry climate, spoke his commander fair, and\r\n      obtained his liberty. When he mingled among the crew once more he found\r\n      them impressed with the idea, not unnatural in their situation, that the\r\n      ghost of the dead man appeared among them when they had a spell of duty,\r\n      especially if a sail was to be handed, on which occasion the spectre was\r\n      sure to be out upon the yard before any of the crew. The narrator had seen\r\n      this apparition himself repeatedly&mdash;he believed the captain saw it\r\n      also, but he took no notice of it for some time, and the crew, terrified\r\n      at the violent temper of the man, dared not call his attention to it. Thus\r\n      they held on their course homeward with great fear and anxiety.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      At length, the captain invited the mate, who was now in a sort of favour,\r\n      to go down to the cabin and take a glass of grog with him. In this\r\n      interview he assumed a very grave and anxious aspect. &ldquo;I need not tell\r\n      you, Jack,&rdquo; he said, &ldquo;what sort of hand we have got on board with us. He\r\n      told me he would never leave me, and he has kept his word. You only see\r\n      him now and then, but he is always by my side, and never out of my sight.\r\n      At this very moment I see him&mdash;I am determined to bear it no longer,\r\n      and I have resolved to leave you.&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The mate replied that his leaving the vessel while out of the sight of any\r\n      land was impossible. He advised, that if the captain apprehended any bad\r\n      consequences from what had happened, he should run for the west of France\r\n      or Ireland, and there go ashore, and leave him, the mate, to carry the\r\n      vessel into Liverpool. The captain only shook his head gloomily, and\r\n      reiterated his determination to leave the ship. At this moment the mate\r\n      was called to the deck for some purpose or other, and the instant he got\r\n      up the companion-ladder he heard a splash in the water, and looking over\r\n      the ship&rsquo;s side, saw that the captain had thrown himself into the sea from\r\n      the quarter-gallery, and was running astern at the rate of six knots an\r\n      hour. When just about to sink he seemed to make a last exertion, sprung\r\n      half out of the water, and clasped his hands towards the mate, calling,\r\n      &ldquo;By&mdash;&mdash;, Bill is with me now!&rdquo; and then sunk, to be seen no\r\n      more.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      After hearing this singular story Mr. Clerk asked some questions about the\r\n      captain, and whether his companion considered him as at all times\r\n      rational. The sailor seemed struck with the question, and answered, after\r\n      a moment&rsquo;s delay, that in general <i>he conversationed well enough</i>.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It would have been desirable to have been able to ascertain how far this\r\n      extraordinary tale was founded on fact; but want of time and other\r\n      circumstances prevented Mr. Clerk from learning the names and dates, that\r\n      might to a certain degree have verified the events. Granting the murder to\r\n      have taken place, and the tale to have been truly told, there was nothing\r\n      more likely to arise among the ship&rsquo;s company than the belief in the\r\n      apparition; as the captain was a man of a passionate and irritable\r\n      disposition, it was nowise improbable that he, the victim of remorse,\r\n      should participate in the horrible visions of those less concerned,\r\n      especially as he was compelled to avoid communicating his sentiments with\r\n      any one else; and the catastrophe would in such a case be but the natural\r\n      consequence of that superstitious remorse which has conducted so many\r\n      criminals to suicide or the gallows. If the fellow-traveller of Mr. Clerk\r\n      be not allowed this degree of credit, he must at least be admitted to have\r\n      displayed a singular talent for the composition of the horrible in\r\n      fiction. The tale, properly detailed, might have made the fortune of a\r\n      romancer.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      I cannot forbear giving you, as congenial to this story, another instance\r\n      of a guilt-formed phantom, which made considerable noise about twenty\r\n      years ago or more. I am, I think, tolerably correct in the details, though\r\n      I have lost the account of the trial. Jarvis Matcham&mdash;such, if I am\r\n      not mistaken, was the name of my hero&mdash;was pay-sergeant in a\r\n      regiment, where he was so highly esteemed as a steady and accurate man\r\n      that he was permitted opportunity to embezzle a considerable part of the\r\n      money lodged in his hands for pay of soldiers, bounty of recruits (then a\r\n      large sum), and other charges which fell within his duty.
