He was summoned\r\n      to join his regiment from a town where he had been on the recruiting\r\n      service, and this perhaps under some shade of suspicion. Matcham perceived\r\n      discovery was at hand, and would have deserted had it not been for the\r\n      presence of a little drummer lad, who was the only one of his party\r\n      appointed to attend him. In the desperation of his crime he resolved to\r\n      murder the poor boy, and avail himself of some balance of money to make\r\n      his escape. He meditated this wickedness the more readily that the\r\n      drummer, he thought, had been put as a spy on him. He perpetrated his\r\n      crime, and changing his dress after the deed was done, made a long walk\r\n      across the country to an inn on the Portsmouth road, where he halted and\r\n      went to bed, desiring to be called when the first Portsmouth coach came.\r\n      The waiter summoned him accordingly, but long after remembered that, when\r\n      he shook the guest by the shoulder, his first words as he awoke were: &ldquo;My\r\n      God! I did not kill him.&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Matcham went to the seaport by the coach, and instantly entered as an\r\n      able-bodied landsman or marine, I know not which. His sobriety and\r\n      attention to duty gained him the same good opinion of the officers in his\r\n      new service which he had enjoyed in the army. He was afloat for several\r\n      years, and behaved remarkably well in some actions. At length the vessel\r\n      came into Plymouth, was paid off, and some of the crew, amongst whom was\r\n      Jarvis Matcham, were dismissed as too old for service. He and another\r\n      seaman resolved to walk to town, and took the route by Salisbury. It was\r\n      when within two or three miles of this celebrated city that they were\r\n      overtaken by a tempest so sudden, and accompanied with such vivid\r\n      lightning and thunder so dreadfully loud, that the obdurate conscience of\r\n      the old sinner began to be awakened. He expressed more terror than seemed\r\n      natural for one who was familiar with the war of elements, and began to\r\n      look and talk so wildly that his companion became aware that something\r\n      more than usual was the matter. At length Matcham complained to his\r\n      companion that the stones rose from the road and flew after him. He\r\n      desired the man to walk on the other side of the highway to see if they\r\n      would follow him when he was alone. The sailor complied, and Jarvis\r\n      Matcham complained that the stones still flew after him and did not pursue\r\n      the other. &ldquo;But what is worse,&rdquo; he added, coming up to his companion, and\r\n      whispering, with a tone of mystery and fear, &ldquo;who is that little\r\n      drummer-boy, and what business has he to follow us so closely?&rdquo; &ldquo;I can see\r\n      no one,&rdquo; answered the seaman, infected by the superstition of his\r\n      associate. &ldquo;What! not see that little boy with the bloody pantaloons!&rdquo;\r\n       exclaimed the secret murderer, so much to the terror of his comrade that\r\n      he conjured him, if he had anything on his mind, to make a clear\r\n      conscience as far as confession could do it. The criminal fetched a deep\r\n      groan, and declared that he was unable longer to endure the life which he\r\n      had led for years. He then confessed the murder of the drummer, and added\r\n      that, as a considerable reward had been offered, he wished his comrade to\r\n      deliver him up to the magistrates of Salisbury, as he would desire a\r\n      shipmate to profit by his fate, which he was now convinced was inevitable.\r\n      Having overcome his friend&rsquo;s objections to this mode of proceeding, Jarvis\r\n      Matcham was surrendered to justice accordingly, and made a full confession\r\n      of his guilt But before the trial the love of life returned. The prisoner\r\n      denied his confession, and pleaded Not Guilty. By this time, however, full\r\n      evidence had been procured from other quarters. Witnesses appeared from\r\n      his former regiment to prove his identity with the murderer and deserter,\r\n      and the waiter remembered the ominous words which he had spoken when he\r\n      awoke him to join the Portsmouth coach. Jarvis Matcham was found guilty\r\n      and executed. When his last chance of life was over he returned to his\r\n      confession, and with his dying breath averred, and truly, as he thought,\r\n      the truth of the vision on Salisbury Plain. Similar stories might be\r\n      produced, showing plainly that, under the direction of Heaven, the\r\n      influence of superstitious fear may be the appointed means of bringing the\r\n      criminal to repentance for his own sake, and to punishment for the\r\n      advantage of society.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Cases of this kind are numerous and easily imagined, so I shall dwell on\r\n      them no further; but rather advert to at least an equally abundant class\r\n      of ghost stories, in which the apparition is pleased not to torment the\r\n      actual murderer, but proceeds in a very circuitous manner, acquainting\r\n      some stranger or ignorant old woman with the particulars of his fate, who,\r\n      though perhaps unacquainted with all the parties, is directed by a phantom\r\n      to lay the facts before a magistrate. In this respect we must certainly\r\n      allow that ghosts have, as we are informed by the facetious Captain Grose,\r\n      forms and customs peculiar to themselves.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      There would be no edification and little amusement in treating of clumsy\r\n      deceptions of this kind, where the grossness of the imposture detects\r\n      itself. But occasionally cases occur like the following, with respect to\r\n      which it is more difficult, to use James Boswell&rsquo;s phrase, &ldquo;to know what\r\n      to think.&rdquo;\r\n     </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Upon the 10th of June, 1754, Duncan Terig, <i>alias</i> Clark, and\r\n      Alexander Bain MacDonald, two Highlanders, were tried before the Court of\r\n      Justiciary, Edinburgh, for the murder of Arthur Davis, sergeant in Guise&rsquo;s\r\n      regiment, on the 28th September, 1749. The accident happened not long\r\n      after the civil war, the embers of which were still reeking, so there\r\n      existed too many reasons on account of which an English soldier,\r\n      straggling far from assistance, might be privately cut off by the\r\n      inhabitants of these wilds. It appears that Sergeant Davis was missing for\r\n      years, without any certainty as to his fate. At length, an account of the\r\n      murder appeared from the evidence of one Alexander MacPherson (a\r\n      Highlander, speaking no language but Gaelic, and sworn by an interpreter),\r\n      who gave the following extraordinary account of his cause of knowledge:&mdash;He\r\n      was, he said, in bed in his cottage, when an apparition came to his\r\n      bedside and commanded him to rise and follow him out of doors. Believing\r\n      his visitor to be one Farquharson, a neighbour and friend, the witness did\r\n      as he was bid; and when they were without the cottage, the appearance told\r\n      the witness he was the ghost of Sergeant Davis, and requested him to go\r\n      and bury his mortal remains, which lay concealed in a place he pointed out\r\n      in a moorland tract called the Hill of Christie. He desired him to take\r\n      Farquharson with him as an assistant. Next day the witness went to the\r\n      place specified, and there found the bones of a human body much decayed.\r\n      The witness did not at that time bury the bones so found, in consequence\r\n      of which negligence the sergeant&rsquo;s ghost again appeared to him, upbraiding\r\n      him with his breach of promise. On this occasion the witness asked the\r\n      ghost who were the murderers, and received for answer that he had been\r\n      slain by the prisoners at the bar. The witness, after this second\r\n      visitation, called the assistance of Farquharson, and buried the body.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Farquharson was brought in evidence to prove that the preceding witness,\r\n      MacPherson, had called him to the burial of the bones, and told him the\r\n      same story which he repeated in court. Isabel MacHardie, a person who\r\n      slept in one of the beds which run along the wall in an ordinary Highland\r\n      hut, declared that upon the night when MacPherson said he saw the ghost,\r\n      she saw a naked man enter the house and go towards MacPherson&rsquo;s bed.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Yet though the supernatural incident was thus fortified, and although\r\n      there were other strong presumptions against the prisoners, the story of\r\n      the apparition threw an air of ridicule on the whole evidence for the\r\n      prosecution. It was followed up by the counsel for the prisoners asking,\r\n      in the cross-examination of MacPherson, &ldquo;What language did the ghost speak\r\n      in?&rdquo; The witness, who was himself ignorant of English, replied, &ldquo;As good\r\n      Gaelic as I ever heard in Lochaber.&rdquo; &ldquo;Pretty well for the ghost of an\r\n      English sergeant,&rdquo; answered the counsel. The inference was rather smart\r\n      and plausible than sound, for, the apparition of the ghost being admitted,\r\n      we know too little of the other world to judge whether all languages may\r\n      not be alike familiar to those who belonged to it. It imposed, however, on\r\n      the jury, who found the accused parties not guilty, although their counsel\r\n      and solicitor and most of the court were satisfied of their having\r\n      committed the murder. In this case the interference of the ghost seems to\r\n      have rather impeded the vengeance which it was doubtless the murdered\r\n      sergeant&rsquo;s desire to obtain. Yet there may be various modes of explaining\r\n      this mysterious story, of which the following conjecture may pass for one.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The reader may suppose that MacPherson was privy to the fact of the\r\n      murder, perhaps as an accomplice or otherwise, and may also suppose that,\r\n      from motives of remorse for the action, or of enmity to those who had\r\n      committed it, he entertained a wish to bring them to justice. But through\r\n      the whole Highlands there is no character more detestable than that of an\r\n      informer, or one who takes what is called Tascal-money, or reward for\r\n      discovery of crimes. To have informed against Terig and MacDonald might\r\n      have cost MacPherson his life; and it is far from being impossible that he\r\n      had recourse to the story of the ghost, knowing well that his\r\n      superstitious countrymen would pardon his communicating the commission\r\n      entrusted to him by a being from the other world, although he might\r\n      probably have been murdered if his delation of the crime had been supposed\r\n      voluntary. This explanation, in exact conformity with the sentiments of\r\n      the Highlanders on such subjects, would reduce the whole story to a stroke\r\n      of address on the part of the witness.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It is therefore of the last consequence, in considering the truth of\r\n      stories of ghosts and apparitions, to consider the possibility of wilful\r\n      deception, whether on the part of those who are agents in the supposed\r\n      disturbances, or the author of the legend. We shall separately notice an\r\n      instance or two of either kind.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The most celebrated instance in which human agency was used to copy the\r\n      disturbances imputed to supernatural beings refers to the ancient palace\r\n      of Woodstock, when the Commissioners of the Long Parliament came down to\r\n      dispark what had been lately a royal residence. The Commissioners arrived\r\n      at Woodstock, 13th October, 1649, determined to wipe away the memory of\r\n      all that connected itself with the recollection of monarchy in England.\r\n      But in the course of their progress they were encountered by obstacles\r\n      which apparently came from the next world. Their bed-chambers were\r\n      infested with visits of a thing resembling a dog, but which came and\r\n      passed as mere earthly dogs cannot do. Logs of wood, the remains of a very\r\n      large tree called the King&rsquo;s Oak, which they had splintered into billets\r\n      for burning, were tossed through the house, and the chairs displaced and\r\n      shuffled about. While they were in bed the feet of their couches were\r\n      lifted higher than their heads, and then dropped with violence. Trenchers\r\n      &ldquo;without a wish&rdquo; flew at their heads of free will. Thunder and lightning\r\n      came next, which were set down to the same cause. Spectres made their\r\n      appearance, as they thought, in different shapes, and one of the party saw\r\n      the apparition of a hoof, which kicked a candlestick and lighted candle\r\n      into the middle of the room, and then politely scratched on the red snuff\r\n      to extinguish it. Other and worse tricks were practised on the astonished\r\n      Commissioners who, considering that all the fiends of hell were let loose\r\n      upon them, retreated from Woodstock without completing an errand which\r\n      was, in their opinion, impeded by infernal powers, though the opposition\r\n      offered was rather of a playful and malicious than of a dangerous cast.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The whole matter was, after the Restoration, discovered to be the trick of\r\n      one of their own party, who had attended the Commissioners as a clerk,\r\n      under the name of Giles Sharp. This man, whose real name was Joseph\r\n      Collins of Oxford, called <i>Funny Joe</i>, was a concealed loyalist, and\r\n      well acquainted with the old mansion of Woodstock, where he had been\r\n      brought up before the Civil War. Being a bold, active spirited man, Joe\r\n      availed himself of his local knowledge of trap-doors and private passages\r\n      so as to favour the tricks which he played off upon his masters by aid of\r\n      his fellow-domestics. The Commissioners&rsquo; personal reliance on him made his\r\n      task the more easy, and it was all along remarked that trusty Giles Sharp\r\n      saw the most extraordinary sights and visions among the whole party. The\r\n      unearthly terrors experienced by the Commissioners are detailed with due\r\n      gravity by Sinclair, and also, I think, by Dr. Plott. But although the\r\n      detection or explanation of the real history of the Woodstock demons has\r\n      also been published, and I have myself seen it, I have at this time\r\n      forgotten whether it exists in a separate collection, or where it is to be\r\n      looked for.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Similar disturbances have been often experienced while it was the custom\r\n      to believe in and dread such frolics of the invisible world, and under\r\n      circumstances which induce us to wonder, both at the extreme trouble taken\r\n      by the agents in these impostures, and the slight motives from which they\r\n      have been induced to do much wanton mischief. Still greater is our modern\r\n      surprise at the apparently simple means by which terror has been excited\r\n      to so general an extent, that even the wisest and most prudent have not\r\n      escaped its contagious influence.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      On the first point I am afraid there can be no better reason assigned than\r\n      the conscious pride of superiority, which induces the human being in all\r\n      cases to enjoy and practise every means of employing an influence over his\r\n      fellow-mortals; to which we may safely add that general love of\r\n      tormenting, as common to our race as to that noble mimick of humanity, the\r\n      monkey. To this is owing the delight with which every school-boy\r\n      anticipates the effects of throwing a stone into a glass shop; and to this\r\n      we must also ascribe the otherwise unaccountable pleasure which\r\n      individuals have taken in practising the tricksy pranks of a goblin, and\r\n      filling a household or neighbourhood with anxiety and dismay, with little\r\n      gratification to themselves besides the consciousness of dexterity if they\r\n      remain undiscovered, and with the risk of loss of character and punishment\r\n      should the imposture be found out.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In the year 1772, a train of transactions, commencing upon Twelfth Day,\r\n      threw the utmost consternation into the village of Stockwell, near London,\r\n      and impressed upon some of its inhabitants the inevitable belief that they\r\n      were produced by invisible agents. The plates, dishes, china, and\r\n      glass-ware and small movables of every kind, contained in the house of\r\n      Mrs. Golding, an elderly lady, seemed suddenly to become animated, shifted\r\n      their places, flew through the room, and were broken to pieces. The\r\n      particulars of this commotion were as curious as the loss and damage\r\n      occasioned in this extraordinary manner were alarming and intolerable.\r\n      Amidst this combustion, a young woman, Mrs. Golding&rsquo;s maid, named Anne\r\n      Robinson, was walking backwards and forwards, nor could she be prevailed\r\n      on to sit down for a moment excepting while the family were at prayers,\r\n      during which time no disturbance happened. This Anne Robinson had been but\r\n      a few days in the old lady&rsquo;s service, and it was remarkable that she\r\n      endured with great composure the extraordinary display which others beheld\r\n      with terror, and coolly advised her mistress not to be alarmed or uneasy,\r\n      as these things could not be helped. This excited an idea that she had\r\n      some reason for being so composed, not inconsistent with a degree of\r\n      connexion with what was going forward. The afflicted Mrs. Golding, as she\r\n      might be well termed, considering such a commotion and demolition among\r\n      her goods and chattels, invited neighbours to stay in her house, but they\r\n      soon became unable to bear the sight of these supernatural proceedings,\r\n      which went so far that not above two cups and saucers remained out of a\r\n      valuable set of china. She next abandoned her dwelling, and took refuge\r\n      with a neighbour, but, finding his movables were seized with the same sort\r\n      of St. Vitus&rsquo;s dance, her landlord reluctantly refused to shelter any\r\n      longer a woman who seemed to be persecuted by so strange a subject of\r\n      vexation. Mrs. Golding&rsquo;s suspicions against Anne Robinson now gaining\r\n      ground, she dismissed her maid, and the hubbub among her movables ceased\r\n      at once and for ever.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      This circumstance of itself indicates that Anne Robinson was the cause of\r\n      these extraordinary disturbances, as has been since more completely\r\n      ascertained by a Mr. Brayfield, who persuaded Anne, long after the events\r\n      had happened, to make him her confidant. There was a love story connected\r\n      with the case, in which the only magic was the dexterity of Anne Robinson\r\n      and the simplicity of the spectators. She had fixed long horse hairs to\r\n      some of the crockery, and placed wires under others, by which she could\r\n      throw them down without touching them. Other things she dexterously threw\r\n      about, which the spectators, who did not watch her motions, imputed to\r\n      invisible agency. At times, when the family were absent, she loosened the\r\n      hold of the strings by which the hams, bacon, and similar articles were\r\n      suspended, so that they fell on the slightest motion. She employed some\r\n      simple chemical secrets, and, delighted with the success of her pranks,\r\n      pushed them farther than she at first intended. Such was the solution of\r\n      the whole mystery, which, known by the name of the Stockwell ghost,\r\n      terrified many well-meaning persons, and had been nearly as famous as that\r\n      of Cock Lane, which may be hinted at as another imposture of the same\r\n      kind. So many and wonderful are the appearances described, that when I\r\n      first met with the original publication I was strongly impressed with the\r\n      belief that the narrative was like some of Swift&rsquo;s advertisements, a\r\n      jocular experiment upon the credulity of the public. But it was certainly\r\n      published <i>bona fide</i>, and Mr. Hone, on the authority of Mr.\r\n      Brayfield, has since fully explained the wonder.<a href="#linknote-85"\r\n       name="linknoteref-85" id="linknoteref-85"><small>85</small></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-85" id="linknote-85"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      85 (<a href="#linknoteref-85">return</a>)<br /> [ See Hone&rsquo;s &ldquo;Every-Day\r\n      Book,&rdquo; p. 62.]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Many such impositions have been detected, and many others have been\r\n      successfully concealed; but to know what has been discovered in many\r\n      instances gives us the assurance of the ruling cause in all. I remember a\r\n      scene of the kind attempted to be got up near Edinburgh, but detected at\r\n      once by a sheriff&rsquo;s officer, a sort of persons whose habits of incredulity\r\n      and suspicious observation render them very dangerous spectators on such\r\n      occasions. The late excellent Mr. Walker, minister at Dunottar, in the\r\n      Mearns, gave me a curious account of an imposture of this kind, practised\r\n      by a young country girl, who was surprisingly quick at throwing stones,\r\n      turf, and other missiles, with such dexterity that it was for a long time\r\n      impossible to ascertain her agency in the disturbances of which she was\r\n      the sole cause.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The belief of the spectators that such scenes of disturbance arise from\r\n      invisible beings will appear less surprising if we consider the common\r\n      feats of jugglers, or professors of legerdemain, and recollect that it is\r\n      only the frequent exhibition of such powers which reconciles us to them as\r\n      matters of course, although they are wonders at which in our fathers&rsquo; time\r\n      men would have cried out either sorcery or miracles. The spectator also,\r\n      who has been himself duped, makes no very respectable appearance when\r\n      convicted of his error; and thence, if too candid to add to the evidence\r\n      of supernatural agency, is yet unwilling to stand convicted by\r\n      cross-examination, of having been imposed on, and unconsciously becomes\r\n      disposed rather to colour more highly than the truth, than acquiesce in an\r\n      explanation resting on his having been too hasty a believer. Very often,\r\n      too, the detection depends upon the combination of certain circumstances,\r\n      which, apprehended, necessarily explain the whole story.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      For example, I once heard a sensible and intelligent friend in company\r\n      express himself convinced of the truth of a wonderful story, told him by\r\n      an intelligent and bold man, about an apparition. The scene lay in an\r\n      ancient castle on the coast of Morven or the Isle of Mull, where the\r\n      ghost-seer chanced to be resident. He was given to understand by the\r\n      family, when betaking himself to rest, that the chamber in which he slept\r\n      was occasionally disquieted by supernatural appearances. Being at that\r\n      time no believer in such stories, he attended little to this hint, until\r\n      the witching hour of night, when he was awakened from a dead sleep by the\r\n      pressure of a human hand on his body. He looked up at the figure of a tall\r\n      Highlander, in the antique and picturesque dress of his country, only that\r\n      his brows were bound with a bloody bandage. Struck with sudden and extreme\r\n      fear, he was willing to have sprung from bed, but the spectre stood before\r\n      him in the bright moonlight, its one arm extended so as to master him if\r\n      he attempted to rise; the other hand held up in a warning and grave\r\n      posture, as menacing the Lowlander if he should attempt to quit his\r\n      recumbent position. Thus he lay in mortal agony for more than an hour,\r\n      after which it pleased the spectre of ancient days to leave him to more\r\n      sound repose. So singular a story had on its side the usual number of\r\n      votes from the company, till, upon cross-examination, it was explained\r\n      that the principal person concerned was an exciseman. After which <i>eclaircissement</i>\r\n      the same explanation struck all present, viz., the Highlanders of the\r\n      mansion had chosen to detain the exciseman by the apparition of an ancient\r\n      heroic ghost, in order to disguise from his vigilance the removal of\r\n      certain modern enough spirits, which his duty might have called upon him\r\n      to seize. Here a single circumstance explained the whole ghost story.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      At other times it happens that the meanness and trifling nature of a cause\r\n      not very obvious to observation has occasioned it to be entirely\r\n      overlooked, even on account of that very meanness, since no one is willing\r\n      to acknowledge that he has been alarmed by a cause of little consequence,\r\n      and which he would be ashamed of mentioning. An incident of this sort\r\n      happened to a gentleman of birth and distinction, who is well known in the\r\n      political world, and was detected by the precision of his observation.\r\n      Shortly after he succeeded to his estate and title, there was a rumour\r\n      among his servants concerning a strange noise heard in the family mansion\r\n      at night, the cause of which they had found it impossible to trace. The\r\n      gentleman resolved to watch himself, with a domestic who had grown old in\r\n      the family, and who had begun to murmur strange things concerning the\r\n      knocking having followed so close upon the death of his old master. They\r\n      watched until the noise was heard, which they listened to with that\r\n      strange uncertainty attending midnight sounds which prevents the hearers\r\n      from immediately tracing them to the spot where they arise, while the\r\n      silence of the night generally occasions the imputing to them more than\r\n      the due importance which they would receive if mingled with the usual\r\n      noises of daylight. At length the gentleman and his servant traced the\r\n      sounds which they had repeatedly heard to a small store-room used as a\r\n      place for keeping provisions of various kinds for the family, of which the\r\n      old butler had the key. They entered this place, and remained there for\r\n      some time without hearing the noises which they had traced thither; at\r\n      length the sound was heard, but much lower than it had formerly seemed to\r\n      be, while acted upon at a distance by the imagination of the hearers. The\r\n      cause was immediately discovered. A rat caught in an old-fashioned trap\r\n      had occasioned this tumult by its efforts to escape, in which it was able\r\n      to raise the trap-door of its prison to a certain height, but was then\r\n      obliged to drop it. The noise of the fall, resounding through the house,\r\n      had occasioned the disturbance which, but for the cool investigation of\r\n      the proprietor, might easily have established an accredited ghost story.\r\n      The circumstance was told me by the gentleman to whom it happened.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      There are other occasions in which the ghost story is rendered credible by\r\n      some remarkable combination of circumstances very unlikely to have\r\n      happened, and which no one could have supposed unless some particular\r\n      fortune occasioned a discovery.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      An apparition which took place at Plymouth is well known, but it has been\r\n      differently related; and having some reason to think the following edition\r\n      correct, it is an incident so much to my purpose that you must pardon its\r\n      insertion.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      A club of persons connected with science and literature was formed at the\r\n      great sea-town I have named. During the summer months the society met in a\r\n      cave by the sea-shore; during those of autumn and winter they convened\r\n      within the premises of a tavern, but, for the sake of privacy, had their\r\n      meetings in a summer-house situated in the garden, at a distance from the\r\n      main building. Some of the members to whom the position of their own\r\n      dwellings rendered this convenient, had a pass-key to the garden-door, by\r\n      which they could enter the garden and reach the summer-house without the\r\n      publicity or trouble of passing through the open tavern. It was the rule\r\n      of this club that its members presided alternately. On one occasion, in\r\n      the winter, the president of the evening chanced to be very ill; indeed,\r\n      was reported to be on his death-bed. The club met as usual, and, from a\r\n      sentiment of respect, left vacant the chair which ought to have been\r\n      occupied by him if in his usual health; for the same reason, the\r\n      conversation turned upon the absent gentleman&rsquo;s talents, and the loss\r\n      expected to the society by his death. While they were upon this melancholy\r\n      theme, the door suddenly opened, and the appearance of the president\r\n      entered the room. He wore a white wrapper, a nightcap round his brow, the\r\n      appearance of which was that of death itself. He stalked into the room\r\n      with unusual gravity, took the vacant place of ceremony, lifted the empty\r\n      glass which stood before him, bowed around, and put it to his lips; then\r\n      replaced it on the table, and stalked out of the room as silent as he had\r\n      entered it. The company remained deeply appalled; at length, after many\r\n      observations on the strangeness of what they had seen, they resolved to\r\n      dispatch two of their number as ambassadors, to see how it fared with the\r\n      president, who had thus strangely appeared among them. They went, and\r\n      returned with the frightful intelligence that the friend after whom they\r\n      had enquired was that evening deceased.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      The astonished party then resolved that they would remain absolutely\r\n      silent respecting the wonderful sight which they had seen. Their habits\r\n      were too philosophical to permit them to believe that they had actually\r\n      seen the ghost of their deceased brother, and at the same time they were\r\n      too wise men to wish to confirm the superstition of the vulgar by what\r\n      might seem indubitable evidence of a ghost. The affair was therefore kept\r\n      a strict secret, although, as usual, some dubious rumours of the tale\r\n      found their way to the public. Several years afterwards, an old woman who\r\n      had long filled the place of a sick-nurse, was taken very ill, and on her\r\n      death-bed was attended by a medical member of the philosophical club. To\r\n      him, with many expressions of regret, she acknowledged that she had long\r\n      before attended Mr.&mdash;&mdash;, naming the president whose appearance\r\n      had surprised the club so strangely, and that she felt distress of\r\n      conscience on account of the manner in which he died. She said that as his\r\n      malady was attended by light-headedness, she had been directed to keep a\r\n      close watch upon him during his illness. Unhappily she slept, and during\r\n      her sleep the patient had awaked and left the apartment. When, on her own\r\n      awaking, she found the bed empty and the patient gone, she forthwith\r\n      hurried out of the house to seek him, and met him in the act of returning.\r\n      She got him, she said, replaced in bed, but it was only to die there. She\r\n      added, to convince her hearer of the truth of what she said, that\r\n      immediately after the poor gentleman expired, a deputation of two members\r\n      from the club came to enquire after their president&rsquo;s health, and received\r\n      for answer that he was already dead. This confession explained the whole\r\n      matter. The delirious patient had very naturally taken the road to the\r\n      club, from some recollections of his duty of the night. In approaching and\r\n      retiring from the apartment he had used one of the pass-keys already\r\n      mentioned, which made his way shorter. On the other hand, the gentlemen\r\n      sent to enquire after his health had reached his lodging by a more\r\n      circuitous road; and thus there had been time for him to return to what\r\n      proved his death-bed, long before they reached his chamber. The\r\n      philosophical witnesses of this strange scene were now as anxious to\r\n      spread the story as they had formerly been to conceal it, since it showed\r\n      in what a remarkable manner men&rsquo;s eyes might turn traitors to them, and\r\n      impress them with ideas far different from the truth.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Another occurrence of the same kind, although scarcely so striking in its\r\n      circumstances, was yet one which, had it remained unexplained, might have\r\n      passed as an indubitable instance of a supernatural apparition.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      A Teviotdale farmer was riding from a fair, at which he had indulged\r\n      himself with John Barleycorn, but not to that extent of defying goblins\r\n      which it inspired into the gallant Tam o&rsquo;Shanter. He was pondering with\r\n      some anxiety upon the dangers of travelling alone on a solitary road which\r\n      passed the corner of a churchyard, now near at hand, when he saw before\r\n      him in the moonlight a pale female form standing upon the very wall which\r\n      surrounded the cemetery. The road was very narrow, with no opportunity of\r\n      giving the apparent phantom what seamen call a wide berth. It was,\r\n      however, the only path which led to the rider&rsquo;s home, who therefore\r\n      resolved, at all risks, to pass the apparition. He accordingly approached,\r\n      as slowly as possible, the spot where the spectre stood, while the figure\r\n      remained, now perfectly still and silent, now brandishing its arms and\r\n      gibbering to the moon. When the farmer came close to the spot he dashed in\r\n      the spurs and set the horse off upon a gallop; but the spectre did not\r\n      miss its opportunity. As he passed the corner where she was perched, she\r\n      contrived to drop behind the horseman and seize him round the waist, a\r\n      manoeuvre which greatly increased the speed of the horse and the terror of\r\n      the rider; for the hand of her who sat behind him, when pressed upon his,\r\n      felt as cold as that of a corpse. At his own house at length he arrived,\r\n      and bid the servants who came to attend him, &ldquo;Tak aff the ghaist!&rdquo; They\r\n      took off accordingly a female in white, and the poor farmer himself was\r\n      conveyed to bed, where he lay struggling for weeks with a strong nervous\r\n      fever. The female was found to be a maniac, who had been left a widow very\r\n      suddenly by an affectionate husband, and the nature and cause of her\r\n      malady induced her, when she could make her escape, to wander to the\r\n      churchyard, where she sometimes wildly wept over his grave, and sometimes,\r\n      standing on the corner of the churchyard wall, looked out, and mistook\r\n      every stranger on horseback for the husband she had lost. If this woman,\r\n      which was very possible, had dropt from the horse unobserved by him whom\r\n      she had made her involuntary companion, it would have been very hard to\r\n      have convinced the honest farmer that he had not actually performed part\r\n      of his journey with a ghost behind him.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      There is also a large class of stories of this sort, where various secrets\r\n      of chemistry, of acoustics, ventriloquism, or other arts, have been either\r\n      employed to dupe the spectators, or have tended to do so through mere\r\n      accident and coincidence. Of these it is scarce necessary to quote\r\n      instances; but the following may be told as a tale recounted by a foreign\r\n      nobleman known to me nearly thirty years ago, whose life, lost in the\r\n      service of his sovereign, proved too short for his friends and his native\r\n      land.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      At a certain old castle on the confines of Hungary, the lord to whom it\r\n      belonged had determined upon giving an entertainment worthy of his own\r\n      rank and of the magnificence of the antique mansion which he inhabited.\r\n      The guests of course were numerous, and among them was a veteran officer\r\n      of hussars, remarkable for his bravery. When the arrangements for the\r\n      night were made this officer was informed that there would be difficulty\r\n      in accommodating the company in the castle, large as was, unless some one\r\n      would take the risk of sleeping in a room supposed to be haunted, and\r\n      that, as he was known to be above such prejudices, the apartment was in\r\n      the first place proposed for his occupation, as the person least likely to\r\n      suffer a bad night&rsquo;s rest from such a cause. The major thankfully accepted\r\n      the preference, and having shared the festivity of the evening, retired\r\n      after midnight, having denounced vengeance against any one who should\r\n      presume by any trick to disturb his repose; a threat which his habits\r\n      would, it was supposed, render him sufficiently ready to execute. Somewhat\r\n      contrary to the custom in these cases, the major went to bed, having left\r\n      his candle burning and laid his trusty pistols, carefully loaded, on the\r\n      table by his bedside.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      He had not slept an hour when he was awakened by a solemn strain of music.\r\n      He looked out. Three ladies, fantastically dressed in green, were seen in\r\n      the lower end of the apartment, who sung a solemn requiem. The major\r\n      listened for some time with delight; at length he tired. &ldquo;Ladies,&rdquo; he\r\n      said, &ldquo;this is very well, but somewhat monotonous&mdash;will you be so\r\n      kind as to change the tune?&rdquo; The ladies continued singing; he\r\n      expostulated, but the music was not interrupted. The major began to grow\r\n      angry: &ldquo;Ladies,&rdquo; he said, &ldquo;I must consider this as a trick for the purpose\r\n      of terrifying me, and as I regard it as an impertinence, I shall take a\r\n      rough mode of stopping it.&rdquo; With that he began to handle his pistols. The\r\n      ladies sung on. He then get seriously angry: &ldquo;I will but wait five\r\n      minutes,&rdquo; he said, &ldquo;and then fire without hesitation.&rdquo; The song was\r\n      uninterrupted&mdash;the five minutes were expired. &ldquo;I still give you law,\r\n      ladies,&rdquo; he said, &ldquo;while I count twenty.&rdquo; This produced as little effect\r\n      as his former threats. He counted one, two, three accordingly; but on\r\n      approaching the end of the number, and repeating more than once his\r\n      determination to fire, the last numbers, seventeen&mdash;eighteen&mdash;nineteen,\r\n      were pronounced with considerable pauses between, and an assurance that\r\n      the pistols were cocked. The ladies sung on. As he pronounced the word\r\n      twenty he fired both pistols against the musical damsels&mdash;but the\r\n      ladies sung on! The major was overcome by the unexpected inefficacy of his\r\n      violence, and had an illness which lasted more than three weeks. The trick\r\n      put upon him may be shortly described by the fact that the female\r\n      choristers were placed in an adjoining room, and that he only fired at\r\n      their reflection thrown forward into that in which he slept by the effect\r\n      of a concave mirror.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Other stories of the same kind are numerous and well known. The apparition\r\n      of the Brocken mountain, after having occasioned great admiration and some\r\n      fear, is now ascertained by philosophers to be a gigantic reflection,\r\n      which makes the traveller&rsquo;s shadow, represented upon the misty clouds,\r\n      appear a colossal figure of almost immeasurable size. By a similar\r\n      deception men have been induced, in Westmoreland and other mountainous\r\n      countries, to imagine they saw troops of horse and armies marching and\r\n      countermarching, which were in fact only the reflection of horses\r\n      pasturing upon an opposite height, or of the forms of peaceful travellers.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      A very curious case of this kind was communicated to me by the son of the\r\n      lady principally concerned, and tends to show out of what mean materials a\r\n      venerable apparition may be sometimes formed. In youth this lady resided\r\n      with her father, a man of sense and resolution. Their house was situated\r\n      in the principal street of a town of some size. The back part of the house\r\n      ran at right angles to an Anabaptist chapel, divided from it by a small\r\n      cabbage-garden. The young lady used sometimes to indulge the romantic love\r\n      of solitude by sitting in her own apartment in the evening till twilight,\r\n      and even darkness, was approaching. One evening, while she was thus\r\n      placed, she was surprised to see a gleamy figure, as of some aerial being,\r\n      hovering, as it were, against the arched window in the end of the\r\n      Anabaptist chapel. Its head was surrounded by that halo which painters\r\n      give to the Catholic saints; and while the young lady&rsquo;s attention was\r\n      fixed on an object so extraordinary, the figure bent gracefully towards\r\n      her more than once, as if intimating a sense of her presence, and then\r\n      disappeared. The seer of this striking vision descended to her family, so\r\n      much discomposed as to call her father&rsquo;s attention. He obtained an account\r\n      of the cause of her disturbance, and expressed his intention to watch in\r\n      the apartment next night. He sat accordingly in his daughter&rsquo;s chamber,\r\n      where she also attended him. Twilight came, and nothing appeared; but as\r\n      the gray light faded into darkness, the same female figure was seen\r\n      hovering on the window; the same shadowy form, the same pale light-around\r\n      the head, the same inclinations, as the evening before. &ldquo;What do you think\r\n      of this?&rdquo; said the daughter to the astonished father. &ldquo;Anything, my dear,&rdquo;\r\n       said the father, &ldquo;rather than allow that we look upon what is\r\n      supernatural.&rdquo; A strict research established a natural cause for the\r\n      appearance on the window. It was the custom of an old woman, to whom the\r\n      garden beneath was rented, to go out at night to gather cabbages. The\r\n      lantern she carried in her hand threw up the refracted reflection of her\r\n      form on the chapel window. As she stooped to gather her cabbages the\r\n      reflection appeared to bend forward; and that was the whole matter.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Another species of deception, affecting the credit of such supernatural\r\n      communications, arises from the dexterity and skill of the authors who\r\n      have made it their business to present such stories in the shape most\r\n      likely to attract belief. Defoe&mdash;whose power in rendering credible\r\n      that which was in itself very much the reverse was so peculiarly\r\n      distinguished&mdash;has not failed to show his superiority in this species\r\n      of composition. A bookseller of his acquaintance had, in the trade phrase,\r\n      rather overprinted an edition of &ldquo;Drelincourt on Death,&rdquo; and complained to\r\n      Defoe of the loss which was likely to ensue. The experienced bookmaker,\r\n      with the purpose of recommending the edition, advised his friend to prefix\r\n      the celebrated narrative of Mrs. Veal&rsquo;s ghost, which he wrote for the\r\n      occasion, with such an air of truth, that although in fact it does not\r\n      afford a single tittle of evidence properly so called, it nevertheless was\r\n      swallowed so eagerly by the people that Drelincourt&rsquo;s work on death, which\r\n      the supposed spirit recommended to the perusal of her friend Mrs.\r\n      Bargrave, instead of sleeping on the editor&rsquo;s shelf, moved off by\r\n      thousands at once; the story, incredible in itself, and unsupported as it\r\n      was by evidence or enquiry, was received as true, merely from the cunning\r\n      of the narrator, and the addition of a number of adventitious\r\n      circumstances, which no man alive could have conceived as having occurred\r\n      to the mind of a person composing a fiction.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      It did not require the talents of Defoe, though in that species of\r\n      composition he must stand unrivalled, to fix the public attention on a\r\n      ghost story. John Dunton, a man of scribbling celebrity at the time,\r\n      succeeded to a great degree in imposing upon the public a tale which he\r\n      calls the Apparition Evidence. The beginning of it, at least (for it is of\r\n      great length), has something in it a little new. At Mynehead, in\r\n      Somersetshire, lived an ancient gentlewoman named Mrs. Leckie, whose only\r\n      son and daughter resided in family with her. The son traded to Ireland,\r\n      and was supposed to be worth eight or ten thousand pounds. They had a\r\n      child about five or six years old. This family was generally respected in\r\n      Mynehead; and especially Mrs. Leckie, the old lady, was so pleasant in\r\n      society, that her friends used to say to her, and to each other, that it\r\n      was a thousand pities such an excellent, good-humoured gentlewoman must,\r\n      from her age, be soon lost to her friends. To which Mrs. Leckie often made\r\n      the somewhat startling reply: &ldquo;Forasmuch as you now seem to like me, I am\r\n      afraid you will but little care to see or speak with me after my death,\r\n      though I believe you may have that satisfaction.&rdquo; Die, however, she did,\r\n      and after her funeral was repeatedly seen in her personal likeness, at\r\n      home and abroad, by night and by noonday.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      One story is told of a doctor of physic walking into the fields, who in\r\n      his return met with this spectre, whom he at first accosted civilly, and\r\n      paid her the courtesy of handing her over a stile. Observing, however,\r\n      that she did not move her lips in speaking, or her eyes in looking round,\r\n      he became suspicious of the condition of his companion, and showed some\r\n      desire to be rid of her society. Offended at this, the hag at next stile\r\n      planted herself upon it, and obstructed his passage. He got through at\r\n      length with some difficulty, and not without a sound kick, and an\r\n      admonition to pay more attention to the next aged gentlewoman whom he met.\r\n      &ldquo;But this,&rdquo; says John Dunton, &ldquo;was a petty and inconsiderable prank to\r\n      what she played in her son&rsquo;s house and elsewhere. She would at noonday\r\n      appear upon the quay of Mynehead, and cry, &lsquo;A boat, a boat, ho! a boat, a\r\n      boat, ho!&rsquo; If any boatmen or seamen were in sight, and did not come, they\r\n      were sure to be cast away; and if they did come, &lsquo;twas all one, they were\r\n      cast away. It was equally dangerous to please and displease her. Her son\r\n      had several ships sailing between Ireland and England; no sooner did they\r\n      make land, and come in sight of England, but this ghost would appear in\r\n      the same garb and likeness as when she was alive, and, standing at the\r\n      mainmast, would blow with a whistle, and though it were never so great a\r\n      calm, yet immediately there would arise a most dreadful storm, that would\r\n      break, wreck, and drown the ship and goods; only the seamen would escape\r\n      with their lives&mdash;the devil had no permission from God to take them\r\n      away. Yet at this rate, by her frequent apparitions and disturbances, she\r\n      had made a poor merchant of her son, for his fair estate was all buried in\r\n      the sea, and he that was once worth thousands was reduced to a very poor\r\n      and low condition in the world; for whether the ship were his own or\r\n      hired, or he had but goods on board it to the value of twenty shillings,\r\n      this troublesome ghost would come as before, whistle in a calm at the\r\n      mainmast at noonday, when they had descried land, and then ship and goods\r\n      went all out of hand to wreck; insomuch that he could at last get no ships\r\n      wherein to stow his goods, nor any mariner to sail in them; for knowing\r\n      what an uncomfortable, fatal, and losing voyage they should make of it,\r\n      they did all decline his service. In her son&rsquo;s house she hath her constant\r\n      haunts by day and night; but whether he did not, or would not own if he\r\n      did, see her, he always professed he never saw her. Sometimes when in bed\r\n      with his wife, she would cry out, &lsquo;Husband, look, there&rsquo;s your mother!&rsquo;\r\n      And when he would turn to the right side, then was she gone to the left;\r\n      and when to the left side of the bed, then was she gone to the right; only\r\n      one evening their only child, a girl of about five or six years old, lying\r\n      in a ruckle-bed under them, cries out, &lsquo;Oh, help me, father! help me,\r\n      mother! for grandmother will choke me!&rsquo; and before they could get to their\r\n      child&rsquo;s assistance she had murdered it; they finding the poor girl dead,\r\n      her throat having been pinched by two fingers, which stopped her breath\r\n      and strangled her. This was the sorest of all their afflictions; their\r\n      estate is gone, and now their child is gone also; you may guess at their\r\n      grief and great sorrow. One morning after the child&rsquo;s funeral, her husband\r\n      being abroad, about eleven in the forenoon, Mrs. Leckie the younger goes\r\n      up into her chamber to dress her head, and as she was looking into the\r\n      glass she spies her mother-in-law, the old beldam, looking over her\r\n      shoulder. This cast her into a great horror; but recollecting her\r\n      affrighted spirits, and recovering the exercise of her reason, faith, and\r\n      hope, having cast up a short and silent prayer to God, she turns about,\r\n      and bespeaks her: &lsquo;In the name of God, mother, why do you trouble me?&rsquo;\r\n      &lsquo;Peace,&rsquo; says the spectrum; &lsquo;I will do thee no hurt.&rsquo; &lsquo;What will you have\r\n      of me?&rsquo; says the daughter,&rdquo; &amp;c.<a href="#linknote-86"\r\n       name="linknoteref-86" id="linknoteref-86"><small>86</small></a> Dunton,\r\n      the narrator and probably the contriver of the story, proceeds to inform\r\n      us at length of a commission which the wife of Mr. Leckie receives from\r\n      the ghost to deliver to Atherton, Bishop of Waterford, a guilty and\r\n      unfortunate man, who afterwards died by the hands of the executioner; but\r\n      that part of the subject is too disagreeable and tedious to enter upon.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      <br /><br />\r\n    </p>\r\n    <hr />\r\n    <p>\r\n      <a name="linknote-86" id="linknote-86"> Note--></a>\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p class="foot">\r\n      86 (<a href="#linknoteref-86">return</a>)<br /> [ &ldquo;Apparition Evidence.&rdquo;]\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      So deep was the impression made by the story on the inhabitants of\r\n      Mynehead, that it is said the tradition of Mrs. Leckie still remains in\r\n      that port, and that mariners belonging to it often, amid tempestuous\r\n      weather, conceive they hear the whistle-call of the implacable hag who was\r\n      the source of so much mischief to her own family. However, already too\r\n      desultory and too long, it would become intolerably tedious were I to\r\n      insist farther on the peculiar sort of genius by which stories of this\r\n      kind may be embodied and prolonged.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      I may, however, add, that the charm of the tale depends much upon the age\r\n      of the person to whom it is addressed; and that the vivacity of fancy\r\n      which engages us in youth to pass over much that is absurd, in order to\r\n      enjoy some single trait of imagination, dies within us when we obtain the\r\n      age of manhood, and the sadder and graver regions which lie beyond it. I\r\n      am the more conscious of this, because I have been myself at two periods\r\n      of my life, distant from each other, engaged in scenes favourable to that\r\n      degree of superstitious awe which my countrymen expressively call being <i>eerie</i>.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      On the first of these occasions I was only ninteeen or twenty years old,\r\n      when I happened to pass a night in the magnificent old baronial castle of\r\n      Glammis, the hereditary seat of the Earls of Strathmore. The hoary pile\r\n      contains much in its appearance, and in the traditions connected with it,\r\n      impressive to the imagination. It was the scene of the murder of a\r\n      Scottish king of great antiquity; not indeed the gracious Duncan, with\r\n      whom the name naturally associates itself, but Malcolm the Second. It\r\n      contains also a curious monument of the peril of feudal times, being a\r\n      secret chamber, the entrance of which, by the law or custom of the family,\r\n      must only be known to three persons at once, viz., the Earl of Strathmore,\r\n      his heir apparent, and any third person whom they may take into their\r\n      confidence. The extreme antiquity of the building is vouched by the\r\n      immense thickness of the walls, and the wild and straggling arrangement of\r\n      the accommodation within doors. As the late Earl of Strathmore seldom\r\n      resided in that ancient mansion, it was, when I was there, but\r\n      half-furnished, and that with movables of great antiquity, which, with the\r\n      pieces of chivalric armour hanging upon the walls, greatly contributed to\r\n      the general effect of the whole. After a very hospitable reception from\r\n      the late Peter Proctor, Esq., then seneschal of the castle, in Lord\r\n      Strathmore&rsquo;s absence, I was conducted to my apartment in a distant corner\r\n      of the building. I must own, that as I heard door after door shut, after\r\n      my conductor had retired, I began to consider myself too far from the\r\n      living and somewhat too near the dead. We had passed through what is\r\n      called &ldquo;The King&rsquo;s Room,&rdquo; a vaulted apartment, garnished with stags&rsquo;\r\n      antlers and similar trophies of the chase, and said by tradition to be the\r\n      spot of Malcolm&rsquo;s murder, and I had an idea of the vicinity of the castle\r\n      chapel.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In spite of the truth of history, the whole night-scene in Macbeth&rsquo;s\r\n      castle rushed at once upon my mind, and struck my imagination more\r\n      forcibly than even when I have seen its terrors represented by the late\r\n      John Kemble and his inimitable sister. In a word, I experienced sensations\r\n      which, though not remarkable either for timidity or superstition, did not\r\n      fail to affect me to the point of being disagreeable, while they were\r\n      mingled at the same time with a strange and indescribable kind of\r\n      pleasure, the recollection of which affords me gratification at this\r\n      moment.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      In the year 1814 accident placed me, then past middle life, in a situation\r\n      somewhat similar to that which I have described.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      I had been on a pleasure voyage with some friends around the north coast\r\n      of Scotland, and in that course had arrived in the salt-water lake under\r\n      the castle of Dunvegan, whose turrets, situated upon a frowning rock, rise\r\n      immediately above the waves of the loch. As most of the party, and I\r\n      myself in particular, chanced to be well known to the Laird of Macleod, we\r\n      were welcomed to the castle with Highland hospitality, and glad to find\r\n      ourselves in polished society, after a cruise of some duration. The most\r\n      modern part of the castle was founded in the days of James VI.; the more\r\n      ancient is referred to a period &ldquo;whose birth tradition notes not.&rdquo; Until\r\n      the present Macleod connected by a drawbridge the site of the castle with\r\n      the mainland of Skye, the access must have been extremely difficult.\r\n      Indeed, so much greater was the regard paid to security than to\r\n      convenience, that in former times the only access to the mansion arose\r\n      through a vaulted cavern in a rock, up which a staircase ascended from the\r\n      sea-shore, like the buildings we read of in the romances of Mrs.\r\n      Radcliffe.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Such a castle, in the extremity of the Highlands, was of course furnished\r\n      with many a tale of tradition, and many a superstitious legend, to fill\r\n      occasional intervals in the music and song, as proper to the halls of\r\n      Dunvegan as when Johnson commemorated them. We reviewed the arms and\r\n      ancient valuables of this distinguished family&mdash;saw the dirk and\r\n      broadsword of Rorie Mhor, and his horn, which would drench three chiefs of\r\n      these degenerate days. The solemn drinking-cup of the Kings of Man must\r\n      not be forgotten, nor the fairy banner given to Macleod by the Queen of\r\n      Fairies; that magic flag which has been victorious in two pitched fields,\r\n      and will still float in the third, the bloodiest and the last, when the\r\n      Elfin Sovereign shall, after the fight is ended, recall her banner, and\r\n      carry off the standard-bearer.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      Amid such tales of ancient tradition I had from Macleod and his lady the\r\n      courteous offer of the haunted apartment of the castle, about which, as a\r\n      stranger, I might be supposed interested. Accordingly, I took possession\r\n      of it about the witching hour. Except perhaps some tapestry hangings, and\r\n      the extreme thickness of the walls, which argued great antiquity, nothing\r\n      could have been more comfortable than the interior of the apartment; but\r\n      if you looked from the windows the view was such as to correspond with the\r\n      highest tone of superstition. An autumnal blast, sometimes driving mist\r\n      before it, swept along the troubled billows of the lake, which it\r\n      occasionally concealed, and by fits disclosed. The waves rushed in wild\r\n      disorder on the shore, and covered with foam the steep piles of rock,\r\n      which, rising from the sea in forms something resembling the human figure,\r\n      have obtained the name of Macleod&rsquo;s Maidens, and in such a night seemed no\r\n      bad representatives of the Norwegian goddesses called Choosers of the\r\n      Slain, or Riders of the Storm. There was something of the dignity of\r\n      danger in the scene; for on a platform beneath the windows lay an ancient\r\n      battery of cannon, which had sometimes been used against privateers even\r\n      of late years. The distant scene was a view of that part of the Quillan\r\n      mountains which are called, from their form, Macleod&rsquo;s Dining-Tables. The\r\n      voice of an angry cascade, termed the Nurse of Rorie Mhor, because that\r\n      chief slept best &lsquo;in its vicinity, was heard from time to time mingling\r\n      its notes with those of wind and wave. Such was the haunted room at\r\n      Dunvegan, and as such it well deserved a less sleepy inhabitant. In the\r\n      language of Dr. Johnson, who has stamped his memory on this remote place,\r\n      &ldquo;I looked around me, and wondered that I was not more affected; but the\r\n      mind is not at all times equally ready to be moved.&rdquo; In a word, it is\r\n      necessary to confess that, of all I heard or saw, the most engaging\r\n      spectacle was the comfortable bed, in which I hoped to make amends for\r\n      some rough nights on ship-board, and where I slept accordingly without\r\n      thinking of ghost or goblin till I was called by my servant in the\r\n      morning.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      From this I am taught to infer that tales of ghosts and demonology are out\r\n      of date at forty years and upwards; that it is only in the morning of life\r\n      that this feeling of superstition &ldquo;comes o&rsquo;er us like a summer cloud,&rdquo;\r\n       affecting us with fear which is solemn and awful rather than painful; and\r\n      I am tempted to think that, if I were to write on the subject at all, it\r\n      should have been during a period of life when I could have treated it with\r\n      more interesting vivacity, and might have been at least amusing if I could\r\n      not be instructive. Even the present fashion of the world seems to be ill\r\n      suited for studies of this fantastic nature; and the most ordinary\r\n      mechanic has learning sufficient to laugh at the figments which in former\r\n      times were believed by persons far advanced in the deepest knowledge of\r\n      the age.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <p>\r\n      I cannot, however, in conscience carry my opinion of my countrymen&rsquo;s good\r\n      sense so far as to exculpate them entirely from the charge of credulity.\r\n      Those who are disposed to look for them may, without much trouble, see\r\n      such manifest signs, both of superstition and the disposition to believe\r\n      in its doctrines, as may render it no useless occupation to compare the\r\n      follies of our fathers with our own. The sailors have a proverb that every\r\n      man in his lifetime must eat a peck of impurity; and it seems yet more\r\n      clear that every generation of the human race must swallow a certain\r\n      measure of nonsense. There remains hope, however, that the grosser faults\r\n      of our ancestors are now out of date; and that whatever follies the\r\n      present race may be guilty of, the sense of humanity is too universally\r\n      spread to permit them to think of tormenting wretches till they confess\r\n      what is impossible, and then burning them for their pains.\r\n    </p>\r\n    <h3>\r\n      THE END.\r\n    </h3>\r\n    <h5>\r\n      PRINTED BY BALLANTYNE, HANSON AND CO. LONDON AND EDINBURGH.\r\n    </h5>\r\n    <div style="height: 6em;">\r\n      <br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br />\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <pre>\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEnd of the Project Gutenberg EBook of Letters On Demonology And Witchcraft\r\nby Sir Walter Scott\r\n\r\n*** END OF THIS PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK LETTERS ON DEMONOLOGY ***\r\n\r\n***** This file should be named 14461-h.htm or 14461-h.zip *****\r\nThis and all associated files of various formats will be found in:\r\n        http://www.gutenberg.net/1/4/4/6/14461/\r\n\r\nEtext Produced by Clare Boothby, Paul Moots and the PG Online Distributed\r\nProofreading Team\r\n\r\nHTML file produced by David Widger\r\n\r\n\r\nUpdated editions will replace the previous one--the old editions\r\nwill be renamed.\r\n\r\nCreating the works from public domain print editions means that no\r\none owns a United States copyright in these works, so the Foundation\r\n(and you!) can copy and distribute it in the United States without\r\npermission and without paying copyright royalties. LIMITED RIGHT OF REPLACEMENT OR REFUND - If you discover a\r\ndefect in this electronic work within 90 days of receiving it, you can\r\nreceive a refund of the money (if any) you paid for it by sending a\r\nwritten explanation to the person you received the work from.  If you\r\nreceived the work on a physical medium, you must return the medium with\r\nyour written explanation.  The person or entity that provided you with\r\nthe defective work may elect to provide a replacement copy in lieu of a\r\nrefund.  If you received the work electronically, the person or entity\r\nproviding it to you may choose to give you a second opportunity to\r\nreceive the work electronically in lieu of a refund.  If the second copy\r\nis also defective, you may demand a refund in writing without further\r\nopportunities to fix the problem.\r\n\r\n1.F.4.  Except for the limited right of replacement or refund set forth\r\nin paragraph 1.F.3, this work is provided to you \'AS-IS\' WITH NO OTHER\r\nWARRANTIES OF ANY KIND, EXPRESS OR IMPLIED, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO\r\nWARRANTIES OF MERCHANTIBILITY OR FITNESS FOR ANY PURPOSE.\r\n\r\n1.F.5.  Some states do not allow disclaimers of certain implied\r\nwarranties or the exclusion or limitation of certain types of damages.\r\nIf any disclaimer or limitation set forth in this agreement violates the\r\nlaw of the state applicable to this agreement, the agreement shall be\r\ninterpreted to make the maximum disclaimer or limitation permitted by\r\nthe applicable state law.  The invalidity or unenforceability of any\r\nprovision of this agreement shall not void the remaining provisions.\r\n\r\n1.F.6.  INDEMNITY - You agree to indemnify and hold the Foundation, the\r\ntrademark owner, any agent or employee of the Foundation, anyone\r\nproviding copies of Project Gutenberg-tm electronic works in accordance\r\nwith this agreement, and any volunteers associated with the production,\r\npromotion and distribution of Project Gutenberg-tm electronic works,\r\nharmless from all liability, costs and expenses, including legal fees,\r\nthat arise directly or indirectly from any of the following which you do\r\nor cause to occur: (a) distribution of this or any Project Gutenberg-tm\r\nwork, (b) alteration, modification, or additions or deletions to any\r\nProject Gutenberg-tm work, and (c) any Defect you cause.\r\n\r\n\r\nSection  2.  Information about the Mission of Project Gutenberg-tm\r\n\r\nProject Gutenberg-tm is synonymous with the free distribution of\r\nelectronic works in formats readable by the widest variety of computers\r\nincluding obsolete, old, middle-aged and new computers.  It exists\r\nbecause of the efforts of hundreds of volunteers and donations from\r\npeople in all walks of life.\r\n\r\nVolunteers and financial support to provide volunteers with the\r\nassistance they need, is critical to reaching Project Gutenberg-tm\'s\r\ngoals and ensuring that the Project Gutenberg-tm collection will\r\nremain freely available for generations to come.  In 2001, the Project\r\nGutenberg Literary Archive Foundation was created to provide a secure\r\nand permanent future for Project Gutenberg-tm and future generations.\r\nTo learn more about the Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation\r\nand how your efforts and donations can help, see Sections 3 and 4\r\nand the Foundation web page at http://www.pglaf.org.\r\n\r\n\r\nSection 3.  Information about the Project Gutenberg Literary Archive\r\nFoundation\r\n\r\nThe Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation is a non profit\r\n501(c)(3) educational corporation organized under the laws of the\r\nstate of Mississippi and granted tax exempt status by the Internal\r\nRevenue Service.  The Foundation\'s EIN or federal tax identification\r\nnumber is 64-6221541.  Its 501(c)(3) letter is posted at\r\nhttp://pglaf.org/fundraising.  Contributions to the Project Gutenberg\r\nLiterary Archive Foundation are tax deductible to the full extent\r\npermitted by U.S. federal laws and your state\'s laws.\r\n\r\nThe Foundation\'s principal office is located at 4557 Melan Dr. S.\r\nFairbanks, AK, 99712., but its volunteers and employees are scattered\r\nthroughout numerous locations.  Its business office is located at\r\n809 North 1500 West, Salt Lake City, UT 84116, (801) 596-1887, email\r\nbusiness@pglaf.org.  Email contact links and up to date contact\r\ninformation can be found at the Foundation\'s web site and official\r\npage at http://pglaf.org\r\n\r\nFor additional contact information:\r\n     Dr. Gregory B. Newby\r\n     Chief Executive and Director\r\n     gbnewby@pglaf.org\r\n\r\n\r\nSection 4.  Information about Donations to the Project Gutenberg\r\nLiterary Archive Foundation\r\n\r\nProject Gutenberg-tm depends upon and cannot survive without wide\r\nspread public support and donations to carry out its mission of\r\nincreasing the number of public domain and licensed works that can be\r\nfreely distributed in machine readable form accessible by the widest\r\narray of equipment including outdated equipment.  Many small donations\r\n($1 to $5,000) are particularly important to maintaining tax exempt\r\nstatus with the IRS.\r\n\r\nThe Foundation is committed to complying with the laws regulating\r\ncharities and charitable donations in all 50 states of the United\r\nStates.  Compliance requirements are not uniform and it takes a\r\nconsiderable effort, much paperwork and many fees to meet and keep up\r\nwith these requirements.  We do not solicit donations in locations\r\nwhere we have not received written confirmation of compliance.  To\r\nSEND DONATIONS or determine the status of compliance for any\r\nparticular state visit http://pglaf.org\r\n\r\nWhile we cannot and do not solicit contributions from states where we\r\nhave not met the solicitation requirements, we know of no prohibition\r\nagainst accepting unsolicited donations from donors in such states who\r\napproach us with offers to donate.\r\n\r\nInternational donations are gratefully accepted, but we cannot make\r\nany statements concerning tax treatment of donations received from\r\noutside the United States.  U.S. laws alone swamp our small staff.\r\n\r\nPlease check the Project Gutenberg Web pages for current donation\r\nmethods and addresses.  Donations are accepted in a number of other\r\nways including including checks, online payments and credit card\r\ndonations.  To donate, please visit: http://pglaf.org/donate\r\n\r\n\r\nSection 5.  General Information About Project Gutenberg-tm electronic\r\nworks.\r\n\r\nProfessor Michael S. Hart is the originator of the Project Gutenberg-tm\r\nconcept of a library of electronic works that could be freely shared\r\nwith anyone.  For thirty years, he produced and distributed Project\r\nGutenberg-tm eBooks with only a loose network of volunteer support.\r\n\r\n\r\nProject Gutenberg-tm eBooks are often created from several printed\r\neditions, all of which are confirmed as Public Domain in the U.S.\r\nunless a copyright notice is included.
